The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

VIRTS REDIVIVA: OR, A PANEGYRICK On the late K. Charls the I. Second Monarch OF GREAT BRITAIN. By THO. FORDE.

q.p: Propoitum et mihi Principem Laudare non Principis facta, nam laudabilia multa etiam mali faciunt.

figure.figDesc: Emblems of England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland

div.p: LONDON, Printed by R. and W. Leybourn, for William Grantham at the Black Bear in St. Pauls Church-yard, neer the little North Door. 1660.

div.head: The Preface.
div.p: XEnophon charactered his Cyrus, not as he was but as he ought to have been: making him rather the ubject of a brave Romance, than a true Hitory.

But uch is the advantage of our Charls his Virtue, that when I have aid all I can ay, it will be infinitely beneath what I hould ay, I hall doe truth no injury to confee the weaknee of Art to repreent
a peron o admirable, without diminihing his glories, whoe Fame urmounts the mot daring Hyperbolies of Rhetorick; and to praie faintly (in Seneca's opinion) is a piece of lander.

I mut be forced to imitate the Comographers, who decribe a large Kingdome by a little point, and confine the whole world in a mall circle: whereto when I have done all, I mut ubcribe this Motto, Intelligitur, plus quam pingitur.

Alexander the Great gave traight commands, that no Painter hould dare to make his Picture, but Apelles: I know no Penill fit to draw great Charls, his Picture, but his own, Ipe, ipe quem loquar, loquatur. And well it is he hath done it in his divine Portrayture, that Aureum flumen orationis: a piece
wherein Learning and Language, Reaon and Religion, peak him at once a Solomon for knowledge, and a David for piety and devotion.

Timanthes that rare and ingenious Artit (as Pliny tells the Story) diviing in a little Table to repreent a Cy • lop • s leeping, becaue he would eem in that little Compae to hew his Gyant-like bignee, he painted little Satyres hard by, taking meaure of one of his thumbs with long perches. Our inufficiency to repreent his acred Majety to the full, may perhaps be none of the leat Arguments to evince the greatnee of his merit, who (as Pindar aid Elegantly of Heiro) cropt the tops and ummities of all virtues, which dipered among all others, met in Him, as in their proper Center.

The Colos at Rhodes, one of the wonders of the World, was no lee admired being beaten down, than when it tood, when as they aw that with one of the fingers they might make many great Statues: Nor can Great Charls his Fall, leen our Admiration of Him, when it hall be conidered that from His incomparable Actions may be drawn perfect Images, and aured Examples of the greatet and mot noble Virtues.
It is the priviledge of Virtue to give a new Life after Death.

q.l: e vera Fama upera la morte,

div.p: Sayes the Italian Proverb; He that ows virtuous Deeds, reaps Renown, and true Fame out-lives death.

How many have we read of who have been buried with ignominy and obcurity; yet in a hort time, the Sun of their virtue hath rien out of the dark grave of prejudice and lander, and hined with more luter than before! Benedet • o Alberti was banihed by the Florentines, and yet after his death, they confeed their errour, and fetcht home his bones, burying him with olemn pomp and honour, whom being alive they had perecuted with landers and reproaches.
It is aid of our Englih Edward the 2d, that they who depied him being alive, o much honored him being dead, that they could have found in their hearts to make him a Saint.

The grave which buries a man hould alo bury all his enemies, it being unnaturall to hate the dead whom we cannot hurt, for the utmot
that malice can doe is to kill; and therefore it is noted a prodigious and unexampled hatred between the two brothers of Thebes, E • ocles and Polinices, as Statius tells us,

q.l:
Nec furiis pot fa • a modus, flammae
que rebelles
Their furies were not bounded by their fate,
One's Funeral flame the others flame did hate.

div.p: Solon made a Law that none hould peak evill of the dead, and his reaon was, for fear of immortal enemies.

Livor pot fata quiecit. Envy leeps after death; ays the Poet, as confidently as if it were not to be quetioned. Onely our Charls hath found it fale, and the men of
our Age alone have made an exception to this generall rule of charity. There have been found thoe who have perecuted his Ghot, and committed Treaon againt his Memory; like thoe chief Priets in the Gopel, who conulted to put Lazarus to death, after his reurrection. But his Virtue hath urvived their malice, and he Lives in pight of Fate or envy.

Haec et CAROLI gloria, ut nullius laudibus crecat, nullius vituperatione minuatur; as Macrobius ayes of Virgil. This is CHARLS his Glory, that as the prayes of his friends can adde nothing to him, o the landers of his enemies can detract nothing from Him. His Virtue needethnot our Encomiums, His Memory contemneth their candals, and his Merits Surpae all Dicoures.

div.head: VIRTS REDIVIVA: OR, A PANEGYRICK On the late K. CharlstheI. Second Monarch of Great BRITAIN.
div.p:
TO praie the living, although never o deerving, is not eldome upected of flattery, and deign: Therefore ay the wie Italians, La lode nacer deve quando è morto chi • h • da lodar; Praies ought not to be born, till the party praied be dead: when both envy in the Reader, and flattery in the Writer are ueles: when the Writers Pen is neither brib'd by favours to a
mercenary, and ordid adulation nor frighted by the frownes of greatnee into a Paral •• ick and haking cowardice.

I have undertaken a Subject which will <> me from the guilt of fawning flattery, as being o far above all praies that I fear not to be guilty of aying too mu • h, but too little in his commendation. The richet colours of Rhetorick are too dark to repreent a life o tranparent, o full of worth, o full of wonder. The brightet language will prove but a dark hadow, to that hining merit which exceeds all apprehenion, much les expreion; well it is if it do not poil, what I confes I am not able to adorn. Materies tamen ipa juvat. Charls the Firt, whom but to name is to cat a cloud upon all former Ages, and to benight Poterity; In taking of whoe Picture, I hall not need to doe as that Painter did, who drew Antigonus imagine lucâ, hal • faced, that o he might hide his want of an eye from the view of the beholder. There is nothing in Charls, but what is lovely and admirable no deformity, or imperfection. I hall rather chooe to imitate the famous Apelles; who to expres his art to the full in the picture of Venus riing naked out of the Sea, aembled together all the mot beautifull women of the Iland of Coos (his native place) uniting in that piece all their divided perfections. There is nothing eminent, or excellent in all the deervedly admired antients, that is not only met, but out-done in Charls. It is affirmed by the learned Raleigh, that if all the pictures and patterns of a merciles Prince were lot in the world, they might all again be painted
to the life out of the Story of Hen. 8. But I hall with as much truth and perhaps more Charity, maintain, that if all the Pictures, and Patterns of a mercifull Prince, of a couragious and contant King, of a vertuous, and brave Man, were lot they might be repaired, if not infinitely excell'd in the Story of Charls the Firt whoe life needs no Advocate, whom detraction it elf cannot mention without commendation. I find not any man in all the Records of the antients, or the Writings of the more modern authors, over whom he hath not ome advantage; nor any ones life, taken altogether, o admirable as His: nor any thing admirable in any, that was not in Him: Qu • imul omnia uno ito nomine continentur. In Him alone are to be found all the vertuous qualities of the bet Princes in the world, without the vices of any of them: for he only hath made it appear, that great vertues may be without the attendance of great vices.

It was aid of our Hen. the 5th. that he had omething in him of C • ar, which Alexander the Great had not, that he would not be drunk, and omething of Alexander the Great, which Caear had not, that he would not be flattered. But Charls had the vertues of all; without the vices of any, tam extra vici • , quam cum ummis virtutibus. He as much exceeded all other Kings, as other Kings doe all other men. In a word, he was what ever a good Prince ought to be, and what others hould be, yet was this Lilly born in the land of thorns and briers, this Roe prang up amidt a field of thitles; I preume the decription hath prevented me aying it was Scotland.

lg.l: A Land that calls in quetion, and upence
Gods Omni-preence, but that Charls came thence.

div.p: In quo nihil praeter unum Carolum et, quod commendemus. A Nation famous for the birth of Charls, but infamous for their treachery and diloyalty to o brave a Prince. But the happines of a brave and incomparable Father, did ufficiently recompence for the place of his birth: So that I may ay of him what is aid of Lewis the 8th of France, father to St. Lewis, that he was Son to an excellent Father, and Father to an excellent Son; a Son only worthy of uch a Father, a Father only worthy of uch a Son. A Father o admirable that Sir W. Raleigh hath left it upon Record to all Poterity, that if all the malice of the world were infued into one eye, yet could it not dicern in his life, any one of thoe foul pots, by which the conciences of all forreign Princes (in effect) have been defiled; nor any drop of that innocent bloud on the Sword of his jutice, with which the mot that fore-went him have tained both their hands and fame. This Encomium of the Father, may jutly decend to the Son as Heir apparant to his virtues, as well as his Crowns.

In his Childhood, the weaknee of his lower parts which made him unapt for exercies and feats of activity, rendred him more retired, and tudious, and more intent upon his Book then perhaps he had been otherwie. So great a Student was he in his younger dayes, that his Father would ay, he mut make him a Bihop: Providence
then eeming to deign him, rather to the Croier then the Crown. By his great tudy he became a great Hitorian, an excellent Poet, a great lover and Mater of Muick, and indeed a generall Scholar. This rare Cien was not grafted upon a wilding or crab-tock, but an innocent and tudious youth, was the prologue to a more active and vigorous manhood. For being grown in years, and tate, he hook off his former retirednes, and betook himelf to all manner of man-like exercies, as vaulting, riding the great Hore, running at the Ring, hooting in Cros-bowes, Muskets, and great Ordinance, in which he became o expert, that he was aid to be the bet Marks-man, and the mot comely Manager of a great Hore, of any one in his three Kingdoms. Nor were thee excellencies ill-houed, but his fair Soul was tenant to a lovely and well proportioned body. His tature of a jut proportion, his body erect and active, of a delicate contitution, yet o trong withall, as if nature had deign'd him to be the trife of Mars, and Venus. His countenance amiable and beautiful, wherein the White Roe of York, and the Red of Lancater were united: his hair inclining to a brown, till cares and grief changed them into a white, at once the Embleme of his innocence, and his fortune; clear and hining eyes, a brow proclaiming fidelity, his whole frame of face and favour, a mot perfect mixture and compoition of Majety, and Sweetnes.
Thus long have we beheld him as a Man: Let us now view him as a Husband, as a Father, as a King; and we hall find him alike admirable in all relations.

As an Husband he is a rare Example of love and chatity; at his firt receiving of his Queen, he profeed that he would be no longer Mater of himelf then whilt he was a Servant to her; and o well did he make his words good, that on the day before his death he commanded his Daughter, the excellent Princes Elizabeth, to tell her Mother that his thoughts had never trayed from her, and that his love hould be the ame to the lat. And indeed no man more loved, or les do ••• d upon a wife.

As a father, how tender was he of his children, without a too remis indulgence! how carefull of their education in the true Protetant Religion, which he alwayes profeed, and learnedly defended, adviing the Lady Elizabeth (and in her the ret) to read Bihop Andrews Sermons, Hookers Eccleiaitcall Politie, and Bihop Laud's book againt • iher, to ground them againt Popery.

Let us now view him as a King, and we hall ee him as the Soul of the Common-wealth, acting vigourouly, and regularly every particular member in its everal place and office. Behold him in his royall Throne, and thence dipencing his acred Oracles of Law and Jutice, to the admiration of all that had the happines to ee and hear him. Witnes Mr. Speaker •
Speech to his Majety on the 5th of Novem. 1640. I ee before my eyes with admiration (ayes that then eloquent Orator, as the mouth of all the Commons of England) the Majety of Great Britain, the glory of times, the hitory of honour, Charls the Firt, in his forefront placed by decent of antiquity, King, etled by a long ucceion, and continued
unto us by a pious & peaceful government; concluding with this erious and loyal promie; And all our Votes hall pas, that your acred Majety may Long, Long, Long reign over us. To which, no doubt, all that heard him aid, Amen. Such was his pious and paternall care over his people, that the mot • ullen ingratitude could not but acknowledge him the Father of his Country: teaching his people obedience to his Laws, not o much by Proclamation, as Example; as he was Imperio Maximus, o he was Exemplo Major, as Paterculus ayes of Tyberius: or as it is aid of Lycurgus, that famous Law-giver, he never ordained any thing to others, which he did not firt exactly oberve himelf.

So chat was he in his embraces, o pious in his devotions, o jut in all his actions, that the Law-maxime of Rex non peccat, was never more true of any King, than of Him. Behold him at the Councill Table, and there we hall find him (by the tetimony of one of his greatet enemies) principall in all tranactions of State, and the wiet about him but Accearies: for he never acted by any implicit faith in State matters; He had more learning and dexterity in State affairs, undoubtedly (ayes that Cook ruian) than all the Kings in Chritendom. And herein, if ever, the good words of an enemy are true.

It is reported of our Henry 4th. that he tood more upon his own legs than any of his Predeceors had done, in caes of difficulty; not refuing, but not needing the advice of others, which might confirm, but not better his own judgement. But this is far greater and truer commendation
in Charls, who ucceeded o wie a Prince as James the firt, the greatet Mater of King-craft (as he ued to call it) that ever wayd the Englih Scepter.

But as our Charls his widome was great, in that he was able to advie, yet was it greater in that he was willing to be advied: being never o wedded to his own opinions but that on good grounds he might be divorced from them; for though ome of his enemies have reported him wilfull, and too tenacious to his own reolves; one who knew him bettet then all of them (though perhaps their malice was greater than their ignorance) affirms, and that without upition of falhood, that though in his childhood he was noted to be very wilfull, which might proceed from that retirednes, which the imperfection of his Speech, not fitting him for publick dicoure, and the weaknes of his limbs and joints (as unfit for action) made him mot delight in; yet afterwards, as he haked off his retirednes, o he corrected in himelf the peccancy of that humour, which had grown up with it, there being no man to be found (ayes my Author, and it is verbum Sacerdotis) of an evener temper, more pliant to good counel, or les wedded than he was to his own opinion. Indeed as he was long and erious in deliberating, o was he jut and true to his reolves, and reolute in the execution of them.

Let us attend him to the Chappell, and there we hall ee him, o pious and devout in prayer, o reverend and attentive in hearing, that we may jutly conclude his piety to be as a rich Diamond
in the Ring of his royall virtues. Contantine alwayes heard Sermons tanding, acknowledging thereby what reverence is due to the Word of God, the irreverence that hath ince crept into our Churches, may well make us bewail the los of that laudable Example of our Englih Contantine, who alwayes bare a great regard to the Church and Church men; whom he reverenced for their function, and loved for their fi •• l •• y; o much a friend was he to all Church men, that had any thing in them beeeming that acred Function, that he hazarded (as he ays himelf) his own interet, chiefly upon concience & contancy to maintain their rights, whom the more he looked upon as Orphans, & under the acrilegious eyes of many cruel & rapacious reformers, o he thought it his duty the more to appear as a father, and patron for them and the Church.

He was at once a dutifull Son, and an indulgent father of the Church, eteeming it (with that good Emperor) a greater honour to be a member of the Church, than Head of an Empire. Nor was he onely a gracious Patron of the Church, but alo a reolute Champion in behalf of the Hierarchy, as well remembring that Prophetick Apothegm of the King his father, No Bihop, no King; his own experience being too great a Comment upon that truth to be by him neglected, or by us forgotten.

Baianus the Emperor refuing the name of Pius, would be called Foelix: on the contrary our Charls choe rather to be informiatly Pious, than irreligiouly properous, well knowing that piety hall not want its reward in a better place. A
King o religious, o devout, that if all his ubjects had been like the King, we might then indeed have had a Kingdom of Saints.

If we enter his Courts of Judicature, there hall we behold Jutice with her word and ballance, equally dividing, and impartially weighing out the rewards of virtue, and punihments of vice: poverty never excluding the Innocent, nor power abolving the nocent; and though the Aylum of his mercy was never hut to the meanet upplicant, whom the rigour of the Law had cat, yet was he alwayes inexorable to the upplications of the greatet offender, if found guilty of willfull murther. Ageilaus wrote to a Judge in behalf of his Favourite, Si caua bona, pro jutitia, in mala pro amicitia abolve. But hath not our Charls delivered up the greatet of his favourites to the entence of the Law? did his power ever hield the mot powerfull offenders from the troke of jutice, though himelf were wounded through their ides? As his jutice was blind to all relations, his hands were continually open to receive the Petitions of his meanet ubject: not like Demetrius who threw the Petitions of his people into the water; He was always ready and expectant to receive them, and never better pleaed than when he took them from the hands of the pooret Petitioner; jutly meriting the tyle of James the fifth of Scotland, who was called, The poor mans King.

Worthy was the Speech of that Goth, a King of Italy, who peaking of his Subjects, aid, Meis n • tra, cunctorum quies: Our harvet is their ret. Such was the vigilancy of Charls, whoe waking
eyes ecured all his flock from being a prey to any ubtle Mercury: No forreign invaion daring to land upon our coats; no home-bred broyles frighting the Husbandman from his Plough, or the Trademan from his Shop: but peace and plenty crowned all their endeavours, they being married in our Kingdome, as nearly as in the French Proverb. Every man ate under his own Vine and Fig-tree, eating the fruit of his own labours. No loading taxes made their trade move lowly, or clogged the wheels of their honet indutry. No polings, no plundrings, no pies to catch at every whiper, and make a man an offendour for a word; but Law was duly adminitred, Religion mainteined, Learning encouraged, the arts liberally profeed and rewarded. Our Merchants traffickt with afety and honour whereoever the neceity of their employments lead them; and no corner of the world o barbarous, but the name of an Englihman was welcome and pleaant.

It is reported that Henry the 8th confeed on his death bed, that he had never pared man in his wrath, nor woman in his lut: But of Charles let me ask, whoe houe did he plunder? whoe wife did he abue? whoe right did he wrong? may it not be more truly affirmed of him, what the Hitorian flatteringly pake of Livia, the wife of Augutus, Ejus potentiam nemo enit, nii aut levatione periculi, aut acceione dignitatis? No man felt his hand unles in raiing the oppreed from the pit of miery, or advancing the deerving to the hill of honour. To uch a pitch of felicity were we then arrived, by the virtues and
indulgence of a gracious Soveraign, that nothing could render us more happy, but a continuance of our happinee. Never was Prince more beloved, or better obeyed by loyall Subjects. Nothing but the want of him could render him more glorious, or deired.

But the greatet felicities are hortet lived, and the mot glorious ummer is followed by the harpet winter; the clearet skie is not without its clouds, the longet day mut have a night. The unne of our glory was arrived to the Meridian and Verticall point, it mut now decline, labour under a ad and almot total Ecclipe; and at lat et in a cloud of bloud, darknes, and confuion. O nulla longi temporis foelicit as! But as the un is no les glorious in it elf, when labouring under the darket Ecclipe, nor leaves his wonted coure, for all the clouds and vapours that flie in his face: So neither was our Charls les great and admirable under the mot fatall Ecclipes of his glory, nor les contant, and unwearied in all the royall Offices of a King, when the clouds and vapours of calumny and edition endeavored mot to obcure and darken his brightnee.

As he was a lover of Peace, he was no lee valiant in War, if we confee at leat valour conits not onely in doing, but alo in uffering. As he was moderate in properity, o was he couragious and patient in adverity: his virtue, courage and Chritian patience having carried him with an unwearied coure through both the Hemiph • res of properity and adverity, compaing (as I may ay) the whole globe of both
fortunes, and rendring him an unparalleld pattern of uch vertues, as were formerly undicovered to the world, and had till remained as a Terra incognita to all other Princes, had not his admirable example taught them, and all others, that no Cros is too heavy for a Chritian reolution, nor any difficulty too hard for vertue to conquer.

On the Sepulcher of Poenius Niger was placed this Epitaph, Here lieth Po. Niger, an antient Roman, who in merit was equal with the virtuous, but in misfortune exceeded the mot unfortunate. We may affix the ame with very little alteration to the Statue of Charles the firt, econd Monarch of Great Britain, That he was equal in merit with the mot virtuous, but in misfortunes exceeding the mot unfortunate: yet did the brightnes of his virtue hine through, and his piety gild and enamel the darket clouds of his afflictions, baffling all the daring mits of malice and envy, and converting them into well-placed hadows, which rendred his Picture more lively and admirable.

Naturalits write of a precious tone called Caraunias, that it is found onely in a day of thunder, glitering when the Sky is overcat with darknes: uch are the virtues of faith, hope, charity, patience, and magnanimity of Charles, which perhaps had never o gloriouly appeared, had not the darknes of his fortune brought them to light: and being like winter flowers produced between torms and tempets, and grown up like the noble Palm under the preures of weights and burthens.

Prolixum et enumerare omnes, cognocite aliquas, as St Ambroe aid of Judiths virtues; I hall only cull out ome few of thoe many rich jewells, to adorn his Panegyrick, and leave the ret to be collected by his Hitorians, and thredded by their more diligent hands upon the tring of their more lating tories.

The eye of mine obervation fixeth firt upon the orient gem of his Patience in affliction, which made him o ductile and plyant to the will of Heaven, that he willingly exchanged his Crown for the Croe, and made his Scepter toop to the Rod of affliction.

In his March after Eex to the Wet, it hapned that one of the carriages brake in a long narrow Lane, which they were to pas, and gave his Majety a top, at a time of an intolerable howre of rain which fell upon him, ome of his Courtiers and others which were near about him, offered to hew him out a way through the hedges with their Swords, that he might get helter in ome of the villages adjoyning; but he reolved not to forake his Canon upon any occaion: At which when ome about him eemed to admire and marvail at the patience which he hewed in that extremity; his Majety lifting up his Hat made anwer, That as God had given him afflictions to exercie his patience, o he had given him patience to bear his afflictions. A Speech o heavenly and divine (ays my Author) that it is hardly to be parallel'd by any of the men of God in all the Scripture. We may oberve him in his divine Meditations, like the indutrious Bee, ucking the Hony of comfort and conolation, out of the bitter flowers of his unequall fortune.

An Ancient aid, he that can bear an injury, is worthy an Empire; But if we conider with how even and equall a temper, with how contant and Chritian a fortitude his Majety bore all the injurious inolencies, and inolent injuries which the tongues and pens of his malitious adveraries continually loaded him withall, we mut be forced to confee, that if merit herein might have won, or jutice have been Elector, he had not been King of an inconiderable Iland, but Emperor of the whole world. So far was He from repining at his afflictions, or being angry at the injuries of his ignorant and inolent enemies, that he never eteemed himelf more glorious, than when dreed up in the robe o • their corn and mockery: alwayes fencing himelf with that royall Maxime as with a hield, Bona agere, & mala patiregium et. Nor could the injuries and affronts of ome, force him to a retaliation, being often angry at, but never pleaed with thoe atyricall invectives againt his enemies which a jut indignation ometimes forced from the harper Pens of ome of his friends.

As his loes could not make him depond, his victories never made him inolent; though the one rendred him more humble, the other could not make him proud; He was rather like Fenugreek, which (ayes Pliny) the wore it is handled the better it proves.

It is aid of that mother in the Maccabees, who aw her even children lain before her eyes, and lat of all was her elf lain; Octies paus et Martyries, that he uffered Eight times over:
and can we think that o indulgent a Father of his people, did not uffer as many everal martyrdomes, as his ubjects ufferd mieries and detructions.

Non placet vindicta, ed victoria, was the applauded peech of the conquering Caear; but we may hear our victorious Charls profee, He never had any victory which was without his orrow, becaue it was on his own ubjects, who like Abalom, died many of them in their in: and yet (ayes he) • never ufferd any defeat which made me dep •• r of Gods mercy and defence. And that he might convince the world that he loved not war nor delighted in the ruine of his ubjects, he ever ought for peace, after his greatet victories; The highet tide of uccee (as he aith himelf, who could bet tell) et him not above a Treaty, nor did any uccee he had, ever enhance with him the price of peace, though he was like to pay dearer for it than any man.

It is Recorded to the honour of the Roman Scipio Africanus, and will be to the glory of our Englih Charls, that he had rather ave one friend, than kill a thouand enemies. But to uch a height were our ins, and the guilty malice of ome particular men amounted, that rendred all his Royal endeavours and tenders of Peace unfortunate and fruitlee; So true is that obervation of the grave Tacitus, Invio emel principe, eu malè, eu benè facta praemiunt: A Prince once ditated is ever upected, and his actions micontrued; it then appearing plainly, that whatever pretentions palliated the deigns
of ome, yet their intentions terminated in a Nolumus hunc regnare; nor was it hard to prophecie that uch Recuants then would in time appear Ravilliac's: and ome there were, who though they could not but admire
• harles, yet they hated the King.

Others there were who too well knew the Maxime of their Countryman Machiavel, that a ucceion of two or three virtuous Princes worketh trange effects, and therefore feared to be at the cot of the experiment, let it might have proved to have been at no cheaper ra • e than the ruine of their deign, the erecting of their Babèl of confuion, thereby to make way for their Catholick Monarch. But to their wonder and their envy, when all his forces were defeated, and his word faln out of his hands, Charles alone maintains the Combat, and ingly duels (like another Athanaius) the whole world, in defence of his Concience and Religion, which were all the wealth his hipwrackt fortune had left him, and which, ma • gre the malice of his fate, he carried afe to hore.

The victories he then gained will remain as Eternal Trophies of his honour, and undeniable arguments of his vat abilities in matters of Controverie: Let his Conference with the Marques of Worceter, the papers which paed betwixt his S. Majety and Mr. Henderon, and thoe other with the Miniters in the Ile of Wight, tetifie how great a Mater he was of reaon, how well read in the Fathers, the Councils, Eccleiatical Hitory, and the cutoms of the Church in all Ages. By all which it will plainly
appear that he was as well the cholar, as the Son of K. James, by whom he was o well intructed in the controveries of Religion, that when he was in Spain, D. Maw, and D. Wren, two of his Chaplains being appointed to follow after, came to K. James to know his pleaure and commands: the King advied them not to put themelves upon any unneceary Diputations, but to be onely on the defenive part, if they hould be challenged; and when it was anwered that there could be no reaon to engage in uch diputations, where there could be no Moderator, the King replied, that Charles hould moderate between them and the oppoite party. At which, when one of them eemed to mile on the other, the King proceeded, and told them, that Charls hould manage a point in Controverie with the bet Studied Divine of them all. He was without quetion Mater of an Imperial pen; His Eagles feathers (upon all occaions) devoured his adveraries gooe-quils, and infinitely recompenced the impediment of his peech, with the advantage of an inimitable tyle.

Spartianus reports of Trajan, that after his death he triumphed openly in the City of Rome, In imagine, in a lively Statue, or Repreentation, invented by Adrian for that purpoe. But Charles triumphs more nobly in his Royal Portraicture, drawn by himelf, with uch curious lines, and lively colours, as no hand but his own could draw. There is he eated more gloriouly than ever he was on his Royal Throne, or in his Royal Robes; there hall he live and
reign, and be as immortal as his enemies malice. Never was devotion clad in a more rich, or more modet dres. There doth he make it appear that his oul was free and unconfin'd, though his body were a prioner, and that he could exercie the office of a Priet, when he was deprived of that of a King. Such was the power of his noble and commanding Soul, even then, that he made his Conquerors his captives, and ubdued the hearts of thoe to love him, who had deprived him of all other weapons.

Such was the Princely carriage of Francis the Firt, King of France, that he thereby o won upon the hearts of Burbon, and the ret of his enemies, to whom he was a prioner, that they honoured him with no lee obervancy, than if he had been on the top of his properity: and Homer much commends his Ulyes, that when by hipwrack he was cat on hore, he had nothing to commend him but his carriage. Had Homer had Charls for his ubject, or Charls Homer for his Hitorian, what an admirable trife would there have been betwixt the workman and the matter, and yet the matter would have exceeded the workmans art.

p.U:
aith of Tyberius, Quod vius praetul •
rit principem, his Countenance proclamed him King: So Majetick was the Countenance, and o winning the carriage of Charls, that his enemies became his converts, and his very Gaolers his Confeors: ome of them having ever ince exchanged their former Maters and Etates, for a prion, and banihment, to expiate
their former injuries to o good a King.

div.p: And now we have brought him to the lat, and mot glorious act of his life, wherein we hall ee him out-do himelf, as he had done all others in his former actions; God fitting him with a Couragious and Chritian patience, as much above all other men, as his cae and condition was trancending all former examples.

Trees that grow on the tops of rocks (they ay) have tronger roots than other trees, becaue they are more expoed to the boiterounes of the winds and weather. His Sacred Majety was now to act a part beyond all preident, and God fitted him with a virtue and contancy beyond all parallel.

lg.l: En horret animus, & pavor membra excutit.
—refugit loqui

mens
• gra, tantis at
que inhorrecit malis.

div.p:
My thoughts are ditracted, and my pen falls out of my hand with amazement, I mut theretherefore draw a veil of ilence over, and Comment upon this Tragical Scene with tears intead of words. I will onely adventure to draw the curtain o far, as may let in the Readers eye to dicover the King ingly maintaining his own Innocence, his Succeors Rights, and his peoples Liberty, againt a Legion of his adveraries, who were at once his Judges and Accuers. Scipio being one day accued before the Roman people of a capital offence, intead of excuing himelf, or flattering the Judges, turning to them, he aid, It will well beeem you to
judge of his head by whoe means you have authority to judge of all the world. Private perons have many Judges, Kings none but God, aid M. Antonius. But our King had to do with people of another principle, who too well knew that politick maxime of Monieur de Foy, That a man mut not trut a reconciled enemy, epecially his King, againt whom, when he draws his word, he mut throw the cabbard into the river.

It was not enough that he had granted whatever they deired, which his concience and the afety of his ubjects would permit, or that his Royal Conceions went beyond the foremot of their hopes and wihes, or that his reaons were unanwerable, and that they had no greater plea againt him, but that of the rapacious wolf to the innocent lamb, Thou hat the better caue, but I have the better teeth. Though Charls was innocent, it was crime enough that he was King, and tood in the place that ambition aimed at.

Semiramis (as Aelian tells the Story) was an humble Petitioner to the King of the Ayrians, whoe Concubine he was, that he might take upon her the government of A • ia, and command the Kings ervants, but for the tranitory pace of five dayes; it was granted, he came forth wit •• a Princely robe, and her firt words were (ingrateful wretch!) Go take the King, and kill him: and o by one venturous tep climbed up to a etled tate of Imperial Government. I leave the parallel to the readers thoughts, and go on to oberve what is truly obervable, that notwithtanding the natural impediment of the
Kings Speech, God at this time of his extremity o looed his tongue, that he delivered his thoughts without the leat tammering or haeitation; enough to have convinced any but a Pilat, and a Jurie of Jewes, that by that miracle God eemed to ay to them, in the language of that dumb man, Rex et, ne occide. But it was argument enough to them to cut off that head, that it wore three Ctowns. A thing o trange and unheard of before our times, that though they made a Preident, they could never find an Example for it in all the Hitories of the world. So acred and inviolable was the Peron of the Prince amongt the Romans, that when Nero (made valiant by his own fear) ran himelf through, Epaphroditus his Secretary, at his requet, helping to dipatch him the ooner, for that ervice was afterwards put to death by Domitian, who thought it not meet to uffer any man to live, who had in any ort lent his hand to the death of a Prince.

The Kings of Peru were o reverenced by their ubjects and o faithfully erved, that never any of their ubjects were found guilty of Treaon. Indeed the people of Nicer a gua in America, had no law for the killer of a King, but it was for the ame reaon that Solon appointed none for a mans killing of his Father; both of them conceiting that men were not o unnatural, as to commit uch crimes. But uch is the mierable condition of Princes, as the Emperor Domitian complained, that they cannot be credited touching a Conpiracy, plainly detected, until they be firt lain. More trange and ad it is,
that men hould commit murther with the word of Jutice, and treaon execute jutice as a malefactor. Such actions eldome want their reward, and many times receive it from the Actors own hands.

It is the obervation of Cauabon in his Annotations upon Suetonius, that all they who conpired againt Caear, lew themelves with the ame poniards wherewith they had tabbed the Emperor. Such a death (aith he) may all have who o wickedly and diloyally enterprize upon the lives of Princes. For a man to attempt upon the life of a forreign or neighbour Prince, may perhaps pae with the guilt of imple murther; but for a ubject to aainate his own native King, is no les than Paracide in the uperlative degree.

At the Solemn Coronation of the Prince, every Peer of the Realm hath his tation about the Throne, and with the touch of his hand upon the Royal Crown, declareth the peronal duty of that honour which he is called unto, namely, to hold on the Crown on the Head of his Soveraign, to make it the main end of his greatnee, to endeavour the etablihment of his Princes Throne. Jutly may thoe branches wither that contrive the ruine of the Stock that feeds them: and well may they prove falling tars, who endeavour the eccliping of that Sun from whom they have received their light and lutre.

Rodolphus D. of Suevia, having uurped the Empire of the Romans, in a Conflict with Henry the right Emperor, his right hand was truck
off in battel, which being brought to him lying upon his death-bed, in the horrour of his guilt he cryed out, This is the hand wherewith I confirmed my promied loyalty to the Emperor. Such as repay hatred where they owe love, and return diloyalty where they owe allegiance, may expect a payment in their own coin from the hand of Divine Jutice.

But to diguie Majety into an habit of treaon, and to dres up treaon in a robe of jutice; to place guilt on the bench, and et innocence at the bar, and by a mockery of Law to condemn the Fountain of Law, is like the Italian Phyician, who boated he had kill'd a man with the fairet method in the world, è mort •
(aid he) canonicamente, è con tutti gli ordini; He is dead (ays he) regularly, and with all the rules of art.

To dwell no longer on this unpleaant ubject, we had inned, and Charls mut uffer. Dilirant Archivi, plectun • ur Reges. He who had worn a Crown of Gold, mut now admit a crown of thornes, that might fit him for the Crown of Glory.

They had promied to make him a glorious King, and now was the time come; Sit divus, modo non it vivus, ay they. His Kingdom was not to be any longer of this world, and therefore he prepares himelf with humility, piety, charity, and magnanimity, to bear this earthly cros; that he might attein his heavenly crown: His enemies cure him, he prays for them; they lander him, he forgives them; they load him with affronts, he carries them with patience. And now his pious oul is on the wing, and makes
many a ally to the place where he longed to be at ret: and in the fire of an ardent devotion, he offers up himelf an Holocaut, being kindled with the flames of Divine Love, and is fill'd with a large meaure of celetial joy, and holy confidence; witnee that admirable Anagram made by himelf on the day before his death,

Hermigildus Son of Levigildus King of the V •
ogoths, foraking the Arrian Hereie, which his Father maintain'd, and embracing the Catholick truth, was threatned by his Father with death, unles he returned to his former errors: To whom the pious Son, Poteris (aith he) in me tatuere pater quod lubet; regno privas? ed peritura tantum: immortale illud eripere non potes. In vincula me rapis? ad coelum certè patet via; ibimus, illuc ibimus. Vitam eripit • s? retat melior & aeterna. Such were the pious reolves of the mot Chritian Charls: You may doe with me what you will, ye may deprive me of my Kingdomes, alas! thee are perihing things; but mine immortal Crown ye cannot reach. If ye confine me to the narrow walls of a prion, my oul vvill mount to Heaven; thither, thither vvill vve goe. If ye take avvay this life, I hall but exchange it for a better and eternal one.
Thus prepared, he vvith all humility and Chritan reignation, offers up himelf the peoples Martyr; to the grief of his friends, the hame of his enemies, and the amazement of all the world.
div.q: Quis talia fando temperet à la • hrymis!
div.p: Many wiped up his blood with their handkercheifs, which experience proved afterwards an admirable Collirium to retore the ight even to thoe (I could name ome of the recovered patients; from whom I received the relation) who were almot blind: this wants not truth o much as a Roman pen, to make it a miracle Sure I am his death opened thouands of eyes, which paion and prejudice had blinded: and thoe who whilt he lived, wih'd him dead, now he was dead wih'd him alive again.

That o great a Prince (who yet choe rather to be good than great, to be holy rather than happy) might not die unattended, many loyal ubjects left this life with the very news of His death: as it is reported of Hugh Scrimiger, ervant to S. W. Spotswood, beheaded by the Covenanters of Scotland, paing by the Scaffold before it was taken down, fell into a wound, and being carried home, died at his own door. The truth of this Relation I leave to the credit of the Hitorian; the former I attet upon mine own knowledge, my elf being aitant at the Funeral of a Kinman, who (with divers others) died of no other dieae than the newes of the Kings death; on whom, as I then betowed, I here depoite this Epitaph.

lg.l: Here lies a loyal member dead,
Who corned to urvive his Head.

div.p: Thus died Charls, Aliorum majori damno, quam uo: It being hard to determine, whether the Church and State were more happy to have had, or more mierable to loe o incomparable a King; who wanted nothing but to have lived in an Age when it was in fahion to Deifie their Worthies, or in a Country where it is a trade to be Sainted. But alas! He lived in an Age when vices were in fahion, and virtues accounted vices. Of whom, his wort enemies (ayes one who was none of his bet friends) cannot but give this civil, yet true Character, That he was a Prince of mot excellent natural parts, an univeral Gentleman, very few men of any rank or quality exceeding him in his natural endowments, and the mot accomplihed King this Nation had ever ince the Conquet.

div.head: Oweni Epigr. in Regicidas.
div.p: Si manus offendat te dextra, abcindito dextram,
Offendat i pes, abjice, Chritus ait.
Corpus in errorem dexter i ducat ocellus,
Ipe oculus peccans, effodiendus erit.
Quaelibet abcindi pars corporis aegra jubetur,

Excipiunt medici, Theologi
que Caput.

div.head: An Elegie on Charls the Firt, &c.

lg.l: COme addet Mue, tragick Melpomine,
Help me to weep, or igh an Elegie;
And from dumb grief recover o much breath,
As may erve to expres my Sovereigns death.
But that's not all; had Natures oil been pent,
And all the treaury of life he lent
Exhausted: had his latet and been run,
And the three fatal Siters thred been pun;
Or laden with yeares, and mellow had he dropt
Into our mothers boome; not thus lopt,
We could have born it. But thus hew'd from life
B'an Axe, more haty than the cruel knife
Of grily Atropos; thus to be torn
From us, whom loyal death would have • orborn,
This trikes us dead. Hence Nero hall be kind
Accounted, he but wihed, and that wih confin'd
Within the walls of Rome; but here we ee
Three Kingdoms at one blow beheaded be:
And intead of the one head of a King,
Hundreds of Hydra-headed Monters pring.
Scarce can I think of this, and not engage
My Mue to muter her Poetick rage,
To courge thoe Gyan • s, whoe bold hands have rent
This glorious Sun from out our Firmament,
Put out the light of Irael, that they might
Act their black deeds ecurely in the nigh • :
When none but new and foolih lights appear,
Not to direct, but cheat the traveller.
But biting births are monstrous, Ours mut be
(My Midwife Mue) a weeping Elegie.
Well may we, like ome of whom Stories write,
From this Sun-et in mourning pend our night:
Until we ee a econd Sun arie,
That may exhale thoe vapours from our eyes.
Since the breath of our notrils we have lot,
We are but moaning tatues at the mot,
Our wiedome, reaon, jutice, all are dead,
As parts that liv'd, and died with our Head.
How can we peak him praie, or our los, when
Our tongue of language ilenc'd is with him.
Or can our fainter penils hope to paint
Thoe rayes of Majety, which pake him Saint?
In mortal weeds, not man; As great a King
Of virtues, as of men; A acred thing,
To uch an heighth of eminency rais'd,
Eaier by far to be admir'd than prais'd.
'Twould puzzle the age Plutarch now to tell,
Or finde on earth our Charls's parallel.
Let Rome and Greece of Heroes boat no more,
To make our One, would beggar all their tore.
Weep ye three Orphan Kingdoms, weep, for He
To you was truly Pater Patriae.
Mourn too Religion, Liberty, and Lawes,
He was your Martyr, and died in your caue.
Levy a tax of grief, for who'll deny,
For this o general los, a general cry.
Though to bear arms be, yet I know no reaon
That loyal tears hould be accounted treaon.
Let not thy grief be mall, I thee intreat,
Britain, for him who onely made thee Great.

div.head: An Anniverary on Charls the Firt, &c. 1657.

lg.l: PArdon, great Soul, the lownes of my vere,
Who after eight years ing thine Annivere:
Since he who well would write thine Elegie,
Mut take an Ages time to tudy thee.
Nay mut be you, for none but you can tell,
Or meaure the jut height from whence you fell.
We know not how to etimate thy los,
Nor can we feel the weight of thy ad cros.
If we hould rack our fancies, to invent
Michiefs, & plots far wore than hell e're meant
To bet of men (when men with hell combine)
They all would prove faint Metaphors of thine.
He who once • old his Kingdom for a draught
Of running water, and then perih't trait,
Had much the better bargain; thou didt loe
All men could wih, for mieries and woes.
Saints (like their Saviour) when for drink they call,
The world preents them vinegar & gall.
What montrous ins of ours made Heaven to frown,
When Virtue met an Axe, and Vice a Crown!
Thrones, Scepters, Crowns, and all the gaudy things,
That ue to deck and load the heads of Kings;
Who now will value you, ince you have bin
Rewards of vice, and recompence of in!
And leave them as revenges to thy foes.
Thee, like the Prophets mantle fell from thee,
When thou, like him, didt climb t'Eternity.
Poor Princes thus to others leave their own
Small tates, when called to a richer Crown.
As when a jewel's taken out the cae,
Attoms and air uurp'd the jewels place;
Or as the Sun leaving one Hemiphere,
Darknes and night preume to revel there.
So is thy place upply'd, the Sphere which thou
Wert wont to fill, we ee invaded now
By a wild Comet, whoe blaze doth portend,
If not a udden, yet a certain end.
Though dead, thou till upon our hearts dot gain,
And o more nobly and more truly reign.
Thoe bleings which we prize not, whilt poet,
Their worth our want of them d • covers bet.
Night makes the day, & darknes gilds the Sun,
Thus things grow greater by comparion.
We envy not thy glory, nor bemoan
With tears thy ad misfortunes, but our own.
Whilt thou with an immortal Crown dot hine,
The woe is ours, the happines is thine.
Thou hat attaind'd the Haven, we are tot
Upon a ea of woes; our Pilot lot;
Driven by th'winds and waves, ditret, forlorn,
Our lading hipwrackt, and our tackling torn.
Cloath'd with a long white robe of innocence,
Thou walk't; in blacket mourning ever ince
Our hearts are clad. To rid us of our pain,
Wee'l die, o be thy ubjects once again.

div.head: Second Anniverary on Charls the Firt, 1658.

lg.l: THe year's return'd, and with the year my task,
Which to perform no other aid I ask,
No Mue invoke, but what my grief affords,
Grief that would fill a dumb mans mouth with words.
A King's my ubject, and a King whoe name
Alone, peaks more than all the tongues of fame.
Charls, good as great, whoe virtues were his crimes,
The bet of men duell'd the wort of times.
But by his ad example we may know,
Exces of goodnes is not afe below.
T'was too much worth jut Aritides ent,
(By a wild otracim) to's banihment.
Oh! hadt thou liv'd when virtue was in fahion,
And men were rul'd by reaon, not by paion,
How had't thou been ador'd! Thy actions had
Been the jut Standard of what's good or bad.
Thy life had pas'd for law, and the whole Nation
Might have been virtuous by imitation.
To have been good, and in the bet degree,
Had been no more but to be like to thee.
Thou art all wonder, and thy brighter Story,
Cats an Ecclipe upon the blazing glory
Of former ages; all their Worthies, now
(By thee out-done) do bluh, and wonder how
They lot the day, beclouded with a night
Of ilence, riing from thy greater light.
Their moral deeds are of too faint a dye,
If once compared with thy piety.
Be dumb ye lying Legends, here's a Reign,
Full of more miracles than ye can feign.
Here is a aint, more great, more true than e're
Came from the triple crown, or holy chair.
We need no farther for Example look,
Than unto thee, thou art the onely book;
Thou art the bet of Texts, hereafter we
Expect no more, but Comments upon thee:
Thou art the great Original, and he
Who will be famous now, mut trancribe thee;
Spight of the Sword and Axe, you found a way
To win the field, although you lot the day.
In thy rare Portraicture thou livet till,
And triumpht more by thine all-conquering quill;
There halt thou reign, and as immortal be,
As was the malice of thine enemie.
Thou hat out-witted all thy foes, and by
Thy Book thou gain't the greatet victory.
That hath enlarg'd thine Empire, and all men
Stoop to the Scepter of thy Royal Pen.
Thy Virtues crowd o fat, I cannot tell
How to peak all, or which doth mot excell.
All I can ay is but Epitomie,
A life's too little for thy Hitory.
I can but write thee in Stenographie,
The whole of others is but part of thee.
But thou hat poke thy elf in uch a train,
Our wits are ueles, and endeavours vain.
Silence and admiration fit me bet,
Let others try to write, I'll weep the ret.

div.p: A THEATRE OF WITS, Ancient and Modern. Repreented in a Collection of Apothegmes. Pleaant and Profitable. By THO. FORDE.

q.p: Omne tulit punctum, qui micuit utile dulci.

Habent enim Apothegmata peculiarem quandam rationem, & indolem uam, ut breviter, argutè, alsè, & urbanè cuju
que ingenium exprimant.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by R. and W. Leybourn, for William Grantham at the Black Bear in St. Pauls Church-yard, neer the little North Door. 1660.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
I Here preent thee with a dih of Apothegmes, pull'd from the leaves of many Authours; if they pleae thee in the tating, but as much as they did me in the gathering, I hall not doubt their entertainment. Amongt thoe warms of books which our age is daily glutted with, there is not one Author hath travelled in this road, nor any one book of this nature (that I know) in our Language,
except a Manual of that great Advancer of Learning, Sir Francis Bacon, which hath long ince been out of print. I had therefore ome temptation to have added mine as a Supplement to his; but upon econd thoughts, conidering none ever attempted to add a line to that peece Apelles left imperfect, I have choen rather to erect a new frame by his model, than to build upon anothers foundation.

That the Volume is mall, my diligence hath been the greater, for I have laboured to ubtract, rather than multiply them; not putting in every one I met with, but what was bet, at leat in my opinion. Thee are but the fi • t fruits, your acceptance may ripen them into a larger harvet, if God hall lend me time and opportunity.

I have waved any particular Dedication,
as not willing to entitle any man to the Patronage of my weaknees; nor am I of that vain humour of Appian the Grammarian, who promied immortality to thoe to whom he dedicated any of his Works.

q.l: And they who write to Lords rewards to get.Donnes Sat.
Are they not like ingers at doors for meat?

div.p:
There is a Vine in Aia, that brings forth Burnt-wine, o excellent (aithJohnton Hit. Nat. mine Author) that none exceeds it. Such is the nature of thee hort entences, they are ready dres'd and dih'd out to thy hand; like ome Diamonds, which grow moothand polihed, and need no farther labour to fit them for ue, but uing. As it is aid of Iidore the Philoopher, that he pake not words, but the very ubtance and eence of things. They
contain magnum in parvo, much matter in a few words. Significant potius quam exprimunt. You have here much gold in a little ore, eaie for carriage, ready for ue. We have many things to learn, and but little time to live; I know not therefore any kind of Learning more pleaant, or more profitable than this, which teacheth us many leons in a few lines. But I will not wate thy time (Reader) whilt I tudy to improve it, and to approve my elf

div.head: Apothegmes:
div.p: AN old Mas-Priet in the dayes of Hen. 8. reading in Englih after the Tranlation of the Bible, the mircale of the five loaves and two fihes, when he came to the vere that reckoneth the number of the guets, he paued a little, and at lat aid, they were about 500; the Clerk whipered into the Priets eares, that it was 5000; but the Priet turned back, and replied with indignation, Hold your peace, irrah, we hall never make them believe they were 500.

p.U: aid, concerning the Elegance of the City of Smyrna, that no man, except he which hall ee it, will be drawn to believe it.

div.p:
The Savages, an Englih Family, held Ardes (in Ireland) long in poeion, amongt whom there goeth a great name of Him, who aid no les toutly than pleaantly, when he was moved to o build a Catle for his defence, that he would not trut to a catle of tones, but rather to a
catle of bones. Meaning his own body.

Columbane, a Monk of Ireland, when Sigebert King of the Frankners, dealt very earntly with him, and that by way of many fair and large promies, that he hould not depart out of his Kingdom: Anwered him, That it became not them to embrace other mens riches, who for Chrits ake had foraken their own.
Porpherie, in regard of the many tyrants riing up in his dayes in Britain, cried out in thee terms, Britain a foolih Province of tyrants.

St. Ambroe in his Funeral Sermon of Theodoius, cryeth out in thee terms: that Eugenius and Maximus (who had five years uurped the Empire) by their woful example, doe tetifie in hell what a heavy thing it is to bear arms againt their Natural Prince.
Of this Maximus it is aid, that he was a valiant man, victorious, and worthy the title of Augutus, but that againt his allegiance he had by way of tyranny and uurpation attained the place.

p.U: aith of one that had a misfortune, It was becaue he did not honour his Parents.

div.p: Upon a triumph, all the Emperor Severus's Souldiers, for the greater pomp, were to put on Crowns of Bayes; but one Chritian there was amongt them which wore it on his arm; and being demanded the reaon, boldly anwered: It becomes not a Chritian to be crowned in this life.
Arnobius was wont to ay, that perecution brings death in one hand, and life in the other; for while it kills the body, it crowns the oul.

The Empres Eudoxia, ending a threatning
meage to Chryotom, (for boldly reproving her) He anwered, Go tell her I fear nothing but in.

p.U: aid of Luther, that he could have of God what he pleaed.

div.p: Epaminondas being asked what was the greatet joy he ever had in the world, He aid Leutrica Victoria, the Battel of Leutrick.

Rocardus, King of Friland, being by Wolfranius perwaded to be Baptized, having one foot in the Font, the other out, asked Wolfranius where went the mot part of his Predeceors that were not Baptized? To hell, aid Wolfranius; then Rocardus drew his foot out of the Font, aying, It was bet following of the greatet company.

The Devil meeting with a devout Hermit, asked him three quetions: Firt, what hould be the tranget thing that God made in a little frame? He anwered, a mans face. The econd, Where was the Earth higher than all the Heavens? Where Chrits body, born of the Virgin Mary, was adored of Angels and Archangels. The third, what pace was between Heaven and Earth? Thou knowet bet (aid the Hermit) which wat from Heaven thrown down to the Earth.

L. Silla finding his ouldiers timerous, and fearful to fight with Archelaus, M •• hridates General, drew out his word, and aid, You ouldiers that mean to fly to Rome, tell them at Rome, that you left Silla your General, fighting in the midt of the Battel, with the enemies in Boetia.

Philipides the Poet, refued to be of King Lyimachus Counel, that when the King aid to
him, What wilt thou that I give unto thee? Nothing (aid the poor Poet) but onely this, that I may not be of thy Council.

In a publick meeting with all the Princes of Germany, at Wormatia; where the Duke of Saxon firt preferring his mettals, and rich veins of earth: the Duke of Bavaria much commending his trong and brave Cities and Towns: and the Duke Palatine of his wines, and fertility of his lands: the Duke of Wittenbergh aid, I can lay my head, and leep upon the lap of any of my ubjects I have abroad in the field, every where. Huic facile concedite palmam (aid Maximilian the Emperor) Give him the palm.
Themitocles being asked whoe Oration he would hear? Even him (aid Themitocles) that can bet et forth my praie, and advance my fame.

Iocrates repeating an Oration of Demothenes his adverary, at Rhodes, they of Rhodes much delighting therein, and much commending the Oration that Iocrates made, though he was enemy to Demothenes, was forced againt his will to ay to the people, What if you had heard the beat himelf pronouncing his own Oration?

p.U: eeing certain men of Apulia, in Rome, carrying Apes upon their arms, playing, asked the men, If they had no women in Apulia to get children to play withal.

div.p: Diogenes, when he aw mice creeping for ome crums to his table, would ay, Behold, Diogenes alo hath his paraites.

Lewis the 10th. was wont to brag of his own Kingdom of France, that it far exceeded all other
Kingdoms, wanting but one thing; and being requeted to know what that was, he anwered, Truth.

The great Antiochus brought Hannibal to his treaures, and hewed him his gold, his ilver, his wealth and treaures, and asked him if all that would not pleae the Romans? Yea, aid Hannibal, it would pleae the Romans, but not atisfie the Romans.

A Councellor of State, aid to his Mater the King of Spain, that now is, upon occaion: Sir, I will tell your Majety thus much for your comfort, your Majety hath but two enemies; whereof the one is all the World, and the other is your own Miniters.
Domitian perceiving many of his Predeceors in the Empire to be hated, asked one, how he might o rule, as not to be hated? the party anwered, Tu fac contra: By not doing what they did.
When M. Cicero tood for the Conulhip of Rome, Q. Cicero wihed him to meditate on this, Novus um, Conulatam peto, Roma et.
Alexander having a ouldier of his name that was a coward, He bad him either leave off the name of Alexander, or be a ouldier.
A brave Roman Captain told his ouldiers, That if they could not conquer Britain, yet they would get poeion of it, by laying their bones in it.

It was a mart anwer which Mr. Durant, a witty and learned Miniter of the Reformed Church of Paris, gave a Lady of upected chatity, (and ince revolted) when he pretended the hadnes of the Scripture: Why,
aid he, Madam, What can be more plain, then, Thou halt not commit adultery.
It was the aying of the dying Emperor Julian, He that would not die when he mut, and he that would die when he mut not, are both of them cowards alike.

Aritippus told the Sailers, that wondred why he was not, as well as they, afraid in the torms, that the odds was much For they feared the torments due to a wicked life, and he expected the rewards of a good one.
It was cold comfort Diogenes gave a lewd liver, that banihed, complained he hould die in a forreign oil. Be of good cheer man, whereoever thou art, the way to hell is the ame.
It was the admonition of dying Otho to Cocceius, Neither too much to remember, nor altogether to forget, that Caear was his ncle.
Iocrates, of a Scholar full of words, asked a double Fee, One, he aid, to learn him to peak well, another to teach him to hold his peace.

Euripides, when he brings in any woman in his tragedies, makes them alwayes bad: Sophocles in his tragedies maketh them alwayes good: whereof when Sophocles was asked the reaon; he made this anwer, Euripides, aith he, repreents women as they be, I repreent them as they ought to be.
Sir Henry Wotton was wont to ay of Sir Philip Sydneys wit, that it was the very meaure of congruity.

Having in Italy acquaintance with a pleaant Priet, who invited him one evening to hear their Veper muick at Church; the Priet eeing Sir Henry tanding obcurely in a corner,
ends to him by a boy this quetion writ in a mall piece of paper: Where was your Religion to be found before Luther? To which Sir Henry Wotton preently under-writ, My Religion was to be found then, where yours is not to be found now, in the written word of God.
To another that asked him whether a Papit may be aved? He replied, You may be aved without knowing that; look to your elf.

To another that was till railing againt the Papits, he gave this advice, Pray Sir forbear, till you have tudied the points better: for the wie Italians have this Proverb, He that undertands amis concludes wore.

To one being deigned for the office of an Embaador, requeting from him ome experimental rules for his prudent and afe carriage in his Negotiation, Sir Henry Wotton gave this for an infallible Aphorime; That to be in afety himelf, and erviceable to his Country, he hould alwayes, and upon all occaions peak the truth; for, aid he, you hall never be believed, and by this meanes your truth will ecure your elf, if you hall ever be called to any account, and it will alo put your adveraries (who will till hunt counter) to a los, in all their diquiitions and undertakings.
He directed this entence onely to be incribed on his Tomb-tone; Hic jacet hujus ententiae Author. Diputandi pruritus fit Eccleiarum cabies.

Bolilaus the 4th. King of Poland, who bearing the picture of his Father, hanged about his neck in a plate of gold, when he was to peak, or doe any thing of importance, he took his
picture, and kiing it, aid, Dear Father, I wih I may not doe any thing remisly, unworthy of thy name.

A gentile pirit aid to an old man, who caued his grily hairs to be painted with the lutre of green youth: Poor fool, although thou couldt deceive the whole world with thy hair, yet death well knoweth they are grey. Sit te Proerpina canem.

It is aid, a French King enquiring one day of a Wie-man, after divers intructions to govern himelf, and guide his Kingdome, this Wie-man took a fair large heet of paper, and for an infinite number of precepts, which others ue to produce upon this ubject, he onely wrote this word: Modus, meaure, or mean.
One who having lived free from the bonds of mariage, caued to be et on his Tomb, Vixit ine impedimento, He lived without hinderance.
A mother grieving for the death of her on, aid, That all her evil came from loving too much what he might loe. Amabam mier a periturum, &c.

An old humourit vapouring once that women had no ouls, was anwered by a modet Lady: Sure, Sir, you are deceived, for I can produce a good text to the contrary, My oul doth magnifie the Lord: and it was a woman that poke it.

Iocrates had an excellent wit, notwithtanding finding himelf detitute of countenance, geture, and confidence, he never durt to peak in publique, contenting himelf to teach, even to his decrepit dayes, and commonly aying, He taught Rhetorick for a 1000 Rials, but would give more than 10000 to him who would teach him confidence.

It was the aying of Lewis the French King, to Henry the third of England, who asking him (in thoe times of implicit faith) whether he would goe ooner, to the Eucharit, or to a Sermon? He anwered, I had rather ee my friend, than hear him onely poken of.
One aid that Aritotles School was a great Scold.
It was not aid improperly of him, who having paed his grand Climacterique, That he was got looe from his unruly paions, as from o many lyons and wolves.

A French Baron, not long ince, meeting two Capuchins going bare-foot in cold froty weather, with their crips upon their backs a begging, and knowing them to be Gentlemen of a good Family, he aid, How grosly are thee men cozen'd if there be no heaven.

An Italian Prince being upon his death-bed, and comforted by his friends, touching the joys of the other world, whereunto he was going, he fetched a deep igh, and aid, Oh! I know what's pat, but I know not what's to come.
There is a aying fathered upon Paul 3d. when he lay upon his death-bed, that hortly he hould be reolved of two things, Whether there be a God and Devil, or whether there be a heaven and hell?

When a rare Italian Statuary offered Rh. 2d. of Spain, that without expence to the King, he would et up his Majeties arms and portraicture over the gates of every City in Lombardy, the King commending the mans good will, anwered, He had rather have a workman, that with
any expence whatoever, could et up his image in Heaven.
When the ouldiers demanded a donative of Galba, he anwered, That he ued to chooe, not to buy ouldiers.
Vepaian was not moved with the coffs of Demetrius Cynicus, but lighted them, aying, I ue not to kill barking dogs.
Domitian punihed Informers, aying, That not to punih uch, was to encourage them.
Trajan delivered his word to the Captain of the Guard, willing him to ue it for him, if he did well, but againt him, if otherwie.
Antonius Pius, Emperor, comming to ee Omulus his houe, he enquired whence he had his marble pillars? Omulus anwered, that in another mans houe he hould be both deaf and dumb.
When Julia, Mother-in-law to Caracalla (whom he married) told him he was too prodigal, he laid his hand on his word, aying, I hall never lack money, o long as this is with me.
Julian robbed the Church of her Revenues, telling the Clergy that they hould be the fitter for Heaven, becaue it is written, Bleed be the poor.

Tyberius Contantinus, Co-Emperor with Jutin, when Sophia the Empres reproved him, as being too prodigal in his bounty to the poor: He anwered, that he hould never want wealth on earth, as long as he had laid up treaures on earth, by relieving the poor.
Maximilian the Emperor, was wont to ay, to compel the concience, is to force heaven.

It was not ill anwered of Merope, to King Polyphontes, who therefore kill'd his brother, becaue he had entertained a purpoe to have killed him: You hould only have done the ame injury to him, which he did to you; you hould till have had a purpoe to kill him.
Aquinas was once asked, with what compendium a man might bet become learned? He anwered, By reading one Book.
A great Italian General, eeing the udden death of Alphonus Duke of Ferrara, kneeled down intantly, aying, And hall not this ight make me religious?

When the Duke of Candia had voluntarily entred into the incommodities of a Religious life, and poverty, he was one day pied, and pitied by a Lord of Italy, who, out of tendernes, wih'd him to be more careful, and nutritive of his peron. The good Duke anwered, Sir, be not troubled, and think not that I am ill provided of conveniencies; for I end a harbinger before, who makes my lodgings ready, and takes care that I be royally entertained: The Lord asked him, who was his harbinger? He anwered, the knowledge of my elf, and the conideration of what I deerve for my ins, which is eternal torments; and when with this knowledge I arrive at my lodging, how unprovided oever I find it, me thinks it is ever better than I deerve.

'Twas a reaonable anwer of Pericles to one that asked him, Why he being a evere and Philoophical peron, came to a Wedding trimmed and adorned like a Paranymph
I come adorned to an adorned peron, trim'd to a Bridegroom.
The Emperor Ferdinand the 2d. had wont to ay to thoe that brought him any ill newes, 'tis good, 'tis Gods pleaure, I am contented.

Sir Thomas Moore, omewhat before he was made Lord Chancellor, built a Chappel in his Parih at Cheley, where the Parih had all ornaments belonging thereunto abundantly upplied at his charge; and he betowed thereon much plate, often uing thee words, Good men give it, and bad men take it away.
The King of Sweden, to the Dutch Embaador, perwading him to a care of his peron, anwered, that his hour was written in heaven, and could not be altered on earth.

Sir Jervis Ellwis, when executed on Towerhill for Overburies death, left thee two Items to Poterity: 1. Not to vow any thing but to perform it. 2. Not to take a pride in any parts, though never o excellent.

A Lord Mayor of London (in K. James his time) topping the Kings carriages as they were going through the treets with a great noie in time of Divine Service, and the King being told of it, he, in a rage, wore he thought there had been no more Kings in England but himelf, & ent a warrant to the Lord Mayor to let them pas, which he then obeyed with this anwer, While it was in my power, I did my duty; but that being taken away by a higher power, it is my duty to obey.

p.U: aid of the Mileians, they were no fools, but they did the ame things that fools did.
aith of St. Cyprian, who had before the Council of Carthage defended re-baptizing, the Author of this errour (aith he) is, no doubt, in heaven, the followers and practiers of it now goe to hell.

div.p: A Gentleman having by fatherly indulgence tolerated the humour of gaming and wen • hing in his on, di-inherited him for drinking, aying of the firt, If he had wit, he would not loe much by it; and of the econd, that in time for his own cae he would leave it; but of the third, he aid, he would prove, the elder, the viler, and hardly ever amend it.

A certain man comming to Athens, meeting one of his friends in the treet, deired him to hew him the rarities of the City: His friend carried him to Solon; but the man having viewed him ome time, would have gone farther: no, aid his friend, You have een all. Viditi Solon, viditi omnia.
It is aid of the Germans, that they undertand more than they can utter, and drink more than they can carry.
A certain old man, being asked why he wore his beard o large and long? that beholding thoe grey hairs (aid he) I may doe nothing unbeeeming them.
Cyrus was wont to ay, that a good Prince was like a good Shepherd, who can by no other means grow rich, than by making his flock to thrive under him.

A maid (in Plutarch) being to be old in the Market, when a Chapman asked her, Wilt thou be faithful if I buy thee? Yes (aid he)
• tiami non emeris, whether you buy me or no.

p.U: aid to him that objected that his Speech melt of the candle; I know my candle tands in your light: The man being upected for a thief.

div.p: Melancthon was ued to ay, He that dealeth with ome men, had need to bring a Divine, a Lawyer, and a Souldier with him to get his right.

St. Bernard comming to the great Church of Spire in Germany, he was no ooner come into the Church, but the Image of the Virgin aluted him, and bad him, Good morrow Bernard: whereat, he well knowing the jugling of the Friers, made anwer again out of St. Paul, Oh (aid he) your Ladihip hath forgot your elf, it is not lawful for women to peak in the Church.
John King of England, being wihed by a Courtier to untomb the bones of one, who whilt he was living, had been his great enemy: Oh no (aid the King) would all mine enemies were as honourably buried.
The Egyptian Calyph, offering an Englih Embaador his hand in his glove, the Embaador anwered, Sir, we come not to treat with your glove, but your elf.
When a Pyrate aid to one of his fellows, Woe to us if we be known: an honet man in the ame hip replyed: And woe to me if I be not known.
Luther was wont to ay, He would be unwilling to be a ouldier in that army where Priets were Captains, becaue the Church, not the Camp, was their proper place.

Plato being demanded how he knew a wieman, anwered, When being rebuked he would not
be angry, and being praied, he would not be proud.

Marques Pawlet, there being divers factions at Court in his time, yet was he beloved of all parties; and being asked, how he tood o right in the judgment of all? He anwered, By being a willow, and not an oak.
Diogenes was wont to ay, when the people mock't him, They deride me, yet I am not derided: I am not the man they take me for.
Rather than want exercie of his patience, he would crave alms of dead mens Statues; and being demanded why he did o? He anwered, That I may learn to take denial from others the more patiently.
Marius was never offended with any report went of him, becaue he aid, If it were true, it would ound to his praie; if fale, his life and manners hould prove it contrary.
A Steward once replyed to his paionate Lord, when he called him knave, &c. Your Honour may peak as you pleae, but I believe not a word that you ay, for I know my elf an honet man.
Philip of Macedon profeed himelf much beholden to his enemies (the Athenians) for peaking evil of him; For (aid he) they made me an honet man, to prove them lyars.
When Diogenes was told by a bae fellow, that he once had been a Coiner of money, He anwered, 'Tis true, uch as thou art now, I once was, but uch as I am now, thou wilt never be.
Socrates, when one asked him why he took uch a ones bitter railing o patiently? Anwered, It is enough for one to be angry at a time.

Dion of Syracue, being banihed, came to Theodorus
Court uppliant, where not preently admitted, he turned to his companion, with thee words, I remember I did the like, when I was in like dignity.
Socrates, being perwaded to revenge himelf of a fellow that kick'd him, anwered, If an as had kick'd me, hould I have et my wit to his, and kick'd him again?
Another time, being told that one pake evil of him He replyed, Alas! the man hath not as yet learned to peak well, but I have learned to contemn what he peaks.
Diogenes, being told that many depied him, anwered, It is the wie mans portion to uffer of fools.

When Dionyius the Tyrant had plotted the death of his Mater Plato, and was defeated by Plato's ecape out of his Dominions; when the Tyrant deired him in writing not to peak evil of him, the Philoopher replyed, That he had not o much idle time as once to think of him, knowing there was a jut God would one day call him to a reckoning.
When once an hot-pur was perwaded to be patient as Job was, He replyed, What do ye tell me of Job? Job never had any uits in the Chancery.
Mr. Bradford was wont to ay, that in Christs caue to uffer death, was the way to heaven on horback.

Jugo, an ancient King, et all his Nobles, being Pagans, in his Hall below, and certain poor Chritians in his Preence-chamber with himelf; at which all wondring, he told them,
this he did, not as King of the Drones, but as King of another world, wherein thee were his fellow-Princes.

It was the aying of a merry fellow, That in Chritendom there were neither Scholars enough, Gentlemen enough, nor Jewes enough: becaue if there were Scholars enough, o many would not be double and treble beneficed; if Gentlemen enough, o many peaants would not be ranked among the Gentry; and if Jewes enough, o many Chritians would not profes uury.
Socrates was wont to ay to Alcibiades, when he met him among gallants like himelf, I fear not thee, but thy company.
Alexander, when a Commander of his in the Wars, pake loudly, but did little, told him, I entertained you into my ervice, not to rail, but to fight.
Illyricus, when one asked him why the old Tranlations (of the Bible) had no vowels? I think (aith he) that they had no cononants, for they could not agree among themelves.
Doctor Reynolds his Lecture in Oxford ceaing, by reaon of his icknes, ome deired him to read before he was well recovered The Doctor aid, He deired o to erve God, that he might erve him long.
