Eramus was wont to ay in his time, That to Preach, with many Miniters, was but Perfricare frontem, & linguam voluere.
Epiphanius, having tayd long at Contantinople, and being to take hip to return home again, aid, He was leaving three great things, a great City, a great Palace, and great Hypocriie.

Charls the Great, when he was hewed by a Duke a Royal Palace, and all the rings, and umptuous ornaments and jewels, aid, Has unt qui nos invitos faciunt mori. Thee are the things that make us unwilling to die.
Eramus was ued to ay, That the dunery and idlenes of the Monks of his time, made him a Student.
The Athenian Commander, being asked what God was, aid, He was neither bow-man, nor pike-man, nor hor-man, nor footman, but one that did know, itis omnibus imperare.
A noble Commander, in the Wars having taken great poils, aid to a ouldier behind him, Tolle itos, Ego Chritianus.
When Cajetan told Luther he hould be banihed, Luther anwered, Si non capiat terra, capiat coelum,
A great man comming to Aquinas, and offering him a Bihoprick, he leaning on his elbow in his Study, replyed, Mallem Chryotomum in Matthaeum.
The • ame Aquinas, when he was entreated to take a Cardinals place, anwered, Sepulchrum cogito, non gradum ublimiorem.
Luther and his Wife, with four children, were in a boat, and being in a great torm, were like to be cat away, Luther laughing aloud, aid, Oh how the Devil would rejoyce, if we were all drowned.

Plato, dicouring unto one of the contempt of death, and peaking trangely upon it, was anwered, That he pake more couragiouly than he lived: To whom Plato replyed, that
he pake not as he lived; but as he hould live.
Caear Borgia, being ick to death, aid, When I lived, I provided for every thing but death; now I mut die, I am unprovided to die.
Geron brings in an Englihman, asking a Frenchman, Quot annos habes? His anwer was, Annos non habeo, I am of no years at all, but death hath forborn me this 50 years.
A man (aid Luther) lives forty years before he knows himelf to be a fool; and by that time he ees his folly, his life is finihed.

p.U: aid of the Athenians, That they had good Laws, but ued ill.

div.p: Augutus lamented for Varus death; being asked why? He aid, Now I have none in my Country to tell me truth.

A certain King of Tartaria writ to the Polonians, then wanting a King, that if they would chooe him their King, he would accept of it upon thee terms, Veter Pontifex, meus Pontifex eto, veter Lutherus meus Lutherus eto. But the Polonians rejected him with this wie anwer, Ecce hominem paratum omni à acra, & deos deerere regnandi caua.

Marius, being accued by the Senate of treaon, tears open his garments, and in the ight of them all hews them his wounds received in the ervice and defence of his Country, aying, Quid opus et verbis, • bi vulner a clamant?
Sir William Stanly, railing againt his native Country, a Spanih Verdugo gave him this anwer, Though you have offended your Country your Country never offended you.

It is toried of a wicked City, which fearing
the invaion of a potent enemy, ought relief of a neighbouring Prince, charging their Embaadors to relate unto him what forces they were able to levy of their own: The Prince replying to the Meage, demanded of them what coverture they had to defend their heads from the wrath of heaven? telling them withal, That unles they could award Gods anger, he durt not joyn with them, God being againt them.

The Mother of Peter Lombard, when having trangreed her vow of Continency, he told her Confeor plainly, that when he aw what a Son he had brought forth, he could not repent that he had inned in having him: But her Confeor adly anwered her, Dole altem, quod dolere non pois.

p.U: aid to them that deired that ome honours might be pent upon his brother Geta, now dead out of his way; Sit divus (aith he) modo non it vivus.

div.p: Edward the Third of England, having ent to France, to demand the Crown by Maternal Right, the Council there ent him word, That the Crown of France was not tied to a ditaff: which coffing anwer he replyed, That then he would tie it to his word.

p.U: aid, He had rather have been the Author and Compoer of one Ode in Horace, than King of all Arragon.

div.p: Cato would ay, He wondred how one of their arupices could forbear to laugh, when he met with any of his fellows, to ee how they deceived men, and made a great number of imple ones in the City.

King Lewis the 11th. looking upon a Tapitry,
wherein a certain Nobleman (who from a mean Clerk of the Exchequer, was advanced to be Lord Treaurer of France) had pourtray'd the teps and degrees whereby he had acended, himelf repreented itting on the top of Fortunes wheel: Whereupon King Lewis told him, He might do well to faten it with a good trong nail, for fear let turning about, it brought him to his former etate again. Which proved a true Prophecie of him.

One who before he was Pope, was the mot crouching ubmis Cardinal that ever was: His manner was to eat upon a net, as it were in a way of devout humility; but after he had obtein'd the Popedom, he commanded them to take away the net, aying, He had caught that which he fih'd for.

When a French King, eeing the Perian pomp of the Popes Court, and pride of the Cardinals, asked a Cardinal of Avinion, Whether the Apotles ever went with uch a Train after them? He anwered, No verily: but you mut conider, Sir, that they were Apotles the ame time that Kings were hepherds.
It was the aying of Rabbi Gamaliel, He that multiplies ervants, multiplies thieves.

p.U: aid, when he furthered the Edition of the Alchoran, that he would have it printed, t videamus quale poema it: That the World might ee what a piece of poetry the Alchoran was.

div.p:
Artabazus, a Courtier, received from King Cyrus a cup of gold: At the ame time Chryantas, the beloved Favourite, received a kis
from him; which the other oberving, aid, The cup which you gave me, was not o good gold as the kis you gave Chryantes.
It was the Speech of an ancient Rabbi; I learned much of my Rabbies, or Maters, more of my companions, mot of my Scholars.

The Emperor Sigimond, demanding of The
• doricus, Arch-Bihop of Collen, the directet coure to happines: Perform (aith he) when thou art well, what thou promiedt when thou wert ick.

A certain King of the Lacedemonians being one day private in his garden, was teaching one of his children, of five years old, to ride on a tick; and unawares a great Embaador came to peak with him in that manner, at which, both the King, and the Embaador in the Kings behalf, began to bluh at firt; but oon after, the King putting away the bluh and the hobby-hore together, and with a pretty mile, asked the Embaador, if he had any children of his own? He anwered, No. Then (aid he) I pray you tell not what you found me doing, till you have ome little ones of your own, and then tell it, and pare not.

The Scouts of Antigonus, relating unto him the multitude of his enemies, and adviing by way of information the danger of a Conflict that hould be undertaken with o great an inequality, He replyed, And at how many do ye value me?

A Wet-Indian King, having been well wrought upon towards his converion to the Chritian Religion; and having digeted the
former Articles, when he came to that, He was crucified, dead, and buried, had no longer patience, but aid, If your God be dead and buried, leave me to my old god the Sun, for the Sun will not die.

p.U: aid, He that knoweth not what he ought to know, is a brute beat among men; he that knoweth no more than he hath need of, is a man among brute beats; he that knoweth all that is to be known, is a god among men.

div.p: The Lord Treaurer Burleigh was wont to ay, That he ued to overcome envy and ill will more by patience than pert • nacy.

The Embaadors of the Council of Contance, being ent to Pope Benedict the 11th. when he, laying his hand upon his heart, aid, Hic et arca Noae, they tartly and truly replyed, In Noahs ark were few men, but many beats.
When one eemed to pity an one-ey'd man, He told him he had lot one of his enemies, a very thief, that would have tolen away his heart.
The King of Navarre told Beza, He would launch no farther into the Sea, than he might be ure to return afe to the Haven.
A clown aid to the Bihop of Collen, praying in the Church like a Bihop, but as he was Duke, going guarded like a Tyrant, Whither thinket thou the Bihop hall go, when the Duke hall be damned?
King Edward the 3d. having the King of France prioner here in England, and feating him one time mot umptuouly, preed him to be merry. The French King anwered, How can we ing ongs in a trange Land?
Calvin anwered his friends with ome indignation, when they admonihed him, for his healths ake, to forbear tudying o hard. What? aid he, would you that my Mater, when he comes, hould find me idle?

Spiridion, a godly Bihop in Cyprus, having not what ele to et before a guet that came to him in Leut, et him a piece of pork to feed on; and when the tranger made a cruple of eating fleh in Lent, aying, I am a Chritian, and may not do it: Nay, therefore thou mayt do it, aid he, becaue to the pure all things are pure.
Dr. Preton on his death-bed, aid, He hould change his place, not his company.

A certain tranger comming on Embaage to Rome, and colouring his hair and pale cheeks with vermilion hue, a grave Senator epying the deceit, tood up, and aid, What incerity are we to expect at this mans hands, whoe lo • ks, and looks, and lips do lye.

Sir Horatio Vere, when in the Palatinate a Council of War was called, and debated whether they hould fight or not? Some Dutch Lords aid, That the enemy had many peeces of Ordnance in uch a place, and therefore it was dangerous to fight: That Nobleman replyed, My Lords, if you fear the mouth of the Cannon, you mut never come into the field.

Sir John Burroughs, receiving a mortal wound in the Iland of Rhees, and being advied not to fear death but to provide for another world. He anwered, I thank God I fear not death, and thee thirty years together, I never aroe in the morning, that ever I made account to live while night.

A learned Frier, at a Council, complaining of the abue of the Clergy, Preaching before the Emperor, wihed him to begin a reformation of the Clergy à minoribus: The Emperor thanked him for his Sermon, and aid, He had rather begin à majoribus, from the better ort of the Clergy.
Aritippus being told that Lais loved him not; No more (aith he) doth wine, nor fih, yet I cannot be without them.
The Lord Burleigh being at Cambridge with Queen Elizabeth, viewing the everal Schools, aid, Here I find one School wanting, and that is the School of Dicretion.
Henry the 4th. told the Prince his Son, Getting is a chance, but keeping is a wit.

A Philoopher, that hearing his creditor was dead, kept the money which he had borrowed without witnees, a night or two; but after ome trugling with his concience, he carried it to his Executor, aying, Mihi vivit, qui aliis mortuus et; though he be ded to others, he's till alive to me.

Severus the Emperor, having paed through many adventures, at lat died in our land, overladen with troubles: weighing with himelf what his life had been, he brake forth into thee peeches, I have been all that might be, and now am nothing the better.
Scipio viewing his army, aid, There was not one who would not throw himelf from the top of a tower, for love of him.

Hildebert, Bihop of Mentz, aid of the Roman Courtiers, Employ them not, and they hinder
you: Employ them in your caues, and they delay them; if you ollicite them, they corn you; if you enrich them, they forget you.

When Antonius had made away his brother Geta, after the firt year of their joynt Empire, he entreated Papinianus (a famous Lawyer) to plead his excues: Who anwered, It is eaier Paricidium facere, quam excuare; thou mayt (aid he) command my neck to the block, but not my tongue to the bar; I prize not my life, to the pleading of an evil caue.
Simonides, being asked what did oonet grow old among men? Made anwer, A benefit.

Apollonius Thianaeus, having travelled over all Aia, Africk, and Europe, aid, There were two things whereat he marvelled mot in all the world: the firt was, that he always aw the proud man command the humble, the quarrellous the quiet, the tyrant the jut, the cruel the pitiful, the coward the hardy, the ignorant the skilful, and the greatet thieves hang the innocent.

A Philoopher being asked, how he could endure o ill a Wife as he had? The anwer which he gave, was, I have hereby a School of Philoophy in my houe, and learning daily to uffer patiently, I am made the more milder with others.

p.U: eeing Diogenes tumbling among dead bones, he asked him what he ought? To whom the other anwered, That which I cannot find, the difference between the rich and the poor.

div.p: Demonax asked one a quetion, who anwered him in old obolete affected words. Prethee fellow, aid he, where are thy wits? I ask thee a quetion now, and thou anweret 400 years ago.

Albertus Duke of Saxony, was wont to ay, that he had three wonders in one City, viz. three Monateries: For the Fries of the firt had children, and yet no wives; the Friers of the econd had a great deal of corn, and yet no land; the Friers of the third abounded with moneys, and yet had no rents.

A Captain ent from Cear unto the Senators of Rome, to ue for the prolonging of his government abroad, undertanding (as he tood at the Council-chamber-door) that they would not condicend to his deire, clapping his hand upon the pummel of his word: Well, aid he, eeing you will not grant it him, this hall give it him.

When Anne Bolen, that vertuous Lady, had received a meage from Henry the 8th. that he mut intantly prepare her elf for death, anwered, That he gave him humble thanks for all his favours betowed upon her; as for making her of a mean woman a Marchiones, of a Marchiones a Queen, but epecially, eeing he could not on earth advance her to any greater dignity, that he would now end her to ret, and reign upon Gods high and holy throne.
When Tully was asked, which Oration of Demothenes he liked bet? He anwered, The longet.

p.U: aid of one, That he cat his houe o long out at the window, that at lat his houe cat him out of the door, having left nothing rich, except a noe.

div.p:
There are two aying fathered on two great
Counellors, Secretary Walingham, and Secretary Ce • il, one ued to ay at the Council-Table, My Lords, tay a little, and we hall make an end the ooner. The other would oft-times peak of himelf, It hall never be aid of me, that I will defer till to morrow, what I can do to day.
Adrian the Sixt aid, A Phyician is very neceary to a populous Country; for were it not for the Phyician, men would live o long, and grow o thick, that one could not live for the other.

It was a bold anwer Captain Talbot returned Henry the 8th. from Calais, who having received pecial command from the King to erect a new work at the Water-gate, and to ee the Town well fortified, ent him word, That he could neither fortifie, nor fiftifie without money.

An Italian Vineyard-man, after a long drougth, and an extream hot Summer, which had parch't up all his grapes, complained, For want of water, I am forced to drink water; if I had had water, I would drink wine.

Andrea Doria, being asked by Philip the 2d. which were his bet harbours? He anwered, June, July, and Carthagena; meaning, that any Port is good in thoe two moneths, but Carthagena was good any time of the year.

A Gallego in Spain, in the Civil Wars of Arragon, being in the Field, he was hot in the forehead, and being carried away to a Tent, the Surgeon earch'd his wound, and found it mortal; o he advied him to end for his Confeor, for he was no man for this world, in regard the brain was touched; the Souldiers wihed him to earch it again, which he did, and
told him, that he found he was hurt in the brain, and could not poibly ecape; whereupon the Gallego fell into a chafe, and aid, he lyed, for he had no brain at all: If J had had any brain, J would never have come to this war.
A Spaniard having got a fall by a tumble, and broke his noe, rie up, and in a didainful manner, aid, This 'tis to walk upon earth.
Alexander quintus, Pope of Rome, aid of himelf, That when he was a Bihop, he was rich; when he was a Cardinal, he was poor; and when he was a Pope, he was a beggar.
King Darius, by chance opening a great pomegranate, and being demanded, of what he would wih to have as many as there were grains in that pomegranate? anwered in one word, Of Zopirues.
It was the anwer of an undaunted captive, who lighting the inulting braves of him who took him: Thou holdet thy conquet great in overcoming me, but mine is far greater in overcoming my elf.
It was the aying of a judicious State-man, he that knoweth to peak well, knoweth alo where he mut hold his peace: Wiely concluding, think an hour before you peak, and a day before you promie.

It was an excellent peech of a famous Hitorian, who being demanded by one who had reduced his Empire to a meer Tyranny, why he remembred not him in his Writings? Becaue (aid he) I read nothing in you worth remembring. Why dot thou not then (reply'd he) record my vices? Let others (aid he) hould erre by your example, and o imitate you.
It was the aying of a famous Orator, I never knew any Poet (yet was I well acquainted with many) who did not think his own doings better than all others.
Zeno's ervant Bruon, being taken in theft, and alledging for himelf, that it was his detiny to teal. His Mater anwered, and thy detiny to be beaten.

Antigonus oberving a ickly ouldier to be very valiant, procured his Phyician to heal him who afterwards began to keep himelf out of danger, not venturing as formerly; which Antigonus noting, demanded the reaon: The ouldier anwered, O Antigonus, thou art the reaon; before I ventured nothing but a dieaed corps, and then I choe rather to die quickly, than to live ickly: I invited death to do me a courteie, now it is otherwie with me, for now I have omewhat to loe.

The Lydian Croeus, enthroned in his Chair of State, asked a wie Sage, if ever he beheld a more beautiful, or graceful Spectacle? Yes, aid he, dunghil-cocks, pheaants, and peacocks; for thoe are cloathed with native beauty, but yours is but borrowed glory.
Carfitides being asked his opinion what he thought of the Sea, and Sea-men? Anwered, That there was nothing more treacherous than the firt, and that the others were it's comrades.

It was a wie anwer, that is reported of the bet and lat Cardinal of this Iland, who, when a skilful Atrologer, upon the Calculation of his Nativity, had told him ome pecialties concerning his future etate, anwered, Such
perhaps I was born; but ince that time I have been born again, and my econd Nativity hath cros'd my firt.

Epaminondas, the Theban Ruler, when the people made merry with banquets and dances on a Solemn Feat-day, went up and down the City in his wort array, and adly (as it were) mourning: And being demanded why he did o? His anwer was, That therefore was he ad, becaue they hould with more ecurity be merry.

The grave Cato, when one asked counel of him in ober earnet, what harm he thought aboded him, becaue rats had gnawn his hoe? He merrily anwered, That it was a trange thing to ee that, but it had been much more trange if his hoe had devoured the rats.

Tully likewie, when one to enforce the verity of Divination, aid, that a Victory which • ell to the Thebans was fore-hewed by an extraordinary crowing of cocks: He replyed, that it was no miracle cocks hould crow; but if fihes had o done, that had been wonderful indeed.

Apollonius being very early at Vepaian's gate, and finding him tirring, from thence he conjectured that he was worthy to govern an Empire; and aid to his companion, this man urely will be Emperor, he is o early.

One being demanded what Caear whipered in his ear? Made anwer, That Caear told
him he would invent a very trange punihment for uch as pried into his words and actions.

Ferdinand the Emperor, making a Speech in a publique Aembly, by chance gave Prician a fillip or two, which a Bihop hearing, tarted up, and aid, Caear, You have forgotten your Grammar: To whom Caear, and you have forgotten your Ethicks, Bihop.
Aexander, being deired to ee Darius daughters, who were fair and young, made anwer, I will have a care not to be vanquihed by women, eeing I have vanquihed men.

Some entreated Cyrus to ee Panthea, which he refued to do; and being told that he was very fair, It is for that reaon (aid he) I may not ee her; for if I do viit her now that I have leiure, he will bind me another time, when I hall be full of affairs.

Pricus Helvidius was advied not to come unto the Senate: He anwered, It is in the Emperors power not to make me of the Senate, but while I am a Senator, he hall not let me from going to the palace. You hall be uffer'd to go, aid the other, o you peak not: Helvidius anwers, I will not peak a word, if they demand nothing of me; but if they ask me, I will anwer what I think fit. If you peak, aid the other, they will put you to death. He replies, And when did I brag that I was immortal? You hall do your duty, and I mine; it is in you to kill me, and in me to die without fear; it is in you to banih me, and in me to go to it cheerfully.

When Athanaius was banihed by the Emperor Julian, he aid unto his friends that came
to orrow with him in his digrace: Courage • my children, this is but a little cloud, which will vanih preently.

Fabius Maximus having poiled Tarentum, and made it deolate, with all kinds of cruelties; when his Secretary came to ask him, What hall we do with the enemies gods? He anwered, Let us leave the angry gods unto the Tarentines.

Scanderbeg had it in particular in all his encounters and military actions, always to begin his firt Stratagems of Victory with the death of the head, aying, That the head hould be firt cut off, and the ret of the body will fall alone; and that he knew no kind of living creature that could urvive, the head being taken off.

It was a witty peech of him that aid, That mens actions were like notes of muick, ometimes in paces, and ometimes in lines, ometimes above, and ometimes beneath, and never or eldom traight for any long continuance.

Rubrius Flavius, being condemned by Nero
• o loe his head; when as the Executioner aid unto him, that he hould tretch forth his neck boldly, he anwered, Thou halt not trike more boldly, than I will preent my head.

Croeus, King of Lydia, eeing Cyrus's ouldiers running up and down the Town of Sardis, he demanded whither they did run? They go to the poil of the Town, anwered Cyrus. They take nothing from me (replyed Croeus, all they carry away is thine, and not mine. Signifying, that the poils of ouldiers are the loes of the Conqueror, rather than the conquered.

One demanded of Sym • nides, why he was o
paring in the extremity of his age? For that, aid he, I had rather leave my goods after my death to my enemies, than in my life-time to have need of my friends.

When Antithenes the Philoopher was in extream pain, he cryed out, Who hall deliver me from thee mieries? Diogenes preenting a knife unto him, aid, This, if thou wilt, and that oon. I do not ay of my life (replyed the Philoopher) but of my pain.

One demanded of Cercidas the Megalapolitane, if he died willingly? Why not (aid he) for after my death I hall ee thoe great men, Pythagoras among the Philoophers, Hecateus among the Hitorians, Homer among the Poets, and Olympus among the Muicians.
A Babler demanding of Aritole, if his dicoure were not trange? No, anwered he, but yet a man having feet, hould not give himelf o long patience to hear thee.
The Embaadors of Lacedemon being come to the King Lygdomnus, he making difficulty to hear them, and feigning himelf ick, the Embaadors aid, We are not come to wretle with him, but to peak with him.

Lewis the 11th. of France, one day went into the kitchin, whereas he found a young lad turning the pit, he demanded his name, of whence he was, and what he did earn? This turn-pit, who knew him not, told his name, and that though he were in the Kings ervice, yet he got as much as the King: For the King (aid he) hath but his life, and o have I; God feeds the King, and the King feeds me.
The Emperor Maximilian anwered a Merchant, who beought him to make him a Gentleman: I can make thee much richer than thou art, but it is not in my power to make thee a Gentleman.

Pope Julius the 2d having had a long feud with the Emperor Frederick (againt whom he had fought 12 Battels) being one day gently admonihed by the Arch-Bihop of Otia, how St. Peter his Predeceor was commanded to put up his word. 'Tis true aid Julius, our Saviour gave the prime Apotle uch a comand, but 'twas after he had given the blow, and cut off Malchus ear.

p.U: aid, That Troy was lot by hores, and the Common-wealth of Athens by aes.

div.p: Alva • o de Luna, whom John King of Catile advanced, and loved above all men of his Realm, aid to them that admired his fortunes: Judge not of the building before it be finihed. He died by the hands of Jutice.

Lewis the 1 • th. King of France, being but a child when crowned, tired with being o long (eight hours) in the Church, and bearing the Crown on his head, with divers other heavy vets upon his body, was asked, what he would take to take the like pains again? He anwered For another Crown I would take double the pains.

Thoe of the Religion, petitioning Lewis 13. for a continuance of holding their cautionary Townes, as Hen. 3. and Hen. the great had done: He told them, What grace the firt did hew you, was out of fear; what my Father did, was out of love; but I would have you know that I neither fear you no • love you.

The Marhal de Saint Geran, comming to
Sir Edward Herbert (then Embaador from the King of England for the Rochellers) after a counter-buff with Luynes the Contable, and told him in a friendly manner, you have offended the Contable, and you are not in a place of ecurity here: Whereunto he anwered, That he held himelf to be in a place of ecurity whereoever he had his word by him.

The Duke of Suilli was a Favourite to Henry the 4th. whom he had reduced from a Roman, to be a Reformit, when he was King of Navar onely; and perwading him to become Roman again, the Duke bluntly anwered, Sir, you have given me one turn already, you have good luck if you give me any more.

Lewis the 13th. when but a youth, he went to the Coutry of Bearn, at his entrance to Pan, the Inhabitants bringing a Canopy to carry over his Head, He asked, whether there was ever a Church in the Town? And being anwered, No: He aid, he would receive no honour in that place, where God himelf had no houe to be honoured in.
William, Prince of Orange, to content thoe that reproved his too much humanity, aid, That man is well bought, who cots but a alutation.

A Preident of a Parliament in France, whoe friends came to ee him at his new houe, began exceedingly to commend it for the rarenes of the Workmanhip, and the goodnes of the tone, timber, marble, and uch like: You mitake (aid he) the tuff whereof it is made; the houe is onely built de tetes les fols, of foolsheads.

Bias, one of the even wie men of Greece, ailing in a hip where ome fellows were that had given themelves over to lewdnes, and yet in a torm were calling unto their gods for help, He aid unto them, Hold your peace, for fear left the gods hould know you be here.
Alexander Severus was wont to ay, That a Souldier is never afraid, but when he eeth himelf well apparelled, and his Belt furnihed with money.
Dionyius the Tyrant, aid, We hould deceive children with dice and cock-alls, and men with Oaths.

Alexander the Great, when one wondred, why he not onely not kill'd his enemies, but took them to be his friends: It eems (ays he) to thee profitable to kill an enemy, and I kill an enemy while I pare him, and make him my friend while I advance him.
The Philoopher Anacharis, aid of Solons Common-wealth, That in the Conultations and Deliberations of the Greeks, Wie-men propounded the matters, and fools decided them.
Darius was wont to ay of himelf, In a pinch and extremity of peril he was always wiet.
Favorinus told Adrian the Emperor, who had cenured him in his own profeion of Grammar, That he durt not be learneder than he, who commanded 30. Legions.
Thou art an Heretick, aid Woodrofe the Sheriff to Mr. Rogers the Proto-Martyr in Queen Maries dayes: That hall be known (quoth he) at the day of Judgment.

General Vere told the King of Denmark, that Kings cared not for ouldiers, until uch time as
their Crowns hung on one ide of their heads.

Tamberlain having overthrown Bajazet, asked him, Whether ever he had given God thanks for making him o great an Emperor; who confeing he never thought of it; Tamberlain replyed, that it was no wonder o ingrateful a man hould be made a pectacle of miery: For you (aith he) being blind of one eye, and I lame of one leg, was there any worth in us, why God hould et us over two uch great Empires?
Luther was wont to ay, that three things make a Preacher, reading, prayer, and temptation; reading a full man, prayer an holy man, temptation an experienced man.

One having made a long, tedious, and idle dicoue before Aritotle, concluded it thus, Sir, I doubt, I have been too tedious to you with my many words: In good ooth, aid Aritotle, you have not been tedious to me, for I gave no heed to any thing you aid.

Aigoland King of Arragon, comming to the French Court to be Baptized, and asking who thoe lazers and poor people were, that waited for alms from the Emperor Charlemain's table? When one anwered him, that they were the ervants of God: I will never erve that God aid he, that keeps his ervants no better.
One being ready to die, clapt a 20 s. peece into his mouth, and aid, Some wier than ome, if I mut leave all the ret, yet this I'll take with me.

Sabina, a Roman Martyr, crying out in her travail, and being asked by her Keeper, how he would endure the fire the next day? Oh
well enough, aid he; for now I uffer in child-birth for my in; but then Chrit hall uffer in me, and upport me.
Cardinal Columnus, when the Pope threatned to take away his Cardinals Hat, That then he would put on an Helmet to pull him out of his throne.

King James, after he had moderated as Dr. of the Chair at Oxford in all Faculties; when in the publique Library there, he beheld the little chaines wherewith the everal Books were fatned to their places: I could wih (aith he) (if ever it be my lot to be carried captive) to be hut up in this prion, to be bound with thee chains, and to pend my life with thee fellow-captives that tand here chained.

Aeop being et to ale with two other laves, a Chapman enquired of the firt, what he could do? He, to endear himelf, anwered, mountaines, and wonders, and what not? For he knew, and could do all things. The econd anwered even o for himelf, and more too. But when he came to Aeop, and demanded of him what he could do? Nothing, aid he, for thee two have fore-talled all, and have left nothing for me.
The Philoopher Byon, when a certain King for grief tore his hair: Doth this man (aid he) think that baldnes will awage his grief?
One being demanded what his tudies would tead him in his decrepit age? anwered, That he might the better, and with more eae leave the world.

The Embaadors of Samos, being come to King Cleomenes of Sparta, prepared with a long
prolix Oration, to tir him up to war againt the tyrant Polycrates, after he had litned a good while unto them, his Anwer was: Touching your Exordium, I have forgotten it, the middle I remember not, and for the concluion, I will do nothing in it.

Scipio being one day accued before the Roman people of an urgent and capital offence, in tead of excuing himelf, or flattering the Judges, turning to them, he aid, It will well beeem you to judge of his head, by whoe means you have authority to judge of all the world.
Atithenes was wont to ay to his diciples; Come on my Maters, let you and me go to hear Socrates, there hall I be fellow-diciple with you.

Julius Druius, to thoe Workmen which for 3000 crowns offered o to reform his houe, that his neighbours hould no more over-look into it: I will give you 6000 (aid he) and contrive it o, that on all ides every man may look into it.
The Stanhop aid merrily, That not he, but his tately houe was guilty of high treaon.

Eleazer, a Jew, being demanded when it would be time to repent & amend? Anwered, One day before death. And when the other replyed, that no man knew the day of his death: He aid, Begin then even to day, for fear of failing.
Apollidorus was wont to ay of Chryippus his Books, That if other mens entences were left out, the pages would be void.

p.U: aid, He had rather men hould ask why he had no Statues erected for him, than why he had.

div.p:
A certain Souldan, who died at the Siege of Zigetum, being perwaded by the Muphti not
to uffer o many Religions as were in his Dominions: He anwered, That a noegay of many flowers melled far more weet than one flower onely.
Pope Sixtus aid, That a Pope could never want money, while he held a pen in his hand.
One aid of Eramus his Enchyridion, That there was more devotion in the Book, than in the Writer.
A Frenchman being asked by one of his Neighbours, if the Sermon were done? No, aith he, it is aid, but it is not done, neither will be, I fear, in hate.
When one asked the Duke of Alva, whether he had not oberved the great Ecclipe of the Sun? No truly, aid he, I have o much buines on earth, that I have no time to look up to heaven.

A Phyician was wont to ay pleaantly to delicate Dames, when they complained they were they could not tell how, but yet they could not endure to take any Phyick: Your onely way is to be ick indeed, and then you will be glad to take any medicine.
Diogenes being asked what time is bet for meals? He anwered, For the rich man when he had a tomack, and for a poor man when he could get meat.

p.U: aid to the Orthodox and Arrian Bihops, contending about Faith: Of your learning I cannot o well judge, nor of your ubtle dioutations; but I can oberve which of you have the better behaviour.

div.p: An Arrian Bihop entreating the Emperor Contantine to give them a Church: He anwered, If your caue be good, one is too few; but if bad, one is too many.
The Philoopher Theodorus was wont to ay, That he gave his cholars intructions and leons with the right hand, but that they received them with the left.
Luther would often ay, That if he thought the reading of his Books would hinder the reading of the Scriptures, he would burn them all before he died.

When one accued a Comical Poet, that he brought a lewd debauched Ruffian on the Stage, and o gave bad example to young men. True, aid he, I brought uch a man on but I hanged him before he went off, and o I gave them a good example.

One being asked what exploits he had done in the Low-countries? Anwered, That he had cut off a Spaniards legs: Reply being made, that it had been omething if he had cut off his head: Oh, aid he, you mut conider his head was off before.

A gallant ometime aid to a reverend Prelate, If there be no judgment to come, are not you a very fool to bar your elf from the pleaures of this life? To whom the Prelate: And what if there be a judgment to come, are not you then a very fool, for the hort pleaures of this preent life, to bar your elf from thoe eternal joyes of your life to come?

Charls the 5th. Emperor was wont to ay, That the King of Spain ruled over aes, doing nothing without violence or blows; the King of France over men; and the Emperor over Kings. And when one of the tanders by aid, that the Polonians alo had their King: I grant, aid he, that he is
their King. Meaning, that his power was limited by them.

When Marhal Biron bid Sir Roger Williams bring up his Companies fater, taxing the low march of the Englih. Sir, aith he, with this march our Fore-fathers conquered your Countrey of France, and I mean not to alter it.

The ame Sir Roger Williams, to an idle Spaniard, boating of his Country-citrons, Oranges, Olives, and uch like: Why, aith he, we, in England, have good Surloyns of Beef, fat Muttons, and dainty Capons, to eat your awee withal.
One demanding of an Italian, why their Muttons and Cattel were o mall and lean? Becaue (quoth he) we Italians eat the gras in allets, and by robbing the patures, deceive the cattel.
A Portugal Captain once told King Sebatian, providing for his journey into Barbary, That wars hould be accompanied with three treams, the firt, of men; the econd, of victuals; the third, of ilver.
Another being demanded how many things were neceary hereunto, anwered, Money, money, money.

Sigimond, the firt King of Poland, moved by Leo the 10th. to war againt the Turk, anwered, Few words hall erve, firt, make firm peace among the Chritian Princes, then will I be not behind the forwardet.

When Ferdinando Cortez had conquered Mexico, the King of Mexico drawing his dagger, gave it to him, aying, Hitherto I have done the bet
for the defence of my people; now I am no farther bound, but to give thee this dagger to kill me with.

Hannibal having ent his Brother Mago to dicover the Romans Camp, and returning, he asked him, What newes, and what work they were like to have with the enemies? Work enough (anwered Mago) for they are an horrible many. As horrible a many as they are (replyed Hannibal) I tell thee brother, that among them all, earch them never o diligently, thou halt not finde one man whoe name is Mago.

Captain Gam, before the Battel of Agincourt, being ent to make the like Dicovery, told King Henry the 5th. That of the Frenchmen, there were enough to be kill'd, enough to be taken prioners, and enough to run away.

At a Solemn Convention of many Philoophers, before the Embaadors of a Forreign Prince, and that every one, according to his everal abilities, made demontration of their wiedom, that o the Embaador might have matter to report of the admired wiedom of the Grecians Amongt thoe, one there was that tood till, and uttered nothing in the Aembly, inomuch that the Embaador turning to him, aid. And what is your gift, that I may report it? To whom the Philoopher, Report unto your King, that you found one amongt the Grecians, that knew how to hold his peace.
A Barber going to the Court, and being at his return asked what he aw? He anwered, the King was neatly trimm'd.

Themitocles, being invited to touch a Lute,
aid arrogantly, He could not fiddle, but he knew how to make a mall town a great City.

Plutarch tells of two men that were hired at Athens for ome publick work, whereof the one was full of tongue, but low at hand, but the other, blunt in peech, yet an excellent Workman: Being called upon by the Magitrates to expres themelves, and to declare at large how they would proceed; when the firt had made a long harrange, and decribed it from point to point, the other econded him with this hort peech: Ye men of Athens, what this man hath aid in words, that will I make good true performance.

King Porus, when Alexander ask'd him how he would be ued? anwered in one word, < in non-Latin alphabet > , Like a King. Alexander replying, do you deire nothing ele? No, aid he, all things are in
< in non-Latin alphabet > .
Solon being demanded how a Commonwealth might bet be preerved in peace? Anwered, that the Common-wealth is in good etate, where the people obey the Magitrates, and the Magitrates obey the Law.
Pelican, a German Divine, aid, concerning his Learning, When I appear before God, I hall not appear as a Doctor, but as an ordinary Chritian.
When Plato aw one indulgent to his fleh in high diet, he asked him, What do ye mean to make your prion o trong?

p.U: aid, that Petitions hould not be given to Princes, as meat to an Elephant, that one is afraid of.

div.p: Vepaian asked Apollonius, what was Nero's overthrow? He anwered, Nero could touch and tune the harp well; but in Government, he ued ometimes to winde the p • ns too high, and ometimes to let them down too low.
A fat man in Rome, riding always upon a very lean hore, being asked the reaon thereof? Anwered. That he fed himelf, but truted others to feed his hore.
Philip of Macedon was wont to ay, That an as laden with gold would enter the gates of any City.

At the Treaty between the Englih, and the King of Spain, the Commiioners being met in a French Town, the firt quetion was, what Tongue they hould Treat in? One of the Spaniards, thinking to give our Englih a ore gird, aid, In French, and thee Gentlemen cannot be ignorant of the language of their fellow-ubjects: No, faith my Maters (aid Doctor Dale, Mater of the Requets) French is too common, epecially in a French Town, We'l treat in the Mother-tongue, Hebrew, the language of Hierualem, of which your Mater is King.
One being exiled his native Country, and one day asked why he looked o heavily? replyed, I bear the Embleme of this place in my front.

When Ennius ought his friend at his houe, and asked his ervant where his Mater was? Who hearing, aid to his ervant, Tell him I am not at home; which Ennius over-heard, but took the anwer from the ervant. The next day the ame man, comming to Ennius his
houe, and demanded of his ervant where his Mater was? Ennius pake aloud, Tell him I am not at home. What, aid he, will you deny your elf with your own tongue? Why, aid Ennius, I believed when but your man told me you were at home, and will you not believe me which ay o my elf?

Eramus being asked by Frederick Duke of Saxony, what he thought of Luther, o much earnetly eeking Reformation? Eramus anwered, Luther had committed two great errours: One was, that he touch'd too near the Crown of the Pope; another, too much the bellies of the Monks.

A certain bold-fac'd fellow, came one day to an Emperor, and deired his Majety to betow ome reward upon a poor kinman of his: I am your kinman, quoth he, both by father and mother, for we come all of Adam and Eve. Indeed, thou ayet true (quoth the Emperor) and gave him a penny. A penny (quoth the other) hall I have no more but a penny? A imple reward for an Emperor. Hold thy elf content, aid the Emperor, If I hould give to every one of my kinmen a penny, I hould oon become a poor Emperor.

Alphonus King of Arragon, anwered an Orator, who had cited a long Panegerycal Oration of his praies: If that thou hat aid, conenteth with truth, I thank God for it; if not, I pray God grant me grace, that I may do it.

A Painter being blamed by a Cardinal for colouring the vi • ages of Peter and Paul too red, tartly replyed, That he painted them o, as • luhing at the lives of thoe men who tyle themelves their ucceors.

When Alexander received any Letters from any of his Commanders in Greece, of ome mall Skirmih, or taking ome Fort (He being ued to great Victories) was wont to ay, They eemed to him but as the battels of frogs and mice in Homer.
Some aying it was a trange reolution in L. Scilla to reigne his Dictatorhip. Caear coffing at him, aid, That Silla could not skill of Letters, and therefore knew not how to Dictate.

Aritippus, having a Petition to Dionyius, and no ear given him, he fell down at his feet, in manner of a worhipper: Whereupon Dionyius tay'd, and gave him the hearing, and granted it. And being reproved, that he would offer that indignity to Philoophy, as for a private uit to fall at a Tyrants feet; He replyed, That it was not his fault, but it was the fault of Dionyius, who had his ears in his feet.

It is a notable peech reported of one Nemon, that was General of Darius his Army, when he was fighting againt Alexander, one of his Souldiers reproached Alexander: The General came to him, and mote him, aying, I did not hire you to reproach Alexander, but to fight againt him.
A great man, who himelf was very plain in apparel, checkt a Gentleman for being overfine: Who modetly anwered, Your Lordhip hath better cloaths at home, and I have wore.
Themitocles, when an Embaador in a et Speech boated great matters of a mall Village, took him up thus: Friend, your words require a City.
It was the aying of a noble Venetian Duke That it is ufficient for a dicreet Prince to have power to revenge, that his enemies may have caue to fear him.

An Embaador of Athens, anwered King Philip of Macedon, threatning that he would caue his head to be cut off: If thou take this head from me, my Country will give me another that hall be immortal. Statuam pro capite, pro morte immortalitatem.

p.U: eeing a certain man dreing and decking himelf for a fetival day, aid unto him thus: Why dot thou take uch pains to trim thy elf to day, eeing that every day is a fetival day to a virtuous man?

div.p: There was a certain rich wretch who had in his houe great tore of wine, but was o niggardly, that he old the bet, and kept the wort for his own ue. A ervant of his, oberving the pinching and prepoterous niggardlines o • his Mater, fled away from him; and being asked afterwards why he had left his Lord? anwered thus: Becaue I could not endure to tay with a man, who having that which was good, made choie of that which was evil.

The Philoopher Aritippus, having lot one of his three Farms, aid thus unto his freinds; That it was babihnes to be orry for one Farm lo • , and not to be merry for the other two that did ret in his hands, eeing that all of them had lien open to the ame adventure.
Secundus the Philoopher being demanded, What is a wife? Replyed, She is contrary to an husband.
Richard Nevil, Earl of Warwick, when the people would have made him King, refued it, aying, That he had rather make Kings, than be one.
Pompey, when his ouldiers, would needs leave the Camp, threw himelf down at a narrow paage, and bid them go, But they hould firt trample on their General.

p.U: aid to one that had perfumed his lo • ks: Be careful your odoriferous head procure you not a tinking life.

div.p: Themitocles to Symmachus, to whom, being deirous to teach him the art of memory; He anwered, He had rather learn the art of forgetfulnes.

p.U: eeing at once two fatal preages of his end, a blazing Comet, and a gaping Sepulcher, turned them both from himelf, with this pleaant coff; aying, The Sepulcher gaped for the old Empres Julia; and the blazing Star portended the death of the King of Peria, who at that time wore long hair.

div.p: When Mr. Sam. Hieron lay on his death-bed (rich onely in goodnes and children) his wife made much womanih lamentation, what hould become of her little ones. Peace Sweetheart (aid he) that God who feedeth the Ravens, will not tarve the Herns.

Mr. Fox (the Author of the Martyrology) being once asked at a friends table, what dih he deired to be et up to him to begin his meal with? He anwered, The lat. Which word was pleaantly taken, as if he had meant
a choier dih, uch as uually are brought at the econd Coure; whereas he rather ignified the deire he had to ee dinner ended, that he might depart home.

Going abroad (by chance) he met a woman that he knew, who pulling a book from under her arm, and aying, See you not that I am going to a Sermon? Mr. Fox replyed, But if you will be ruled by me, go home rather; for to day you will do little good at Church. And when he asked, at what time therefore he would counel her to go? Then (anwered he) when you tell no body before-hand.

When a young man, a little too forward, had, in preence of many, aid, that he could not conceive any reaon in the reading of old Authors, why men hould o greatly admire them. No manuel, indeed, (quoth Mr. Fox) for if you could conceive the reaon, you would then admire them your elf.
One told a Grecian Statit, who had excellently deerved of the City he lived in, that the City had choen 24 Officers, and yet left him out. I am glad, aith he, the City affords 24 abler • han my elf.

When one of Antipaters friends (who was an imperious and tyrannous Governor) commended him to Alexander for his moderation, that he did not degenerate into the Perian pride in the ue of Purple, but kept the ancient habit of Macedon, of black. True, (aith Alexander) but Antipater is all purple within.

Alexander, when he gave large gifts to his
friends and ervants, and one asked him what he did reerve for himelf? He anwered, Hope.
One asked a grave Gentlewoman how her maids came by o good husbands, and yet eldome went abroad? Oh (aid he) good hubands come home to them.
One having a hrewd wife, yet loth to ue her hardly, awed her by telling her, That he would beat her when he was dead. Meaning, that he would leave her no maintenance.
One complaining that never had father o undutiful a child as he had. Yes, aid his on, (with les grace than truth) my Grand-father had.

A Farmer rented a grange, generally reported to be haunted with Fairies, and paid a hrewd rent for the ame at each half-years end. Now a Gentleman asked him how he durt be o hardy as to live in the houe? and whether no Spirits did trouble him? Truth (aid the farmer) there be two Saints in heaven, vex me more than all the Devils in hell; namely, the Virgin Mary, and Michael the Arch-angel; on which days he paid his rent.

When a Profeor preed an Anwerer (a better Chritian than a Clerk) with an hard argument: Reverende Profeor, aid he, ingenuè confiteor, me non poe repondere huic argumente. To whom the Profeor, Rectè repondes.
When one told Latimer that the Cutler had cozend him, in making him pay two pence for a knife not (in thoe dayes) worth a penny: No, quoth Latimer, he cozened not me, but his own Concience.
When Buchanan lay on his death-bed, King James ent to know how he did? He returned this anwer, That he was going whither few Kings came.
Q. Metellus Pius, to one wondring at what he intended to do, and demanding of him what he meant? Let alone, aith he, farther to enquire; for if my hirt knew what I meant to doe, I would burn it.

Pericles being requeted by his ouldiers to fight, and that with vile reproachful terms, replyed thus: That if he could repair loes, and recover life, he would as gladly adventure as they. But you ee (aid he) trees being cut, they grow again; but men once lain, revive no more.

Henry the 4th. King of France, eeing the Chappel which the family of Baom Pierre had builded, and reading this vere of the Palm, which was et down for an Embleme: Quid retribuam Domino, pro omnibus quae retribuit mihi? He aid, Baom Pierre as a German hould have added, Calicem accipiam.

To one, telling him that there is nothing doth ooner make thoe who are out of their wits to become temperate, than the punihment which is inflicted upon them, the King interrupted his peech, and told him, Mercy pardoneth thoe who have not deerved it; and the juter that wrath is, the more commendable is mercy.

When men pake of the inolencies and ryots of the City, during the troubles, &c. He aid, The people of Paris are good, it goeth as it is led; michief commeth from thoe which go before, and not from their implicity which follow after, and grow bad by infection.

Conidering on a time that Taxes were exceive in undry places of the Kingdome: He aid, My people are made to pay a double tax, one to me, and another to my Officers. The econd makes the firt inupportable; for the expence of the Officers amount to more than the tax: It is a hard matter to keep my elf unrob'd, and almot impoible but that my people hould be o.
He was wont to ay, That he would not ee them uffer harm, which were not in cae to doe any.

Some one beought him to give him leave to carry the Cannon againt ome that held his houe: The King demanded of him what he would do when he had forced them? His choller made him anwer, That he would hang them all: Whereupon the King ent him away with this mild reply, I have no Cannon to that ue.
A maker of Anagrams, preenting omething unto him upon his name, and telling him that he was very poor: I believe it, aid the King, for they that ue this trade, cannot grow very rich.
He was wont to ay, That it was an offence to God, to give credit to thoe Prognoticks: and that, having God for his guard, He feared no man.

The ame Henry, being at the Siege of Amiens, amongt others of the Nobles which he ummoned for that ervice, he ent alo to the Count Soions, a Prince of the Blood
to whom the King gives 5000 crowns penion. The Count, at that time dicontented, returned the King anwer, That he was a poor Gentleman, and wanted meanes to come to that ervice, as became one of his birth and place, being a Prince of the Blood, and Peer of France: He therefore mot humbly craved pardon, and •• at he would mot humbly pray for his Majeties properous uccee, which was all he could do. Well (aith the King) eeing prayer is not acceptable without fating, my Couin hall hereafter fat from his penion of 5000 crowns.

He ued much this noble Speceh, when I was born, there were a thouand other ouls more born; what have I done unto God, to be more than they? It is his meer grace and mercy which doth often bind me more unto his jutice; for the faults of great men are never mall.

When certain Romans practied by ecret counel to kill the Emperor Domitian, and gave part thereof to Trajane: He did anwer; I do well ee that Domitian deerved not to be elected Emperor, and much les to be uteined in the ame; yet never the more hall I conent unto his death, for that I will rather endure a tyrant, than procure the renown of a traytor.
The Emperor Adrian aid, That he remembred not ince the age of ten yeares, whether he tood till, or walked by the way, that he had not either a book to read in, or ome weapon to fight with.
Being demanded why he was o bountiful unto his Miniters of Jutice? He anwered, I make the Miniters of Jutice rich, becaue by robbery of Jutice they hall no • make other men poor.

When Favorinus, having an old houe, at the entry thereof he had raied a tately porch, painted with whi • e: The Emperor aid unto him, This houe of thine eemeth a gilded pill, which outwardly giveth pleaure, but within is full of bitternes.

Another friend of Adrians, named Silvius, very black of face, and of evil hape of body, comming one day unto the Palace, all clad in white, Adrian aid unto thoe that were preent, That black face, with that white garment, eemeth no other, but a flie drowned in a poonfull of milk.

There was in Rome a certain man named Enatius, omewhat entred in age, and of natural condition mutinous, ambitious, importune, intermedling, quarrellous, and full of garboyl. The Emperor Adrian being advertied that Enatius was dead, He fell into a great laughter, and ware, That he could not a little marvel how he could intend to die, conidering his great buines both night and day.

There was a Senator named Fabius Cat • , a man of a mall tature, which would oon be offended, and as oon be pleaed; unto whom Adrian aid, Since your chimney is o mall, you mut beware to lay much wood upon the fire, for otherwie it will be always mokie.

When a certain cunning man made offer to the
Emperour Antonius Pius, to place him teeth wherewith to eat or peak; Antonius made anwer: Since never from my heart proceeded feigned or double words, there hall never enter into my mouth feigned teeth.

Antonius alwayes, for the mot part, went bare-headed; and one adviing him the air of Rome to be very hurtful, and therefore neceary to have his head covered, anwered, aure me from troubles of men on earth, and I am aured that nothing hall trouble me which the gods hall end me from heaven.

He ent Fulvius Tuculanus as Praetor into the Province of Mauritania, whom within half a year he deprived of his Office, for that he was both impatient and covetous; who complaining of the injury, aid, that in times pat he had been a friend unto Antonius, but now it was forgotten: Whereunto Antonius anwered, Thou hat no reaon thus unjutly to blame me, becaue the office was given thee by the Emperor, and not by Antonius; and ince, thou didt not offend as Fulvius, but as Praetor; o I dicharge thee of thy Office, not as Antonius thy old friend, but as Emperor of the Roman Empire.

Some peaking in his preence of Wars and Battels, that Julius Caear, Scipio & Hannibal had fought and overcame in the field: Antonius Pius anwered, Let every man hold opinion what he thinketh good, and praie what it pleaeth him; but for my own part, I do more glory in conerving peace many yeares, than with wars to conquer many battels.

Before he gave any government unto Praetors,
Cenors, or Quetors, he caued them to give an Inventory of their own proper goods, that when their charges were finihed, the increae of their wealth might be conidered: Saying unto them, That he ent them to adminiter Jutice, and not by fraud to rob Countries.
The Emperour Pertinax ued to ay, That, of Princes charging their Kingdomes with unjut tribute, there ucceedeth a wilful denial of due and mot jut payments.

He had a Son whom the Romans would have Created Augutus; which he would never like of, or conent unto; aying, The gods never grant that, with the hopes of the Empire, my on hould be nourihed unto vice and idlenes.
The Emperor Baianus would often ay, I know not what man, having bread to eat, or garments to wear, and cover himelf on land, would (to become an Emperor) go to Sea.
The Emperor Alexander Severus was wont to ay, Princes are not to be known by their vaals by their rich robes, but by their good works performed in their Common-wealths.
Lewis the 12th. King of France, when he heard that the Pope had extreamly cured him; He aid, That this was a Pope made to cure, but not to pray.

He had in King Charls his time been evilly ued by divers, of whom he was advied to take revenge at his comming to the Crown: Whereunto he anwered, That it became not a King of France to revenge the injuries done to a Duke of Orleans.

Looking upon the Roll of King Charls his ervants, he found two that had been his dead enemies, upon each of whoe names he made a cros; wherewith they being in great perplexity, uppoed the gallows to be prepared for them: Which their fear being dicovered to the King. He ent them word To be of good cheer, for he had croed all their evil deeds out of his remembrance.
When a certain Courtier complained grievouly of his wives unchatnes, The King bad him be of good cheer, for he that repected his wives incontinencie, or the Popes cure, hould never leep quiet night.

Charls of Bourbon had often in his mouth the Apothegme of a Gacoigne Gentleman, who being demanded by Charls the 7th. what reward might win him to break his faith with him, whereof he had made trial in o many important affairs? I could not be drawn thereunto (anwered he) though I might have your Kingdom given me, or the Empire of the Earth, and all the treaures of the world; but I might be moved to doe it by an outrage that might be offered me, and for ome injury that might touch mine Honour.

Plancus being told that Ainius Pollio had written certain Invective Orations againt him, which hould not be publihed till after Plancus his death, to the end they might not be anwered by him. There is none (aith he) but Ghots and Goblius that fight with the dead.

Peter Earl of Savoy, who to do his Liegehomage
to the Emperor Otho the 4th. came before him in a two-fold attire; for he had on the one half of his body, on the right ide, from the top downward, et out with cloth of gold: and the other half on the left ide, covered with hining armour. The Emperor asking him what uch a divers furniture meant? Sir, anwered he, the attire of the right ide is to honour your Imperial Majety; this of the left, heweth me ready to fight until the lat gap, againt thoe that wih you ill, and peak ill of you.

Pope John the third, being asked what thing was farthet from the truth? The opinion of the common people (anwered he) for all that they praie deerve blame; all that they think is nothing but vanity, all that they ay is nothing but lying; they condemn the good, they approve the evil, they magnifie nothing but infamy.
Lewis the 11th. ued this Apothegme, Where pride and preumption goe before hame and los follow after.

Dionyius having taken the City Reggio, and in it the Captain Phyton, he told him, how the day before he had caued his on and his kinfolks to be drowned: To whom Phyton anwered nothing, But that they were more happy than himelf by the pace of one day.
Thales being asked how a man might be cheerful, and bear up in afflictions: Anwered, If he can ee his enemies in wore cae than himelf.

A ouldier being demanded by Nero, why he hated him: Anwered him thus: I loved thee whilt thou nere worthy of love; but ince
thou becamet a paracide, a jugler, a player, and a coach-man, I hate thee as thou deervet.
Another being asked why he ought to kill him? anwered, Becaue I find no other coure to hinder thy unceant outrages, and impious deeds.

Francis Duke of Britanny, Son to John the 5th, when he was poken unto for a marriage between him and Iabel a Daughter of Scotland, and ome told him he was but meanly brought up, and without any intruction of learning, anwered, He loved her the better for it; and that a woman was wie enough, if he could but make difference between the hirt and doublet of her husband.

Demothenes companions in their Embaage to Philip, praied their Prince to be fair, eloquent, and a good quaffer: Demothenes aid, They were commendations rather fitting a woman, an advocate, and a punge, than a King.
Theodorus anwered Lyimachus, who threatned to kill him: Thou halt do a great exploit to come to the trength of a cantharides.
Aritotle being upbraided by ome of his friends, that he had been over-merciful to a wicked man: I have indeed (quoth he) been merciful towards the man, but not towards his wickednes.

When an Epigramatit read his Epigrams in an Auditory, one of the hearers topt him, and aid, Did not I hear an Epigram to this purpoe from you lat year? Yes, ays he, it's like you did: But is not that vice till in you this year, which lat years Epigram reprehended?

Some came and told Philopoemen, the enemies
are with us: To whom he anwered, and why ay you not that we are with them?

When Sicily did cure Dionyius, by reaon of his cruelty, there was onely one old woman that pray'd God to lengthen his life: Whereat Dionyius wondering asked her for what good turn he hould do that? She Anwered, That it was not love, but fear; for (aid he) I knew your Grandfather a great tyrant, and the people deired his death; then ucceeded your Father, more cruel than he, and now your elf wore far than them both; o that I think if you die, the Devil mut come next.

Pompey being in Sicily, preing the Mammertines to acknowledge his authority, they ought to avoid it, pretending that they had Priviledges and ancient Decrees of the people of Rome. To whom Pompey anwered in choler, Will you plead Law unto us, who have our words by our ides?

When Lewis the 11th. demanded of Brezay Senecall of Normandy, the reaon why he aid that his hore was great and trong, being but little, and of a weak tature: For that, anwered Brezay, he carries you and all your counel.
He aid, That if he had entred his Reign otherwie than with fear and everity, he had erv'd for an example in the lat Chapter of Boccace his book of unfortunate Noblemen.
Conidering that Secrecy was the Soul and Spirit of all Deignes: He aid ometimes, I would burn my Hat, if it knew what was in my Head.

He remembring to have heard King Charls
his Father ay, that Truth was ick: He added, I believe that ince he is dead, and hath not found any Confeor.
Mocking at one that had many Books, and little learning: He aid, That he was like unto a crook-back't man, who carries a great bunch at his back and never ees it.
Seeing a Gentleman which carried a goodly chain of gold, He aid unto him that did accompany him; You mut not touch it, for it is Holy: Shewing that it came from the poil of Churches.

On a time eeing the Bihop of Chartre mounted on a Mule, with a golden bridle, He aid unto him, that in times pat Bihops were contented with an As, and a plain halter: The Bihop anwered him, That it was at uch times as Kings were hepherds, and did keep hee • .

Abdolominus, a poor man, rich in plenty except plenty of riches; to whom Alexander of Macedon proffering the Kingdom of Sydon, who before was but a gardiner, was by him refued, aying, That he would take no care to loe that which he cared not to enjoy.
When one told a Reverend Bihop of a young man that Preached twice every Lords day, beides ome Exerciing in the week-days: It may be (aid he) he doth talk o often, but I doubt he doth not Preach.

To the like effect Queen Elizabeth aid to the ame Bihop, when She had on the Friday heard one of thoe talking Preachers, much commended by ome-body; and the Sunday after heard a well labour'd Sermon, that mel •
of the candle: I pray (aid he) let me have your boome-Sermons, rather than your lip-Sermons; for when the Preacher takes paines, the auditory takes profit.

When Dr. Day was Dean of Windor, there was a Singing-man in the Quire, one Wolner, a pleaant fellow, famous for his eating, rather than his inging: Mr. Dean ent a man to him to reprove him, for not inging with his fellows; the meenger (that thought all worhipful that wore white Surplices) told him Mr. Dean would pray his worhip to ing: Thank Mr. Dean (quoth Wolner) and tell him, I am as merry as they that ing.

A Husbandman dwelling near a Judge that was a great builder, and comming one day among divers of other neighbours, ome of tone, ome of tinn, the Steward, as the manner of the Country was, provided two tables for their dinners; for thoe that came upon requet, powder'd beef, and perhaps venion; for thoe that came for hire, poor-John and apple-pyes: And having invited them in his Lordhips name to it down, telling them one board was for them that came in love, the other was for thoe that came for money; this husbandman and his hind ate down at neither, the which the Steward imputing to implicity, repeated his former words again, praying them to it down accordingly: But he anwered, He aw no table for him, for he came neither for love nor money, but for very fear.

Scipio being made General of the Roman Army, was to name his Quaetor, or Treaurer
for the Wars, whom he thought fit, being a place in thoe dayes (as is now) of great importance. One that took himelf to have a pecial interet in Scipio's favour, was an earnet uitor for it; but by the delay, mitruting he hould have a denial, he importuned him one day for an anwer. Think not unkindnes in me, (aid Scipio) that I delay you thus; for I have been as earnet with a friend of mine to take it, and yet cannot prevail with him.

A pleaant Courtier and Servitor of King Henry the 8ths. to whom the King had promied ome good turn, came, and pray'd the King to betow a living on him, that he had found our, worth 100 l. by the year, more than enough: Why, aid the King, we have no uch in England. Yes Sir (aid he) the Provothip of Eaton; for, aid he, he is allowed his diet, his lodging, his hor-meat, his ervants wages, his ridingcharge, and 100 l. per annum beides.

Ellmar Bihop of London dealing with one Maddox, about ome matters concerning Puritanime, and he had anwered the Bihop omewhat untowardly and thwartly, the Bihop aid to him, Thy very name expreeth thy nature; for Maddox is thy name, and thou art as mad a beat as ever I talked with. The other not long to eek of an anwer: By your favour, Sir, aid he, your deeds anwer your name righter than mine; for your name is Elmar, and you have marred all the Elms in Fulham, by lopping them.

In the dayes of Edward the 6th. the Lord Protector march't with a powerful Army into Scotland to demand their young Queen Mary
in marriage to our King, according to their promies. The Scots refuing to do it, were beaten by the Englih in Muleborough-fight. One demanding of a Scotch Lord, taken prioner, Now Sir, how do you like our Kings mariage with your Queen? I alwayes (quoth he) did like the marriage, but I do not like the wooing, that you hould fetch a Bride with fire and word.
Theocritus, to an ill Poet, repeating many of his veres, and asking which he liked bet? Anwered, Thoe which he had omitted.

Catruccio of Luca, aying to one that profet himelf a Philoopher, You are of the condition of dogs, that alwayes goe about thoe who can bet give them meat. No (ayes the party) we are like Phyicians, who viit their houes that have mot need of them.

Catruccio going from Pia to Ligorn by water, and a dangerous torm there ariing, and thereupon being much perplex'd, was reprehended by one of his followers as puillanimous, aying himelf was not afraid of any thing: To whom Catruccio reply'd, That he nothing marvel'd thereat; for every one valu'd his life according to it's worth.
Being asked by one, what he hould doe to gain a good eteem? He anwered him: See when thou goet to a Feat, that a block it not upon a block.
When one boated that he had read many things: Said Catruccio, It were better thou couldt brag thou hat remembred much.

Another bragging, Though he had tippled
much, he was not drunk: Reply'd, An Oxe doe the ame.

Catruccio kept a young Las, which he lay with ordinarily; and thereupon being reprov'd by a friend, telling him that it was a great wrong to him, that he had uffer'd himelf to be o taken by a wench: Thou art mitaken, aid he, I took her, not he me.

Being one night in a houe of one of his Gentlemen, where there were divers Ladies invited to a Feat; and he dancing and porting with them, more than befitted his condition, was reproved by a friend: Anwered, He that is held a wie man in the day-time, will never be thought a fool in the night.
When one ask'd him a favour with many and uperfluous words; Catruccio aid to him, Hereafter, when thou wouldt any thing with me, end another.

Having caus'd a Citizen of Luca to die, who had help'd him in his riing to his greatnee; when it was aid to him, he had ill done to put to death one of his old friends: He reply'd, You are deceiv'd, I have put to death a new enemy.
He aid, He wondred much at men, that when they bought any veel of earth or glas, they ound it firt whether it be good; but in taking a wife, they are content onely to ee her.
Seeing that one had written upon his houe in latine, God keep the wicked hence; Said, The Mater then mut not enter here.

Treating with an Embaador of the King
of Naples, touching ome goods of the Borderers, whereat he was omewhat angry, when then the Embaador aid, Fear you not the King then? Catruccio aid, Is this your King good or bad? And he anwering, That he was good, Catruccio replyed, Wherefore then hould I be afraid of thoe that are good?

The Lord Tinteville aid to a great Peronage of France, that none could write the life of his deceaed Mater (Lewis the 11th.) o well as he. To whom he anwered wiely: I am too much bound to him to peak the truth.

King James, being invited in a hunting journey, to dine with Sir Tho. J. of Barkhire; turning hort at the corner of a Common, hapned near to a Country man, itting by the heels in the tocks, who cryed Hoanna unto his Majety, which invited him to ask the reaon of his retraint? Sir Tho. aid, It was for tealing a gooe from the Common. The fellow reply'd, I beeech your Majety be Judge who is the greater thief, I for tealing geee from the Common, or his Worhip for robbing the Common from the geee? By my ale, Sir (aid the King to Sir
• ho.) Ie not dine to day on your dihes, till you retore the Common for the poor to feed their flocks. Which was forthwith granted to them, and the witty fellow et free.

Prince Henry was never heard to wear an oath: And it was remembred at his Funeral-Sermon by the Arch-Bihop; That he being commended by one, for not replying with paion in play, or wearing to the truth: He hould anwer, That he knew no game or value
to be won or lot, could be worth an Oath.

There was a Duel between two eminent Perons of the Turks, and one lain: The Council of Bahaws reprehended the other thus: How durt you undertake to fight one with the other? Are there not Chritians enough to kill? Did you not know, that whether of you were lain, the los would be the Great Seigniors.

King James having made a large and learned Speech to the Parliament, the Lord Keeper, as Speaker to the Peers, whoe place there uually adds to the Kings mind and meaning, thus excues himelf: After the Kings Eloquence to be ilent; not to enamel a gold ring with tuds of iron. As one ayes of Nerva, That having adopted Trajane, he was immediately taken away: Ne pot divinum & immortale factum, aliquid mortale aceret; So he durt not after his Majeties divinum & immortale dictum, mortale aliquid addere.

Alphonus King of Arragon, eeing a young Lady dance with a Gentleman who made love to her, aid to him, Comfort your elf, this Sybil will quickly render the Oracle you ask: Becaue the Sybils gave no anwers but in motion.

The Monk, who ambitious of martyrdom, told the Souldan, That he was was come into his Court, to die for Preaching of the Truth; was anwered, He needed not to have rambled o far for death, for he might eaily find it among his Princes at home.
Antigonus being asked by his own on, what time he would remove his Camp? He aid, The ound of the trumpet hould give them notice.
The Conpirator had learn'd the leon of ilence well; who being asked his knowledge, anwered, If I had known it, you had never known it.

Pyrrhus King of the E • irotes, having in two et Battels, with great los of men, put the Romans to the wort, and hearing by a Favourite of his, this his o great good fortune moothingly congratulated: He aid unto him, That two Victories indeed he had gotten of them, but them o dear, that hould he at the ame rate buy a third, the purchae would no les than undo him.
A ouldier of Augutus, when his enemies throat was in his power, hearing the Retreat ounded, gave over his violence, with thee words; Malo obedire Duci, quàm occidere hotem.

The Janizaries are very true to a man that truts himelf with them, and patient in bearing abues. One of them being trucken by an Englihman, as they travelled through Morea, did not onely not revenge it, nor abandon him to the pillage and outrage of others, but conducted him unto Zant in afety: Saying, God forbid, that the villany of another hould make him betray the charge that was committed to his trut.

A great Courtier of the great Moguls, noted to be a great neglecter of God, a ouldier of approved valour; but being in dalliance with one of his women, he pluckt an hair from his bret, which grew about his nipple, which preently began to feter, and in hort time after became a canker incurable: Seeing he mut die, he uttered thee words: Who would have thought but
that I, who have been o long bred a Souldier, hould have died in the face of my enemy, by ome intrument of war, &c? But now (though too late) I am forced to confes, that there is a great God above, whoe Majety I have ever depied, that needs no bigger lance than an hair to kill an Atheit, or a depier of his Majety.

King Henry the 7th. having preed Doctor Fiher to the Bihoprick of Rocheter, all men thinking it to proceed from the requet of the Lady Margaret, the Kings Mother, and his Mitris: The King aid; Indeed the modety of the man, together with my Mothers ilence, pake in his behalf.

He refued the Bihopricks of Lincoln and Ely, proffered him by Henry the 8th. contenting himelf with his former, though les: Saying, Others have larger patures, but I have leer charge of ouls; o that when I hall be called to an account for both, I hall be the better able to give an account of either.

Bihop Fiher, having all his plate tolne in one night, his ervant puruing the thieves, found ome pieces that they had let fall by the way; the Bihop oberving the next day the ad countenances of his ervants, when knowing the caue, aid: If this be all, we have more caue to rejoyce, that God hath retor'd us to ome, than to be dicontented that wicked men have taken away any; for the leat favour of God Almighty, is more to be eteemed, than all the evil (which the Devil and all his wicked intruments can do unto us) therefore let us it down and be merry, thank God it is no wore, and look ye better to the ret.

Sir Thomas Moore, meeting the Bihop going before the Kings Commiioners at Lambeth, aluted him in thee terms: Well met my Lord, I hope we hall meet in heaven. To which the Bihop reply'd: This hould be the way, Sir Thomas, for it is a very treight gate we are in. They both uffer'd for refuing the Oath of Supremacy.
The Bihop would alwayes ay, That the remembrance of death came never out of eaon.

The Bihops man being clapt up a cloe prioner, and threatned to be hanged (for carrying letters from his Mater to Sir Thomas Moore) they then being both prioners in the Tower) asked the Keeper, If there were another Act of Parliament come forth, whereby a man hould be hang'd for erving his Mater.

When Henry the 8th. was told the Bihops reolve, to accept of the Cardinals Hat, if the Pope ent it to him: The King aid; Yea, is he yet o luty? Well, let the Pope end him a Hat when he will, Mother of God, he hall wear it on his houlders then, for I will leave him never a head to et it on.

Cardinal Poole aith of Bihop Fiher (in an Epitle Dedicatory to Henry the 8th.) That if an Embaador had been to be ent from earth to heaven, there could not among all the Bihops and Clergy o fit a man be choen as he.

A foreign Embaador, ome 200 years ince, comming to Durham, addreed himelf firt to the high and umptuous Shrine of St. Cuthbert, If thou beet a Saint, pray for me. Then comming to the plain, low, and little Tomb of St. Bede, Becaue, aid he, thou art a Saint, good Bede pray for me.

Richard the • d. aid no les pightfully than fally of the Woodvills (brethren to the Wife of his brother King Edward the 4th. by whom they were advanced) That many were made noble, who formerly were not worth a noble.
One asked which was the bet Edition of St. Augutine? To whom this anwer was given (generally true of all ancient Authors) Even that Augutine which is leat corrected.

There is a tradition of King Henry the 8ths. fool, comming into the Court, and finding the King tranported with an unuual joy, boldly asked of him the caue thereof: To whom the King anwered; It was becaue the Pope had honoured him with a tyle more eminent than any of his Ancetors. O good Harry (quoth the fool) let thou and I defend one another, and let the faith alone to defend it elf.
The Lady Katherine, King Henry the 8ths. divorced Wife, was wont to ay, She accounted no time lot, but what was laid out in dreing of her.

Once an Eloquent Orator, free only of words, being otherwie extreamly covetous, made a large and elegant Oration in Latine to perwade others bountifully to contribute to a proper object of charity, whilt he himelf would not part with one penny to that purpoe. To whom one of his Audience (though far his inferiour in Eloquence) made this harp but hort return: Qui uadet; ua det. Let him who eeks to perwade others, give omething of his own.

Henry the 5th. having born away the Crown,
uppoing his Father had been dead; when his Father ued thee words, How I came by it, and what right I have unto it, God knows: He aid, I am to receive it from you, as your next heir; and howoever you came by it, I will keep the poeion of it by the word, againt all mine enemies.
When Gowry was led to the Tower, a friend of his told him, Ah, my Lord, I am orry you had no more wit. Tuh (quoth he) thou know't not what thou ayet, when awet thou a fool come hither?

When the Romans had nominated Titus Manlius Torquatus to be Conul, he alledging the infirmity of his eyes, refued the honour, and aid He hould bring in a very ill and pernitious example, if he hould undertake to govern the Common-wealth with other mens eyes.

Charls the 9th. King of France, offered to the Prince of Conde his choie, whether he would go to Mae, or chooe perpetual banihment, or imprionment?
