What, replyed he? to goe to Mae, is imply a in, therefore I will never chooe that; but to chooe either perpetual banihment, or imprionment, that I cannot doe, for then I hould imply a certain guiltines in my elf; but it is in your power, O King, to inflict which you pleae, and I am ready to uffer.

When Dionyius preented three whores before Aritippus, bidding him make choie of them: He aid, That Paris had uch bad ucces for chooing one of that kind, that he would never make choie of one of the three.

A certain Scholar amongt the Jews, asked one
of the Rabbies, his Mater, Whether he might read any of the humane Writers, or not? He gave him this Anwer: You may read them, provided you read them neither day nor night.
Apelles, when his boy hew'd him a painted Table, and told him that it was done in hate: He anwered, He might have pared to tell him o, for the work ufficiently hew'd it.

p.U: aid, The Cardinals were like Foxes, weeping the houe with their tails, raiing more dut than they cleaned.

div.p: Mr. Greenham anwered one that pake omewhat in his own diparagement: Oh (aid he) why do you praie your elf o much?

p.U: aith of the Bihops in the Council of Trent; They were learned in their aitants.
aid of Roniface his Extravagants, They will doe well with a word in hand.

div.p: The Roman General aid of a recruited Army of Enemies, That thoe African Nations, muter'd under everal names, were but the ame men whom they had formerly beaten under the notion of Carthaginians.

When a Roman Senator asked the Carthaginian Embaador, How long the Peace hould lat? That (aith he) will depend on the Conditions you give us, If Jut and Honourable, they will hold for ever; but if otherwie, no longer than till we have power to break them.

Batton Deidiale, who moved the people of Dalmatia to rebel againt the Romans (eeing them oppret too much with tributes and exactions) making uch harp war againt them,
as Tyberius the Emperor asked him on a time, why he had caued the people to take Arms? To whom he anwered b • dly, That the Romans were the caue thereof; for they, in ending them hepherds with good dogs to preerve them, they had ent them wolves which devoured them.
The Emperor Maximilian the 2d. could not endure that War hould be made for Religion; and was wont to ay, That it was a deadly in to eek to force mens conciences, the which belongs to God only.

At the Treaty for delivery of the Town of Antwerp, the Hollanders initing upon explaining the word, candal, &c. the Duke of Parma aid: Can you not do as the Countryman did at Rome, who paing along the treets before an Ecce homo (which is the figure of the repreentation which Pilate made of our Saviour Jeus Chrit unto the people) having made reverence, and paing on, he bethought himelf that Pilate might attribute this honour unto himelf; wherefore turning and putting off his hat again, He aid, It is to the Chrit, not to the Pilate.
Pieresk us, the famous Frenchman, was wont to ay, That whooever eeks after the uncertain good things of this world, hould think and reolve, that he gathers as well for thieves, as for himelf.

p.U: aith, That the Lawes of Neceity are o inevitable, that the gods themelves cannot alter them.

div.p:
Caracalla having mierably impoverihed the people, his Mother reproved him: To whom he hewing his naked word, replyed,
As long as I have this, I will not want.
Aurelian demanding how he might govern well? Was anwered by a great Peronage: You mut be provided with iron and gold; iron to ue againt your enemies, and gold to reward your friends.

The Caliph of Babylon demurring to give the Embaador of Almerick (King of Jerualem) his hand bare, but gave it him in his glove. To whom the reolute Earl of Caearea aid: Sir, truth eeks no holes to hide it elf; Princes that will hold Covenants, mut deal openly and nakedly; give us therefore your bare hand, we will make no bargain with your glove.

Lewis King of France, going the econd time to the Holy Land, paing by Avignon, ome of the City wronged his Souldiers; wherefore his Nobles deired him to beiege the City, the rather, becaue it was upected that therein his Father was poyoned. To whom Lewis mot Chritianly: I come not out of France to revenge my own quarrels, or thoe of my Father or Mother, but injuries offer'd to Jeus Chrit.

p.U: everely punihed blaphemies, earing their lips with an hot iron. And becaue by his command it was executed upon a great rich Citizen of Paris, ome aid, He was a Tyrant. He hearing it, aid before many: I would to God, that with earing my own lips, I could banih out of my Realm all abue of Oaths.

div.p:
It was the Speech of Gutavus Adolphus, but three dayes before his death: Our affairs (aith he) anwer our deires; but I doubt God will punih me for the folly of the people, who attribute too
much unto me, and eteem me as it were their God; and therefore he will make them hortly know and ee I am but a man. He be my witnes, it is a thing ditateful unto me: And whatever befall me, I receive it as from his divine will; onely in this I ret fully atisfied, that he will not leave this great enterprize of mine imperfect.
Hormida being asked what he thought of Rome? Said, He took contentment in this onely, that he had now learned, how even there alo men are mortal.

Socrates, appointed to uffer death, would learn to ing: And being asked what good it would do him, eeing he was to die the next day? He anwered thus: Even that I may depart out of this life, learning more than I knew before.

Themitocles, after a Battel fought with the Perians, epying a pair of bracelets, and a collar of gold, lying on the ground, Take up thoe things (quoth he, peaking to one of his company that tood near unto him) thou art not Themitocles.

A Jew being turned Turk, oon after, buying of grapes of another Turk, fell at variance with him about weighing the grapes; from words they fell to blows, and the Jew-Turk beat the other, which he endured very patiently, to encourage him (as it eem'd) in his new Religion. Soon after another Jew came to the Turk who had been beaten, and demanded of him why he uffered himelf to be o abued? Who anwered, You hall beat me as much, if you will turn Muulman. So zealous are they to win Proelytes.
Philip the 2d. King of Spain was devoted to his Religion in o intene a degree, that he would often ay, If the Prince his Son were an Heretick, or Schimatick, he would himelf find fuel to burn him.
The Chyrurgeons being lancing his knee one day, the Prince his Son ask'd him, Whether it did not pain him much? He anwered, My ins pain me much more.

Reading a letter that brought him the newes of the los of his Fleet in 88. He aid (without the leat motion, or change of countenance) Welcome be the will of God; I ent my Couin, the Duke of Medina, to fight with men, not with the Elements.
He ued to have a aying often in his mouth: Time and I will challenge any two in the world.
Bias being demanded by a wicked man, what was piety? He was ilent: The other asking the reaon of his ilence: I anwer not (aith he) becaue you enquire after that which nothing concerns you.
It was the entence of Cleobolus: Do good to your friend, that he may be more your friend; to your enemy, that he may become your friend.
To one who reproved Anaxagoras, for not taking care of his Country: Wrong me not, aid he, my greatet care is my Country. Pointing to the Heavens.

Portugal being revolted, the Conde D'Olivares came miling to the King (Philip the 4th.) aying, Sir, I pray you give me las albricias to hanel the good newes; for now you are more abolute King of Portugal than ever, for the people have forfeited
all their priviledges by this Rebellion: • eides, the Etate of the Duke of Briganza, with all his Complices, are yours by right of Confication; o that you have enough to ditribute among your old loyal ervants by way of reward.

Attabali • a, a wild Pagan King when he heard that his Kingdom was given by the Pope to the King of Spain: Surely (aid he) that Pope mut be an egregious fool, or ome unjut and impudent tyrant, that will undertake to betow other mens poeions o freely.

An Indian being to die, was perwaded by a Francican Frier to turn Chritian, and then he hould go to heaven. He asked, Whether there were any Spaniards in heaven? Yes, aid the Frier, 'tis full of them. Nay, then (aid he) I had rather go to hell, than have their company.

It was an excellent aying of Herod the Sophit, when he was pained with the Gout in his hands and feet: When I would eat (aid he) I have no hands; when I would go, I have no feet; but when I mut be pained, I have both hands and feet.

John, King of Hungary, ued oftentimes to ay, That the favour and love of valiant men, gotten by bounty and courteie, was the bet treaures of a Prince, for that courteous and thankeful men did oftentimes, in ome one worthy piece of ervice, plentifully repay whatoever had been betow'd upon them; as for uch as were unthankeful, they did, to their hame, bear the tetimony of another mans virtue.

After the Victory of Lepanto, one of the chief of the Turkih prioners, hearing it compared to the los of Cyprus, aid: That the Battel lot,
was unto Selymus, as if a man hould have his beard, which would ere long grow again; but the los of Cyprus was unto the Venetians as the los of an arm, which once cut off, could never be again recovered.

A Countryman in Spain, comming to an Image inhrin'd, the extraction and firt making whereof he could well remember; and not finding from the ame that repectful uage which he expected: You need not (quoth he) be o proud, for I have known you from a Plum-tree.

A Perian in England attending on the Embaador, anno 1626. who perceiving wealthy people in London, in the time of the plague, tumultuouly poting to their Country-houes: What (aith he) have the Englihmen two Gods, the one for the City, and the other for the Country?

Frederick, Burgrave of Noremberg (which he obtained of the Emperor Sigimond, for his many good Services) making his Will, he intended to give that charge to his econd Son Frederick; and acquainting his eldet Son John, (who was a contemplative man) anwered: I did always think that Frederick had been more dear to you than my elf, which did omewhat grieve me; but now, dear Father, I will change my opinion, and love and honour you, who by your lat Will bequeath ret to me, and cares to him.
Caear was counelled to have a guard alwayes about him. Whereto he anwered: That he would have none; for he would rather die once, than live continually in jealouie and fear.

After his Victory in Spain, againt Pompey's Sons (conidering the danger he had been in)
he ued to ay, That only that day he fought for his life, and in all other Battels, ever for honour and victory.

When the Captaines and Souldiers would have given Valentinian a companion and equal in the Empire, He told them: It was in your hands, and in your pleaure, when I was not Emperor, to give me the government and command of the Empire; but now, that I have the government, and am in poeion thereof, it is no part of your charge, neither ought you to intermeddle therein, for that it is my charge onely.

Valentinian the 2d. caued Ecius his General againt Atila to be lain, having ome upition of him; but demanding of Proximus, a dicreet and noble Roman, Whether he had not followed the bet and mot profitable Counel, by putting Ecius to death? He anwered: Whether the Emperor hath put Ecius to death with, or without reaon, I dare not determine; but this I dare affirm, that by killing him, thou hat with thy own left hand cut off thy right.

The Emperor Henry the 4th. having lain his Competitor Rodulph, whoe ervants going about to bury the body of their deceaed Lord, with the Enignes and Ornaments of the Emperor, ome asked of the Emperor Henry, Wherefore he uffered Rodulph to be buried with uch honour, eeing he was a Tyrant, and his enemy? Whereto he anwered: I would to God that all mine enemies were like Rodulph, buried with the Ornaments and Enigns of Emperors.

David Game, one of the bravet and mot
judicious Souldier of his time, being ent by Henry the 5th. to make an etimate of the number of the French Army (which infinitely exceeded the number of the Englih) went to the top of an hill, and eeing all the Champion covered with Tents, and blazing with fires, brought word back, That there were enough of them to be lain, enough to be taken prioners, and enough to be made run away.

A Kentih Knight, having pent a great Etate at Court, and brought himelf to one Park, and a fine houe in it, was yet ambitious to entertain the Queen at it; and to that purpoe had new painted his gates, with a Coat of Arms, and Motto, over-written thus, OIA VANITAS in great golden letters, the Treaurer Burleigh offering to read it, deired to know of the Knight what he meant by OIA? who told him it tood for Omnia: The Lord replyed: Sir, I wonder, having made your Omnia o little as you have, you notwithtanding make your Vanitas o large.
The Philopher, when he aw a vain proud Gull, He wihed (he aid) that all his friends were but uch as that man thought himelf, and all his enemies uch as he was.
Epiphanius having tay'd long at Contantinople, and being to take hip to return home again, he aid: He was leaving three great things, a great City, a great Palace, and great Hypocriie.

Bihop Andrews, whom no man will envy the reputation of one of the greatet Clerks in his Age, when a plain man came eriouly to
him, and asked his opinion concerning an obcure paage in the Revelation: Anwered: My friend, I am not come o far.

Henry the 4th. King of France, ued to ay; That in his Kingdome he oberved there was a double tribute ued to be paid: One to the King, the other to his Officers; but the firt was made intollerable by the econd.

Tierceline, a Knight of very ancient Extraction, oberving in his time, the ale of Honours and Offices, nay, the highet Dignitie of all, which is St. Michaels Order, was protant for money: He aid; The Order of St. Michael was become a Collar now for every Ae.

Robert, Duke of Normandy, when he was going to the Holy Sepulcher, being met by one of his own Subjects, as he was mounted upon a great Saracens back; and being much tyr'd, he aid: Commend me to all in Normandy, and tell them, I am going to heaven upon the Devils back.

It was a witty aying of King James, when he was onely King of Scotland, when he received a Caveat from his Godmother Queen Elizabeth of England, to take heed of the Spanih Fleet; He anwered: For his part he deired but one requet of the Spaniard, uch a one as that Polyphemus had promied Ulyes, that when he had devour'd others, he would wallow him lat of all.

After the los of Calais, an Englih Captain, having trus'd up his bag and baggage, to goe for England, as he was going out of
the gates, in a jeering way, was ask'd, O Englihmen, when will ye back again to France? The Captain, with a ad and erious countenance, anwered: When the ins of France are greater than the ins of England, then will the Englih return to France.

When one told Tyberius the Emperor, of ome aperions that were cat abroad upon him; He anwered: We are not angry that there are ome who peak ill of us; it is enough that we are in uch a condition, that no body can do us any ill.

Two Perian Embaadors were imploy'd to Pope rban the 5th. who being admitted, and deired to deliver their Embaage as uccinctly as they could, in regard of the Popes indipoition; yet they made a long tedious Oration, which did diquiet his Holines, as it was oberved by the Auditors; the firt Embaador having at lat concluded, the econd ubjoyned very wittily, aying: We have this moreover given to us in charge, that if you will not condecend to our demands, this my Colleague mut repeat his Speech again, and make ome additions to it. The Pope was o much taken with this, that he preently dimied both of them very well atisfied for the buines they came about.

A Gentleman, who in a Duel was rather cratcht than wounded, ent for a Chyrurgeon, who having opened the wound, charged his man with all peed to fetch uch a alve from uch a place in his Study. Why (aid the Gentleman) is the hurt o dangerous? Oh yes (anwered the Chyrurgeon) if he returns
not in pot-hate, the wound will cure it elf, and o I hall loe my Fee.

A notable fellow, and a ouldier to Alexander, finding his firt admiion to be the greatet difficulty, put feathers into his noe and eares, and danced about the Court in an Antique fahion, till the trangenes of the Show brought the King himelf to be a Spectator. Then this mimick throwing off his diguie; Sir (aid he to the King) thus I firt arrive at your Majeties notice in the fahion of a Fool, but can do you ervice in the place of a wie man, if you pleae to employ me.

A man full of words, who took himelf to be a grand wit, made his brag that he was the leader of the dicoure in what company oever he came; and none, aid he, dare peak in my preence, if I hold my peace. No wonder, anwered one, for they are all truck dumb at the miracle of your ilence.

When once a Gentleman admired how o pithy, learned, and witty a Dedication was match'd to a flat, dull, foolih Book: In truth, aid another, they may be well match'd together, for I profes they are nothing a kin.

A Gentleman travelling in a myty morning, ask'd of a hepherd what weather it would be? It will be (aith the hepherd) what weather hall pleae me: And being requeted to expres his meaning: Sir, aith he, it hall be what weather pleaeth God, and what weather pleaeth God, pleaeth me.

A rich man told a poor man, that he walked to get a tomach for his meat: And I,
(aid the poor man) walk to get meat for my tomach.

A rich landed Fool, whom a Courtier had begg'd, and carried about to wait on him, comming with his Mater to a Gentlemans houe, where the picture of a fool was wrought in a fair uit of Arras, cut the picture out with a pen-knife; and being chidden for o doing. You have more caue, aid he, to thank me; for if my Mater had een the picture of the fool, he would have begg'd the hangings of the King, as he did my lands.

When the tanders by comforted a natural which lay on his death-bed, and told him that four proper fellows hould carry his body to the Church: Yea (quoth he) but I had rather by half go thither my elf.
One braved a Gentleman to his face, that in skill and valour he came far behind him: 'Tis true (aid the other) for when I fought with you, you ran away before me.

Sir Francis Drake, riding within the Road of Port-Rico, a hot from the Catle enter'd the Steerage of the Ship, took away the tool from under him as he ate at upper, wounded Sir Nicholas Clifford and Brute Brown to death. Ah! dear Brute (aid Drake) I could grieve for thee, but now is no time for me to let down my pirits.
One walking in London-treets, met a gallant, who cry'd to him a pretty ditance before-hand, I will have the wall. Yea (anwer'd he) and take the houe too, if you can but agree with the Land-lord.
It was a mannerly anwer which a young Gentleman gave to King James, when he asked him what kin he was to uch a Lord of his name? Pleae your Majety, aid he, my elder brother is his Couin-german.

When one, being an Husbandman, challenged kindred of Robert Grothead Bihop of Lincoln, and thereupon requeted the favour of him to betow an Office on him. Couin, (quoth the Bihop) if your Cart be broken, i'le mend it, if your Plough old, i'le give you a new one, and Seed to ow your Land; but an Hubandman I found you, and an Husbandman I'le leave you.

Arminius meeting Baudius one day diguied with drink, he told him, Tu Baudi dedecoras notram Academiam: Et tu Armini (anwered he) notram Religionem: Thou Baudius digracet our Univeritie; and thou Arminius our Religion.

Henry the 4th. of France, being troubled with a fit of the Gout, and the Spanih Embaador comming then to viit him, and aying he was orry to ee his Majety o lame, He anwered: As lame as I am, if there were occaion, your Mater the King of Spain, hould no ooner have his foot in the tirrup, but he hould find me on horsback.

King James asking the Lord Keeper Bacon, what he thought of a French Embaador, who had then lately had his Audience? He anwered, That he was a tall proper man. His Majety reply'd, but what think you of his
head-piece? Is he a proper man for the Office of an Embaador? Sir, aid Bacon: Tall men are like high houes of four or five tories, wherein commonly the uppermot room is wort furnihed.

Lewis the 9th. who, in the Catalogue of the French Kings, is call'd St. Lewis, was Baptized in the little Town of Poyy; and after his return from Aegypt, and other places againt the Saracens, being asked by what Title he would be ditinguihed from the ret of his Predeceors after his death? He anwered, That he deired to be called Lewis of Poyy. Reply being made, That there were divers other places and Cities of Renown, where he had performed brave Exploits, and obteined famous Victories, therefore it was more fitting that ome of thoe places hould denominate him. No, aid he, I deire to be called Lewis of Poyy, becaue there I got the mot glorious Victory that ever I had; for there I overcame the Devil: Meaning that he was Chritned there.

Don Beltran de Roa, being to marry a rich Labradors (a Yeomans) daughter, which was much importun'd by her Parents to the match, becaue their Family hould be thereby ennobled, he being a Cavalier of St. Jag • : The young Maid having undertood that Don Beltran had been in Naples, and had that dieae about him, anwered wittily: Truly, Sir, To better my blood, I will not hurt my fleh.

It was the anwer of Vepaian to Apollonius, deiring entrance and acces for Dion and Euphrates,
two Philoophers: My gates are always open to Philoophers, but my very breat is open unto thee.

It is reported of Como de Medici, that having built a goodly Church, with a Monatery thereunto annex'd, and two Hopitals, with other monuments of Piety, and endow'd them with large Revenues, as one did much magnifie him for thee extraordinary works; he anwer'd: 'Tis true, I imploy'd much treaure that way; yet when I look over my Leiger-book of accounts, I do not find that God Almighty is indebted to me one penny, but I am till in the arrear to him.

It was a brave generous aying of a great Armenian-Merchant, who having undertood how a veel of his was cat away, wherein there was laden a rich Cargazon upon his ole account, he trook his hand upon his breat, and aid: My heart, I thank God, is till afloat, my pirits hall not ink with my hip, nor go an inch lower.

Sir Edward Herbert being Embaador in France, there hapned ome claings between him and the great French Favourite Luynes; whereupon he was told that Luynes was his enemy, and that he was not in a place of ecurity there: Sir Edward gallantly anwered, That he held himelf to be in a place of Security whereoever he had his word by him.
Faenetra in Pectore. OR, FAMILIAR LETTERS. By THO. FORDE.
LONDON, Printed by R. and W. Leybourn, for William Grantham at the Black Bear in St. Pauls Church-yard, neer the little North Door, 1660.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
THe witty Lucian brings in Momus, quarrelling at the Mater-pieces which the gods had made; and the onely fault he found with Man, was, That he had not a window to look into his breat. For this reaon, I call this Packet of Letters Fenetra in Pectore; Letters being the bet Caements, whereby men dicloe themelves. Judicium fit per Brachium, ay the Phyicians; and I know no better Interpreter of
the Heart, than the hand; epecially in Familiar Letters, whereby friends mingle ouls, and make mutual dicoveries of, and to one another. The pen, like the pule, dicovers our inward condition; if it become faint, or intermitting, like the paing-bell, it gives notice of the decay, if not the departure of friendhip; which is the oul of humane Societie.

For thee, I have no better Apology than their publication their impudence (if it be o) bepeaking their innocence. They deire to pleae all, to injure none. If you find ome things in them that appear not calculated for the Meridian of the preent times, know, that they are left but to hew what the whole piece might have been, had my time and the times accorded; they might then perhaps have given you ome
remarks of the miracles of our age, But the Dutch Proverb tels me, Who bringeth himelf into needles dangers, dieth the Devils martyr.

p.hi: Nulli tacuie nocet, nocet ee loquutum.

div.p:
And I very well remember that notable Apothegme of the famous (though unfortunate) Sir W. ••
leigh: Whooever hall tell any great man, or Magitrate, that he is not jut; the General of an Army, that he is not valiant; and great Ladies, that they are not fair; hall never be made a Counellour, a Captain, or a Courtier.

Thou wilt ay, it may be, I had little to do to publih my follies to the world, and I am contented thou houldt think o, if it may pas for my Apologie, That I had little ele to do. If it be a crime, the number
of offenders in this kind, is enough to authorize the fact, and turn the guilt into a pardon, if not a pas-port.

p.hi: For they who write, becaue all write, have till,
That excue for writing, and for writing ill.

div.p: At this time I hall ue no other, nor trouble thee any farther (Reader) when I have ubcribed the Author,

closer.signed: Thy Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. T. C.
div.p:
AT my arrival here, I finde all out of order, though abounding with orders. The King and Queen are departed, which makes us all dead for what caue I cannot tell you, unles it were for fear of the arrival of a tranger to this Kingdom, and one that hath been long ince banihed from hence: Nor durt hee appear now, but that 'tis Parliament-time. She was landed at Wetminter by the rout of Water-men, when they frighted away the Bihops commig to the Houe of Commons door, it was put to the Vote, Whether he hould come in or no? The better part upecting by •• r habit it was Rebellion (they having een
her before in forreign parts) would not admit her: But the Major part carried it in the Affirmative, and the five Members were appointed to entertain her; which they, did, and ome ay, he was placed in the Speakers Chair. She came not in the Lords Houe, they could not Brook it; but I dare Say he had a Conference with ome of them in the Painted Chamber. Her Lodgings are provided in the City, where he goes attired (as neceary) with a fair new cloak of Religion, a Scotch Bonnet, a French Doublet, and Coats like Dutchmens Slops; her hair red, like an Irihmans; neither Bands nor Cuffs, for he indures no Linnen for pight of Lawn Sleeves, unles a two or three Night-caps, becaue they are of Holland. You would wonder to ee in what droves our Citizens flock after her, did you not know it is their nature, after trangers. But I'll follow her no farther, let you upect me for one of her followers, who am, Sir,

div.head: To Mr. T. C.
div.p:
THe Fire is now broken out of the Houe, and the parks of edition fly about the City, being blown by the long-winded lungs of ome Pulpeteers. Here want not editious Sheba's
to blow the Trumpet, and as a Preludium, here is an hot skirmih of Pens, but the Kings eems to excel them, as much as an Eagles wing a Gooe quill. The Women and Maids to epoue the quarrel, bring in their Thimbles, Rings, and Bodkins, with as much zeal as the Iraelites did their Jewels to making of their Golden Calf. Such a tyde of Plate every day ebbs and flows at Guild-Hall, that the Roman Emperour who wam in wine, had he enjoyed this, might have ailed in an Ocean of Gold and Silver. They have exercied their hands and Pens o long, till their Arms begin to be engaged, and 'tis thought it may prove a Generall Engagement. I can go no farther for the Pres, but mut here remain, Sir,

div.head: To Mr. R. R.
div.p:
I Received your Letter, wherein Love and Friendhip eem to our-vie each other; and which is predominant, were not eaie to determine. Whereat, how I was tranported with joy, you may eaier gues than I expres. For thoe unmerited Encomiums you o liberally put upon me, I conceive you rather thereby intruct me what I hould be, than tell me what I am. Or
ele, you look'd on thoe poor m • tes with the Multiplying-glas of friendhip. Your offer to continue this Literal correpondence, I willingly accept, and was never o ill bred as to neglect uch a benefit, when profered. Willingly hall I exchange my glas for your Gold: yet how mean oever my expreions may be; you hall find them richly quilted with Love, which hath long ince knit my affections to your vertues

lg.l: Nec i urgat c • ntimanus Gygas,
—divellet unquam.
The Gyant with his hundred hands,
Shall not untie thoe ilken bands,
VVhich bind me fat to your commands,

div.p: Concerning the Books you wrote for, I cannot but admire you hould not have received them, ince I delivered them to the ame Carrier that brought you my Letter. They et out together, however my letter out-trip't them in peed, but I wonder not, that being wing'd with love and deire to viit that breat, which the Mues and Graces emulate to make their Habitation. I may not forget to remember my repects to your Brother, and Mr. P. and to aure you, that a letter from either of them would be very acceptable; and the rather, though you tell me my friends are all lame, that they are not • ame friends. This is the deire of

closer.signed: your and their Friend and Servant, T. F

div.head: To Mr. J. A.
div.p: I know you will much wonder at this eeming Solecime, and I wonder as much at the caue thereof. Having found the truth of the former part of the vere, that vox audita perit—I am bold to make an experiment of the latter, and try—Si litera cripta manebit. Since words, like running meengers, have the fate to have their errand forgot as oon as they are gone, may this erve as a more contant Leiger, to whiper in your ears, that he who was o bold to requet that mall courteie of you, was emboldned thereto by a conideration, that he was till, as you were once pleaed to tyle him, your Friend. I protet, Sir, in that confidence I o long importun'd you, that I was ahamed to appear to you again with the like requet. And yet, deirous to ee that poor brat of my own brain, I reolv'd to make ue of this Proxie, the rather, becaue (you know) Literae non erubecunt. Sir, I readily believe that your occaions are great; yet, if you pleae to make truce with your time, but o long as you may look that poor paper, I will engage the utmot of my abilities to make you a requital; and if you doubt of my ability, 'twill be a work of charity in you to forgive me.

In Solomons Temple there was an outer Court, into which trangers were admitted; and an inner Court, where onely Jewes were to aemble; and the Sanctum Sanctorum, where onely the High Priet might enter. Give me leave to tell you, that though you hut me out of the Sanctum Sanctorum of your Friendhip, nor will admit me into the inner Court of your Familiars, you hall not exclude me from the outward Court of your acquaintance. And in this reolve he rets, that is Sir,

closer.signed: What, or how you pleae to call him beide T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. F.
div.p: I Received your welcome Letter, and as welcome Token: For the one I end you an Anwer, though not anwerable; but to the other, I forbear to retaliate, let I hould thereby turn your Gift into a Bargain.

Sir, I am very glad to hear that you receive your due money for your piritual bread, although, I fear, it is not the Tenth of your deert, knowing that you cannot feed them but with fine Flour. And although I would not rob your Family of their Dimenum, yet hall I hope you will not deny me a continuance of
thoe witty crums that fall from their Table. Nor can I be o far mine own enemy, as not to think of yours, as Tully did of Atticus his Epitles, that the longet are the bet. And aure your elf, as Cato aid, He never knew an old man forget where his gold was. My Fancy often turns Forreter, and walks the round, till I meet with you, when I am infinitely tranported with that but imaginary enjoyment of that peron I o much delight in; the conceit of which, has driven me into a erious conideration and earch, after the wonderful force of the Imagination. And I find, ome have been kill'd, others preerv'd, meerly by the trength of their imagination. Here could I be tediouly copious in as facetious as trange tories to this purpoe; but I will not, with Phormio, read a Lecture to Hannibal. It hall uffice me, to hope that uch Imagies of the brain, are no breach of the econd Commandement: Nor yet am I of the belief of that Priet, that was fully perwaded, That nothing was fale that was printed. Whatever be, I am ure this is not, that I am

div.head: To Mrs. B.
div.p:
ALthough unknown (but by your courteie) I am bold hereby to alute you, and have ent this poor paper to kis your hands, who have o kindly provided for mine; not doubting but you will as much admire at thee rude lines, as I did at your kinder token. I call it yours, and therefore hold my elf obliged by the laws of Gratitude, to return you thanks. And, let that hould be too poor a requital for o great a favour, be pleas'd to accept of this mall token; for I hate to be ingrateful, and am loth to be in debt, either i •
• oyn or courteie. And, that I may not part thoe whom God hath united, I mut not forget to return like thanks to your loving Companion, as knowing it was from your Conjunction this Influence proceeded. May your Lives be as Lines parallal, knowing no date till they both meet in our common Centre of happines. But I fear to be tedious, time and opportunity may o propitiouly befriend me, as in ome kind or other, at leat, to endeavour you a larger requital: In the interim acknowledge me

closer.signed: Your ready, though unknown Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. B. R.
div.p: BEing informed by our common friend N. H. that your intentions are for—next week, I thought it un mannerly, or rather unfriendly, not to bid you Farewel: And I know not better how, than in the words of the Lyrick Poet to his Florus,
div.q: I bone quo virtus tua te vocat, I pede Fauto.
div.p:
And this not being preent in peron, I am forc'd to do by Proxie, and with
• o in the Poet, Litera pro verbis. I dare believe, though you go farther off, yet your affection will be never the les; for I may jutly confer on you, what one once did on Augutus,
div.q: Rarus tu quidem ad recipiendas amicitias, ad retinendas verò contantiimus.
div.p:
Story tells us of two Palm-trees, growing on the two oppoite banks of a River, which notwithtanding the ditance of the roots, and depight of the intervening water, did lovingly infoliate and twine their branches So, notwithtanding the ditance of place, our bodies are planted in, maugre all oppoition, we may entwine our branches (Letters I mean) neither (I hope) hall any envious Catterpiller (or fale
friend) eat away thoe leaves, o long as life remains in the root of

div.head: To M. A. E.
div.p:
THe opportunity of this Bearer is ufficient importunity to me of troubling you at this time, and your wonted ingenuity, I hope, will be my ufficient warrant: Nay I hould be very much wanting to myelf, and that repect I owe you, if I hould not. To let you know, that you have not own the eed of your favours in an altogether barren oyl, as doth he that confers a benefit on an ingrateful peron. But it is my grief, that the crop of my abilities falls o much hort of your deert, and my deire. To tell you any Newes, were but to put you in mind of thoe mieries which you are already too enible of; yet, let you hould expect it, be pleas'd to undertand, there was another meage came lately from the K. to the H. H. who have voted an anwer to it; God grant it may •• for Peace, the onely Aqua-vitae to retore • is fainting Kingdome. I hope it is not yet
with us, as it was once in Peria, when there was a Law made againt Peace; though I know ubjects eldome draw the word againt their Sovereign, but they throw away the cabbard. I forbear to ay more, becaue I know not whoe hands my letter may go through; uch is the miery of our Times that Burglary in this kind was never more practis'd nor les punih'd: Nay, Lyes are more tolerable now in Print, than loyal Truth in Writing: Yet fear I not who ees and knows that I profes my elf (as I am)

div.head: To Mr. T. F.
div.p:
NOt having had the happines to ee you of late, and hearing that you intend to let the Country ingros your company, I thought good to viit you by this ilent, yet (to make it a Paradox) peaking meenger, and I had rather you hould imagine the caue; yet, if you will not, I mut be bold to tell you, that I much wonder I hould all this while hear no noie of my Viol. Seriouly, Sir, I had uch a confidence of your reality to your friends (in which number I eteem my elf one) that I could not believe the
contrary, though it were trongly intigated to • e. And Sir, whether your uage of me hath been anwerable to my expectation of you, I leave your elf to judge. I cannot imagine that you hould think I would ell my—for the mending or lend it, with an intention to loe it. I hould be very orry, that that which was made for Harmony, hould be an Intrument of Dicord between friends; it lies in your power to prevent it: I am willing to believe you will; give not, I pray, my good opinion of you the lye, becaue I deire to remain,

div.head: To Mr. J. A.
div.p:
SInce your departure, the cruel Fates, intending thereby to make me truly mierable, have robb'd me of a very friend, and that by the irrecoverable hand of Death; and, as if they intended me the ole object of their envy, have protracted, if not put off the performance of your promis'd courteie; o that now I am left alone, olitarily pondering the complaint of old Eramus: Anicorum meorum, alii moriuntur, alii mutant animum. Me thinks I am depriv'd of all my Senes, ince I can neither ee you, nor hear, either of, or from you. Knowing
not the reaon, I am ready to believe the bet, and have Charity (which Eramus in his time compar'd to a Friers Cowle, becaue it covers a multitude of ins) enough to hide all urmies, till Time, the on of Truth, hall dicover all things in their perfect colours. Me thinks I have the fortune of ome children, who having lot one arrow, hoot another after it, hoping thereby to find it, and not eldome loe both: However you hall not Him, that will reolve to continue

div.head: To Mr. N. C.
div.p:
I Have ent you as many Letters, as there are Graces, and now, I hope, I may lawfully deit, and I have the old rule for my warrant: Si ter pulanti nemo repondit, abito. I have long look'd, and attentively litned for that happy word, which hould at once put a period to your ilence, and mine expectation. Happily you may thereby tacitly intruct me of the unwelcomnes of my too forward cribling; but I hall end with this, let I fall under the lah of the Italian Proverb: Chi crive à chi non riponde, ò è matto, ò hà di biognia: He that writes to one that anwers not, either he is a fool, or
has need of him. Your ilent action makes me remember the conceit of one, that going in the treet, and eeing the Signe of the Golden Cros, would lay a wager with him that went with him, that he would make the Mater of the hop (whom I very well know) to pull down his Signe without peaking a word to him: The wager being laid, he pulls off his his hat, and drops half a dozen legs to the Signe; firt, on one ide, and then on the other; which the Mater of the hop eeing, thinking to prevent his future Supertition, uddenly pulls down his Signe, which is now upplied with the badge of the Gilded Trumpet. Enough this time, when I have ubcribed

div.head: To Mr. R. R.
div.p:
I Am o ambitious of continuing our ancient friendhip, almot as old as our elves, that I cannot omit the leat occaion, that may ei increae or preerve it. And although, me thinks, I hear you tell me, that my ounding on o light a knock, doth but argue me the empter veel, whilt you who are more full fraught, give no anwer, though with much importunity; I have no other excue, but to tell you, that I do it, to let you ee, I had rather eem to be a troubleome, than a forgetful friend. Truly ayes our Englih Proverb: He loves not at all, that
knows when to make an end. And the Italians are not amis, who ay, L'amore enza fine, non ha fine. Love that has no by-end, will know no end.
For my part, I profes no other end in my affections, but your ervice, for which I once gave you my Heart, and now my Hand, that the World may ee whoe ervant is

div.head: To Mr. C. H.
div.p: AS I was going to Church, to keep the Fat, your Letter encounter'd me, and (as good reaon) turn'd my Fat into a Feat; but uch a one, as my Senes were more employ'd on, than my Palat: It rejoyc'd me exceedingly to hear of that ingenious Fl. though I expected to have heard from him before this: But I ee
Non factis equimur omnia qu • loquimur, I am ure, Non paibus aequis.
To thoe Poeies you tell me of, I hall only anwer them with expectation, ince the Intructer of the Art of Poetry tells me;

And to return you omething for your Newes, I can only tell you this, that our treets abound with Grahoppers ilenc'd by our great Hercules; and others, that look like hores
thrown into a certain River in Italy, which are conumed to the bare bones. For your deire to be made merry, I mut confes, Laeta decet laetis pacere cor • a jocis. But for you to deire it of me, eems to be a jet it elf. I doubt to be tedious, and well know Seneca's rule, That an Epitle hould not Manum legentis implere. I onely take time to ubcribe my elf

div.head: To Mr. S. M. at Barbados.
div.p:
I Received your as welcome, as unexpected Letter; of which I will ay, in the words of Seneca that famous Moralit, in an Epitle to his friend Lucilius, Exulto quoties lego Epitolam tuam, implet me bonâ pe: jam non promittit de te, ed pondet. And God forbid that I hould be o uncharitable, as not to believe it: Yet, let me tell you, that without the reality of the actions, it is but a dead letter; nay, 'twill prove a deadly, for, hould you neglect to do, what you there promie, or peak there, more than you do, that very letter will one day rie up in judgment againt you. Pardon my plainnes, and think never the wore of the Truth for my bad language; Truth may many times have bad cloaths, yet has he alwayes a good face. It is a good mark of the moral Philoopher, that heep do not come to their hepherd, and hew him
how much they eat, but make it appear by the fleece that they wear on their backs, and the milk which they give. I will not wrong the harpnes of your judgment by applying the Moral. I have read of two famous Painters, who, to hew their skill, the one drew a bunch of grapes o lively, that he cozened the Birds; the other drew a veil o perfectly over his grapes, that he deceiv'd the Artificer himelf: Could we draw the colour of our good works never o lively, as to cozen every mortal eye, and draw o fine a veil over our evil deeds, as to conceit our elves into a conceit we had none, yet is there an All-eeing eye, to whom the darket ecret is mot appar • nt. Did we but truly conider this, it could not chue but hinder us from committing thoe things we would be ahamed to do in the ight of Man, which we daily doe in the ight of an Omnicient God. Therefore the advice of the Heathen Philoopher, may be made good Chritian practice, who advied to et the conceit of Cato, or like Grave man, alwayes before us, to keep us from doing what might mis-befit their preence. It is a Character of the wicked man, drawn by the Divine hand, that in all his wayes he ets not God before his eyes: There is alo another witnes within us, that can neither be brib'd, not blinded. O te mierum, i contemnis hunc tetem! O have a care to offend that Bird in the breat, that mut one day ing, either your joyful Elogie, or more doleful Dirge. Camd • n our Englih Hitoriographer, tells us of a place in Stafordhire, call'd Wotton, in o doleful a place, under
the barren Hill Weaver, that it is a common Proverb of the neighbours,

lg.l: Wotton under Weaver,
Where God came never.

div.p: But alas! there's no uch place on Earth to be found; yet can I tell a place where his pure Spirit abhors to enter, namely, into a peron contaminated and defiled with in, and thereby made the harbour of Satan, and hatred of the mot High.

Whereas you tell me you are faln to labour, let me comfort you with this, that it is as univeral as unavoidable a Fate laid on us by the mouth of Truth. Man is born to labour, as the parks to fly upward: As if Man and Labour were Termini Convertibiles. But that you take more pleaure now in Labour, than you did before in your Pleaure, it much comforts me, auring me that you are now enible of that which the Romans taught by placing Angina, the goddes of orrow and pain, in the Temple of Volupeia, the goddes of Pleaure; as if that pain and orrow, were the neceary conequences of pleaure: Whereas on the contrary, Goodnes is like the Image of Diana, Pliny peaks of: Intrantes, tritem; Euntes, exhilerantem. How wretched therefore is their condition, that have their portion in this life! Well may we be trangers in this worldly Aegypt, o we may be inhabitants hereafter of the Heavenly Canaan. And you, and I may ay in the words of Seneca, Satis multam temporis parimus, incipiamus nunc in vaa colliger • : We have pent time enough
already, and 'tis high time now to ave the ret and to make the bet of the remnant of our life, becaue we know not how hort it is. It was a wie caution of Eleazer, a Jew, who being demanded, When it would be time to repent, and amend? Anwered, One day before death. And when the other replied, That no man knew the day of his death. Begin then (aid he) even to day, for fear of failing. Hoc proprium inter caetera mala, hoc quoque habet, tultitia proprium, emper incipit vivere, quid et enim turpius, quam enex vivere inipie • s. Give me leave, not to intruct you, but to tell you what counel I deire to practie; for it was an envious dipoition of that Muician, that would play o oftly on his Harp, that none could hear but himelf. Firt, 'Tis my care not too much to indulge my body, as knowing that thoe things the body inclines to mot, are of the world, which is enmity with God; and what the Spirit prompts to mot, mut needs be bet, becaue the Spirit is heavenly, and more of kin to the Deity. Honetum ei vile et, cui corpus nimis charum et; aid one, that knew well what he aid: 'Tis not for nothing that our inward pirit is alwayes mot ad, when our outward man is mot merry. In the econd place, 'Tis my deie to avoid ill company, becaue, as 'tis aid of the Tyrant Mezantius, Corpora corporibus jungebat mortua vivis. In that the Living rather putrefied by reaon of the Dead, but the Dead did not revive by the Living. Such is the nature of man aith St. Gregory, t quoties bonus malo conjungitur, non ex bono malus meliocriter, ed ex malo bono contaminetur.
It is a good caution therefore St. Bernard gives (in his 48th. Serm. in Cantic.) writing upon thee words, As the Lilly among thorns, &c. Vide (aith he) quomodo cautè ambulas inter pinas. I peak this the rather, becaue I preume you walk there among thorns, and I know not whether there be a place there like the treet in Rome, that was called vicus obrius, becaue there was never an Ale-houe in't. And, as Socrates aid of Alcibiades (that miracle of his time) when he aw him among Gallants, I fear not Him, but his Company. Now the number of this Company, hould not be a meanes to make us run with them, but rather to run from them. And to this end, 'tis neceary for a man to be ever reident on his Calling, let he be turn'd out of his Living, or at leat of his well living, for nonreidency. Out of a mans Calling, out of Gods Protection. 'Tis an Apothegme of a late Wit, That he who counts his Calling a Prion, hall at length make a Prion his Calling. But whither do I traggle? Me thinks I hear you ay, as Queen Elizabeth once did to an Embaador, who made a long Oration before her in high terms, She anwer'd him, Expectavi Legatum, Inveni Heraldum; I expected an Embaador, but find an Herald: So, me thinks, I hear you ay, Expectavi Epitolam, Inveni concionem. I mut confes, I might have learn'd o much modety from Rocius the Roman Orator, who was ever mute when he din'd with Cato; and the Thruh never ings, if the Nightingal be by. I might very well have par'd this labour, it being perform'd o well by—yet if I have done amis,
it hall atisfie me, that I did it to atisfie mine own concience. Now might I relaxare animum, recreate your mind, by making you ome mirth with the dicords of our Times; but truly they appear to me a fitter ubject for our tears of orrow, than of mirth. Aure your elf, I had not thus far trangret upon your patience, did you not know me to be

div.head: To Mr. A. E.
div.p:
THough I have not had the happines of late to be o propitiouly be-friended by occaion as to write to you,; yet am I o confident of your wonted ingenuitie, that you will not attribute it to any neglect of mine; which if I were concious to my elf were o, I hould judge it a crime o great, that I hould not forgive my elf. But the truth is, I find more danger in the conveying of Newes, than in the hearing of it: Nay, my miery is, I cannot, or dare not at leat, inform you of more than every Pamphlet can; to uch a height of upition are we now arrived. Beides o barren is each day of Newes, that 'tis not worth doing penance in a heet: yet, becaue you are deirous to know (and I as willing to atisfie your deire) what's done in the Aembly and P. I
will venture to tell you in an old tory. 'Tis this: Mr. Popham, when he was Speaker, and the lower Houe had ate long, and done, in effect, nothing, comming one day to Queen Elizabeth, She aid to him, Now, Mr. Speaker, what hath pas'd in the lower Houe? He anwered, If it pleae your Majety, even weeks. You need fear no danger in this, for 'tis Nothing; and the Treaty is come to as much, both Parties being not like to meet, tanding till at their former ditance. This was prettily Emblem'd by two Sphaerical bodies, touching onely in Puncto with this Motto, Pungere pount, pacificari non pount.

Thus, Sir, you ee, amidt thee dusky clouds, Friendhip dares mingle flames in a Convex, though not in a direct line. Acertain your elf of this, That as it hall ever rejoyce me to hear of your health; o it hall be my endeavour alwayes to be

div.head: To my Father.
div.p:
AFter the remembrance of my duty, which at all times wants not in my will, though ometimes in my power. I lately aw Mr. M. but cannot tell you whether with greater joy, or grief. It rejoyc'd me exceedingly to hear of your health, but grieved me more to hear of my Mothers grief, for a fale information, that
I was a Sectary, and a Malignant. Give me leave therefore to ay omething, whereby I may at once recover her right opinion, and my reputation. And firt for the Sectary, Should I ay nothing, my practice were enough to tetifie, that I do as much hun their Companies, as hate their Tenents. I count them as moles and warts, nay, wens in the face of the Body Politick, which, if not timely lanced, will in time not onely deface, but detroy our Common Mother the Church: Neither do I love to run into thoe by-wayes of Sects and Schimes, but rather keep the afer road of the Churches practice. There is but one Way, one Truth; and I account all thoe (not one better than another, but) all out of that one Way, all oppoites to that one Truth. I eteem them but as wilde beats broken into the Vineyard of the Church, the hedge of our Government being pull'd up; but as nettles and weeds, (own and water'd by that envious man) grown up to uch an height, that will in time, not onely o're-top, but o'return the good corn. They are true vipers, a beat, whereof Naturalits report, that firt the he-viper biteth off the he-vipers head, and o he conceives with young, and thoe young g • aw a paage through their dams belly; o that their life is the death of both Father and Mother, as I may o peak. This tory I onely relate, not apply, the Time and Times will not permit me. But that thee Vermin do daily encreae, is as true as lamentable; and they go on with that impudence, that they dare to quote Authority for their fale actions. If this be not enough
to evince my integritie in this particular, I here protet, that I am o far from falling, or leaning after any of thee wayes, that I utterly abhor and detet them. I come now, to wipe off that other aperion of a Malignant; a term that hath as much implicity as malice in't: For indeed, it is a name fitter for the Devil, than a Chritian; nay, the Devil, in French, is call'd The Malignant Spirit: And, according to the true ignification of the word in our language, it ignifies one that bears malice, or grudge to another. Now, if this be the thing is meant, I thank God, I bear no man in the world the leat grudge or pight; therefore, in that regard, I am no Malignant: But, if this be not their meaning, for my part, I doubt of knowing it, whilt they are ignorant of it themelves. Well, I ee I mut, like children, frame a Baby of clouts to hoot at, fancie a conceit in my brain, which I mut confute. If then, by a Malignant, is meant one that oppoeth the Parliament; be it known, that I never, in the leat word or action, did, or will do any thing to adopt me to be a Malignant: Or, if by it is intended uch a one, as will not run with the giddy multitude, that run before they are ent, and are for that (with les implicity, though as much malice, term'd Round-heads) that is, one that in ever turning, is never etled. And, indeed, I know not how they hould otherwie but wander in the Labyrinth of Errors, not following the Cloud of the Churches practice: whereas, it is the Character of a good man, to be like the Timber of Noah's Ark, which was (not round,
but) four-quare, and would, therefore, not turn, but abide firm: If to be o, be to be a Malignant, I care not to profes my elf one. It is with men in thee Times, as I have oberv'd in a Company of Souldiers, upon any motion, thoe that are skilful and tried Souldiers, it is but taking a tep with one foot, whilt the other tand • fat, and the motion is performed; whereas uch as are ignorant, run to and fro, perplexing themelves, and putting the whole company out of order, before they get into theirs. So it is with us, we move not without the word of Command, and then we hall, without moletation, face about, if our Leaders think fit: Holding in this particular, the Politicians rule; However we admire what's pat, to ubmit to what's preent. It were eaie to be infinite in this dicoure. To hut up all, when I know better what it is to be a Malignant, I hall be ready to give an account of my judgment and practice. In the mean time, I beeech you to believe, that I am neither Sectary, nor Malignant: But

div.head: To Mr. E. B.
div.p: GIve me leave to tell thee a truth in the words of that witty Martial, to his Friend Pricus.

lg.l:
Cum te non noem, dominum, regem
que vocabam,
Cum bene te novi, tam mihi Pricus eris.

div.p: I will not venture at a Tranlation, let it hould loe by't. But let me tell thee, I uppoe more friendhip in that Monoyllable, than all the welling colours of abued Rhetorick. 'Twere a needles Tautologie, to tell thee thy Letter was welcome to me; Diu deiderata dulcius veniunt. Thou dot enhance my value of them by their carcity. But, for mine, alas, poor ex tempore things! I make them as common, as they are eaie; and yet am careles of my credit, that I may not eem careles of my friend. Thou needt not beg uch a trouble, that is as certain as the Moons coure. I am glad thou hat got a witty Companion there, for 'twas long ince (here) turn'd out of the Line of Communication. Commend me to L C. L. and tell him, his name hould peak him my friend; for, really, I am more beholding to that name, than any one I know. But I need not goe o far about, 'tis ufficient he is thy friend, and then he cannot chue but be mine; for, among friends, all things are common, and why not friends too? Really, I am o taken with that witty companion (and I know thou wilt not be-lye him) that if he will honour me with his name in a piece of paper, I will keep it as a Relick. And if I have run into an aburdity, let my fault be excuable, in that it is in relation to that thou callet Wit; and

lg.l: If Cloris do at upon her face,
The fault is in her Looking-glas.

div.p: But for Newes, I know your eyes out-trip my pen, and, me thinks, I ee thee firt look for the Newes at the latter end; that thou readt my Letters, like Hebrew, backward. Yet, this time, thou wilt onely finde, what's no Newes, that I am

div.head: To Mr. C. F.
div.p:
REolving, not alwayes to act the Eccho onely in ingle Anwers, to your welcome Letters. No longer ago than the lat night (my thoughts were wholly imploy'd upon a more pleaing object than leep it elf) in a erious contemplation of you, my Second-elf: The reult of my thought, after a full conultation, were, to viit you by a more real Proxie than my rambling fancie: For, though I have read of a Gentleman, who, going to the Spittle, to hear one of thoe annual Sermons, it eemes his lownee had hut him out of all hope of hearing, and
almot eeing the Preacher; till, remembring he had a Perpective glas in his pocket, thereby drawing the Preacher nearer to his ight (to prove a communitie of the Senes) the tory tells me, he heard him audibly. I never tryed the experiment, but I dare affirm, that by the Perpective-glas of Fancy, I have both viibly and audibly enjoy'd your wihed preence. You know the old maxime is, Ubi amat, ibi animat: 'Tis therefore no Paradox to affirm, that I have often been in the New Forret, (which your weet preence converts into a Paradie) although I was never there. But I fear, this is no better than Crambe bis co • ta, and o naueous, I quit it therefore, and return to my firt purpoe, which was to tell you, that your lat letter really prevented my reolved intentions, which yet I am (and ever hall be) glad of, to be thus intercepted, as profeing it to be more proper to my weak pen to be Repondent; which you will not doubt of, if you conider, that Trumpeters love to ound near Fordy places, where the Eccho ues to be mot olvibly Repondent: But I talk of an Anwer, and return none.

In brief then, thus: I begin where you end, and here deire to erect an Altar of thanks to the protecting providence, that hielded you (and in you my elf) from that firt imminent, then eminent danger; as knowing the truth of that aying, That Bleings often ravel out, for want of h •• iming by thankefulnes. I cannot peak my mind fuller, than he has done to my hand: Now, to your deire, I cannot yet return you
other anwer, than that the utmot of my endeavours were long ince devoted to your commands: And for—I expect him daily in Town; when he is, I hall acquaint him with your intentions to him. I hear that he is already turn'd Predicant; me thinks 'tis omething too oon, to pend his mall tock of parts, which, I fear, will make him Mendicant. But I had forgot to tell you, that I cannot but apprehend, that Providence in your late delivery, hath plainly given you a Caveat, that you, at leat your Credit, will be mot afe in your own houe. Prethee pardon me if my affection make me thus (if not too) bold, to tell th •• , that you betray that precious jewel of your credit to the rape of every felonious tongue, which would be far more afe in your own Houe. I could ay more, but verbum at, &c. Take it as the counel of

closer.signed: Your really endeared Friend, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. B.
div.p:
IF there be one, whom the neceitie of my Stars compel me to love, 'tis thee: But beides this, I find my elf entangl'd with a double tye; firt, of thine unparallel'd Love, as the tree; and now a gift, as the fruit of that: And, how willingly am I imprioned with thee fetters!
which, certainly if I could, I would not break; a three-fold cord is not eaily crack't. Well, I acknowledge my elf, not onely thy Debtor, but thy Prioner, and count it my onely Liberty. Expect no uch golden-mouthed Letter from me as yours was, nor any ilver-tongu'd Complements Believe me, where I ee mot complement, I uppoe leat friendhip. Let me onely affirm, that though our bodies are evered, our ouls till meet; though we are divided, we are not divorced; but like this Virgin-widow, till flourih, though in the All deflowring Winter. Take it therefore, not as a Token but an Embleme of our Love. I preume it cannot be unwelcome; if not for the Senders, yet for the Author, and the Subjects ake: And for the other, if there be a Sympathy in Friendhip (as I believe there is) then cannot that be unpleaing to you, which was o uperlative pleaing unto me. However, I have aimed onely at a upplying you with what (I conceive) your Countrey is defective in. Sure I am, the offence cannot be great (if it be o) the gift it ell being o mall; epecially from

div.head: To Mr. R. R.
div.p: WIth how much joy I received your exquiite Epitle, is eaier for you to imagine, than me to relate. You know me too well to expect the like Return from me; yet hall I deire to follow you,
And to pay you your Golden Royals (if the comparion be not too mean) with my farthing language: Yet, hoping it may be Current among friends; for, I dare aure you, they carry the tamp of the Heart.

lg.l: My Tongue's not tip't with Complements, which be
But like green leaves to skreen Hypocriie,
With words as fale as fair. Who Fucus layes
pon her face, It's homelines betrayes.
Nor skill I of the powerful charms of Art,
But I can peak the Language of the Heart.

div.p:
I admire others Neatnes, but practice Reality, which I eteem o much the more, as I find it les ued. I think the Publique Faith has devoured all fidelity, and the Sword cut that (uppoed) indioluble knot of friendhip, cancell'd the Bond of all Obligations. Henceforth, hall they be onely Names, and ucceedings Ages not know what they meant. But to your
Letter, and my Anwer; which when I conider I cannot but apply that proper Speech of the deep Putean to his Friend; Scribere ego poenè impudentiam, ilere tu delictum ceneas. Yet know I not of any letter that lies by me unanwer'd; for, I hold it a breach of the Articles of Friendhip, not to be punctual in Returns of this Nature. If you accue me of breach of promie, I cannot but tax you of delay in yours; though I count this but Billinggate policie. Proceed, then, my Friend, and let our friendhip be a Particular Exception from the General Rule of the worlds falhood. Our weet Flower is tranplanted to a remote oyl, near the Ile of Wight. Pardon me, if I be covetous of your learned lines, to upply the vacuum of his abence: Nor is this covetounes unlawful; for I dare pronounce it (in Seneca's tyle) Avaritia Honeta. And, hoping your fair Cham will not didain the ilent whipers of a hallow Forde aure your elf, you hall not hereafter complain for want of this kind of trouble: Although, to deal ingeniouly with you (as I would have my friends to deal with me) I have o long dicontinued this practice, that my pen is grown blunt, and my ink thick: But ome of your Academick Flames, may contribute much to the ublimating of my etled fancy, which hall wholly run in Channels of your commands: For I am

div.head: To L. C. L
div.p:
YOu are pleaed to tyle me your Honoured Friend, which I mut confes to be too high a tyle for my low deerts to climbe, did I not conider, that my Honour conits onely in your Honouring me with o unmerited a Title. 'Tis a Maxime, Honor non et in honoranti, non in h •••
rato. Sir, I protet I intended nothing that might occaion a bluh; if it were, it was more proper for my elf: yet, having uch a mirrour, I was bold, againt the rules of Maiden-modety, to look a tranger in the face. And truly, though I have no skill in Palmitry, yet, by thoe fair lines of your Hand, I dare, without fear of flatterie, tell you, that Ned nothing wronged you; for, I aure you, I dicover in them a great deal of ingenuitie. But, to cat off all terms of ditance, that we may meet in a cloer conjunction, believe it, Sir, in plain Englih, that I love you with an implicite love; and hall count my elf not a little happy, if thoe eeds of friendhip, own in Winter, may flourih in the Spring, and out-date time it elf. This hall not be wanting, either in the deires, or endeavours of

closer.signed: your as real as unknown Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. B.
div.p:
I Should carce believe there were uch a thing in rerum naturâ, as what we call a Friend, did not you come in, and convince me that you are one; and, what's more, Mine. Goe on and let the world ee, there is yet living that flame of antique friendhip, which the Ancients boat, and we depair of. I heartily thank thee for thy lat letter, though by the hand of a left-handed man-midwife it mi-carried in the delivery; and (as bearing the fate of the Author) is gone on Pilgrimage as far as Exeter. I much lament the los, and hould more did I not think the kinder Fates did it out of love to me, let I hould have perihed with too much joy. Hat thou not heard? I am ure I have read of many, that have been mothered with too much Happines. Alexander, when hearing that he was at once made Father of a Son, and Conquerour of his Enemies, deired the gods to qualifie it with ome cros. It were eaie to be copious in this ubject, did I not write to one, that may read to me in Hitory: And, truly, my lat letter had the fate to be out-dated long before I could get conveyance for it; wherein it much reembled the worm (in Pliny) called Multipoda, or many feet, and yet hath a very low pace. Ned, I wih thee often here, yet am I never abent from thee: For, ince that friendhip
incorporated us, it is no Paradox to affirm, Hoc memorabile et, ego tu um, tu es ego, unanimi umus. Neither mayt thou think, that ditance, or cold can under me, but I hall burn in friendhip by an Anteperiteis. Things are now at the Height, that we expect a udden crack: I will not make my paper guilty of relating any of it, you will ee it in Print. What effects 'twill produce, I will not Propheie: But you know, The Philoopher that looked too high, fell into the ditch. Farewel, and continue to Love

div.head: To M. C. F.
div.p: MY lat was in anwer to yours of the 18th of September; ince when, I have been forced to recreate my fancie, with thoughts of thee my econd elf, as Dido, in the Poet, did her Aeneas:
Which I find well paraphraed to my hand, thus:

lg.l: Whilt abence ever'd them apart,
She aw, and heard him in her heart.

div.p:
If my thoughts were o atiated with a meer
what would your real Letters doe? which I know to be fraught with profitable pleaure, the perquiites of a true Epitle: And though mine be not equal to ballance yours, yet I hall endeavour to recompence in number, what they want in weight.

lg.l: Yours are rich wares, mine poor baggatels,
Yours Orient Gems, mine rugged oyter-hels.
Yet Tokens, with the true tamp, may
Be currant, though of bae allay.

div.p:
Sir, flattery is no part of friendhip; Non amo quemquam nii offendam, aid a wie Heathen. Give me therefore leave to tell you, that you are too careles of your credit: I hear you have thereby lot much ground in your P. affections, which I could wih by Mr. E's example, you would be careful of; for I can aure you, in thee times, the peoples affections are but a fickle foundation to build ones hopes on: 'Tis a thouand pities, that the bet ground hould be the dirtiet, and the bet work-men the wort husbands; epecially one of your colour, who ought to walk not onely catè, but cau • è. You know who ayes, A Miniters Doctrine is like a candle, if not guarded by the lanthorn of a cautious life, will oon be blown out by the wind of detraction. The Egyptians Hierogliphick God by an open eye: He is totus oculus; and I am perwaded, there is no colour o much in his eye as black Enough of this: I am not willing to run into the common errour of the Times, to uurp Moes Chair. If my zeal to your welfare has already committed a trepas, let it be ufficient,
that it was out of perfect friendhip. It is aid of Geron (that famous Frenchman) that he took not content in any thing o much, as in a plain and faithful reproof of his friend: And, it is the note of that venerable Bede, that Semper optimos apientum ut dictum majorum aucultent, aliquando minorum. And I will not onely uffer, but thank you, to deal o with me. Concerning Newes, I am of the Italians mind, That nulla nuova, is bona nuova; the leat newes is the bet newes. Take it briefly thus: His Majetie doth lay aide his own Interet wholly, that He may (if poible) comply with his Conquerors; that I may truly apply to him that aying of an undaunted Captain, lighting the inulting braves of him that took him, thus: Thou holdet thy Conquet great, in overcomming me, but mine is far greater, in overcomming my elf. 2. Death is grown as inatiable a Country C. M. for he hath of late wallow'd all the living creatures, men, women, dogs, cats, &c. in a whole Citie in Spain, not leaving one alive to relate it. But I forgot your buines. I mention'd it to Sir Ch. who is no Orderly man, nor willing to receive it: I have mention'd it to others, with as much earnetnes as you can imagine, but the great ditance of place, makes them not meet my deires. Though I have ued this (as I thought perwaive) argument, The farther out of ight, the more afe: For I am confident, many a mans Good Living, and not his bad life, has entitl'd him to a Prion. Therefore count I you wie, in equetring your elf, to avoid a Sequetration. Sir, I hope you will
judge of my endeavours by the ucces, but believe me to be

closer.signed: Yours as real as obliged Friend and Servant, T. F.

lg.l: NOw mut my wearied fancy undertake
A tedious task: to eek I know not where,
Whom I hall find, alas! I know not when:
Yet on I mut, bound by a thred of love,
Which happily may prove a clew to guide
Me in this wide Maeandring Labyrinth.
So have I een (as groping in the dark)
An arrow hot at randome, hit the mark.
On then, my Pilgrim-pen, mask'd in the weeds
Of blacket orrow; and with big woln eyes,
Seek him thou cant not ee: make hils & dales
Reound with thy loud voicing of that name,
Whoe Eccho tands in competition with,
And far out-vies the muick of the Spheres:
At whoe ole ound my duller enes dance
A Galliard; but that failing, lifeles tand.
Like that trange Lake, that whilt the muick ounds,
Doth flow in meaures; and then ebb as fat,
When that doth ceae: Or like the tones & trees
That danc'd attendance on Orpheus Harp.
Strike thou blet Lyre, and with thy muick call
My orrow-fetter'd enes from the grave
Of lumpih grief; which Reurrection mut
Only be wrought by thine all-charming pen:
Or ele, as great Augutus, in a kis,
Surrender'd up his latet breath unto
His dearet Livia; thereby making her
Sole Heir to that urviving part, which long,
By tranmigration, lived in her breat.
So mut my tarved Hopes urrender to
Thoe long and fierce aailants, which beiege
Me, with their troops of fears, and pale depair,
If not relieved by thy timely quill.
But fear, like to a cunning enemy,
Doth labour to perwade my jealous thoughts,
That thou art not in a capacitie.
Now, therefore quickly, my Terpander, come
With thy Harmonious layes, allay thee tirs,
And civil broyls, in my perplexed thoughts,
For fear they mutinie, and me betray.
Delay not, now, to give my fears the lye:
For, pinning out the thred of time, will make
But a ad woof to cloath my orrows with,
And turn my Tragick vere to Elegies.
And thus my many feet have almot run
My fancie out of breath: Here I mut ret,
And Tantalize with weary expectation,
Till mother-time (that's gravidated with
A dubious iue) be deliver'd of
A maculine, white boy of mirth, or with
A female Negro of grief; which will be
Strange welcome to

div.head: To Mr. S. M.
div.p:
IT is reported by Pliny, that Apelles, that famous Painter, was wont, when he had finihed any piece of work, or painted table, to et it forth in ome open place, or thorow-fare, to be een of Paengers; and himelf would lie cloe behind it to hearken what faults were found in it; in that, preferring the judgment of the vulgar before his own, imagining they would pie more narrowly, and cenure his faults more everely than himelf could. Having expoed this homely piece to publick view, I have, with Apelles, li • n uneen, and to that purpoe, unknown, that thereby I might the better learn what others opinions were thereof: Not truting to my own, as knowing that Ely was not the onely indulgent Father to his own Off-pring. And, as it was his aym to relie upon the judgment of the mot judicious (of which number, I eteem your elf none of the leat) it had been preented to you in the firt place, had I not been deterred, as not daring to approach the corching rayes of your everer cenure: Like him, that being in the preence of Augutus the Roman Emperor (who had a piercing Eagle-eye) turn'd away his face; the Emperour demanding the reaon why he did o? He replied, Quia fulmen oculorum tuorum ferre non poum. The like may I affirm: Ter
limen tetigi, ter
que recedi. Oft have I been about it, and as oft repuled by the conciounes of mine own unworthines: Yet have I, at length, adventured, in confidence that you have, as well charity to pardon, as judgment to find out errours. With uch a hope therefore, that you will skreen your everer cenure with a veil of charitie, I have, at length, preumed this into your preence: The rather, becaue I do hereby but return you the Hony, made from the various flowers of your own garden; where, I hope, I have not (as ome that do, Spinas libroru • colligere) weeded books; but crop't their bloomes, and yet left never the les behind me. Naturalits (thoe Clerks of Natures cloet) report of the Peach-tree, that it receives the qualitie of the oyl where it is planted. In Peria it is poyonous, elewhere nutrimental: Such is the condition of our nature, that it ever reteines the avour of that liquor wherewith it was eaoned in its youth. It hath been my care, and is my hope, that I may one day affirm that of the Philoophers cholar, Me mihi melior reddidit, quàm accepit. Another obligation there is alo, which hath occaioned in me this preent boldnee, and to you this preent trouble: Tha • you are one that do not caenam ervire, but are truly enible of the irregular actions of thoe, who would be thought the line of Truth. I think the Poet Propheied of our age, when he complain'd,

lg.l: Victa jacet pietas, & cedit viribus aequum.
Non metuunt leges, tat pro ratione voluntas.
Omnia pro tempore, nihil pro veritate.

div.p: Comines complaines, that many mens Offices and Lands were taken from them for running away (in the Battle between Lewis the 11th. and the Burgundians) and given to thoe that ran nine miles farther. But I have made too long a Parentheis in your more erious occaions; and, me thinks, I hear Apelles his Ne utor ultra crepidam, rounded in my ear. I here ceae, though not from being

div.head: To Mr. C. F.
div.p:
YOur Letter of the 2d. of November, came afe; and though late, yet at lat I return you an anwer: For, though the Apotle aith, it is the duty of a good ervant < in non-Latin alphabet > not anwering again: yet I think, it is no part of a good friend. Whereas you tell me, it is no Newes to hear of the theft of felonious tongues, but that it were a greater wonder, if they hould turn honet, it puts me in mind of a facetious peech of the grave Cato: When one asked counel of him oberly, what harm he thought
boaded him, becaue Rats had gnawn his Hoe? He anwered with this jet: That it was a trange thing to ee that; but it had been much more trange, If his Hoe had devoured the Rats. Now, to be erious. If you will needs know from whence that moak came, I mut tell you, it aroe from the New Forret, but I dicover'd it at London; and finding it might forerun a torm, I was bold to fore-warn you of it, becaue, you know, Praemonitus, praemunitus. Neither ought you (I uppoe) to depie it, (epecially comming from a hand aimed only at your afety. Great hips have been cat away by a little leak unlook'd to. I remember the Fable that the Butterfly asked the Owle, How he hould deal with the fire that had corched her wings? Who counelled her, not to behold o much as its moak And, becaue you will know of me where this vapour did beat in; Truly, I was informed, you were like to ruine your fortune, and that by one whom I know you eteem your friend. Therefore was I bold to advie you to provide an Ark againt the Deluge: Not like the merry Scholar in Chaucer, that he might lie with the Carpenters wife. But I talk idle. Really, I had not aid any thing, had I not been confident, you would take it with the right hand, as I gave it; and the rather, that I might thereby engage you to deal with me in the ame manner: For, Hoc officium (as I take it) is Maximum beneficium. And now, would not my very excue increae my fault, I would Apologize for my (I fear) too tedious prolixitie. I will onely add, that I hall
be very glad your more urgent buinee would permit you to punih me in the ame kind: Who am, not queint, nor quick now, but till

postscript.head: Pote.
postscript.p: The Fratres Gladiferi are till predominant. People were never o poor, nor never o brave, as if they would be proud by an Antiperitais.

div.head: To Mr. J. W.
div.p:
THat you accot me with the name of Friend, I am not a little joyful, but more to be yours. It is a term ued by all, undertood by few, but practied by none, that I can find. But I will not build my credit upon the ruines of others: It is ufficient, that I can boat of this, that I am yours; and I hope you will till deign to be mine. And now Sir, I hall return an anwer to the everal particulars of my Letter, Ordine quique uo. Firt, You tell me you are olitary and Hermetical. I could hardly forbear envying of your Happinee: 'Tis a life I as much deire, as I little hope for. But, Sive pluit Jupiter, aut non pluit, non omnibus placet. And o I quit that, and am arrived at your deire, which to me is a ufficient command. 'Tis
Newes you deire, and it would have been Newes indeed, if you had not. In brief then, Kent is, for the general, quiet, onely ome excepted places: But, to make you laugh, Prophet, Hunt, the other day, at a full Exchange, came crowding into the middle, with a joynttool upon his head; which, when he had et down, he tood up on, and cried, O yes, if any man in the Town, or Country, can tell me what good the Parliament hath done thee eight yeares, let him come, and peak, and I'll it down and hear him: and, that you may know the truth of it, he is in Bridewell for his labour. And now I meet with your Cordial, which is Cordiality, well may we invent new terms to ignifie realitie by; for I think, hereafter the old will not be undertood. I have remembred you to as many as I uppoe your friends, and have only in return, Mr. Th. E's ervice. The ret, not concluding you aymed at them in particular, ince you onely hot at Rovers in the general. The econd part of your commands, I have performed onely upon your welcome Letter, and have ent this to kis your hands. If this may contribute any thing to the delivery of your expectation, I hall count your acceptance a ufficient reward. But I will not add feathers to the wings of time, which I know you put to lawful uury. Here then I take my Ret, and reolve to remain,

closer.signed: yours ready to erve you, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. W. L.
div.p:
LEt my Hand now peak for my Heart, and know that the lines of the one, is the language of the other. But I will not tire thee with a preamble, let it might be upected for a piece of Rhetorical ininuation; but abruptly tell my errand, without repect o much as to a civil Complement. Will.
