How really I am obliged to thee in my affections, my engagements thereto, by thy many multiplyed courteies, may ufficiently tetifie: And for that reaon (to make hort work) I am reolved to give thee that, for which, from another I hould have expected, and happily have had a price. You cannot imagine me o little Man, or that to cot me o little paines, but that I mut conceive it worth as much as every puny Pamphlet; or (grant it were not) think me o imple, as to run the Gantelope of the worlds cenure for Nothing. Yet is not any, or all of thee trong enough to draw me from dipening with mine own profit, or credit, when they tand in competition with a friend. In brief therefore, if you can imagine it worth your acceptance, or but enough to trike off the leat notch from the tally of mine engagements, 'tis yours. I refer it, and my elf, wholly to your dipoe. Some (you cannot but think) I mut
betow on ome friends; and I hould be loth to buy, what I did not ell, or have and mut give away. My hort tay here, will not admit any long delay. Let thy anwer be like my time, and my departure, hort and hortly. I am till

div.head: To Mr. J. W.
div.p:
FOr o I preume to call you, becaue, if your Tongue and Heart were Relatives when you wrote your lat kind Letter, you were pleaed to dihonour your elf with that Title. To lay aide all terms of ditance, that we may cloe, and mingle oules in the flame of friendhip, pardon me hereafter, if I lay aide the name of Mr. as incompatible with that of friendhip. But let me tell you, that I can carce think your invective againt Complements to be real, ince you cannot compleat your Letter without them. Tully once told a Lawyer, pleading a bad caue: Tu nii fingeres ne ic ageres. For your Complements you betow on me and mine, I hall onely aure you, you truck the ball to an ill hand, if you look for a rebound. Your quibble upon my name, would have pleas'd me exceedingly, had you not married (and o marr'd) it with o di-agreeing an Epethite,
as to call that deep, whoe very name peaks it but hallow: So that by tyling me deep, you have taken away my name of Forde. But if you will have my Etymologie, it is this; Vadum à vadendo, from going; and o it tells you, that I hall never be wearie of travelling in your ervice. Or, if you will, it is < in non-Latin alphabet > , trajicere, to pas over, and o I pas it by. That that poor draught has atisfied your thirt, I am not a little glad; but it eems, it was of the nature of alt water, which makes the drinker but the drier. And, truly, I quetion not but you are, if you keep your promie, and not drink till the return of this, which I wih may be anwerable to your expectation. For your complaint of want of Books, I conceive it needles in you, who are a walking Library. Now will I relate what they here tell for truth. One Rolph, (omething near Ravillac) a Shoomaker, had plotted to have brought his Majetie to his Lat; but (as Heaven would have it) he prov'd but a Cobler at it, and o was dicovered. Your Letter which mine was big with, is afely delivered, by

closer.signed: Your Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. B.
div.p: FInding friendhip to be as cold as the weather, we thought to repel it, by celebrating this preent time with the remembrance of thee; when we turned thy Aurum Palpabile into Aurum Potabile; and I dare affirm it was Cordial. We did remember thee Pleui • poculis; and becaue two make no muick, we engaged two or three other Conorts, to compleat our Harmony. And that thou mayt ee, we did not only drink like irrational animals, I will tell thee (if my memory fail me not) the Original of Healths. When the Danes Lorded it over our Kingdome, (whence by corruption they were termed Lurdanes) they were quartered in everal Houes, (a word, I mut confes, I undertood not when I read it firt; but ince, the Times have intructed me with a witnes.) They were o imperious, that no man thought himelf ecure in their preence: and knowing the advantage men have of one that is lifting his hand to his mouth in drinking, they ued (which after was a cutome) to drink to one at the Table, who was thereby engaged to be their pledge, or urety for their afety, whilt they were drinking and ome of our Countries do till retein the original, in anwering Sir, I pledge for you. To this I doubt not but the witty Waller alludes in his Poems, where he ings,

lg.l: Wine fills the veins, and Healths are undertood,
To give our friends a title to our blood:
Who naming me, doth warm his courage o,
Shews for my ake what his bold hand would do.

div.p:
Newes is o confued, that I know not where to begin; yet where hould I, but at home: and that's in the Church-yard, that you may know In nomine Domini incipit omne malum. Our yard is a place of Rendezvouz, a Bridewel, an Execution-place, &c. Here the gallant Pitcher went to Pot: I mean, was broken, by the merciles blind bullets; or (if thou wilt have it in plain terms) was hot to death. I could not name him without an Elegie, but that I think my Mue is run away, to eek a better Mater in thee hard times. And indeed, the Mues may well be Maids, for they are commonly farthet off, when mot intreated. Mary was once the hate and burthen of the City, and the name's but Anagrammatiz'd; but they are as weary of their Phyicians, as they were before of their dieae. I cannot reemble our rich Citizens better, than to ome Hogs I have read of, that were o fat, that Mice made nets in their buttocks, and they felt them not. But now they have pretty well eaten through their fat, and are come to the quick, and now they begin to be enible of them. Here are ome deperate Members, that gape wide to devour their Head, and there is nothing can recue him but a miracle. And now, I hope, the largenes of my Letter will excue me from adding any more
No wonder my Letters are o big, being o old before they come to hand. Let me onely add that I am till

closer.signed: Thine, uque ad aras, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. F.

lg.l: Friend, or Brother, chue you whether,
Natures bonds are trong in either.

div.p:
THough I never knew the happines of a Brother, I count that want infinitely upplyed, if not out-gone, by the adoption of ome friends: of which number, I need not now tell you, you hold a chief place. You may eaily imagine how welcome your lat was to me, the rather, becaue it aured me of your, not onely receiving, but accepting mine; which (eriouly) I doubted, when afterward I read Seneca's Caveat: Vide, non tantum an verumit quod dicis, ed an ille cui dicitur veri patiens it. But, believe me, it was pure friendhip that praecipitated my pen; and in friendhip, thoe are great faults, that are not venial. And now it lies in your power only, to make thoe poor papers a true glas (as you are pleaed to call them) in a reflection of my own face, without partiality; and indeed, this was the chief intent of my deigne at firt: and you cannot think
how I will • ug it, nay, out-dote Narcius himelf. I hope, though you have entertained the Graces, you have not quite cahier'd the Mues: For, though the Times be hard, yet they are no chargeable retinue. But, I know you expect ome Newes: and truly, here is Nova, & ina • dita rerum facies. Here, they that count Stables as good as Churches, have made our Churches Stables. But enough of this, and for this time, when I have tyled my elf

div.head: To Mr. L. C. L.
div.p:
THe lat claue of your lat ingenious Letter, has proved a Propheie: For, you are pleas'd to tell me, that you long for my anwer, and truly I have made it a long anwer, though a hort letter: and that, till it come, every day's a moneth; and I am ure, it will be a moneth every day e're you have it: yet be confident, it was not for want of love, but want of leiure. You know, Parvus amor loquitur, ingens tupet. Great love (like great grief) mut move gradatim. Sir, that you tell me, ince you aw my lines, you are grown womanih, and long for a view. I dare not think it flatterie, becaue from a friend; yet am I not a little proud on't. Thus have we the happines (like Princes) to
wooe by Picture, and wed by Proxie. For though I have hitherto been an Atheit to female love, yet have I thus often wooed, and as often won a econd-elf; for o's a friend, as well as a wife, and the marriage of the minds, is no les firm and honourable, than that of the body. And I will aure you, Sir, I am more ambitious of that happy viit you are pleaed to promie me, than ome Amorett •
would be of his Mitris. In the mean-time, I hall hope to ee you in thoe lively Images of your ingenious elf. To thoe unmerited Encomiums you are pleaed to betow on my unworthy Poeme, I will anwer nothing, ave that I will make it an argument of your love to me; for 'tis a Symptome.

lg.l: Quae minimè pulchra unt, e •
Pulchra videntur Amanti.

div.p: If now you expect any Newes, I mut deceive your expectation; for here is none, ave what you will ee by the Printed Papers: and truly, I am afraid this cold weather will uher in a hotter Summer. You'l pell my meaning, though in a myterie; becaue, Plura literis committere, nec vacat, nec tutum et. But that I am

closer.signed: Your mot affectionate Friend. T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. F.
div.p: I Received your late (I think lat) Letter, fraught with Flowers: and, credit me, with as welcome a countenance, as we behold thoe early violets, the firt fruits of the Spring, after a long and tedious Winter. I heartily congratulate your entrance into the Bond of Wedlock, for 'tis a bond, though a weet one, and quetion not but you have a fit yoke-fellow. Now are you a Compleat Man, which the Rabbins ay no man is, till he have his female Rib retor'd him, which before he wanted. That you have match'd one of my name, I cannot account any other than an act of the Divine Providence, to make our Friendhip grow up into a Brotherhood: So that now it hall be no longer as you ay,

lg.l: Friend and Brother, chue you whether,
But Friend and Brother both together.

div.p:
Hereafter hall I be not a little proud of my name, that it may be erviceable to the production of uch weet Flowers as your elf. Wonder not now, that in tead of greeting you with an Epithalamium, I grace you with an Elegie. Indeed, I mut acknowledge, that mourning is not fit for a Wedding garment, yet mot fit for me at this preent, being really enible of the death of the general Father of our Country,
and fearful of the death of my own dear Father in particular. And to expres my elf in the words of the Poet,

lg.l: Hei mihi difficile et imitari gaudia fala,
Difficile et triti fingere mente jocum.

div.p: Give me leave onely to preent your Wife, my Siter, with my as hearty, as inviible alutes; and o I take my leave of you both, with that of the witty Catullus:
div.q: —Boni Conjuges bone vivite, & munere aiduo valentem exercite juventam.
div.p: This is the hearty wih of him that is proud to be accounted

closer.signed: Your glad (though orrowful Friend and Brother, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. B.
div.p:
AS I was going to write a Letter to thee, came thine to me; and, believe me, with no little welcome. I thank thee for thy Letter, more for thy Veres, but mot of all, for thy contant pereverance in friendhip. Goe on, and let us (if poible) draw the knot of
our love yet fater. I dare preume thou wilt, and for me, may the Mues, or what's more, the Graces hate me, when I ceae to love thee: For thy uperlative wihes, may they rebound a thouand, times multiplied upon thine own head. But for the particular of Trading, truly, I hall chue (in thee (times) to it down, rather than et up; not daring to put to Sea, while this Tempet lats. Me thinks, we wander till as in a night of mieries, and yet ee no Heperus of any comfort appear, that might be the welcome Harbinger of a more wih'd for than expected Sun: We till like (the Andabates) fight blindfolded. No ooner has two Parties conquer'd one, but they oppoe each other: and yet, as if the Tragedie were ended, the Souldiers have routed the Players. They have beaten them out of their Cock-pit, baited them at the Bull, and overthrown their Fortune. For thee exploits, the Alderman (the Anagram of whoe name makes A Stink) moved in the Houe, that the Souldiers might have the Players cloaths given them. H. M. tood up, and told the Speaker, that he liked the Gentlemans motion very well, but that he feared they would fall out for the Fools Coat. But you know who has Acted that part, and may very well merit that, among the ret of his gifts. Ask me no more for Newes, for now I am careles how things pas, as etting down this reolution, that nothing can happen well, nor wore than has. Being tun'd with that fatal blow, I am not enible of any thing ele: only that I am till

div.head: To L. C. L.
div.p: LEaving the incloed to peak for it elf, and indeed the mutenes of grief is Eloquence. I am orry that our infant-friendhip hould finde o udden a grave of forgetfulnes; but I hope it is not dead, though leeping: Let this be as the Trump to awaken it to a Reurrection: For, aure your elf, it will be as welcome to me, as a dead debt to an Uurer. We are faln into Times (like thoe the Father pake of) In quibus non erat quandum vivere. And truly, thee peaking pictures of my friends, are the onely Scaene of mirth to me in this deep Tragoedy. Pardon me Sir, if I now claim a debt of you; for a promie is a debt, I mean an Elegie: I'll aure you I have expected it long, and I know it will not come hort of mine expectation: I know you have delay'd it all this while but to inhance its value; but there needs no art to make me prize a wel-writ Poeme, and uch I dare not but think yours to be, Fortes creantur fortibus, &c. I dare not flatter my elf into o high a preumption, as to merit it by any thing of mine, yet may this erve as a challenge and though I loe my credit, I hall account my elf a gainer by the bargain.

closer.signed: The lat, though not the leat of thoe that honour you, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. F.
div.p: SO willingly could I have born the Bearer company, in o pleaant a Pilgrimage, that I cannot but at once complain of my hard hap, and envy this papers Happines.

lg.l: But though my body be confin'd
To time and place, o's not my mind.

div.p: For with my nimble fancie I out-run both this and them, and alute you, as the Food Neus did Pythagoras, and called him by his name, as one admired for his flood of widome, if we credit the faith of Aelian. And I dare not upect but you feed your friendhip with equal flames, that it may be like the Vetal fire, perpetual. Nor can I think your pleaant Forde will prove a Lethe of forgetfulnes, to drench the remembrance of our friendhip. I have read of a mountain o high, that what was written in the ahes of one years Sacrifice, was found legible in the next: So, hope I, the Characters of our friendhip indelible by ought but Death. I am now changing the air, but not my mind of being

closer.signed: The admirer of your worth, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. J. P.
div.p: I Received your Letter, and that with as much welcome as Penelope did her lyes, after an Ages abence. Seriouly, that I have not hitherto writ to you, was not either for want of Love or Leiure, but blind-folded by ignorance of the place you make happy with your preence, I knew not how to find you out. Believe me, Sir, you, with my honet Lightfoot, are o deeply fixed in the fatet of my affections, that I hall ooner forget my elf to be, than you to be my friends, or my elf your ervant: And think not this a complement, but a lively Image of my thoughts; which, though I want your Art to give it colours, yet is as really decypher'd in this poor black and white, as in the richet tincture. Sir, I pray let the hortnes of my time (at preent) excue the hortnes of my Letter, and be confident, that my next Anwer hall be more anwerable to your deert, and my deire; the height of whoe ambition is but to continue

div.head: To L. C. L.
div.p: NOw have I found a way to try thy yet unquetion'd friendhip; 'tis this. See here a poor Pamphlet hrowding it elf under the patronizing wings of all that dare tyle themelves the Authors friends. My abence from the Pres, has fill'd it with an innumerable company of unpardonable Errata's: So that, beides the principal of pardoning the irregularitie of the thing it elf, there aries an unexpected core, for unlook'd for Errata's. Well, it cannot now be help't: 'Tis the Image of thine unknown friend; and, though much difigur'd in the limning, if thou cant but dicern a Real Heart, 'tis all I wih for. Read it over, tell the errours, and tell me of them, o halt thou truly approve thy elf, what I would be loth not to believe thee. You know, Caecus amor proli. Parents eyes are blind to their own, they read with the multiplying glas of elf-love, which ees a park of fire through an heap of ahes. Do me therefore that real part of friendhip, as to end thy mot rigid cenure of it: And in o doing, thou halt (if poible) yet farther oblige

div.head: To Mr. E. B.
div.p: BEing now reduced to my primitive condition, I have for the preent haken hands with the world, and retired my elf into my Cell: there will I lie perdu, and laugh at the madnes of the Times, without envying their State. May they have as much as I contemn; 'tis riches enough for me, to loe as little as I can, which whatoever it be, I am able to make up with thoughts of you my real friends. Excue my preent hortnes, and meaure not my love by my lines; but acertain thy elf I honour thee as an unparallel'd piece of real friendhip. I cannot quetion my farther ditance will any whit turn the edge of thy quondam contancie, for what need words among friends. Ned, This unworthy piece will adventure upon thy charitie, eriouly, not without the hame of the Sender; For, beides the Errours of the thing, the Printer has filled it o full of gros Errata's, that I cannot give one without an Apologie; and I cannot devie one good enough to equal the badnes of the Pres. However, draw the veil of thy friendhip over the errours, and where thou findet them, pardon them. But one thing more, end me thy everet judgment of it; lay friendhip aide, and tell me truth, without repect of peron: Then hall I boat to have been

div.head: To M. C. F.
div.p: AT length have I found a way, whereby this poor brat may bles the Author with the happines of kiing your hands. 'Tis Freeborn, though begot in ervitude. But I dare not venture upon your more judicious brow, without an Apologie; not o much for the Printing, as the mi-printing. I mut needs ay, whilt I was at the pres to overlook it, I durt own it; but as oon as I was gone, the Printers o di-figured it, that I knew it not again, when I aw it. Had I been with them, I hould have erv'd them as the Philoopher did the Potter, reading and mi-reading his veres, he brake all his earthen ware: The Potter demanding his reaon, he anwered; You break my head, and I break your Pots. Seriouly, I think I hould break their pates as mierably as ever was poor Pricians by any Pedantick. But, prethee exercie thy friendhip o far, as to end me a perfect Anatomy of it: I mean, thy judgment, without hands or eyes. Shut out the name of friend, whilt thou cenuret it, and end me that cenure, as to one that is no whit indulgent to his own. Then hall I boat to have vowed my elf
One thing I forgot to tell thee, the Printer has rob'd it of its Letters of Credence: But you mut put that upon his core.

div.head: To Mr. J. W.
Grace.
div.p:
ANd now I dare promie my Letter a welcome, marching under, and with o good a Grace. But I long to hear whether thou hat given thy Grace a Sirname yet, for I cannot find it among all the Catalogue of Virtues. Perhaps I mitook the Index, and hould have looked for W. but I could not o readily hear of my Gloves. Thou eet I have found a way to whiper my yet unparched friendhip, though at a ditance. I have read of a place called the Hall of Gyants, in Mantua, which hath this trange and unuual Art, that how low oever one peak, at the Corners 'tis intelligible to be heard, whilt thoe in the Midt hear nothing. Me thinks, it fitly reembles our intercoure by Letters: Hereby hall we be able to conquer ditance, and live together, though far aunder: Friendhip hereby works like weapon-alve, at a ditance, and undicernable. But I intended a Letter, not a Character of Letters. Now, having in part paid my debt promied, it will not be unmannerly to demand yours; for promies are debts: and I love as little to be indebted
in courteie, as in coyn. If thou earchet the File of thy promies, among other particulars, thou wilt find this, Item, A Letter to

closer.signed: The expecter of that Happines, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. B.
div.p:
WIth thy Letter I received an Anwer to my Search. 'Tis too long, and my time too hort, and my wit too weak to return a Reply. Be contented onely with an acquittance for the receit of it; the rather, becaue I would not fail your expectation; for I hate abortives of that nature. But before I give you a dicharge, I mut quarrel with you, for ome bad coyn. Tell me of Hitory, Quotations, and Comments! What Galilaean-glas didt thou ue for Spectacles, when thou read't my letter? Your Comment has bely'd my Text: And what argument hat thou to prove me a Poet, except poverty; and perhaps, an ill face, with Hipponax, who was no Painter, as you make him, but a Poet, with o ugly a face, that two Gravers in tone et out his Statue to the world, and him to the deriion of the beholders: At which he was o inraged, that whetting his Pen with anger, he did o thick dicharge his Porcupine-quils, and his Badger-Jambicks o bit, that (as the Stories
ay) for very anger made the two Gravers hang themelves. Newes I can tell thee none, but that Trading, which before was wounded, is now dead. That the Army have now done what the King all this while fought for, namely, put a point, if not a period to the perpetual Parliament. And having eized the King in Hurt-Catle, have poet themelves of the major part of their Maters, and thrown them into Hell. But now I begin to grow as tedious to thee, as the time of thy abence will be to me: In deteining thee too long from that name

closer.signed: So much obliged to you, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. W. L.
div.p:
THe Romans had a cutome, that after any one was dead, one hollowed three times in their ear, and after the third call, pronounced, Conclamatum et, He's pat recovery. I have called three times without an anwer, yet I dare not pronounce a conclamatum et of our friendhip, I know it is not dead. Thy lat was in anwer but to a part of mine. Dot thou mean to Comment upon my Letters in Tomes and Volumes? Certainly we hall make excellent Harmony with the everal notes of Muick, in Longs, Briefs, Sem-briefs, Minims, Quavers, and Crotchets. But J. H. acts a part, (or rather no part),
which, I think, is beyond the Muicians Ela: I find no name for it; but let not them overhear me, and I'll call it a Paue. Well, this conceit is neither Meane nor Bae, but, if you will, Treble, becaue we are three. Send me word what fortune my poor brat finds in the world. how it goes off, and is relihed: And do it as forgetting me to be the Author, or

div.head: To Mr. J. H.
div.p:
LIttle les than infinite will number mine engagements to thee; and when I hall quit cores with thee, I know not; yet may it hew a willingnes to pay, in him that confees the debt. I am glad of uch an argument of omething good in that worthles piece, as the dilike of the world will draw for a Concluion. Really, I never intended they hould like it, and hould have upected it, if they had: For he that will pleae the Times, mut go attired in a Fools coat, not a Scholars habit. Didt thou never hear of the Philoopher, that when (in an Oration) the people applauded him, turn'd about to ome of his friends, and asked, What he had aid amis
• Thy Newes of the Hangmans o untimely death, when he was at the full ga •• of one and thirty, drew this ex tempore Epitaph from me.

lg.l: Here lies the Royal Headman, who in's time,
Of the Court-cards hath cut & drawn the Prime:
But oh ad fate! death thus hould Trump about,
And now at one and thirty put him out.

div.p: But I hate to ubcribe my elf

closer.signed: Thy much engaged Friend, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. T. P.
div.p:
I Had hitherto fully reolved, that the name of Mecoenas now lived onely in Horace lines; but your late Larges has made me recant my humour, and believe that there are yetome that dare patronize the Mues when grown poor: But as the carcitie increaes your honour, o would it my hame, if I hould be o ingrateful as not to acknowledge it; though I mut confes, my retribution will be as bad, as my mind is good, to erect a Pyramid to your ingular example in this Age. Not that I intend any Panygerick of your praies, that were fitter for the Pen of Pliny, or the Mouth of Cicero, Give me leave only (without a bluh) to acknowledge my many engagements to your merit, let I hould meet with the obloquie of the French, who (the Hitorian ayes) remember good turns no longer than they are in doing. Sir, when I eriouly
conider your large reward of o hort a deert, me thinks (had I Plutarchs art) I could parallel it with the bounty of Artaxerxes, who return'd precious gifts to poor Sinaetas for his handful of water: Or, if that be too mall, to Alexander the Great, who returned doubly to Anaxar
• hus, for a mall gift he received of him. Thus rich grounds yeild double flowers, for ingle eeds. Or yet, if thee be too low, to Streton, who tudied to excel all other men in Liberalitie. And might it not be thought flattery (to praie a man to his face) I would tell others, that your Generous dipoition is a miracle in this Age) equal'd, if not excel'd one, of whom the Ancients boat, that was readier to give, than others to receive. But I fear to offend your modety, & will therefore ilently admire, what I cannot afely peak, knowing there is alo an eloquence in ilence. Yet would I not altogether have my thankfulnes (like men near the River Ganges) without a Tongue. Alas Sir! what worth was there in that plain piece, that hould caue o rich a recompence! Truly, Sir, beides the reverence (which as a dictate to natures law) I alwayes bare you, your many favours, but epecially the lat, will exact from me (without a complement) the peech of Furnius to Caear, Efficiti ut viverem & morer ingratus. Excue the relating it in it's proper Idiom: For, though it be aid, that the Tucane Speech ounds better in the mouth of Sirangers, than of the Natives, I think not o of the Latine. You have o obliged me, that (to ue the expreion of a Father to his friend) I owe you, Et quae poum, & quae
non poum. So that, did I not hope to meet with a merciful Creditor, I mut break without hope of compounding: However, though you have cat your gift into a hallow Forde, yet it is o tranparent, that you may ee it, without fear of being covered with any Lethe of forgetfulnes. Nor have you cat your coyn on o oft a nature, that you hould not hear it gingle, at leat in an Eccho of Thanks: Although, when I have done all, my Thankfulnes mut be like Timantes his Pictures, wherein was more to be undertood, than there was expret. Thus, Sir, auring you here is nothing, but what is the immediate Trancript of my Heart, I crave leave to boat my elf,

closer.signed: your olely engaged Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. J. H.
div.p: THy Letter was as welcome to me, as ever was rain to the parched earth. I thank thee thee infinitely, but that's no payment. Well, et all upon the Tally, and 'tis poible we may one day cros cores. Excue my hortnes at this time, and let this Country Newes upply the defect. 'Tis this: That Phoebus (now) courts the Lady Flora as rudely as he did his Mother, that bit off her ear, when he hould have kis'd her.
That the Quadrupled Animals fare deliciouly, for they feed on Roat-meat every day.
That the Sun hath aved the Husbandmen a labour of mowing and making their Hay; for it now grows Hay, like him that owed Malt, to avoid the charge & trouble of making it of Barly.

That the world being turn'd Round, our Climate is exchang'd for Spain, or ome more weating Country: That we here know no reaon of this unparallel'd Heat, unles it be becaue we have now o many ruling Suns in the Sphere where there ued to be but One.
That, if this weather hold, we are like to have no raw fih, but all ready boyl'd before taken, and all our drink burnt-wine, or vinegar.
That the poor Ephemeris uffer Martyrdome every day.
That, at night, when Sol is with our Antipodes, we feel his heat through the cracks of the earth.
That this extream heat makes the Heavens weat a little ometimes, in tead of rain.
Item, That my Ink is converted to Jet.
Item, That there's no more Newes.
For 'tis none that I am

div.head: To Mr. R. R.
div.p:
I Dare not pretend to o much Philologie, as to criticize upon your term of Infinitiores gratias; your adopting (by your uing) it, is ufficient to patronize it, and pas it through the guards of the trictet enquiry. Here could I well ceae, and, in tead of anwering (which I hall never) admire at your Elegant Letter you were pleaed to honour me with: wherein, what treams of Eloquence! what flames of Love! what Rhetorick! what Realitie! nay, what not! So that, were all Epitles like yours, I would not wonder that Learning and Letters are terms convertible. I honour the preence of my friends; but may it ever be upplyed by uch Letters, and I hall never complain of their abence. Before, I loved you as a friend, but now, I honour you as a Wit. But how eaily doe paions exalted tranport us! And how willingly do we yield the cloak of our reolutions to the flatttering Sun of praie! But I am too concious of mine own unworthines, to admit thoe large Encomiums your flourihing pen hath adorned me with. 'Tis a Po • e of rare beauty; but I dare not accept it, let there hould lie a nake of flattery, under thoe fairer Flowers: And I wih you have not hown your Wit, and hazarded your Judgment. When I read
your neat lines, really I cannot but love them for their gallantnes, and pitie them that, they had no better a Subject. Me thinks, they eem like rich cloaths upon a poor man (that do not ute) or like the Kings Saddle upon the Millers hore. Who will not upect your eyes blindfolded with love, that have made Paris choie, and extoll'd a homely face, for an Heavenly beauty. Well, ince my deerts are too hort to cale them, I hall (I'll aure you) keep it by me, as too rich a cloth for my meannes, and hall lay it before me, as a pattern of what would I be, rather than a picture of what I am. Now, to your Why, let me return a Wherefore I have (to ue your expreion, and who can ue better) masked my elf under the ingle letters of T. F. that being unknown, I might more freely hear the worlds cenure. I remember a facetious tale of a Frenchman, that had printed much, concealing his own name: One asking a man that brought his Copies to the pres, Who the Author was? He aid, 'Twas one that deired to erve God inviibly. My humbler ambition flies no uch pitch; 'tis enough for me, if it may but reach to the ervice of my friends, of which number, I know you to be o intenely one, that, as 'tis aid, that Plutarch once being named, the Eccho anwer'd, Philoophy; o, hould I call R. (I doubt not but) it would return friendhip. This is the Happines of him that cares not to acrifice his credit to your worth,

div.head: To Mr. R. R.
div.p:
THat my late lines have produced your later Letter, I am not a little glad; but that they hould occaion a quarrel, I hould be more orry. If the exception be my fear of flatterie, know, that it was not the Height of your expreions, but my own lownes, that frighted me into uch a fear. Would not a little David think himelf mock't, to be proffer'd a Goliah's armour? But, for my part, your merits are caveat ufficient to keep my words from the leat upition: And the contruction of my words will be bet made by the Grammar-rule of friendhip; for I was never guilty of o much Rhetorick, as to tell a learned lye. My tongue and my pen (if I deceive not my elf) are alwayes Relatives: Becaue Favorinus praied the Feaver, hould not we praie Health? And becaue ome Romans acrifice to that, might not others to Aeculapius? 'Twere more hame to d • ny praies where they are due, than to admit them where they are not. Why therefore are you o bahful? as if thoe parts (omething above the degree of admiration) had erept into your boome unawares? And though your modety is uch, (as may ilently hame my forwardnes) that you will not hew your elf to the world, like that plant in Pliny, which buds inwardly, and hooteth out no bud, bloome,
or leaf outwardly; yet give us leave to admire it, though you bury your worth in the ore of obcuritie. We count him a rich man, that has his wealth in his chet, not on his back; yet excue me, if I think it an envious dipoition, in him, that would play o oftly on his Lute, that none hould hear but himelf. But whether is my pen tragled? Surely as far from the matter of my firt intentions, as the anwers of the two deaf perons were from one another, that pleaded before a deaf Judge in the Greek Epigram. To return therefore from my digreion to your Letter. How hall I interpret thoe expreions, of exact, ingenious, and learned Comment? rare, trancendent, and incomparable Anwer, not to ay of flatterie, but of very large Hyperbolies!

But you have made me amends for them, when in the next entence you handomely call me fool under the name of the Indians: where you tell me, I look on my elf afar off, through a perpective, and upon you near hand, &c. Me thinks, I cannot obtein of my elf to believe, that I am farther from my elf, than I am from you; and therefore the multiplying glas mut go with the greater ditance: But I am afraid I have turn'd the wrong end, and rather overeen than over-valu'd your crecent parts. To your deire of eeing ome other pieces of mine, I mut onely anwer, that I am very much unprovided of any, for my tore lies in a Chaos, as yet unformed, in mold unmelted, or unminted; but uch as I have will be proud of your Sight and Cenure. And for a continuance of
this literal correpondencie, know that I cannot be o much an enemy to my elf, as not to deire it; and with as much affection as I am

div.head: To M. J. H.
div.p: THe ancient Romans, who made a Deity of every thing, yet acrificed not to death, becaue from death are no Returns. For the ame reaon, hould I not write to London, and by conequence, not to your elf. Trumpeters love to ound where there is an Eccho, and I love to write whence I can hear an anwer. Seeing once a Weaver at work, I oberved, that by cating his huttle from one ide to the other, he finih'd his web: Therein I aw a lively Embleme of friends correpondencie by letters; if either fail, the web's imperfect. I make it now my imployment, that the ball hould not fall on my ide. I mut confes I have been from home of late, but now I am returned to that, and to my cutome. Letters unanwered, like meat undigeted, breed no weet breath. Well, I hall expect an anwer as long as the time I have waited for one, till when I hall reolve to be

closer.signed: Your mot aured Friend, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. S. M.
div.p:
OBliged by your courteies, your command, and my duty, that ingratitude mut be more than Herculean, that could break this three-fold tie. I have reolved therefore now, to be rather preumptuous, than ingrateful; that I may tender you thanks for the engagements you have laid upon me, though the very act increae them; and to aure you, that I am nothing of the nature of that beat, that is o forgetful, that though he be feeding never o hard and hungrily, if he cat but back his head, forgets immediately the meat he was eating, and runs to look after new. And if my ilence eems to accue me, believe me, Sir, it was meerly out to elf-conciounes of my own unworthines to preent you with any thing worth the reading; yet alo remembring, that the great Alexander would admit a return of Epitles between himelf and Publius his Bit-maker. I am a little encouraged you will at leat pardon my poor cribling; if not for it elf, or the ender, yet becaue it carries thanks in the front, and they are currant coyn, and in which the pooret may be rich, without • ear of a Sequetration. That word that ham-trings all indutry, and makes men embrace the Stoical aying for a Maxime, Benè qui latuit, benè vixit. And truly, for my part, I think we are faln into Nero's
age, in which Tacitus aith (Inertia, apientia fuit.) Sloth was a virtue. When the Ship of the Common-wealth is teer'd by a Tempet, 'tis bet lying till in the Harbour: But I intend an Epitle, no Satyre. I am

closer.signed: (without a complement) your very humble ervant T. F.

div.head: To Mr. J. A.
div.p:
PArdon the familiarity of the Title, I ue no complements to my friends; not do I think them my friends that ue them to me. The Italians peak out of experience, The more tongue, the les heart; and you know their Proverb, La penna della Lingua i dove tingere nel inchiotro del cuore. I could wih that all the letters of friends were like Tullies, Epitolae Familiares; and the Polite Polititian tells me, that the greatet ornament of all Epitles is to be without any. James. I love thee, I honour thee, and that ine fuco, ine fallaciis. I would have my letters like the Herb Perica, which the Egyptians offer'd to their god Iis, whoe fruit was like an heart, and the leaf like a tongue. Hereby do I talk with thee, now abent, and if thou wilt vouchafe me the like, thereby hall I ee thee. Pardon me, if I challenge, nay, expect your
your promie, which if you perform not, I hall upect your humour omething of kin to that of an excellent Archer, that would rather loe his life, than hew a trial of his skill. Letters are like thoe mutual pawns the Grecians gave as Symbols of their friendhip; like Dido's little Aeneas, to upply their abence. Hereby are they preent in England, Spain, or France, all in an intant, and at once. Let it not be thought a Paradox, for Love goes beyond Art. But what do I talk of love and friendhip in this Age, wherein fat friends are gone on pilgrimage, and their returns uncertain. But I grow tedious: 'Tis the fault of parting friends; and now, like one in that extaie. I know not what to ay next: whether to commend thy diligence, in outvying lyes, in that which the Poet ayes made him wie. Whilet I am like the illy Grahopper, that lives and dies in the ame ground: Or hall I fear thy danger, and with Charonidas, wonder not at thoe that go to Sea once, but at thoe that go again: Or hall I dare to aume the preumption, for me, who am no Traveller, to counel thee, that art; no, I dare not. Yet let me remember thee of the Speech of one that was; That a Traveller mut have Eagles eyes, Aes ears the tongue of a Merchant, a Camels feet, a Hogs mouth, and an Aes back. In a word, mayt thou meaure, thy happines by the Ell of thine own deires, which hall not exceed the wihes of

div.head: To Mr. J. H.
div.p:
YOur Letter was as welcome to me, as your abence is tedious. Complements uit not the reality of my intentions; but imagine all the meer complemental expreions of flattering Courthip put into truth, and all fall hort of my affections. To obey your command, if your patience will pardon the tediounes, I will give you as brief an account as I can of my preent etate. I have read, that one Philotratus lived even yeares in his Tomb, to acquaint himelf with Death. Truly, I have convered above two even years among the Dead, for o are our Authors eteemed; and indeed, our Shops may not unfitly be reembled to a Charnel-houe: and there, and thus, have I gotten uch a familiaritie with thoe faithful and unflattering Counellours, that I rather choe to lie in the valley of obcurity, than to climb the dangerous Alps of apiring greatnes, o long as the wind blows o high, and the tream runs o wift. Rather had I it till (by their perwaion) than rie to fall; or to fare hardly, than feed on others bread: And, me thinks, I find my elf very well decypher'd by the Embleme, which repreented certain Grahoppers, that uck the dew, and pas their time inging, with this Motto; Di queto mi contento, è megilio pero. With this I am content, and hope better, when
God hall o order the tide of occaions, and the blats of my friends favour, to lanch me from the poor harbour, where I now lie windbound. Thus, Sir, I hope I have made you reparation for my late ilence, not doubting but you will make it but a Parentheis, which hall break no ence in our friendhip: And this I hall eteem a very great addition to your former Engagements; to all which, I hall without cruple Subcribe

div.head: To E. W. Equire.
div.p:
COuld my meenger have delivered his errand in but intelligible non-ene, I hould willingly have pared you this trouble: But ince it mut be o, I hall endeavour to make a virtue of neceity, and from hence take occaion to tell you, that o many have been your favours, and o few the returns of my thanks hitherto, that they have rendred mine ingratitude as uperlative as your goodnes. Though you write your courteies in running water (to which a Forde is of very near kin) I deire to write my thanks in marble; and had I o advantagious an occaion, I would make the whole world the Witnes of mine Obligations. To this purpoe, I could wih this poor paper immortal, that my gratitude, at leat, might rival your bounty. But, Sir, you have endeavoured to make me
live and die in your debt, which I hall rather reolve to uffer, than to lander your noblenes with a thought of my lender requital. Now, Sir, if you pleae to honour me with the additional courteie of your Cambden, you hall hereby infinitely add (if they urmount not that piece of Arithmetick already) to your former favours and my engagements. And may this erve for my Surety, that I will keep it carefully, ue it warily, and return it peedily. Thus, Sir, kiing the hands of your fair Venus, and her three Graces, I humbly take my leave, who am proud to wear the livery of

closer.signed: your and their mot obliged Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. H.
div.p:
HAving armed my elf cap à pe, with patience to receive as you promied, your mot rigid cenure, I finde, in tead of arms, you encounter me with flowers, and, like Paris, make me toop to your golden ball. Nor do I les wonder at it, than the poor Norvegian did, the firt time he aw roes, who durt not touch them for fear of burning his fingers, being much amazed to ee (as he uppoed) trees to bear • ire. With little les wonder, do I behold your learned lines, nor with les amazement, to ee flames
of love, and treams of eloquence o Homogenial.

To your Letter, I hall return nothing, but onely tell you, that what I undertand is excellent, and o I believe, and admire the ret. Your Allegory of the Cook is neatly dres'd, but except you be pleaed to tinde one of his lights, I hall fear to remain in darknes, and dicover no farther than his uperficies. The cenures of thoe blind-minded Jewes you peak of, I hall account my greatet commendations: Like Crates the Philoopher, who, having received a blow on the face by one Nicodromus, a man full of bae condition (and as bae conditions) was contented, for revenge, to et thee words on his wound, Nicodromus faciebat. To thoe large Encomiaticks you betow on my poor Pamphlets, I hall onely ay I am orry they had no fitter ubjects; yet am I glad I was o happy to afford you any ground for your nimble fancy to work on, and hall here promie you, that if you pleae to continue this literal commerce, you hall not want a whettone to harpen your ythe, as you are pleaed to deire; and this property I may have (like the whettone) though blunt my elf to harpen another. Nor need you fear that you can ue too much ingenuity to me; for I am no whit affected with the hereie of the Times, which count learning and wit (as you ay) the cum of the bottomles pit; but know how to honour it as much as I want it. In a word, Sir, I thank you for your Letter, more for your Veres, but mot that you pleae to tyle me

div.head: To Mr. R. R.
div.p: I Return you your New-Forret, with as many thanks as it merits, and that's infinite; which ubmiion to your better judgment (from which I would no ooner dient, than from truth it elf) I conceive this not at all behind the firt part, but in time; it appearing to me of as fine a thred, and no les curious workmanhip. Happily the others, being chequer'd with forreign flowers, may render it more delectable. But why hould we think a forreign garden of flowers, and perhaps ome weeds, better than an Englih Forret? Well may it be more ightly, but, I'm ure, 'tis not o erviceable. Scarce can I hold my pen from glutting in his praies, who is far above it's highet flight, did not the Italian proverb check me, and tell me truly, La Lode nacer deve, quando è morto chi i ha da Lodar: That praies hould not be born, till the praied be dead. I will therefore content my eff to ay, that I hope uch pleaant groves are not upertitious; and could wih, that the whole Kingdome were o turned to a Forret, and the Author the Ranger General.

lg.l: That's body might not be confin'd,
Who's a free Monarch in his mind;
One who with's Majetick Pen,
May give the Law to other men.

div.p: Sir, I have ent you a Clavis to it, not that I think you need any, but that, if you invite any friend to thoe pleaant walks, they may have an entry of undertanding, without picking the lock by a fale contruction. It was done at a heat, and I have not time to file it over, but uch as it is, 'tis yours. If you pleae to end me the lat Edition of the Kings learned pieces, I hall keep it carefully, return it peedily, and remain continually

div.head: To Mr. W. L.
div.p:
I Mut eteem it an happinee to hear of you, though I cannot hear from you: and that I heard nothing of your icknes, till I heard alo of your recovery; o that now to tell you I am ad or orrowful for your icknee, were as prepoterous, as to grieve for your death after your reurrection, or to bid you good-night in the morning when you are rien. But like the trembling needle between two equally attractive Loadtones, o am I between the two different paions of joy and orrow: Joy for a friends recovery, and orrow for a friends retraint. Not to be joyful for your recovery, were to envy a publick good, and I might jutly be accued for an enemy to the State, in not rejoycing at a
happinee o common, that deerves a day of Publick Thankgiving. Then, not to be affected with the orrows and ufferings of a friend, and uch a friend as E. B. were as great a crime as his whom the Romans condemned to death, For wearing a Crown of Roes in a time of common calamity. I long to hear how our honet friend tands, ince the High Court its; which if I do not now from thee, I hall think, that whilt thy body uffer'd under the fire of a Feaver, thy friendhip was ick of an Ague; that though the Dog-tar reigned in thy blood, thy affections laboured under Capricorn. But, ince thy icknes is in it's Declenion, I hall expect thy friendhip to be again Acendant, that before did Culminate. And for my part, think not that thirty miles ditance, cold raines, or your ilence, can make me forget you, or that I am

closer.signed: As much as ever Sir, your Friend, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. J. H.
div.p:
HAving hitherto waited with ilence, to hear of your receit of my Letter, and finding none, makes me fearful that it micarried in the delivery; and I am not ignorant, or inenible of the many abortives of the Carriers Midwifery.
But I hope your candor is ufficient to dipel all clouds of upition that might eem to ecclipe my realitie, or to think that I am o much foe to my elf, as not to deire, or at leat not to endeavour the gainful commerce of your letters. I am not ignorant that all kind of Learning hath been wrapt up in Letters: And I aure you, Sir, I hall, in the enjoyment of yours, think my elf little les honoured, than I do Lucillius by Seneca's. Nor hall I be a little proud, that I may be any wayes (though but occaionally) intrumental to you, to exercie your excellencie in this way: Neither do I altogether doubt of the pardon of my rude cribling, becaue I am

closer.signed: (without Complement) your very humble Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. H.
div.p:
THough I have paid the Principal, in returning your books, I am till indebted for the Interet you were pleaed to lay on them, in giving you my account of them. For your Cauin, I return you thanks, in tead of cenures, wihing that he were now alive, that our late Tragedies might be acted over again by his highflying quill, and be thereby committed to incredulous
poteritie. The Novum Lumen Chymicum, I undertand, is lately Tranlated; and indeed it were a wonder, if there were any New Lights, that we hould not have in Englih in thee Times. But, becaue you told me you lent me that onely to laugh at, I hall only tell you, it no whit failed your intention, or my expectation. Now for your Vaughan, be pleaed to take notice, that he is ince anwered by one Moore learned and better famed than He; and therefore I hall let that Anwer be mine: Yet withal, that I erve uch Books as the good Bihop erv'd Perius, when he threw him on the ground with a Si no • vis intelligi, debes negligi. Thus, as the Hollanders ometime made money of pat-board, I make my payment in Paper, and in this coyn I hall pay you liberally for your Arithmetick. Believe me, Sir, 'tis Homers Iliads in a Nut-hell, and o handomely compacted, that the doggedet Critick cannot faten on it; onely let me tell you, it is deficient in one thing, and that is, that it is not able to help me to number the Engagements you have lain upon

div.head: To Mr. R. R.
div.p: HE's a bad debtor that payes by halfs; but he's a wore that never payes. That I may not be guilty of that uperlative ingratitude, I have ent you two Books of your three. And for Bacon, I pray think it not long, if I hould keep it till Lent; for I mean, to all his Experiments, to add one more of your friendhip. If you expect an account of your I ••• B •• : know, it is far above my cenure, as my praie; I go to that, as to my Bible, yet omething in Allegiance. Certainly, that Portraiture was drawn by a Divine hand, and wrote with a pen pull'd from ome Angels wing. If there be one that wrote by divine inpiration ince the Apotles times, 'twas He, when He pen'd thoe Meditations. Henceforth his Pen hall be his Scepter, His Book his Throne, and the whole World his Empire: There hall he live and reign, and be as immortal, as ome of his enemies malice.

Take a more particular account of your Balzack thus: I undertook the reading of him, rather for penance, than profit; but having read him once, that induced me to read him again, and the econd time drew on a third, and the third a fourth; and now I end it you home, let if I hould keep it a little longer, I hould trancribe the whole Book. A better Character cannot be given of him, than he gives of himelf,
take it therefore in his own words, That his Writings mell more of musk and amber, than of oil and weat. But to ave time, I have ent you a Pamphlet, that may erve as a foyl to et off Balzack the better: Wherein expect neither Cicero nor Seneca; neither Howel nor Balzack; neither Learning nor Language; nor any Letters beginning with the ambitious title of My Lord, or Madam, they are more proud of the name of Friend, and, carrying that tamp, they preume to be currant, though they be but bras. Not that I intend to make my private Letters publique, but onely to advance a communitie in friendhip, and to fulfil a command of yours in a letter (in that particular) yet unanwered, of eeing ome pieces of mine. And truly, thee are no other than pieces; yet, as in the everal pieces of a broken Looking-glas, you hall in every one ee the perfect reflection of

closer.signed: yours in all Offices of Friendhip, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. B.
div.p:
RAther had I accue the Carrier with negligence, than thee with forgetfulnee: Nor can I think the requeting of a friendly courteie, could care thee into an unfriendly ilence. Sure
ye are all truck dumb at London, or your ink, if not your affections, is frozen. The erious thought of which, hath made me almot believe, that the name of friend is but the fabulous birth of ome Philoophical Poets, or Poetical Philoophers, and fitted for Sir Thomas Moore's topia, or Plato's Common-wealth; not for an Iron Age, or the dregs of Time. If thou art ilent becaue thou hat no Newes to write, write that thou hat none: However, let the world ee there is one dares call himelf a friend, though in uch an Age as this. And believe it, that the all-elf-devouring teeth of time hall never eradicate the name of B. from out the heart of him, whoe onely pride is to tell the world who is

postscript.head: Potcript.
postscript.p: You may, if you pleae, communicate this to all thoe that call themelves my friends, and tell them, that till I hear the contrary, I hall uppoe their practice of ilence intended for my pattern.

div.head: To Mr. W. L.
div.p: NOr will I accue your ilence, nor excue my own; 'tis ufficient I have broken the Ice, and adventured to tell thee, 'tis poible to be a friend, and ilent; nor do I depair to hear the ame from you: In confidence of which, I ay no more now, but tell you, I expect it. To your Father thus much. Concerning the re-printing of my Characters, and augmenting them, I have had ome erious thoughts, and the reult is this. I find them, upon perual, not uitable to the preent State, being Calculated for the Meridian of a Kingdome, not a Commonwealth, they are now like old Almanacks out of date. And to go to them with the Arithmetick of Addition and Subtraction, with the Penil and the Spunge, were to make my elf guilty of what I there condemn. Beides, they were then my reolved (and not yet retracted) thoughts: So that I hold it not afe for you to print, or me to enlarge them, nor this, farther than to tell thee, I long to hear from thee, and of our dearet Ned. I have a Letter hath been deigned for him a long time, did I but hope there were a crevie in his cloe prion, that I might peep through to aure him that I am his (as thine)

div.head: To Mr. E. H.
div.p: YOur lat Letter I met on the way, as drawn thither perhaps by Sympathy, like the Magnetick teel, to meet her loved Loadtone I know love and friendhip work miracles, and act in Paradoxes: It makes the enjoyers thereof flame without conuming, preent and ditant (if that word may be admitted in friendhip) all at once. By this I ee my friend, when inviible, and hear him, though ilent. Like the Philoophers Stone, of which the Chymits o much boat, Contraria operatur, ed emper in beneficium naturae. This is (if any thing) the true Sympathetick powder, that works truer, and at a greater ditance, than weapon-alve. Willingly could I loe my elf in this pleaing Maeander; but I will rather commend the Theory to your more active Pen, and reolve to act the practick part my elf. For your Veres, I will rather remain in your debt, than pay you with bad coyn. I aure you Sir,

lg.l: I have no vein in vere; but if I could,
Incloe each word a Mine, believe't I would:
I onely Court her that drops Elegies,
Whilt others Muesing, mine onely cries.

div.p: Yet hall I not refue what your injunction hall lay upon me, becaue I am

closer.signed: As really your Friend, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. T. P.
div.p:
FOr me to attempt an Anwer to your Letter, were to venture at the flights of an Eagle, with a Sparrows wing. The Italians tell me in a Proverb, The higher the Ape climbs, the more he hews his nakednes. And truly, hould I endeavour to reach the pitch you have et me for a pattern, I hould rather imitate Icarus in his fall, than you in your flight. It is enough for me to admire and applaud the happines of your undertakings, that can at once captive Apollo and the Mues, and make the Triumphs of former Ages, the Trophies of your Pen's victories. Where you profes your elf Davus, I mut confes my elf no Oedipus: Giving you therefore the libertie the Civil Law allows (and I hould be uncivil if I hould not) to interpret your own words, I will guee at your meaning, and return you, not onely an Anwer to your Riddle, but the reaon of it. Sir, if my lee comprehenive Genius deceive me not, you like not Latine lace to an Englih uit; and herein you have light upon an humour, that I have long ince retracted, and eteem now as too pedantical. But you may perceive they avour of the ferula, and imagine my then regnant humour; like young tomacks, that like raw fruit, better than reated food: Yet mut I farther confes, I have been o concious of mine own inabilities, and
o confident of the Ancients worth, that I have preferred to ue their more refined lines, than my unfiled language: So that I dicover in my elf the fancie of the Painters boy, who thinking to upply the defect of his skill, by the richnes of his colours, had loaden Venus picture with gold and ilver, in tead of native beauty: For which he met with this cenure from his Mater, that he had made her rich, whom he could not make fair. So have I embroidered my courer cloth with others ends of gold and ilver. It onely remains that I tell you, that I cannot tell you how much you have won me by that one act of dealing freely with me; and to aure you, that you could not have tudied a way to oblige me more. And that you may believe my realitie herein, be pleaed to inform me of the Author of your Utinam necire Literas; and if it prove the peecch of that Negro-black Tyrant, you hall find my ubmiion as humble, as your conquet noble. If you think the Frontipiece dicrepant to the following leaves, I hall conform the printed Title to the written Book, not the written Book to the printed Title For I reolve not to change their name, nor alter their propertie of Familiar Letters, for my private friends. But I hinder you too long, from what I onely intended, to acknowledge my elf

div.head: To Mr. T. P.
div.p:
THat that poor grain of mine hath produced me o udden, and yet o large a return, argues the fruitfulnee of the Soyl wherein 'twas cat, not the goodnee of the eed, or of the Sowers les skilful hand. Hereafter hall I believe, what before I took for a fable, That there is ome ground o fruitful, that the husbandman reaps at night, what he owed in the morning. Your Chritning my fancie with the name of a Thruh, might very well teach me the modetie of that volatile, who is aid to be ilent, whilet the Nightingale (chief Chaunter of the aiery quire) produceth her more clear and tuneful note, did I not hope by my plain Song to gain your more artificial decant. Your proclaming my attempt rather Pheatontick than Icarian, is no more (pardon the boldnee of my ignorance) than for a man to be killed with a ilver word, rather than an iron dagger, the only preheminence being in this, that he perihed like the other, but with this addition of honour (if it be o) of falling under the burthen of more bold attempts. Where before I but confes'd, I now profes my elf no Oedipus, nor made I any riddles, but gues'd onely at the meaning of yours, and therefore am not apprehenive of your Analogie of the Cobler (whom I leave to maintein his more ambitious title of a Tranlator)
unlee you intended your picture of your friend, like Horace's monter, which begins with a fair womans face, and ends in a foul fihes tail at lat. But it was your Phaetons fate, to meet with o dangerous a fall, from the Chariot of the Sun to a Shop-window. Nor need we any Sphin • , to unriddle this repugnancie in terms, whoe part it was to make them. At what words of mine you admire, I know not, 'tis my endeavour to avoid that Selecime Augutus found fault with in M. Antony, of writing uch things as men hould rather wonder at, than undertand. I applaud the happines of your Genius, who can coyn words with your own tamp; onely I uppoe, that of unoepodize, would be no whit lee currant, were it horter by the firt yllable. Of that Socratick vice you peak of, I have not o much in me, as to defend it: Far be it from me, to adopt the quarrel of thoe great Clerks; it is enough for me, if I may boat my elf their, and Learnings unworthiet ervant. To your confirmation of Nero's tinam, I now yield my full belief, and hould do o, you affirming it, though all Hitorians denied it, and withal, my promied ubmiion: Only give me leave to cleave the hair, and tell you, that it was the peech of Nero, though not then a barbarous tyrant, having then but newly entred his Quinquennium, o much by all extoll'd, whilet reteining his Mater Seneca's more than Philoophical intructions. And o I leave him, when I have told you, I hall accept thoe unmerited Encomiums you impoe upon me (with that then good Emperors peech to the Senate
giving him thanks) Cum meruero. Sir, I do, and hall (I think) perit in confining thoe poor papers from the eye of the world, not daring to let them goe abroad in this uper-fine Age, in o homely a dres; nor herein can I apprehend my elf guilty of that < in non-Latin alphabet > , you Propheie me guiltie of, unles it be, in that I have anwered your letter before I had returned you the due thanks & praies the worth of that would jutly exact from the mot ullen ingratitude. Believe me, Sir, you are Mater of an Imperial pen, and would you once break through the veil of derogating ilence, your beams would be ufficient to create a day, even in the nightie Chaos of my duller intellect, to cat a cloud upon all former names, and be night poteritie. But I hall rather chue an admiring ilence, than an undervaluing commendation, becaue I deire to make good to a tittle the title of

closer.signed: your faithful Servant, and not unfaithful friend, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. T. L.
div.p:
THat you may ee how willing I am to comply with every occaion that may put me in a capacitie of erving you, I hall now anwer your command, with my opinion of Speed, and
his Hitory. For the Hitory, it is a work of deerved commendations, and without any exception. For the Author, I cannot o well aure you; but if Speed be not too much wronged in the relation, he was but the Journeyman-Taylor in the buines: It was (ay ome) cut out by abler workmen, he onely made it up, and in that hath merited the commendations of a very good workman, beides what we are indebted to him for the fahion, the lining, facing, and preing; but for the lat, I believe we are more beholden to the Printers pres, than to his gooe. This preents me with a fair occaion of preenting you with a Copie of Veres, not unworthy your reading, upon Speeds Chronicle, ent from a Son to his Father.

lg.l: God be my Speed, o I began, 'tis true,
And now 'tis time to wih a Speed to you:
Then briefly thus, as long as life endures,
God be my Speed, and let my Speed be yours.
If great books be great evils, loe a hift,
To turn this Speed into a leer gift.

div.p: Take but ome vowels out, and then 'twill be but an Epitles Preface, S. P. D.
Excue me, for once, if I make it the Epilogue, and with it conclude my elf

closer.signed: your real, though remote Friend, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. F.
div.p: WOuld you meaure my love by my ilence, you could not pronounce it hort. Oft hath my pen been on the paper to write to you, and as oft been taken off, with a conideration of the rudenes of my rutick cribling, which is now worn into uch an habit, that you will willingly retract whatever upition you have formerly had of any ingenuity in me. However, let a continued ilence hould cat me in (and out of) your affection I am reolved to ay omething, though it be but to confes my elf guilty of that mot unpardonable offence in friendhip, Ingratitude. Yet am I not without ome excues, which would be ready to plead in my behalf, did I not rather wih to receive a new life, of happines by your pronouncing my pardon. I am your prioner, deal with me as you pleae, onely grant me my liberty, without which, I cannot make good, as I deire, the title of

closer.signed: your though rude, yet real Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. D. P.
div.p:
PReuming your goodnes will pardon the rudenes of the addres, I have ent a brace of Pamphlets to kis your hands. Being concient to themelves of their own unworthinee, like trewant Scholars, they durt not appear without an Apologie; neither hould they, or this, but that I know you daily meet with uch Exercies of your patience, and that I know you have indulgent charitie enough to cover the faults of thoe you love. Pleae you to upend your everer thoughts, and to make a mall truce with your nobler employments, I hall humbly beg their pardon in a very few words. That they came no ooner, was out of neceity; that I hall crave you will vouchafe to indulge; that they come now, is out of duty, and that I hall promie my elf, you will deign to accept. Sir, I hate to be officiouly injurious to my friends and therefore I will not increae my fault in excuing theirs: only let me impetrate one thing more, which, I conceive, will deceive your expectation. It is not that you will correct their faults, that the world knows you can do; nor that you will forgive them, that your wonted candor flatters me you will doe; but, that having atteined your hands (which are the bounds of their ambition) they believe they have obteined their end, and they deire not to out-live that
happinee; but that you will condecend, as I have made them an offering, to make them a acrifice, be you the Priet, your harth the Altar, and their Urne; and beides the courteie you hall do your elf, in aving the reading of uch nugacities, you hall thereby anwer their deert, and my deire, who am o far from craving their reprieve, I would my elf be the hatener of their punihment. Here would I ceae, but I am loth to leen the noble office of your mercie; by what impule of pirit I know not, but uch is the tendencie of my deires, to expree the realitie of their profeions to your ervice, that to ay I love you, is beneath the ardor of my affection: I am ready to profee, with that old Roman, who proclamed, he was not onely in love with Cato, but inchanted with him. Onely here is the defect, that, as the Italians ay, He that paints the flower, cannot paint the mell: So, in profeing my ervice to you, I cannot dicover the realitie farther than you will pleae to give me credit, and believe that I am

closer.signed: your mot real Friend, and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. T. J.
div.p:
WHat in Superiors is counted gift and bounty, in Inferiors amounts to no more than homage
and gratitude: And well it is, if, in tead of abating, it increae not the audit of their Obligations. Such is the nature of the preent; and though it pretend not to acquit the leat part of that debt your civilitie hath involved me in, yet hall I hope it may arrive at the tender of a grateful acknowledgment; and I wih my thanks may prove but as large, as you were liberal. Think it not trange that I have been thus long ilent, nor account me an unclean beak, if I till chew the chud in a thankful remembrance. Sir, the noble entertainment you vouchafed to me, a tranger hath cherihed the incloed pamphlets into a confidence, that you will deign them not onely a favourable acceptance, but that your goodnee will alo grant them the benefit of the late Act of Pardon, without which, they will eem as much trangers to our Common-wealth, as their Author was to your elf, who hould now too much wrong your noble nature, if he hould not profee himelf,

closer.signed: your mot indebted Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. A.
div.p:
I Being of late arreted at the uit of ome importunate occaions, which would willingly be called neceary, I have been o much their
prioner, that till I had atisfied the utmot minute, I was o far from a poibilitie of being your ervant, that I was not my own Mater. Now mut I compound with you, and intreat, that if my o long ilence deerve not to be anwered with a repeated act of that dormant pardon you long ince pleaed to grant me, yet, that you will at leat, accept of this as Interet, till opportunitie hall enable me to dicharge the whole. I hall now begin to turn the weekly hour-glae of our Commerce, and hereafter meaure my life by my letters: For, though I have intermitted my contant coure you are in no more likelyhood to be rid of this trouble, than you have hopes of loing your Ague by the alteration of the fits. If friendhip be the incorporating of two bodies, by an union of ouls making but one of two: Me thinks, this contant correpondence fitly anwers to that deervedly applauded notion of the Circulation of the Blood. It hall be my care, that no top be made on my ide, that we may preerve the life of our Friendhip, during the life of

div.head: To Mr. T. P.
div.p:
BEides the natural Antipathy of my Genius to Controveries, I have been of late o divorced
from my elf and my own thoughts by the motion of an higher wheel than my own occaions, that I am altogether dicouraged to give you any account of this piece, upon o tranient a view, that I fear I hall give you as ill an account of it, as he did of Venice to King James, that told him, He knew nothing of it, for he rode pot through it: Yet, to atisfie your command, againt all thee dicouragements, I hall adventure a few haty lines to your more etled judgment. Sir, did not the Authors worth out-poize thoe petty exceptions that might be taken in advantage, as the carce ene of the title, and ome other inconiderate expreions in the whole, that eem to clah one againt another, I hall onely commend to your conideration thee few thoughts. The Proverb is common (wherein wit and experience club, to ay much in a little) That marriages are made on Earth, but matches are made in Heaven. I am eaily induced to believe, that the omnicient providence, which decends to take care of the falling of a parrow, and the number of our hairs, hould much more take care of that grand Climacterical Action of a mans life, the retoraration of his lot rib: I hall therefore not fear to affirm, that a man hits not upon his mate by chance or caualty, but by the undeclinable • ate of Gods prae-determination: And having laid down this for a ground, I hall adventure this Supertructure, that it is not in the power of a man to di-joyn himelf from the companion which providence hath joyned him to, in o indioluble a link of amitie, that one member is not
more truly a part of a mans body than his Wife; and therefore he ought rather to undergoe with patience what God hath ordained him, perhaps for other reaons than he can undertand, than to forgoe it with wilfulnee. I remember it was the reolution of a compleat man, That he took the untowardnes of his wife as a School of patience. Yet, to purue the Allegory, though I would not have a man to cut off a limb for a curable dieae, yet if it out-face art and nature in a remedy, then Ene recidendumet. And having done o, I cannot uppoe it lawful (though I hould grant all his aertions for indiputable truth) that uch a man hould admit another member, like a wooden leg; and, if I mitake not (to help him a little) the weight of our Saviours argument, lies in the lat claue, that whooever puts away his wife for other caue than adultery, commits fornication, If he marry another. To come as near therefore as I can, to comply with your Author, I hall lay down this Poition, that it is altogether unlawful for a man or wife to divorce, If both parties be not equally agreeing to it, and if either of them marry again. And to this I hall add this inconvenience, that being parted, they mut not expect that the Devil, who is the Father and Factor of diviions, will be les active in o wide a breach, that is o ready to widen the leat cranny of dicontent into his advantage: He that will creep in when the doors are hut, hall we imagine him to be lee willing to enter when they are wide open? This farther, I mut confes, there are ome natures o Hetrogenious,
that the treightet, and mot gordion knot of Wedlock is not able to twit, of which the Epigrammatit peaks my mind better than I can my elf:

lg.l: Non amo te Sabide, nec poum dicere quare,
Ho • tantum poum dicere, non amo te.

div.p: Take the Englih, is the words of a Gentleman to his wife.

lg.l: I love thee not Nel,
But why, I can't tell:
But this I can tell,
I love thee not Nel.

div.p: So that I mut confee I cannot but afford them my pitie, that are thus joyned in you know whoe phrae, like a Spread-Eagle, with one body but two heads: But whether this diviion ought to make a Divorce, I had rather ubcribe to your judgment than tell you my own, who am

closer.signed: wholly at your dipoe, T. F.

div.head: To Dr. S.
div.p:
NOt to confes your favours, were a ullennes beyond the in of ingratitude; they were too late to be forgotten, and too large to be requited Civilities, that might very well contitute a Turkih Paradie: A debt beyond my
meannee to dicharge, o that you have paid me before-hand for all the ervices I hall ever be able to do you: And it hall be my endeavour, that my performances of your commands, may be as wift as Lightning; or the flights of that Bird, which is happy to make his net in your Arms. My thanks will bear the better weight (for they are too light of themelves) if you pleae to tender them to Mr. L. whom it were a Solecime to put lat: To your elf varyed, and your elf multiplied: And give me leave to kie your hands, as I give you mine, that I am

closer.signed: your much obliged Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. A.
div.p:
IT was once my mierie, and your good fortune, that I have had, of late, no leiure to dicharge my weekly tribute, which indeed amounts to no more, upon your audit, than the product of a contant trouble. Aure your elf, I take no pleaure in being my own enemie: For how many rare fi • h might my coure bait happily have taken! But truly, I have been o crampt, or rather crippled with ome not unneceary diverions,
that my pen hath been forced to wander from the direct road of your ervice. Now, having retrived an opportunitie of in happying my elf, by this literal exchange, I hall take leave to tell you, that I will not forgive my elf, till you pronounce my pardon. And I cannot but indulge my hopes, with confidence that you will once more exercie that noble virtue, from the many repeated acts of which goodnee, I am apt to plead pr • cription. Though, having dealt o unworthily with you, I am omething upitious you will retract that title of worth, your friendhip hath formerly fatned on my unworthines, and no longer vote thoe lines for jewels, which in the midt of Summer, preent you with conceits as cold as ice, or our modern charity. However, in obedience to the Sovereignty of your Judgment' I hall reolve to etimate my elf by your valuation of me, and make your opinion the Standard, whereby to meaure my abilities to your Service. And, as we meaure our hours by minutes, and thoe by the minuter attoms of and, may my everal Letters but run into Syllables, by which together you may read me (though imperfectly)

closer.signed: your very faithful Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. F.
div.p:
PArdon the bahfulnee of my Pen, that hath been hardly drawn to the preumption of endeavouring an anwer to your ingenious lines. Had my fancie been better, or yours wore, you had long before this time received an Anwer. But uch is the unequal fate of the greatet merits, that they alwayes meet with the leat returns; tupendious worth exacting from our urprized enes, but admiration (at bet) in tead of praie; and admiration is never o well dres'd, as when 'tis cloathed in ilence. Sorry I am that you hould wate your o great repects upon one that deerves o little, and that hath nothing to return you, but the protets of a mot real affection. The Gentleman you peak of, I have not yet een, nor heard of, but in your relation: Whenever he comes, aure your elf he hall be as welcome as his own worth and your commends can render him: But he hall pardon me, if I wih rather it had been your elf. It is an Age, me thinks, ince I enjoyed you, and I grow old in my unhappinee: 'Tis in your power to create a Spring in my oul, and to make thoe faculties live again, that have hitherto been buried in a ilent grave of negligence. One li • e of yours will be trong enough to draw me from that depth of dulnee into which ome late melancholly
thoughts have thrown me, though it were as profound as the pit wherein Truth lieth hidden. The fire that hines in your expreions is onely able to call forth that quondam ingenuitie you accue me of: If ever I enjoyed any uch thing, 'twas when I enjoyed you; and that left me, when I left London: Like inects in Winter, retired to their firt nothing, as reolving to enjoy no life, in the abence of the Sun their Father. Since I cannot encircle you in peron, let me embrace your picture, and let your pen upply the ilence of your tongue. If you will ometimes vouchafe me this happines, I hall quit cores with my wihes, and reolve to be no happier in this unhappy Age. Thus, becaue you have expected it long, I have at length returned you a long Letter, to aure you that I am, and mot incerely

closer.signed: your Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. A.
div.p:
THis Letter mut begin, where yours ended' becaue, what you commend to me as an object of my pitie, hath been the ubject of my thoughts; for it is impoible my friends hould uffer any los, and my elf not be enible of, and orrowful for it. If the tream of your grief may be ubtracted by diviion, I refue
not, and that willingly, to take my part, that yours may be the les. The caue that challengeth our grief (for now 'tis mine as well as yours) peaks it elf in the los of a Friend, of a Mother. To begin with that ends all, Death, me thinks, I can find as little caue to lament, as to wonder at it, it being o general a neceitie, that none ever did, or ever hall avoid it. We were born to live, and live to die. It is the onely thing we can here expect, without a forta • , the onely certainty of which we cannot be deprived. Epictetus wondred no more to ee a mortal man dead, than to ee an earthen pitcher broken. And as wie a Philoopher as the former, entertained the newes of his Sons deaths, with no more but a Scivi eos mortales ee natos: As being a greater wonder that they hould have o long, than that they died o oon. Why hould we wonder, or grieve, to ee one goe before us, the ame way that we our elves mut follow. Vale, vale, nos t • equemur, was the olemn leave the Ancients took of their deceaed friends; and, if we believe the Grammarians, from thence we call a Funeral Exequiae, the ame being noted not without a ilent leon in our common cutome, of the Coare's going before, and the attendants following after. It is Seneca's obervation, Nature hath ordained that to be common, which we account o heavy, that the cruelty of the fate may be leened by the equality. But 'tis the death of a Mother, and here nature and affection will put in a plea, and plead precription for our grief; yet may we entertain our fortune with dry eys.
We know he was mortal, and o liable to the common • ate; a mother, and o by the order of nature to goe before her children: She was before them, that they might be after her. It was thought ominous among the Jewes, and not without the re-mark of a punihment, for the Father to burie the Son, as if it were an inverion of the coure of nature, and not to be een without a Prodigie. But I remember what the Schools teach: That an Angel of an inferiour, cannot enlighten a uperiour Hierarchy: Yet I preume you will excue the rahnes of the attempt, ince it proceeds from the affection of one devoted to be in all relations

div.head: To Mr. C. A.
div.p:
THat a dicoure of death from a ick peron, and firm arguments from an infirm and haking brain, hould have the good hap to rout, or, at leat, to prevent the triumph of your orrows, was certainly to be acribed to the benevolent Planet that co-operated in their production; or rather, to your own more favourable Apect.
