I hall not purue a flying enemy, nor torture that argument to a martyrdome, that is already a willing Confeor. Your quoted Author hath expreed himelf Fuller, than the
malnes of my reerve pretends to. That the death of one, breaks anothers heart, is not afe to contradict, ince it hath obteined the general vote of a Proverb. But I hall humbly adventure to lay the Scene at a greater ditance, and date it from that Golden Age when hearts were o entwined, they could not part without breaking, when that Gordian knot of amitie was not to be united, till it were cut by the Sythe of him that out-conquers Alexanders word. Were it not to upbraid the preent Age by the comparion, I could willingly venture at a Character or Encomium of that venerable Friendhip, the Imitation of former, and Depiar of later Ages. But I hall do the ubject more right to commend it to your more commanding Pen, and tudy always to make good the precie value you are pleaed to put upon

closer.signed: the meanet of your ervants, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. D. P.
div.p:
WHether this hould be an Apologie for my former, perhaps too frequent viits, or my later, as uncivil forbearance, I know not, ince both have been equally liable to the piquant cenures of detracting tongues; and in o loud an accent, that I quetion not but they have long ince arrived your eares. It is not my intention
to make this paper guilty, by relating thoe tories which would be tedious for me to write, and troubleome for you to read. Had they been vented with as much innocence as falhood I could have looked upon them as ome pretty Romances, and at once both laugh'd at the Relation, and pitied the Relator. But finding them o loaded with the over-weight of candal, as well as lander, I hould belye my own thoughts, if I hould not ay they have touched the mot enible part of my oul. That I have hitherto been ilent, and contented my elf to be an auditor onely, was, that o, if it had been poible, they might have found a grave in their birth And it is a common aying among the Jewes, That lyes have their feet cut off; they cannot tand long to what they ay. But ince I ee (by what deigne I know not) that they have already out-lived the common age of a wonder, though I know you are too wie to take up any ware upon trut from uch walkingpedlers (for o I am informed the original peaks a Tale-bearer) I am not altogether diffident of your pardon if I hall enter my protets (which is all the re-action I hall endeavour) that whatever ome have fancied, or others reported, I never propounded any other end to my elf (either in a direct or collateral line) in my approches, than to make my elf happy by the enjoyment of your ocietie. This was the caue that inducted me into your acquaintance, and I am not concient to my elf of any Apotacy from my firt reolutions, or that thoe real intentions have uffered any dilapidations. I mut
confes, 'twas my ambition to rival your goodnes, and to make my repects (i • it had been poible) as infinite as your merit; and I have read, that excees in friendhip are not onely tolerable, but laudable. But that what I thought obedience, hould be interpreted impudence, is a fale contruction of the Syntaxis of my intentions. 'Twas not your fortune, but your favour that I have courted; were you as poor as Codrus, I hould love you no les than I do; and were you as rich as Croeus, I could love you no more. I conceived my elf obliged by my Profeion to wait upon you as a Scholar, and by your courteies, engaged to love you as a friend; and if this be a crime, I bluh not to confes my elf guilty in a very high meaure: But if any of my words have been wrack'd by others, to make them depoe any thing contrary to what I here profes, believe them not. I lit not to enter the pitch'd field of a dipute; nor will I retreat to the common intrenchments of excues, I lay down my Arms at your feet: And, as I can have no other witnes, I will have no other Judge but your elf; reolving to be either innocent, or guilty, as you hall pronounce me. It was no mall commendation Paterculus gives of Pompey the Great, where he affirms, that he was Amicitiarum tenax, in offenis exorabilis, in recipiendâ atisfactione facilimus: Of this I believe your continual practice an exact Tranlation. What though the Comical Speech of Florence be Canonical, Mulier aut amat, aut odit nihil et tertium; it would be as fally applied to you, as truly to the Sex 'tis poken of. And
for my part you hall do me but right to believe that I ever was, am, and will be

closer.signed: your Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C.
div.p:
NOt out of any uncivil di-repect to your commands, nor any unwillingnes to erve you (o far as the too hort line of my abilities will tretch) have I hitherto been ilent. Could I have wrought my elf to that height of preumption, as to think any thing of mine of merit enough to arret your ight, you had long ince had an anwer, and perhaps as long as your expectation. It was not that I thought a letter lot to me, but becaue I knew it would be los to you; and hereof this is too ufficient a witnes. Yet, Sir, let you hould think I am either too full of buines, that I cannot, or of idlenes, that I will not write to you, I have ent thee lines to kis your hands, and to aure you, that you have infinitely obliged me by your late letters you vouchafed to honour me with: So full fraught were they of your wonted ingenuitie, that (to tell you the truth) I could pare no time from reading of them, to return any anwer to them. But now, ince you are pleaed to decend o far below your elf, as to entreat for what you might command, I hall no
longer dipute, but obey: Yet will I not tire my elf with troubling you, farther than to re-aure you that I am

closer.signed: your very humble Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C.
div.p:
HAving already confes'd the debt, your late ingenious Letters have engaged me in, I hall take leave to pay you (ince you are pleaed to grant me that favour) as unolvent debtors do their patient creditors, by mall ums weekly. I would willingly peak my gratitude in as loud an accent as you have done your goodnes: But, as you have honoured me beyond the utmot of my wihes, and placed my meannes on o high a pinacle of happines, as my mot ambitious thoughts durt never apire to; o you have onely left me modetie enough to bluh at my own unworthines, and to promie you, that I hall hereafter lay hold on every handle of time, and court all opportunities to erve you. But, Sir, I wih you have not undervalued your judgment, by over-valuing thoe looe lines you undertake to call mot choie jewels; which ('tis my fear) will prove but pebbles, or Britow-tones at bet: If they carrie any thing of jewels in them, it is onely this, that they have nothing of worth, but what your valuation puts
upon them. However, ince it cannot be admitted as Hitory of what I am, may it prove a Prophecie of what I may be, and that my endeavours may overtake the mark your charitie hath already anticipated, that you may not repent that you have owned me for

div.head: To Mr. J. S.
div.p:
SO long it is ince I received your Letter, that I hould be ahamed to confes it, did I not believe that I have hitherto done you a courteie, by not troubling you with my rude lines: yet dare I no longer maintein that opinion, let you hould vote that for a neglect, which I have thought a favour. You would pardon, if not pitie me, did you know how I have been rack'd with diverions, neither pleaant, nor profitable, but as vexatious as the tediounes of the law, and the much buines of the Lawyers could render them But, I am now in hope that my Caue will hang in upence no longer than till the next Aizes. The old rule was, Inter arma ilent leges: I hall alter it, and ay as truly, Inter leges ilent literae I mut hope my friends will forgive me the Lawyers faults, ince they have rob'd me of the mot necearie functions of my life: nay, I am in doubt whether I may put this lat year
into the account of my life, ince I have not had time to tender you the ervices and repects due from

div.head: To Mr. C. M.
div.p: YOur civil reception of the tender of my endeavours to your ervice, hath made me preume, that your goodnee will maintein your firt favour with a econd; and, if occaion erve, to mention my deires to thoe noble Gentlemen in conjunction with you; from whom I cannot depair of a favourable Apect, being repreented by o happie a Medium as your elf. But I hould be too injurious to the publick good, to detein you longer from your more noble employments. I hall onely beg the happinee of a room in your memorie, in qualitie of

closer.signed: your mot humble Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. T. P.
div.p:
HAving long ince received your Letter and not receiving any anwer, you might jutly think I either not received, or lighted your command. But, when you have read this, you will believe that my ilence was neither out of loth, nor lighting; it being much againt my will that I have deprived my elf of the pleaure I take in erving you. The reaons that obliged me this delay, were more jut than I wih they had been: For, this vagrant Pamphlet that now attends you, was tragled from me, and much time pas'd before I could procure a Pas to end it home to the place of its birth. Since when, I undertood that your occaions called you to a greater ditance, which rendred me uncapable of erving you. Thus, Sir, you ee it was not out of any covetous or envious humour, or a fear of the expence of a few lines; which when you have them, are o worthles, that I might have done you a greater courteie to have forborn them now. Onely this rudenes may erve to let you ee how much I eteem you my friend, in that I have taken no more care to entertain you with that tudied repect which I hould, to any but my Familiar. I hall not Apologize for the rudenes of this undret Pamphlet, which now waits upon you in obedience to your call; nor tell you, that I
deire you would read it to your own ears onely; nor that I hall long to ee it again: But onely deire you to remember what place you hold in the number of his firt friends, who is

closer.signed: your old Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To M. C. F.
div.p:
I Have heard of thoe men-moles, that Ner •
like, rip up the entrails of their Mother Earth, to plunder her of her hidden Excrements (who many times dig o long under ground, that they meet with their own graves before they are willing) though none of the bet men, yet have they this good qualitie, that they are continually calling and talking to one another, that if a udden damp hould urprize any of them, the ret may peedilie be readie to help and ait them. It is no hame for the bet to learn what's good, though from the wort of men. Conidering therefore the many clouds and vapours that continually are readie to overwhelm and tifle us in this vault of earth (where we are but day-labourers) it is a necearie dutie of friends to be frequent in thee Offices of friendhip. How unhappie had I been, had that boiterous wind blown down your earthlie tabernacle, and deprived me of a friend without any warning! And though my eyes and ears were
lately the happie witnee of your recoverie: Yet, me thinks, I know not how to credit them, till you vouchafe to give it me under your hand and eal, and confirm to me the continuance of my health and happines in yours. Certainly, there is more intended in thee viits, than common cutome and complement. Letters are the lawful Spies and Intelligencers of amitie; the honourable Leigers to continue a good correpondencie amongt friends. And, if, as our late Phyicians hold, mot dieaes and ditempers of the bodie are occaioned by the topping of the bloods circulation, urely, the omitting of thee correpondencies, breed no good blood, but, like the intermitting pule, proclame the decay, if not the death of friendhip. It is not enough that you are alive and well, unles you tell me o, and communicate your happines to me, by the information. I cannot afely ay I am well, unles I know my friends are o, who are my elf. Let your Letters ometimes tell me how I do, and be at once my phyick and Phyician; and I hall duly pay you the Fee of being

div.head: To Mr. S. S.
div.p: HAving ounded a retreat to my elf from my former, perhaps too familiar convere with the world; being able by experience to confirm the wie mans cenure, that it is not only vanity, but vexation of pirit. I have confined my elf to my own home: Yet, becaue man is Animal ociale, and God himelf thought it not fit for Him to be alone, I have undertaken (that lawful Negromancie) to convere with the dead; the bet and mot impartial intructors. I hall make bold (in obedience to your command) from your well-furnihed Market, to borrow ome upply: For knowledge is truly pabulum Animae, and Books the bet Caterers of that entertainment. Had I time, I would venture at an Encomium of thoe bet of Companions. But the meenger tayes, and I cannot. Let me therefore (without a Preface) crave the priviledge of your Fuller; from whoe Pigath, I am ambitious to take a view of that Holy Land for which, and your many former favours, I mut ubcribe my elf

div.head: To Mr. T. L.
div.p: AMongt the ill turns of my cros fortune, it was not the leat, that I could not attein the happines of eeing you, when lat in London; though your goodnes often endeavoured it, and I was not idle in the like returns. If you will pardon me my City-misfortune, in recompence, I will enjoyn my elf the penance, or rather the happines of a twelve miles pilgrimage, to kis your hands, at your own home, when the weather and the way hall o far be-friend me. In puruance of that ervice I owe you, I have now ent, &c.—I uppoe you expect, and I preume, as good and as cheap as you could have bought them: For I would willingly obtein your belief, that my ervice to my friends is not mercenary; and that I look not to be paid again for thoe acts of dutie which your courteies have paid me for before-hand. This is no complement, but the real, though ex tempore dictates of my Heart.

div.head: To Dr. S.
div.p: THe ingenious Italians have three ignificant phraes whereby they character a work exactly done. They ay, it was performed, Con diligenza, con tudio, & con amore. Without any ambition, I mut crave leave to tell you, that in order to the content I take in erving my friends, and epecially your elf (to whom I am bound by o many repeated acts of friendhip) I have not failed in any of thoe particulars in my earch for—. For, to have enjoy'd the pleaure of atisfying your expectations, I ued all the diligence and care that could be thought on: For I think I left not a hop unviited, though yours were my onely errand, and, but for one place, I mut have returned with a non et inventus. Sir, your goodnes makes me apt to believe, that you will not cenure the Act by the Iue; and I hall live in hope, that ome other command may render me more happy in the performance Let the hortnes of my time and paper excue this abrupt tender of my thanks and ervice to your elf, your good bedfellow, and the ret of your happie Familie; and do me the favour, or rather the jutice, to believe me to be

closer.signed: your very ready and real ervant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. S. S.
div.p: AS needie debtors pay one um, but with an intent to borrow a bigger; o I end you home three Books, with a requet to borrow a fourth. Thus doe I link your courteies, and my engagements together; and knowing the undoubted fertilitie of your friendhip, I hall make every former favour the Parent of another. So that, if it be a fable that Pliny tells of ome Mice in Caria, that are o fruitful, that the young ones are with young in their Dams belly: The pregnant acts of your Friendhip may be the Moral. I hall therefore requet the ue of your Plutarch's Morals, which (I doubt not) will intruct me how to return you due thanks for your many courteies, whereby you have o many times bound me to be

closer.signed: your thankeful Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. C. F.
div.p:
OF all pleaures, reading is the bet: of all readings, thoe Antelucanas Lectiones are to me the mot pleaant and profitable. And urely there is omething in it, that Lectus and Lectio are of near affinitie. Thee are the onely Curtain-Lectures. Not long ince I fatened upon Sir Richard Bakers Soliloquie, or, as he calls it, Pillar of thoughts; deervedly o tyled, for the olidity of the compoition, the rarenes of the materials, and height of the fancie. There, amongt other choie notions, he falls upon the immortality of the Soul, and hath o well dicharged himelf in it, that he hath left no place for a Sceptick to ret in: Onely I could not ee (for indeed my candle is not of the larget ize) how he doth clearly evince the Original of the rational oul, but (with St. Augutine) refueth to determine whether it be propagated, or infued. I dare not reolve, where o great men doubt, and wherein the oul it elf is ignorant, or ilent; as if it had drank of Virgils Lethe, before it came into the bodie, forgetting how it came there. Weighing the arguments of both ides, my reaon holding the ballance with an equal hand, the arguments for the Traduction, in my eye eem to be mot weightie. Perhaps becaue I know not how to anwer them. When I conider the births of batards, and other uch
like irregular productions (the Anomalies of nature) I cannot (me thinks) alve Gods jutice, who, if the oul be not ex traduce, mut favour thoe irregularities, o much againt his Holines: And what hath the poor innocent oul done, to be imprioned in a inful polluting bodie? For, if the oul be not propagated, then the bodies of Infants onely have inned, and are onely liable to the punihment of Original in. Now certainly, it cannot be properly aid that the bodie inneth, for the bodie is but the ouls intrument, and what evil hath the oul of a young dying Infant committed, if his oul were not derived from Adam? And if the oul be infued, who doubts but that it comes pure and unpotted from the hands of God? It was an errour reckoned upon the core of the Arrians, that our Saviour took onely fleh of the Virgin, but not the oule: But it is the opinion of the Church of England, that Chrit took mans nature upon him in the Virgins womb; whence it mut necearily follow, that he took both body and oul, ince either, without the other, make not perfect man. Yet, if this be evaded, as extraordinary, in the Hitorie of the Creation, when God took Eve out of Adams ide, it is not aid, that He breathed into her the breath of life, as before He did to Adam: Perhaps (and if ilence may be interpreted conent) to intimate that her oul was derived with her body from the man. But, that the oul, which Philoophers call Anima, compoed of the vegetative and enitive faculties, is ex traduce, is yielded; the onely quetion being about the Spiritus, which, they ay, is the
breath of God, infued in the third, or four th' or ixth moneth; or, to ay truth, they know not when. Now, if this Spirit be infued before the birth, why ee we not the effects and workings of this Spirit? But it eems as dull as the body is feeble; whereas, experience tels us, Chickens as oon as hatch'd, fall to pecking, ducklings to padling, the colt fals to ucking as oon as foald, the lamb as oon as faln; whereas this Spirit in man is not een, till almot the third part of his life be pent, and perhaps not at all Let a child be brought up in a wood, or a wildernes, what difference will appear between him and a beat? So that this Spirit eems to be encreaed by, if not derived from civil ocietie, and liberal education; whereas, if the oul be infued by God, that it mut come perfect from his hands, who makes a quetion? Thee things my faith can eaily leap over, and turn thee mountains into mole-hils; but my reaon is at a tand, and craves the favourable aitance of your courteous hand, becaue I know you will doe it, and that dexterouly. If you have the good fortune to rout thee light arguments, which I end out as my forlorn hope, I have yet a reerve left, which may tell you, that a man may be victus in praelio, and yet victor in bello. But I leave you to your good fortune, with aurance that your enemy is no other than

closer.signed: your Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: D. P. B.
div.p: INfandum (Philippe) jubis renovare dolorem Dolorem ub igillo ilentis ignandum ee, vel lachrymis potius quam verbis exprimendum Nefandâ illâ nocte, flagranti amicitiâ, fluenti eloquentiâ, medio de fonte leporum, urgit amari aliquid. A Cacumine montium um dejectus, è Paradio ejectus; in orbem iturus, rediturus nunquam: foemininae linguae gladius veratilis regreum prohibet.

Heu! quae nunc tellus, quae me aequora pount accipere, aut quid jam miero mihi denique retat? Silentium olim pendidit Amyclas, jam vana loquacitas perdidit Amicos. Nunc eriò, ah nimis era! illud C • mici, Mulier aut amat, aut odit, nihil et tertium. Tu tamen vale & contanter Ama.

div.head: To Mr. S. S.
div.p:
CHritian moderation is the bet reconciler of all controveries; for it hath been too often found by ad experience, that in the heats of
diputations, men have ought victory, rather than verity, Truth being often lot by an overhot and haty earch: Witnes the many, and too eager Diputes concerning Admiion to the Lords Supper; to which ome men, by a too haty, and les charitable zeal, have excluded all, though never o worthy, let they hould loe the authoritie of Examination, which the Scripture no where commands, no • hardly anywhere allowes; it being not poible for any man to know what is in man, but the Spirit of man which is within him. The Apotle St. Paul therefore layes the injunction upon every man to examine himelf, not ending him to another to uurp the power of Auricular Confeion, which they condemn in the Papits, yet would exercie themelves. I denie (under ubmiion) that any man can hew any one direct place of Scripture that commands or enjoynes the Miniter to examine his Parihioners; it being his Office to teach them their duties, to reprove them for, and convince them of their errours, and it is left to the people to examine and reform themelves by that glae which the Miniter holds out unto them. We accue the Romanits (and jutly) of grand Sacriledge, for denying the Cup unto the people, whilet we are deprived not onely of part, but of all. How jutly, let the Scripture, and the practice of all Ages (till ours) hew. It is denied that Judas received the Sacrament with the other diciples, though three Evangelits abolutely relate it, and the fourth doth not denie it. It is alo denied, that the Sacrament is a converting
Ordinance, becaue the Scripture doth not ay o in expree terms: By better reaon we ay it is, becaue the Scripture no where denies it, and reaon it elf peaks the ue of it to be verbum viibile, it etting forth Chrit and his Paion to our eyes, as the Word preached doth to our eares; and we have alwayes been taught, that the Eye is the aptet Scholar If it be not a Preaching action now, it is becaue we have it not to ee; ele to what purpoe did our Saviour command us to ue it in remembrance of him? That all hould receive the Sacrament of the Supper, becaue all have been Baptized, is an argument framed onely by the Con • uters thereof; for none (that I know) who plead for a free admiion, but make ome exception from this general rule, as infants, fools, and excommunicate perons; for that all have a right to eat, is an argument never maintein'd, the onely quetion being who have this right, and who have not? That Infidels, Ideots, and Children have not, all agree, for reaons too plain to be quetioned. That candalous perons have no right, we denie not neither, onely ay, they are not to be accounted o, till excommunicated: Nor can that man be lawfully accounted guilty in the ence of the Law, till proofs have convicted, and entence determined him to be o: For to denie a man the priviledges his birth allowes him till the Law determine that he hath forfeited them, is an injutice, and no command of Chrit or Scripture. Sure I am, the Mater in the Parable reproved not his ervant for admitting him without the wedding garment, it
was their part to invite all, and if any would preume to come unfitted, it lay upon himelf to bear the entence of their Lord; the Apotle telling us, as it is a dutie upon every one to examine himelf, o he comes upon his own peril, to eat and drink his own damnation. And becaue he that eats and drinks unworthily, eats and drinks his own damnation; yet it followeth not that the Sacrament hould be denied them: For who knows not, that though a man have been looe and careles in his converation, yet God may work a change in him in an intant, even in the very act of Adminitration: And certainly, no meanes ought to be denied any man, that may conduce to, if happily not produce that good end for which all the Ordinances of the Gopel are ordained. But I forget, I intended a Letter, not a Dipute, ince without controverie I am

closer.signed: your Friend and Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. S. S.
div.p:
I Am not at all infected with that itch of Diputation; how contrary it is to my more peaceable temper, all that know me can witnee. But having routed the main body of your arguments, I hall now catter your reerve. It is aid the Church of Epheus is commended for
trying and judging of men: But it is clear by the next words, that this trial was of their doctrine, not of their lives; and that they were found fale Apotles. Neither can this (if it were as is pretended) authorize a particular Miniter to that, which may be lawful to the Church, it being too tender a thing to be truted with one man alone to determine; for what inconveniences would thence follow, may eaily be imagined. The Priets indeed (as you ay) were commanded to make a eparation between the clean and the unclean, but it was of beats for the acrifices, as the Texts expres themelves. And St. Peter aith God had hewn him, that he hould not call any man common and unclean: And St. Paul tells the Corinthians, that he had no power to judge them without. That Chrit gave the Supper onely to his Apotles, is plain, but it is as plain that one of them was a Judas; and what elect company was ever in this world, wherein was not ome cloe hypocri • e? and no Devil to the white Devil. I have done with your arguments, and hall now ound a retreat to my elf, and reolve to draw my pen no more in this quarrel: For I know not whether this kind of duelling be not forbidden by the late Act; if it be not, I wih it were, for I love not to contend with my friends with any other weapons than love and ervice. When you conquer me at thoe weapons, I mut forget your merit, or that I am

closer.signed: your friend and ervant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. T. F.
div.p:
HAving lately (not without pleaure and profit) read your Church-Hitory; by which, you have not only indebted our Church in particular, but the whole Common-wealth of Learning in general; my memory continually upbraided me with ingratitude, till I found out this way to convey my reentments. For, though our Returns of thanks ought to be large and univeral, as your merit, yet your goodnes (I hope) will not refue the ingle gratitude of private perons. In that number (though the lat, and the leat) I am bold to tender my mite. A task indeed better befitting a more equal pen, ince none is able to do it but your own. But I know your modety is as great as your merit, the highet worths being always accompanied with the lowet humiltie. May your name ever live, who have rais'd o many to life, and recued their memories from the tyranny of oblivion. Amongt many others, I am particularly obliged to your courteie, in the remembrance of that good man Mr. Udal, whom by kindred I am omething related. One, of whom we have this tradition, that he was the firt man King James asked for when he came into England; and being anwered, that he was dead, the King (whoe judgment was an exact tandard of learning & learned men) reply'd, By my al, then the greatet Scholar in Europe's dead. And certainly, by his own party (if they may be admitted for
competent Judges) it is not yet reolv'd, whether his Learning or his Zeal were greatet; and they think they jutly boat him a Confeor, if not a Martyr for that Caue, which ince hath paid thoe cores with Interet. Now, though I am no heir to his opinions, yet a mall affinity to his Peron, makes me embrace the opportunitie of proffering you that Intelligence you complain to want, the rather, becaue (perhaps) no man can now do it but my elf; and I have a Relation of all his Trials, Cenures, and Sentence, written by himelf; which (I doubt not) may give you a atisfactorie account in what you deire. If you pleae to command it, I hall be ambitious to erve you, and the truth therewith. But I could wih you would review that paage in the 31 Sect. After the Execution of Udal, &c. for he died at the White-Lyon (jut as his pardon was procured) and was buried at St. Georges Southwark. And o I leave him to his Ret, wihing his good name and doctrines may urvive his dicipline. Sir you have not onely engaged Learning, but Religion, to perpetuate your labours. Fame is much in arrears to your Deert, and therefore cannot in jutice but continue that veneration in length to your memorie, which it yet wants in breadth. Thoe Religious Houes, erected by a better devotion, than that which detroy'd them, are more beholding • o your Pen, than to their Founders, or Materials; you having made them a task for the remembrance and admiration of future Ages, o long as Time hall hold a Sythe, or Fame a Trumpet. I would ay more, if the univeral
applaue of all knowing men had not aved me a labour. And (to pay you in ome of your own coyn) It is no flattery to affirm, what envy cannot deny. Did I not fore-ee that the relation would well my dicoure beyond the limits of a Letter, or the length of your patience, I hould aume the libertie to inform you, that my neighbourhood to the place, acquaints me with ome Relicts of Religious Houes, at and near Ma • don, bearing till the name of an Abbey, a Friery, and a Nunnery. And, if we may judge of Hercules by his foot, of the whole piece by the remnant, and of them by their Remaines, I hould uppoe them not behind many in England. As yet, I know little of them, but their ruines; but, if you vote it convenient, I hall endeavour to improve my preent ignorance into a dicoverie of them I uppoe it will be no hard task; I am ure it hall not, when in relation to your command. I mut now take pitie of your patience, which had not run this hazard of abue, did I not know I have to do with o great a Candor, from which I can expect no les than pardon. And in that preumption I crave your leave to be, as I ubcribe my elf

closer.signed: your mot aured ervant, T. F.

div.head: To M.—
div.p: WEre I ure of the caue of your malady, I could eaily hope the Cure; but, being to gues at the one, it will be no wonder, if I mis the other. Of all dieaes, thoe of the mind are wort, of thoe, that of melancholy: of melancholies, the religious. I know not by what unhappy wit, the the badge of melancholy hath been fatned upon the pirit of Calvin, that Patriarch of Presbytery. This I know, ince that unhappy Planet hath reigned over us, we have too enibly felt all thoe unlucky effects that an ill-boading Comet could produce. What wars, what blood-hed, what ruines have we een in the State? What factions, what fractions in the Church? What envy, what hatred, what diviions amongt private perons? What doubts, what feares, what ditractions in all mens minds? In a word, what not?

Gladly doe I remember thoe happy dayes (now happy onely in the remembrance) that Golden Age, wherein we had but one Truth, but one Way, wherein men walked lovingly together, without contentious jutling one another. When thoe Silver Trumpets of the Sanctuary gave no uncertain ound; when the way to Heaven was, though a narrow, yet a plain and direct path; not block'd up by envious cenures, by ditracting clamours. But
now I adly ee, and igh to ay, our Rents are like to prove our Ruine, and our ditractions our detruction. I remember a Storie of a knavih Painter (o my Author calls him) who, being to make the Picture of ome goddes for a Citie to worhip, drew the Counterfeit of his own Mitris, and o caued her to be courted that (perhaps) better deerved to be carted. I wih this tale were not too true of our times. It is too obvious to conceal the Parallel. Do we not daily ee Religion dret up in the everal hapes of every ones fancie, and obtruded upon the eaie multitude, as the onely Deitie for their adoration and obervance? our faith made as changeable as our fahions? And, what's the mierie of our mieries, none are o eaily deluded, as the well-meaning, imple-hearted, honet Chritians; who, out of an excee of Charitie, are ready to believe all men mean truly, becaue they doe o themelves.

If this be your cae (and I am to eek if it be not) let me give you this Caution, Beware of that evil which commeth near to the hewof good; none can o eaily deceive you, as thoe Hyaena's, who have learn'd your voice, to draw you out of the way. Take heed of thoe erpents of the colour of the ground. Let St. Paul beeech you to mark them which caue diviions and offences: Contrary to the Doctrine which you have learned, and avoid them. I am mi-inform'd, if the ame word which we read Contrary, doth not alo import near. There are no opinions o dangerouly contrary
to the truth, as they that eem very near it.

Let me aure you, it is the old way, which is the good way, wherein you hall find ret. There hall you find a direct road, without any turnings and windings of private interet or faction: No briars and thorns of quarrelling diputes; no oul-detroying doctrines, under the otentious titles of oul-aving truths. It is no uch long and melancholy way, as we ee now chalk'd out by thoe who have found out new paths to heaven, that our Fathers never dream't of. There hall you find gravity without moroity and mirth without madnes; Chritian cheerfulnee as well commanded, as commended. Religion is no uch frowning fury: Palms and Hymns ar her daily practice, as well as prayers and teares. The ame Holy Spirit that commands us to pray alwayes, enjoyns us alo to rejoyce evermore. We in, if we rejoyce not: There is not more errour in fale mirth, than in unjut heavines. Can they be ad, who have a God to defend, a Chrit to ave, and an Holy Ghot to comfort them. It is for thoe that know not God, or know him dipleas'd, to droop, as men without hope.

An humble practice of thoe Common truths, alone neceary to alvation, is far more afe, more happy, than all the towring and lofty peculations of unquiet Heads, and too buie Brains. There is ome reaon in the old Scotch Rithme.

lg.l: Rob. Will. and Davy,
Keep well thy Pater noter, and Ave,
And if thou wilt the better peed,
Gang no farther than thy Creed:
Say well, and do none ill,
And keep thy elf in afety till.

div.p: Our way is not tedious, nor our burthen heavy; why then hould we add length to the one, and weight to the other, by an un-necearie adnes? Whilet hypocriie lies under the clouded brow of a Phariee; a cheerful countenance is the badge of innocence. It is a diparagement to our Mater, and his ervice, to follow him ighing, I have done. Pardon me this (perhaps un-neceary) length, and believe me, however the Phyick chance to work, it is tender'd with an hand ayming onely at your happinee; and that would gladly wih no better employment, than to trew your way to heaven with Roes. This is the height of his ambition, who is

closer.signed: your mot humble Servant, T. F.

div.head: To M. D. P.
div.p:
THe Italians ay in a Proverb, That words are but females, deeds are males. I can allow them to be females, o they be fruitful in thee
maculine productions, and not ubject to micarry of thoe fruits, with which they often eem o big. I have endeavoured my promies hould not prove abortive; but it hath taid o long by the Carriers Midwifry, that what you expected as a gift, will amount to a purchae; for, a courteie delay'd, is dearly bought. Beides, I cannot expect it hould arie to the merit of a gift, ince it will hardly amount to the leat mite that I owe you. Your courteies have been o many, your favours o large, and the continuance o long, that I depair of dicharging the Interet, hould your goodnes abate me the Principal. But if a thouand thanks, and ten thouand good wihes may pas for pay, you hall never have caue to call me ingrateful; for herein I can be as liberal as your elf. I remember the Dutch Hitory tells us, that at the Siege of Alcmar, the ouldiers within, being without pay, the Magitrates caued dollers of tin to be coyned, of three hillings a piece, with promie, that the Town being delivered, they would redeem them for good ilver at the rate. I will wrap up this poor preent with a faithful promie, that when propitious Heaven hall tranmute my tin and copper into gold and ilver, payments hall be more proportionate to your merits, and my obligations, by which I tand firmly bound to profes my elf

div.head: To M. J. W.
div.p:
NEither out of loth, nor lighting; not out of forgetfulnes, nor unwillingnes, have I hitherto delay'd this debt of duty, which you may jutly have expected ooner. Believe me, I have not yet forgot thoe many, many favours whereby you have perpetually bound me to erve you. My ilence thus long, hath been not out of negligence, but deigne. I was not willing to meet your orrow in its full careere, reolving rather to await the turning of the tide, and expect an ebb of your paion; let in tead of a lenitive, I had brought a corroive; and in tead of abating, encreaed your grief. By this time, I hope, your Reaon hath ubdued your Paion, and natural affection given place to Religion; which, as it allows a moderate orrow for the death of our friends and relations, o it appoints bounds to our tears, and commands us, Not to weep as thoe without hope. When my thoughts reflect upon your loe of o dutiful a daughter, o good a wife, o pleaant a companion, o true a friend, in the fair flower of her youth, in the pleaant Spring of her age; me thinks, I could mingle my tears with yours, and forget what I intended. But when agen I conider the mieries of this life, the troubles of this world, the loes and croes, the corroding cares, the doubtful fears that attend us here: when I ballance
our los with her gains, the mieries he is pat, with the happinees he enjoyes, I can find o little caue to mourn, that I mut confes we have infinitely more reaon to rejoyce. Alas! what is our life but a ea of troubles, a pilgrimage of dangers, a race, a warfare, a banihment; the world a prionfull of chaines and captives, at bet an Inn, no habitation? Death is our quiet harbour, an end of our journey, a concluion of our warfare; that brings us from exile to our native home; that gives us a Kingdome for a prion, crowns for chains, and for this poor baiting-place of earth, an everlating habitation in Heaven. Shall we then grieve for thoe are gone before us, who are releaed from the evils preent, and ecured againt thoe to come, who are taken from labour to ret, from expectation to fruition, from death to life. Is it not unjut? Is it not envious? The Philoopher, who was asked, Which was the bet hip? wiely anwered, That which is afely arrived. Shall we weep for thoe, who have already made their voyage, or rather for our elves, who are till toed upon the waters of trife, who are till ubject to thoe torms and tempets, which they have happily pat? They are not lot, but gone before; not perihed, but perfected; not dead, but departed. A long-ick man commanded this Epitaph to be written upon his grave, Here I am well. Fortune (they ay) mot hurts, whom he eems to favour; Death mot favours thoe he eems to hurt. Nor may we account an early death untimely: The fruit which to our apprehenion is blown down green and untimely, is gathered
full ripe in Gods providence. The fairet flowers oonet fade. The Sun and Moon, the mot bright and glorious of thee heavenly bodies, fulfill their coures in a hort eaon, whilet the dimmer and duller Planets are longer time wheeling about. It is ometimes the happines of young John, to out-run old Peter to the Sepulchre. This is Gods will, and therefore not to be reited, not to be repined at. It is their happines, therefore not to be lamented. Can our feares profit them where they are, or bring them back to us? I could allow you to be lavih of your ighs, to be prodigal of your tears, were they not unfruitful, were they not unlawful. I can eaily believe your los of her, to be as great as your love to her; but your meeting again will be more joyous, than your parting was grievous. But what do I do? I forget that I write to one, whoe Chritian carriage hath (I doubt not) already prevented me this office; and whoe excellent parts are able to anticipate whatoever I am able to ay. Give me leave onely to kie your hands, and once more to aure you, that I am till as much as ever,

closer.signed: the mot humble, and the mot real of your Friends and Servants, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. T. C.
div.p: IT is informed from everal parts, that the Butchers have knock't down the Excie-men, and cut the throat of the Excie upon meat: And they have o generally thrown off that yoke, that it is believed they will hardly be brought to admit the putting of it on again. Whither do thee confuions tend! Where will they end! We are like the poor As in the Fable, who often changed his Mater, but alwayes for the wore. Will not all thee mieries yet open the eyes of the blinded multitude! I would be-peak them in the words of Ananus, one of the Jewih Priets, inciting the people againt the factious Zealots; amongt other paages (which you may find in Joephus) he thus quetions them,—But why hould I exclame againt the tyrants? Did not you your elves make them great, and nourih their power and authority by your patience? Did not you, by depiing thoe who before were in authority, being but a few, make all thee, who are many in number, tyrants over your elves?

When Conuls ucceeded the Roman Kings, the Hitorian ayes, they changed gold for bras, and loathing one King, uffered many tyrants, courging their folly with their fall, and curing a feter'd ore with a poyoned plaiter. Do we not plainly ee the Fable moralized by our elves? The Serpents Tail would needs one
day fall a quarrelling with the Head, aying, that he would by turns goe before, and not alwayes come lagging behind; which the Head having yielded unto, was the firt that repented it, not knowing how, or whither he hould goe; and beides, was all rent and bruied, being forced, againt nature, to follow a member that had neither eeing nor hearing to conduct it. Our factions, fractions, and lawles liberty, render us like the poor Bactrans, of whom it is aid, that they are Sine Fide, ine Rege, ine Lege. But whither is my pen running? Since I began with the Excie in England, I will waft you over into Holland, where it firt began, and was invented; there you hall ee how ill the Dutchmen at firt relihed this Tax upon their drink: It occaioned this Libel in Dutch, which you hall read in Englih:

lg.l: I wih long life may him befall,
And not one good day there withal;
And Hell-fire after this life here,
Who firt did raie this Tax on Beer.

div.p: With this Potcript, The Word of God, and the Tax on Beer, lat for ever and ever.

But it is no wonder the Dutchman hould be o angry with this charge upon his drink, ince you know it is aid, Germanorum vivere, et bibere. And they account the turning of water into wine, the greatet Miracle that ever Chrit did; which miracle onely made one of them wih that Chrit had lived in their Country. No more now, but that I am till as always,

div.head: To Mr. T. C.
div.p: WE have now (thanks to our Preerver) lived to ee thoe men confuted to their faces, who would needs determine the end of the world, before the end of the year; and upon no better ground, that I could hear from any of them, than this, becaue (ay they) the old world was drowned in the year from the Creation, 1657. And I find the Learned Altedius fathering of this fancie, becaue he found the ame number of yeares in the Chronogram of Conflagratio Mundi. How mierably, and yet how often have the too credulous vulgar been deluded by the vain Predictions of uch idle Atrologaters! I remember Hollinghed tells a torie of the Prior of St. Bartholomews London, who built him an houe on Harrow-hill, to ecure himelf from a uppoed flood foretold by an Atrologer: But at lat, he, with the ret of his educed company, came down again as wie as they went up. Such is the fate and folly of thoe fale prophets, that they often live to ee themelves confuted. It is a witty jeer the Cambro-Britannian Epigrammatit puts upon the Scotch Napier, who more wiely had determined the end of the world at a farther ditance.
div.q: Cor mundi finem propiorem non facis? ut ne ant • obitum mendax arguerere: Sapis.
div.p: Thus, as is well oberved, by a late and Learned Author, Atrologers have told of a ad and dicontented day, which would weep it's eyes out in howers, which when 'twas born proved a Democritus, and did nothing but laugh at their ignorance and folly.

Infinite are the Stories upon Record of the madnes of thoe men, and the vanitie and credulity of the eaie multitude: Strange, that they hould be o groely, and yet o often cheated with the ame bait! But I conclude with a more erious obervation of Ludolphus, of the two detructions of the world: As the firt, ayes he, was by water, for the heat of their lut; o the econd hall be by fire, for the coldnee of their love. In hopes that ours is not yet grown cold, I ubcribe my elf,

div.head: To Mr. E. M.
div.p:
BOdin the Frenchman, in his Method of Hitory, accounts Englihmen barbarous for their Civil Wars: But his Countrymen, at this time, have no great reaon to cat dirt in our faces, till
they have wah'd their own. They who have hitherto et us on fire, and warm'd their hands by it, are now in the like flames themelves. It hath been one of their Cardinal Policies to divide us, let our union hould prove their ruine. It was the aying of the D. of Rohan, a great State-man, That England was a mighty Animal, and could never die, unles it kill'd it elf. Certainly we have no wore enemies than our elves, as if we had conpired our own ruine: For Plutarch calls the ardent deire of the Graecians to make Civil Wars in Greece, a Conpiracie againt themelves. But well may the winds and waves be Pilots to that hip whoe inferiour Mariners have thrown their Pylot overboard. Dum ille regnabat, tranquillè vivebamus, & neminem metuebamus, aid the people of the Emperour Pertinax. We remember the time when we lived in peace and plenty, till we urfeited of our happines; and as our peace begat plenty, o our plenty begat pride, and pride brought forth animoities and factions, and they, if not prevented, will be delivered of our ruine and detruction.

In times pat (ayes Cornelius Tacitus of our Countrymen) they lived under a Monarchy; now, that they are ubject to divers Maters, one can ee nothing but faction and diviions amongt them. This was poken of our forefathers; and our Poteritie will think it meant onely of us. The God of union re-unite us, and out of this Chaos of confuion, create an happy concord amongt us, before our rents prove our ruine, and our ditractions our detruction.
This is the contant and hearty prayer of

div.head: To Mr. T. C.
div.p:
I Mut tell you, you are not jutly troubled at the injutice of our new Judges, ince they have thereby rendred thoe brave men Martyrs, which otherwie had died as Criminals. Socrates his wife exaperated her grief by this circumtance, Good Lord, aid he, how unjutly doe thee bad Judges put him to death! What, wouldt thou rather they hould execute me jutly? replyed he to her. The injutice of the Judges entence, declare the jutnes of the condemned's caue. It is not the being a Judge that makes his entence jut, or the prioner guilty: There have been thoe, and we have een them, who have committed murther with the Sword of Jutice, and executed Jutice as a malefactor. Nor have the friends of thoe happy Martyrs any caue to be ahamed of, or grieved for their death, or manner of it: Damnari, diecari, upendi, decolari, piis cum impiis unt communia: (ayes Eramus) Varia unt hominum judicia, Ille foelix qui judice Deo abolvitur. The old Martyrs have accounted martyrdom the way to heaven on hor-back. The firt man that died
went to heaven, but the firt man that went to heaven died a Martyr, uffered a violent death by the hands of a cruel and unmerciful brother. We have lived to ee that politick principle of Periander put in practice, who being conulted with how to preerve a tyranny, bid the meenger tand till, whilet he, walking in a garden, topt all the highet flowers, thereby ignifying the cutting off, and bringing low of the Nobility. Yet will not this do with us; it is but like Cadmus his owing of erpents teeth, which will raie up armed men to revenge the quarrel of thoe brave pirits: For though our Curfeu-bell hath been rung out, and the fire of our zeal rak'd up in the ahes of Acts and Orders, yet it is not extinguihed: Witnes thoe Sparks who have revenged the death of their Sovereign with the hazard of their own lives.

By this time, I doubt not, but they who mot endeavoured his Majeties death, have een caue enough to wih him alive again, and are ready to engrave that Motto upon his Statue (which they threw down with contempt) which was et upon the Statue of the Roman Brutus, tinam viveres. It is yet ome comfort that we can mingle ighs, and ait one another with mutual counels and courteies, which hall never be wanting from

div.head: To Mr. T. L.
div.p: BEing lately at our New Court, there I aw his Highnoe, o environed with his guard, as if he had been their prioner, and wondred how he durt venture himelf amongt o many dangerous weapons. I was ready to have aid unto him, as Plato did to D • onyius the tyrant, when he aw him compaed about with many ouldiers of his guard, What, hat thou committed o many evils, that thou tandet in need of uch a guard of armed fellows? To ee the difference betwixt fearlee innocence, and fearful guilt! M. Aurelius, that good Prince, never had any guard; for (ayes my Author) he tood not in fear of his ubjects. Innocence is the uret guard, as Pliny told Trajan the Emperour: Haec arx inaccea, hoc inexpugnabile munimentum, munimento non egere. Frutra e terrore uccinxeret, qui eptus charitate non fuerit. Armis enim arma irritantur.

White-hall is now become Black-hall, with the moak of coals and matches: But it would make one ad and igh to ee what havock is made of his Majeties goods and houhold-tuff, and to whoe uing his houe & furniture is faln. It minded me of a tory in Q. Curtius, who ays, Alexander (that great robber, as the petty Pyrat call'd him) itting in Darius Seat, which was not fit for him, but higher than erved for
his tature, his feet could not touch the ground; one of his Pages put a board underneath for him to tread upon; whereat one of the Eunuchs that belonged to Darius, looked heavily, and fetch'd a deep igh, whoe adnee when Alexander perceived, he enquired of him the caue? He anwered: That when he beheld the board whereon Darius was wont to eat, employed to o bae an ue, he could not behold it without grief. Who can ee thoe brave hores which ued to draw his Majetics Coach, now drag in enemies cart, without pity & indignation? But enough of this, and for this time I am,

closer.signed: your very Friend, Servant, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. E. H.
div.p:
HAving now retrived my rude draught of that excellent, but lot virtue of friendhip, I end the picture to you the pattern, that it may be corrected by the comparion. It cannot be expected that it hould be an exact piece, or that I hould draw it to the life, which hath been dead to us poor mortals; epecially having had o little light, and at o great a ditance as we are removed from that golden age wherein friendhip flourihed. I cannot but admire, that o noble a ubject hath found o few friends: For, except that Triumvirate of Eloquence, the Roman
Cicero, our Englih Seneca, and that great Dictator of Learning Sir Fra. Bacon. I have found few or none, who have written any jut dicoure of it: From their trine Apect hath my dicoure received ome light and augmentation. Yet have I not altogether trod in their teps, nor made any better ue of them, than admire thoe I could not imitate; neither have I ued any gay or painted language, but plain and imple, like the ubject I handle. I have laboured to make it like, rather than handome. An Embaador comming to Treat with the Roman Senate, having his head powdered, and his face painted, Cato told them, they could not expect any truth from him, whoe very locks and looks did lye. I have therefore tudied to repreent this Lady, ine fuco, ine fallaciis, without the dreings of any artificial handomnes, or auxiliary beauty. If you like it, love it; if not, draw the curtain of your charity over it, and let it lie, till ome abler workman hall take the penil in hand. It is enough for me, if it can but peak the Author

div.head: To Mr. J. A.
div.p:
DId not the ame peremptory buinee that preed me down, till keep me here, I houd (at leat) have prevented the Office of this Paper, and not been beholding
to a mute proxie for the delivery of a meage I hould rather, if not better, have done in peron. Since fate will have it thus, let me crave your credence, that what you hall here read, is not o much the dictate, as the trancript of my heart. Sir, I left not my careful thoughts with your line of Communication; they have been, and will be my contant companions. Haeret lateri lethalis arundo; and I depair of any other cure, than the dictamen of your friendly counel. I am confident your goodnes will doe me not onely the courteie, but the jutice to believe that my recee was rather retreat, than a flight from the negotiation we had in hand, A buinee (if my thoughts deceive me not) too weighty to be carried to the end without a ret. Pardon me, if I am willing to look before I leap.—But after the verdict of my mot coniderate and erious thoughts, I mut profee I have a large and long experience of the skill and fidelity of you my leader: Nor doe I fear a micarriage where you are pleas'd to be my guide. To ay nothing of other circumtances I am not forgetful of, though ilent in, allow me the liberty to tell you, Spem de futuris foveo: principium liquet; and it hall not only be my wih, but the mot earnet of my endeavours, < in non-Latin alphabet > . I have hitherto but tythed my thoughts, which hould I allow my pen the liberty to write, would be too tedious for you to read. In a word therefore (to doe you the courteie of concluding) I hall promie, that one line from—(if he pleae to maintein his firt favour with a econd) will
eaily and quickly draw me from the mot earnet of my engagements to tell him Vis à vis, that I am what I ever was, and till hope to be accounted

closer.signed: your very very Friend, T. F.

div.head: To Mr. R. H.
div.p:
IN my addrerees to my friends, I do always intend too much reality, to be beholding to a Complement, in this to you, if an exces of affection hould unawares tranport my pen to an extravagant flight, your merits to me, and my obliged repects to you, may ufficiently ecure me from the guilt of a upitious hyperbole. When I have aid all I can, I hall be o far from thinking it too much, that I mut confee it to be too little. I could rather have contented my elf to have been till your ilent debtor, than by the adventure of a few haty lines to tand in need of your pardon. To think to quit cores with you, by any thing I can ay or doe, is beyond the mot confident of my hopes; and had not your command exacted it, I hould not now have put you upon a new exercie of that goodnee, to which I am already o much indebted. In the large Catalogue of thoe whom your repeated civilities, and contant courteies have purchaed to be your friends, I dare affirm,
you have none more eriouly enible of your favours, or that doth more really wih your welfare, than my elf. May ucces and properitie wait upon all your undertakings; may health and happines be your contant attendants; and may the ame good Angel that carries you from us, guide you in your journeys, and return you in afety.

Let not your dear Conort (the bet of wives and women) think that I have all this while forgotten Her: She is too much your elf to be divided from you in our good wihes. Sir, I am equally, and at once her and your

div.head: To his Worthy Friend Mr. Thomas Forde on his LOVES LABYRINTH.

lg.l: TRue Friend, while others me out-vie, and grace the •
(As thou dot them far more) I carce can trace thee
I many thouand miles do wander
Of Pilgrimage in thy Maeander,
Till by the golden thred,
Of Love I'm afe through led.
Thy Wit is far beyond the Serpentine;
Thy wreathings chequer-work and warp divine;
Thy curious inter-woven Plots,

Rich twine,
• y'd all in Lovers-knots:
Thy Skill is exquiite,
To untie and unite.
Thy Tent-works in-let pleaes me o well,
I'de have none out-let: I'de rather dwell.
I love thy labyrinth, and approve,
That thou houldt labyrinth my love:
There I poor well-hous'd elf
Might afely loe my elf.
I ee, work-women a'n't above workmen
How far hort comes the needle of the pen!
Thoe Damoels, who are o devouts
In pricking little holes in clouts,
Thy lively Tapetry-tory
Out-trips their painted glory
Let pleen it elf judge eithers manu tract:
Their female works can't peak, thy male-words Act.
A drop of this your art (Sr.) paes
Beyond an Ocean of alluiv • ad gr. < in non-Latin alphabet > . the Laes
Their by as-titch doth quint,
But thine's down-right in print.
Nay all thou do't would be uch ne'retheles,
Though it ne're aw the light, nor felt the pres.
Thy lat impreion comes behind,
The firt and chief is in thy mind:
Thou art beyond the ret,
Thy firt Edition's bet.
None living can (I probably conjecture)
No not thy elf) repair this Architecture.
Each line's right perpendicular,
Reaon thy Pium, and Truth thy Square:
Each full-point may be ead,
A nail driv'n to the Head.
But I could wih there were no period,
That (though all's even) yet omething till were od;
That after all Exits might begin
Still more freh Intrats to come in.
The whole frame o divine is,
Nought vexes me but FINIS.

div.head: To my ingenious Friend, Mr. Thomas Forde, on His LOVES LABYRINTH.

lg.l: WHo truly will thy Labyrinth commend,
Shall find it hard, both to begin, and end:
Yet thou hat pun a thred, with which t'untwine
The wandring Lover, though all things combine
To top his paage: Such a flowing Style
Thou uet too, as did my ene beguile:
For whilet I read, I neither Scaene nor Stage,
"Could think were feign'd: I aw an Active Rage
"Appear in Damocles, which to my eye
"Not Acted eem'd, but real Tyranny.
"Sephetia's love and doom; the better fate
"Of Pleuidippus, not more fortunate:
"For he Loves Labyrinth did alo tread,
"And Court incetuouly his Mothers Bed.
"And o her father, husband too (none known)
"Yet he by ympathy did claim his own,
"And had a grant, which mov'd the Tyrants pleen,
"(Since he could not enjoy her for his Queen)
"To kill e'm both; their detinies prevent,
"As loth to have detroy'd the innocent.
"Yet at the lat each thing ucceeds with good:
"Though the foundation eem'd t'be laid in blood.
"And then the harmles hepherds rural port,
"Whoe innocence makes every place a Court.
And all things in o cononanat a dres,
Makes more the eeming, not the being les.
That (credit me) there is not in't a line,
('Tis all o rare) but I could wih were mine.
And as before, o I ay now of this,
Thou hat thy skill by Metempychoi •
Proceed then Worthy Friend, and may thy Fame,
Like Laureat Johnon, ever peak thy Name.

div.p: The Scaene Arcadia

div.head: Scaene 1
div.stage: Enter King Damocles with two Lords, and Lamedon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: CAn this be true?

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.p: My Liege, as truth it elf.

lg.l: And will neither the power of a King,
Nor precepts of a father over-way
Her fond affections; but that thus he will
Run head-long to her ruine? Let her go.
Yet hot he not at rovers, but a Prince
He is, young and deerving; therefore ince
Sh'has hit the mark, it will now be in vain
To give her aym, or make her hoot again.
Was he o haty, that he could not tay
To take our Fatherly advice with her?
No wonder if he wander in the Labyrinth
Of love, without the clew of our counel.
Come brother come, he's not the firt has done
A mis; her own affections were the uret guide
Unto her own content: he choe to pleae
Her elf, not you, come, let this anger ceae.
'Tis now too late for to recal what's pat,
The match is made, and that o urely fat,
'Tis pat diolving now; a Grandfather
You are alreay: From their conjunction hath
This in ••• ence proceeded, a fair boy
Hath given them earnet of ucceeding joy.
How! a boy! and hall that bae brat enjoy
My crown? no, no, I'll take a coure for that.
Why brother, 'tis a Prince by birth, & why
Not born to Reign?
Ay, michief's on my head,
But I'll prevent the plot and torm, we'l end
Them far enough from troubling of our tate:
Ditance and danger hall they firt ubdue,
Before they gain our Crown; the lavih waves
Shall be their ubjects: l • t them go and and win
The trydent of great Neptune, waters King.
I mean to et them forth.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.p: What means my Liege?

lg.l: Nay, I'm reolv'd, ince that they do no more
Regard my favour, they hall feel my frowns.
O ye Coeletial Deities! where are
Your power and wonted jutice now become?
All things run head-long, and the feet forget
Their duty to their Head, and traitors turn,
Breaking the bonds of government; that now
A Princes power, or Fathers care's contemn'd,
And only recompenc'd with light and corn.
But Sir, though he her duty do forget
To you, yet is he till your child, and may
Be eaily reclaimed. Shall one mideed
Forfeit all former loyalty? She us'd
To be more ready to give, than you
Could be to ask. Come, let the weight of that
O're-poize your anger, and this light offence.
I'll hear no more, all pity now is gone,
And anger hath the catle of my breat
So trongly fortified, whole valleys of
Requets can never move: ceae then your uit,
To which my ears are deaf, and tongue is mute.
Heaven is not o impregnable, but that
Entreaties may both iege and conquer it:
If that your daughter hath run on the core
Of one offence, will nothing cancel it?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: My reolution's writ in Adamant.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.p: Dread Sir, and may not tears then blot it out?

lg.l: Nor all the liquid drop the ea contains
Shall quench my rage; for now I have forgot
All pitie of a father, and that wretch
Shall feel what 'tis to loe a fathers love.—
Since he will needs light and contemn our care,
I'll have a Bark provided, without oar,
Or ail, or pilot, but the wilful wind,
And waves, true emblemes of their giddy act,
And therein with her brat, and mate imbarqu'd,
Shall eek their fortunes: And ee you it done
Without delay, our Will admits no time,
T'expotulate no more than alteration
O good my Lord command my ervice in
Some nobler act than this and do not try
My faith in that, for which • 'de rather die,
Than do't. What heir hall ucc • ed your elf
In the Arcadian Diadem, if thus you drown
The Sun of all our hopes, which mut
Supply your place, when as your Sun hall et
In darket clouds of death, mut night enue,
And eize upon our Horizon?—O let
Some pity of our drooping tate prevail.
All will not do. I'll have it done; then go
Or tay and pull my vengeance on thy head.
Will you turn traytor too, to our commands?
As you tender our favour, or your afety,
Go execute my will without delay.
And mut my afety prove their ruin? can
They not live, but I mut die? I'll do't.
Perhaps the tyrant-waves may prove more kind
Than is their King My Liege I'l eae your mind.
And mut they, & they only prove (poor hearts)
A acrifice to fury for their love?
I'll be companion of their fortune. We
Will leave this cured land, which is nought ele
But a dry ea of mieries, in which
We dayly float; the ea can never be
More merciles. O what a maze of woe
Do lovers tread (dire fate) that for their love,
Are recompenc'd with hatred. Farewel world,
Thou ball of fortune banded to and fro,
And never quiet; we will try what fate
Awaits us in the ea, it can't be wore
Than here we uffer by our dearet friends.
Well brother, ince you are o weary of
The world, pray take your hare with them, and care
Of her: I leave her unto you, and to
The mercies of the waves, and o adieu.
Was ever man o reolute to undo,
What an whole age can't recompence again?
To cat away a Lady of that worth,
That bankrupt nature cannot furnih forth
Her Parallel: A beauty that would tempt
The gods to lut: But guarded with an eye
So modetly evere, it would trike dead
All lutful hopes of the hot raviher.
See where he comes, like Phoebus newly roe
From Thetis bed: Little doth he uppoe
The cruelty of her once happy Father,
In having uch a daughter, now no • fit
T'enjoy a bleing which he values not.
What news my Lord? Is the ice of my fathers
Anger broken? Hath the un of counel
Thaw'd his frozen breat?

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.p: Ay, into a flood—

lg.l: What meanes this paion? Speak man, for I am
Prepar'd; it can't be wore than I expect.
Why then it is—
Let me firt drown my elf
In mine own tears, and vent my mind in ighs:
Madam, you may gues ooner than I can tell.
Prethee torment me not thus with delays,
More tedious than the thing can be, what e're
It is. Come, I am armed with the hield
Of patience, my breat is michief-proof.
'Tis eaier far to tell than execute:
I wih my task were done with telling it.
Madam, He hath made me the ad Over-eer
Of that dire act, which he o fears to peak.
Silence will not relieve, it may protract
The doing of that horrid fact, which who
Shall hear, will loath the name of father, for
Your fathers ake, who when perhaps y'are gone
By's want will prize your worth the more, and, love
You better than he ever did before.
Thus are we taught to value of the light,
By the dull ilence of the darker night.
But to your tory, and my doom, which ure
Mut needs be great, that it can find no vent.
Come eae your houlders of this burthen, lay
It on mine, who have deerved it.
Lady, wonder not at our unwillingnes
To tell what we had rather wih our tongues
Out, than to be th'unhappy meengers
Of uch ad news, the truth whereof mut rob
Arcadia of it's richet, choiet Gem,
That doth adorn her Princely Diadem:
By venturing all our hopes to the mercy
Of the cruel waves, He hath pret to be
Your only Pilot; being hip't alone,
With your dear babe and husband, without ail,
Or oar, to contradict the lawles eas,
In their unbounded raging tyranny:
Whoe heedles rigour yet may hap to prove
More kind unto you than your fathers love.
Heavens will be done: But had another hand
Inflicted this, it would have lighter eem'd:—
Yet is there comfort in his cruelty,
That hath not parted me from him, for whom
All this will be but light; his company
Will weeten all my orrows, and convert
My mourning into mirth: Can I be ad,
Enjoying him will only make me glad?
I cannot win my brother to revere
His cruel entence, but it mut be done.—
Dear Neece, I'm thy companion; miery
Shall never make my friendhip to turn edge,
But at the lowet ebb of fortune hall
My love till flow: the ea hall never quench
That flame which virtue once hath kindled in
My breat, nor hall it meet, or be put out
With any cold extinguiher but death.
If many houlders make griefs burthen light,
Then o hall ours: and may mine ceae to be,
When they hall ceae to bear their equal part,
And ympathize with thee, as doth my heart.
Uncle, my thanks. How rare it is to find
A friend in miery! Men run from uch,
Like Deer from him is hunted with the dogs,
As if that miery infectious were.
Men fly with Eagles wings away,
But creep like nails, when they hould uccour lend.
I cannot therefore chue but prize your love,
Who dare be true unto your friend; a name
Nearer than that of kindred, or of blood:
This is th'effect of noblet virtue, which
Ties firmer knots than age can e're undo:
Such is the knot my Maximus and I
Have tied, pight of my fathers anger, it
Shall hold, when envy's tired to invent
Michiefs, in vain, to cut the knot in two,
Which heaven hath knit too fat to looe again.
Alas fond man! who thinks to unravel what
The gods have wove together.—'Tis in vain.

div.head: Scaen. 3.

lg.l: Lady, time cals upon you not to tay,
Let by a fond delay you call upon
His fury to convert into ome wore,
And udden punihment, which may deny
All hopes of future afety; of all ills
The leat is always wiely to be choen.
Go and prepare that floting grave, which mut
Devour's alive, I will attend you here.
Before when will my dearet find his grief,
In finding me thus lot without relief.
Why doth my Love thus tarry? urely he
Forgotten hath the place, or time, or ele
He would not tay thus long; but can I blame
Him, to be low to meet his ruine? I
Could wih he would not come at all, that o
He yet might live, although I perih; but
How fondly do I wih to be without
Him, without whom alas! I cannot live.
'Twere as impoible as without air:
He 'tis for whom I uffer, and with him,
All places are alike to me.—See where
He comes, who is ole keeper of my heart.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My dear!

lg.l: Ah, dear indeed, for whom thy life
Mut pay the hot of cruelty enrag'd.—
What meanes my love? is't he, or do I dream?
Sure this cannot be he, whoe words were wont
To be more weet than honey, oft as oil:
Thee words, more harp than daggers points, n • 're came
From her I know—What ayt thou my weet?
The ame—truth will not uffer me to peak
Other, let I hould injure her—O that
'Twere poible o to dipene with truth,
Not to betray our elves—I know not what to ay.—
Heavens bles us, what a udden change is here!
Love, who hath wrong'd thee? tell me, that I may
Thrid their lives upon my word, & make their
Dead trunks float in their own blood, till they bluh
At their own hame: Tell me my heart, who is't?
Alas poor oul! thou little dreamt what ad
News do's await thine ears; my tongue doth fail,
Not daring once to name the thing mut be
Our loves ad end, and dire Catatrophe.
My fathers fury—Oh that that name
I once delighted in, hould odious be
To mine affrighted enes!—But for thee
Alone, it is I grieve, not for my elf.—
Be't what it will, o that it be but in
Relation to thy love, I will embrace,
And hug, and thank that malice too, that o
Invented hath a means whereby I may
But tetifie my loyalty to thee:
For whoe weet ake I would encounter with
Legions of armed furies; acrifice
My dearet blood unto thy ervice, which
I more eteem, than all the wealth the world
Can boat of: 'Tis thee alone I value,
Above whatever mens ambitious thoughts
Can fathom with their boundles appetites.
This flame of love mut now be quenched in
T •• foaming ea; we are deign'd a prey
Unto the fury of winds and waves.—
The deadly Barque's providing, which mut be
Our moving habitation; the ea
Mut be our Kingdom, and the caly frie
Our ubjects:—This, this, the portion is
Of fortunes frowns, and fathers fiercer hate.
Fly, fly, my dearet Maximus, and ave
My life in thine; oh tay no longer here.
Why dot thou torment thy elf before
Thy time? wilt thou anticipate the ea?
And drown thy elf in • ears? Deny me not
To hare with thee in uffering, as well
As I have done in pleaure; 'tis for me
This torm is rais'd, were I once cat away,
His rage would ceae. I, I have wrong'd thee,
And I'll be jut to thee and to my word.
I'll ope the luces of my fullet veins,
And et them running, till they make a flood,
Wherein I'll drown my elf—

div.stage: He offers to kill himelf. She tays his hand.

lg.l: Thine heart lies here;
'Tis here, lock't up ecurely in my bret:
Firt open that, and take it out; for death
Shall ne're divorce me from thy company:
I will attend thee through thoe hady vaults
Of death, or thou halt live with me.—Dot think
This body poible to live without
A oul? or without thee? Have pitie on
Thy tender babe, whoe life depends on thine,
And make not me widow, and him orphan,
With unadvied rahnes—Sheath thy word.
Mine eyes will ne're endure it, to behold,
Thee mierable, no, no, death firt hall draw
A able veil of darknes over them——
Pardon my rahues, I will live with thee,
And tire thy fathers rage with uffering,
So he'l but uffer thee to live in mirth,
The greatet orrow hall not make me ad.
Here comes my father, cerainly his rage
Will know no bounds: I fear it will
Break forth into ome deperate act on me.
Although he be a King, which acred name
I reverence, and as a mortal god
Adore; he hall not dare to injure you
Before my face: firt hall he wear my life
Upon his word, if he but dare to touch
Thy acred elf.——
How now light-skirts? have you got your Champion
To hield you from our anger? know I have
Not yet forgot the name of father, though
You thus have lighted it; but as a King,
We mut be jut to punih your contempt.
Did you o well know your beauty to be
Proud of it, and yet o little value it,
As thus to throw it all away at once?
Well, get you gone.—Since that you have eteem'd
A trangers love before your lovalty
To me, or my care to you, a tranger hall
Inherit what you were born to, had not
Your fond affections forc'd this vile exchange.
Sir—for your fury will not uffer me
To call you father; think not your daughter
Undervalued by her love to me:
Her love ran not o low, as to be to • p'd
To meet with crime, who am a Prince n • les
Than is your elf: Cyprus my Kingdome is.
What drew you hither then? you mut needs know
It is no les than treaon for to teal
An heir to our crown: what drew you hither?
Hither I came, drawn by that forcible
Attractive, for to offer up my elf
A acrifice at th'altar of her love.
Tot with a ea of mieries, I came
To anchor in the haven of her heart:
And if this be treaon, I hall not bluh
To be eteem'd a traytor. But if not,
Then pardon me, if bolder innocence
Doth force me tell you, 'tis not jut in you
Thus to oppoe what Heavens have decreed.
Believe me, Sir, it's neither afe nor jut,
For you to violate the lawes of fate.
Let not your pride o far tranport you, that
You tax our jutice. I hall courge your hate th'wind
Into a leiurely repentance, when
The ea hall teach you that your teares, and
That ighs become your headlong rah attempts.
Great Sir, lay what you will on me, I corn
To crave your favour for my elf; but yet
Let Nature prompt you to be merciful
To her who is a chief part of your elf.
No, as ye have joyn'd your elves in mirth, o
Will I joyn ye too in mourning; and becaue
Two no good conort make, my brother hall
Bear a third part in your grave harmonie.
Father, let me the heavy burthen bear
Of this ad ong alone: let all your fierce
Jutice center in my breat.——
No more,
Our entence is irrevocable, nought
Shall atisfie me ele: I'll have it done.
My Liege, the barque is ready, and attends
Your pleaure; the commands of Kings are not
To be gain-aid, or broken; for the will
Of heaven is obey'd in doing them.
We do obey it then, and willingly,
Father, for yet I can't forget that name,
Although thee injuries would raze it out
My memorie; I will not now dipute,
But readily obey your will: and know
The pleaures of your Court hould not entice
Me hun this comming terrour, which will be,
More welcome to me by my companie.
And thus I take my leave. Here may you find
That happines you wih, and we hall want
Whilet that we prove our elves loves Confeors,
If not his Martyrs.——
I will hear no more.
Away with them, my Lord, you know the place,
Our entence and the time, I long to ee
Me, and my Kingdom from thee monters free.
Arcadia adieu! Thou hat before
Been famous for the happines of loves:
Now michief hath uurp't the eat, and may
It be the object of the gods hatred,
Since Love's the ubject of their crueltie.
Come dearet, let us winde our elves o cloe,
That envie may admire, and o depair
To enter here, where love poeion keeps.
Now hall I live ecure, for now there is
None left, whoe nearnes to our blood might edge
Their hopes, by killing us to gain our Crown.
Kings lives are never afe from thoe that wih
Their ends, which mut initiate them into
Th'enjoyment of a Kingdom; this ame crown
Is uch a bait unto ambitious pirits,
'Tis never afe upon the wearers head.
Why weeps my dear?
Ask why I do not weep.
(Poor Artaxia) are my tears denied me!
Ask why I do not rave, tear my hair thus,
Why uch a weight of orrow doth not rob
So much of woman from me, as complaints!
Or rather, why do I not cloud the skie
With ighs; till at the lat with one bold tab
My own hand take from inulting fortune,
This mierable object of her port.
Ask why I do not this, not why I weep!
Or tint thy teares, or mingle mine with them,
By a relation of their caue; thee eyes
Trut me Artaxia, are not yet drawn dry,
Nor hath trong orrow e're exhauted them,
To make them bankrupt of a friendly tear,
But not a fond one. Why Artaxia!
Why dot thou haten thoe that come too fat,
Sorrow and age, clear up thy clouded brow.
Ah Damocles! how hat thou lot thy elf!
And art become a monter, not a man,
Thus to deprive me of my onely joy,
The onely tay and comfort of mine age,
Which now mut fall. Break heart, and give
My orrows vent. Ah! my Sephetia's gone,
For ever lot unto the world and me.
Content thy elf, not I, but jutice hath
Depriv'd us of her: Jutice, that is blind
To all relations, and deaf to intreats
Of fond nature, or fonder affection.
Ah cruel jutice! Jutice! no tyranny,
This is: Death, be my friend, & joyn once more
My dear Sephetia and me—I come
Sephetia I come; curs'd world farewel.
Help, help, Artaxia, my dear, help, help,
Sephetia doth live, he is not dead.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis too late—oh-oh-oh—

lg.l: Heavens! what a ight is here?
The Queen, he's dead, tark dead, what hal we do?
This wretched land is fruitful grown of late,
Of nothing ele but mieries and wo • s

l.U: ends his darts like hail-hot, no place free:

lg.l: Ah mierable man I am, a wretch,
Who thus have lot two jewels that the world
Can't recompence: I know not what to do.—
Now could I tear my elf in pieces, that I have
Thus parted friends, & left my elf alone.
I am reolv'd, I will no longer live.
Stay, good my Liege, live, & repent of what
Y'have done, you have killd enough already.
If I hould kill my elf, and loe my crown,
I were better live.—Call us a Council quickly.
But my wife, my dearet Artaxia!
That I could breath life into thee again,
Or ele were with thee!

sp.speaker: 2 Lo.
sp.p: He's not yet o mad.

lg.l: O ye powers above! what mean ye thus
To wrack us mortals with uch blacker deeds
Than hell it elf! or remove them, or take
All enes from us. Bear the bodie in,
And ummon all our Lords with peed t'attend
Upon us, that we may find out from whence
It is we uffer this ad influence.
Unhappy King! he hath undone himelf,
And all the Land. His ublimated rage
Hath owne a crop of michiefs, which no age
Can parallel; great-belly'd time is big
With orrows; and our next ucceeding times,
Mut reap the harvet of his bloody crimes.
HOw mad a thing is Love? It makes us loe
Our enes; whilet we wander in a maze
O • endles torments: ometime with his miles
The cunning thief doth flatter us with hopes
And tantalize our expectations, when
Strait our winged joyes are gone, and we
Do wrack our elves with future coming fears:
A mitris frowns doth cloud our clearer skie.
Fond love no more,
Will I adore
Thy feigned Deity.
Go throw thy darts,
At imple hearts,
And prove thy victory.
Whilt I do keep
My harmles heep,
Love hath no power on me:
'Tis idle oules,
Which he controules,
The buie man is free.
Ah Menaphon, my Siter Peana, a pies
On her, I had almot forgot her name, with come.
Thinking on her buines.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: VVhy what's thy buines, Doron? tell me,

lg.l: My buines, 'tis none of my buinee, I tell you,
'Tis my iter Peana's buines.

sp.speaker: Men.
