sp.p: VVell, what's her buines then? I prethee tell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ah Sir! he's ick.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: VVhat is he ick of Doron? let me know.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: VVhy truly Sir, he's ick of you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: She ick of me? why, am I a dieae?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I mean—I mean—he is ick for you.

lg.l: That's kindly done of her, Doron, that he
Will be ick for me: I'll make her amends.
Will you make her amend, aid you? I am
Afraid you'l make her end firt; but truly
Menaphon I have a uit for you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Hat thou a uit for me? Is it a new one?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I ay I have a uit to you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: To me? well, and what is your uit made of?

lg.l: In good ooth, Sir, I mut intreat you will
Love my iter as well as you have done.
No, Doron, love and I are faln out, and he
Will not let me love thy iter or thee either.
No • my iter, nor me neither. Out thou
Caterpiller, thou weael, thou hedg-hog,
I will make you love me, and my iter too.
You are out of your uit now Doron, and
I fear you will catch cold, now you are hot.
Where am I now? Sure 'tis Arcadia.
A land happy in giving birth to my
Sephetia Ah my Sephetia!—
But now no • my Sephetia, ince the waves
Have ravih'd her from me, and all my hopes
Are prov'd abortive; why do I now live!
Since he is gone, whoe life & mine were both
Twited on one thred! Ye fatal Siters!
Why did not your cruel knife cut my life
In twain, when hers was broken off by the
Rude waves & blutring wind, who trove which hould
Gain her from each? But both from me have robd

Her
• now may the ea well boat, and out-vie
The begger'd earth; ince it hath her who was
The earth's whole um of riches. O ye gods •
Why did ye once make me o happy
To enjoy her, and now natch'd her again
To make me thereby the more mierable?
Yet is he not quite drowned; for her heart
Is here: 'tis mine the ea doth prey upon.
Well, my Sephetia, oh that name doth ravih
Me: This body hall a monument be,
And my whole life a continued Elegie,
Both conecrated to thy memorie.
I'll drown thee once more in my tears,
Which I will daily pay, as tribute to thee.
Cyprus adieu, greatnes alo farewel.
I ee, thoe who are lifted highet on
The hill of honour, are nearet to the
Blats of envious fortune, whilt the low
And valley fortunes are far more ecure.
Humble valleys thrive with their booms full
Of flowers, when hills melt with lightning, and rough
Anger of the clouds. I will retire from
The front of honour, to the rear of a
Shepherds life: where whilt I do daily tend
The harmles heep, will I ing forth ad notes
Of their blet happines, and my misfortune.
I will no longer keep this mierable name
Of Maximus but clad in orrows weeds,
Will I wear the name of Melecertus.
No more Maximus Prince of Cyprus, but
A poor hepherd will I be: when you ee
Thoe weeds, and hear Melecertus name,
I am that wretched he, who, like the nake,
Have cat my former coat by creeping through
The hole of mierie, and got a new.
My Carmela is comming, and I'm provided to cat
A heeps eye at her.
Now I ee how Love came blind, he flung
His eyes at me in tead of a love-dart.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha, my Carmela, let me kis thy honyuckle lips

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You kis o hard, you'l leave your beard behind.

lg.l: By my troth, Carmela, wains cannot wear,
But—I do love thee—by our great god Pan
I love thee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You aid you could not wear, and yet you Swear you love me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Love, I have tared o long at thee, that I Am now grown blind.

lg.l: Then hall you be led, like blind beggars
With a dog and a bell, or ele be beholding
To the glaier for a new pair of eyes.
I know not what you mean eyes, but I am
Sure that I am off the hooks. You tell me of
Eyes, eyes, but 'tis your no's that torments me.
This blind god, that the Poets call Cupid, has een
To hit me with his dart, I know not how,
But as the blind man kil'd the crow.
Then you are one of the wanderers in Loves
Labyrinth, I prethee let me lead thee.
Ay, o we may both fall; but no matter,
For if you fall firt, I'll fall on thee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Fie, Doron, fie, are you not aham'd?

lg.l: Aham'd? of what? marry better falling
Falling out.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You'r very merry Doron, where's your in, than muick?

lg.l: Let me play on thee, my pretty bag-pipe,
And I know thou wilt ing, loth to depart.—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And I'll try that, now follow me.

lg.l: Nay, when you came to the nuff once, I thought
You would quickly go out.
Oh Menaphon, hark, I am undone, as a man
Should undo an oyter.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why Doron, what's to do with thee now

lg.l: Why man, thy iter Carmela is grown
proud,
And is jut uch another as thy elf, he lights
And corns poor Doron; and yet becaue I love
her
As my iter doth thee, he laughs at me. Well,
I will be even with her for if he won't love
Me with a good will I'll love her againt her
Will; and I think I hall be even with her there
Come, Doron, come, count love a toy,
As I do, who take far more joy to view
My flocks; here's my content; when heavens frown,
I think upon my faults; and a clear skie
Puts me in mind of the gods gracious love:
Envie o're-looketh me, nor do I gaze
So high as tall ambition; and for love,
I feed my elf with fancies, uch as thee.
Venus (the Poets ay) prang from the ea,
Which notes to me th' incontancie of love,
Changing each day with various ebbs & tides
Sometimes o're-flowing the banks of fortune
With a gracious look from a lovers eyes,
Ebbing at other times to th' dangerous helf
Of cold depair, from a Mitris frowns.
Your Cupid mut be young to hew
He is a boy, his wings incontance tell
He's blind, to note his aym is without rule,
Or reaons guide; uch is the god ye erve.
Treaon, treaon againt the god of love
Menaphon, though you be my friend, I will
Have you articl'd againt at the next meeting well
Of the Shepherds.
Lovers orrows be like to the retles
Labours of Siyphus.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Like thy tongue then.

lg.l: Your Mitris favour's honey mixt with gall
A bitter weet, a folly wort of all,
That forceth reaon to be fancies thrall.
Then love who lit for me, if beauty be
So owr, then give me labour till.
How I would laugh to ee Menaphon once
Manacl'd with loves fetters, that he might repent
His blaphemy againt the hepherds deitie.

div.head: Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Sephetia hipwrack't, with her ncle Lamedon.

lg.l: Ah cruel fortune, but more cruel father,
Mot wretched I, who thus am rob'd of all
My pregnant hopes, my pringing joyes blated
With winter frowns. Jove end a flaming dart
Into my breat, to melt my frozen heart
Into a flood of tears, that I may drown
My elf in them ince that the waves have prov'd
Unkindly courteous to preerve my life,
But to prolong my mierie, and he
Is drownd who was my lifes preerver.
Ah ye enraged deities! could ye
Be o unkind to draw my life's thred out
Thus long, to urvive him who was my life?
Why did ye not, or ave his life with mine,
Or detroy mine with his, that o I might
Enjoy his companie in life or death?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Ay, in the gods time, Neece, but not before.

lg.l: And oh my dearet Pluidippus! could
The waves be o hard-hearted, as to crop
Thy blooming youth, to end thee to thy grave
Before thou wert a man? Had they but left
Me thee, it would have eas'd thy fathers los,
If I had had his trancript to have view'd
In thee, who wert his perfect Image. Now
In tead of heir to the Cyprus crown,
The cypres grove hall be Joynter, where
I'll adly pend the remnant of my life,
To weep my loes, and my own ad fate,
Which thus I will revenge; my Maximus
Shall live till freh within my memorie,
There fixt too ure for all the briny waves
To wah away. Nor hall I e're forget
My on, my Pluidippus. I could feed,
My elf unto eternitie with thee
Sweet names, which do as far out-vie
The Nectar and Ambroia of the gods,
As pearls do pebbles. I can hold no more
My heart's o full, 'twill break, or over-run
The luces of mine eyes.— • 'll weep the ret.
Why dot thou thus torment thy elf in vain?
Thy tears wil not recover them again.
Fates dart is hot, and cannot be recall'd,
Nor is there any alve for fortunes wounds,
But patience; therefore eeing me
Partaker of thy orrows, now lean all
Thy cares on me, it is ome relief,
In orrow to have fellows of our grief.
My husband and my on are gone, and I
Survive alone un • o their mierie.
Chance is like Janus, double-fac'd; ometimes
With miles he comforts us, ometimes
With frowns he cats us down again: A calm
Succeeds a torm, and a harp winter doth
Precede a pleaant pring.
Oft turnings tire
The weary traveller; and love doth loe
His followers, in a wild Labyrinth
Of woes. How am I faln from all my hopes!
(An exile in my native Country:) and
The crown hope eem'd to place upon my head:
Banihed from the pleaures of the Court,
Parted for love from him I could not chue
But love, from Maximus, who hath for me
Suffer'd as many michiefs as malice
Could invent, and now all um'd up in death.
What of all this? after the torm that rent
Our hip, we found a calm that brought us afe
To th' hore, whilt Neptunes mercie was beyond
The envious blats of Aeolus; and thus
The gods do recompene us with their favour,
For the di-courteies of your father.
Sweet Lamedon, once partner of my joyes,
Though now partaker of my wants; I ee
You are as contant in my ad ditres,
As you were faithful in my richer fortunes:
Though friends eldom prove friends in poverty
Misfortune hath not chang'd your mind, but you
Temper my exile with your banihment:
Your aged years hall be my ole directors,
Your will the ruler of my actions.
If you perwade me to content, Portia
Shall not exceed Sephetia's patience:
If you will have me trike my ails, I will,
And teer my coure by th'compas of your care.
Since hope is all the portion we have left,
Let's thank the gods that av'd our lives, and ret
Our cares on them, they can return us more
Than we have lot, or fit our minds to bear
Our preent tate. Contentment gives a crown,
Where fortune hath denied it: patience
Makes all things eaie to an humble mind.
Cares are companions of the Crown, the Court
Is full of buie thoughts, and envious trife,
Whilt peaceful leeps attend a Countrey life.
Then Lamedon will I diguie my elf,
And with my cloaths will change my former thoughts,
Meaure my actions by my preent tate,
Not by my former fortunes. Sephetia
No more: Alas! I know not where, or how
VVe hall betow our elves: Surely this is
Some un-frequented place, no harmles heep
Do feed, nor hepherds tend their thriving flocks.
Heavens! what a ight is here! Such tars appear
But rarely in our Country Hemiphere,
I am o Planet-truck with one hort glance,
I neither can retire nor yet advance.
VVhat reolution is of proof againt
Such charms as thee! Some goddes hath aum'd
An humane hape to tempt us weaker mortals.
Cupid, I cry thee mercie now, although
I were an Atheit unto thee before,
Thou art the Deitie I will adore.
Sure they are in ditres, thoe pearly tears
Furrow her cheeks with cruel trife
Which hall run fatet, are no ooner dried,
New ighs, like the warm outhern wind proclame
A freh approaching howre. I fear they are
Some paengers late hipwrack't, for I aw,
(When walking by the hore) ome floting parts
Of a torn hip, contending with the waves.
Courteous hepherd, if ditreed perons
Fortune hath rob'd, and the ea favoured
(If it be a favour to live and want)
May crave your aid o far, as to direct
Us to ome place may ret our wearied bones,
Our charges hall be paid, and you hall have
For recompence, uch bleings as the gods
Ue to betow on hopitable men.
Strangers, your qualitie I know not, nor
Shall now dipute; but if a country cell
May not too diparage you, here is
Hard by my cottage, and your home.
Kind Sir, your courteie is much beyond
Our merit, and our preent hopes below
A uitable return; pleae you accept
Our thanks, as earnet of that larger debt
Future abilitie may ee dicharg'd.
Lady, I have no curious hangings to
Adorn my walls, nor plate to hew my wealth:
Yet do I live content; and you hall find
Such welcome as a cottage can afford.
Sir, blame not our wills, but preent want, which now
Makes us thus plentiful only in thanks.
Carmela, by my great bel-weather, Carmela,
I'm over the tops of my high-hooes in love,
And there hall I tick and tarve, if thou dot
Not pull me out.—Where hat thou been
This live-long hour?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, does the mouth of your affections water?

lg.l: Water? No, it fires. I'm o all a-fire, that I dare
Not go amongt my flocks for fear, let
I hould burn up all their pature, if thou
Dot not howre down ome dew of
Comfort to cool me.
I hall oon cool your courage Doron; for
I cannot, may not, will not love thee.
Out you goip, not love me? go, get
You pin on Ixions wheel.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No, Lovers pin on that, and o mut you.

lg.l: How fond was I, when I as vainly trove
To keep my heart againt the god of Love!
I little thought his power; when I reolv'd
To live, and not to love: Nature I ee
Cannot ubit without loves harmonie.
In vain I hut the door, and bolted it
With reolution; trait the thief,
Thorough the caements of mine eyes got in,
And tole away my heart; as once of old
He erv'd the merry Greek Anacreon;
Whoe fancie fits my fortune: Here it is

lg.head: Loves Duel.
lg.l: Cupid all his Arts did prove,
To invite my heart to love;
But I alwayes did delay,
His mild ummons to obey;
Being deaf to all his charms.
Strait the god aumes his Ar •• .
With his how and quiver, he
Takes the field to Duel me.
Armed like Achilles, I,
With my hield alone defie
His bold challenge, as he cat
His golden darts, I as fat
Catch'd his Arrows in my hield,
Till I made him leave the field.
Fretting, and diarmed then,
The angry god returns agen,
All in flames; tead of a dart,
Throws himelf into my heart.
Ueles, I my hield require,
When the Fort is all on fire.
I in v ••• the field did win,
Now the Enemy's within.
Thus betray'd, at lat I cry,
Love thou hat the victory.
Alas! what heart's o fortify'd, to prove
The ev'ral batteries of the god of love!
What ear's not charm'd with th'rethorick of a voice,
Whoe ingle note would ilence all the Quire
Of the Aërial feather'd Choriters!
What eye would not be blinded to behold
Thoe eyes which cat a cloud upon the Sun,
And bring his light under diparagement.
Witnes that face, whoe Shrine hath made me blind.
How fares my fairet guet?
The better for
Your courteous entertainment, may the gods
Be favourable to your flocks, as you
Have friendly been to us.
May I preume
To crave your name, and to enquire how
Hard-hearted fortune could be o unjut,
To injure innocence? Signe he is blind.
My name is Samela, my parentage
But mean, the wife of a poor Gentleman
Of Cyprus, now deceas'd: How arriv'd here
Pray do not now enquire; time may reveal,
What preent orrows force me to conceal.
I will not pres your yet freh bleeding wounds,
With a rude hand; 'tis time and patience
Mut work the cure; the gods allow a alve
For ev'ry ore, but we mut wait on them:
Their time is bet; for when we trive to heal
Our wounds too fat, they do but feter more.
Ret here content; a Country life is afe,
Fortune o're-looks our humble cottages
We are not pain'd with wealth, nor pin'd with want,
Our heep do yield us milk for food, and wooll
To make us cloaths; hunger & cold we light:
Envie hath here no place, we'l friendhip keep,
Free from all jars, and harmles as our heep.
O happy life! would I had never known
Other than this, which by comparion,
Renders mine odious to my memorie.
Sorrow its heavy on her heart, but hews
More lovely in her face; thoe tears appear
Like chrytal dew upon the bluhing roe.
Beauty thus veil'd, is more inviting, than
Shining out in it's unclouded plendor.
Fortune, I hate thee, for thy pight to her,
But thank thee for thy courteie to me,
In ending her for helter to my houe.
Kind love ait me now, and I will be
Her contant ervant, and thy votarie.
THis preent to the King of Thealy
Will gain us both reward and pardon too
For all our former Pyracies upon
His eas and hips.
Ay, he hath ne're a on,
For to inherit the Thealian Crown:
Hereby this lad may gain a Kingdom, whilt
We eek but our liberties and lives,
For time to come, and pardon for what's pat.
This is the place the King doth oft frequent,
When publick cares oppres his Royal head,
Here he unloads the burthen of his thoughts,
And changes cares for recreation.—
See where he comes! God ave your Majetie.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Long live Agenor, King of Thealy.

lg.l: What meanes this bold intruion? who are ye?
That dare preume into our private walks?
Pardon, great Sir, we come not to offend
Your acred Majetie, but to preent
You with this living gift.
This is a gift
Indeed; where had ye him, or what's his birth?
Pleae you, dread Sir, grant us your pardon then,
We hall declare unto you what we know.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Take it, we freely pardon ye. Now peak.

lg.l: Then be it known unto your Majetie,
VVe the two famous Pyrats are, you have
So long laid wait to take, but all in vain.
Roving upon the coats of Arcady,
VVe found this beauteous youth upon the hore,
VVhom (we uppoe) the eas had wrack't, but av'd
His life, which we have nourih'd ever ince,
And now bequeath unto your Majetie:
For which we beg no recompence, but this,
To eal our pardons for our former faults.
Look that for time to come ye honet be,
And for what's pat we freely pardon ye.
Thanks, Royal Sir, the remnant of our lives
VVill we pend in your ervice, and o give
Again, our lives which you have given us,
VVhen they were forfeit to your laws and you.
This is a welcome gift. VVhat a divine
Beautie doth parkle in his countenance!
Surely he cannot be of mortal race
Decended, but Jove himelf hath ent him,
To be the happy heir of my Kingdom.
Immortal Jove! I thank thee for this gift.
Thou couldet not have ent a welcomer.
My pretty lad, where wer't thou born? cant tell?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: I know not, Sir,—my name is Pluidippus.

lg.l: Come, follow me, now have I found at once
An husband for my daughter, & an heir
For the Thealian Crown. Thrones are upplied forth,
By Jove, who, when the root is withered,
Can make more heav'nly branches to prout
Which may in time grow mighty trees to hade,
And helter all their liege-ubjects under.
Strike home, great Cupid, with thy flaming dart,
As yet thou dot but dally with my heart:
'Tis rather cratch'd than wounded; I do hate
A luke-warm love: give me a love flames high,
As it would reach the element of fire,
From whence it came; a low and creeping flame
Befits • chimney, not a lovers breat.
Give me a love dare undertake a task
VVould fright an Hercules into an ague.
A love dare tempt the boldet fate, and die
An honour'd captive, or bold conquerour.
Give me a daring, not a whining love,
A love grows great with oppoition:
A love that corns an eaie task, things great
And noble always are mot difficult
This is the love (blind Cupid) I would have,
A love that brings home trophies, or a grave.
I'll tempt his god-hip with a ong, and ee
If vere, not ighs, will gain the victorie.
No more, no more,
Fond Love give • 're,
Dally no more with me;
Strike home and bold,
Be hot, or cold,
Or leave thy deitie.
In love, luke-warm,
Will do more harm,
Than can feavers heat:
Cold cannot kill
So oon as will
A fainting, dying weat.
I cannot tell,
When ick, or well,
Phyick, or poyon give;
Still in anguih,
I do languih,
Or let me die, or live.
If I mut be,
Thy Votarie,
Be thou my friend or foe:
If thou wilt have
Me be thy lave,
Hold fat, or let me goe.
Sure Cupid hath reign'd his place, and giv'n
His god-head unto Carmela, whoe eyes
Wound more than ever did his darts.
But what is that, if he have power to hurt,
And wanteth mercie for to heal thoe hurts.
I fear whilt I make her my deitie,
I do but thereby make her proud,
And with my own hands place her out of reach.
Yet he is in ditres, and that hould make
Her humble: I relieve her, therefore he
Hath the more reaon thus to relieve me;
And certain, he will rather love than want.
Ha ha, ha, &c. are you catch'd, Menaphon?
I'faith, I think y'are fetter'd now, you'r hang'd
Ith' brambles of love, as well as I. You laugh'd
At me before, but now I'll laugh at you.
Ah Doron! now I crave thy pitie, for
I never thought an earthly beautie could
So oon have fetter'd me; what did I ay?
An earthly? No, Doron, he is heavenly,
Brighter than Phoebus in his glittring pride:
Venus her elf was not o fair a Bride.
How now Menaphon! I'm afraid thou wilt
Be a beggar hortly, thou art a Poet already.
One of the thred-bare crew, that ragged regiment.
See Doron, ee, ee where he comes, who with
Her brighter lutre can create a day
At mid-night, when the Sun is gone to leep;
Eclipe his noon-tide glory with her light:
Her abence would benight the world & cloath't
In blacket darknes, for to mourn it's los.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Good-morrow Hot, how thrive your well-fed flocks?

lg.l: My flocks do thrive (Lady) and can't do les,
Blet with the aupicious un-hine of your eyes;
And I were too ingrateful, if I hould
Deny to give you back again, what I
Enjoy but by your beauteous influence.
Y'are merry, Menaphon, if not prophane,
To rob the gods of what is due to them,
To give it to the object of their corn.
Could I dipene good fortunes, I hould not
Forget my elf, & chue the meanet lot.
This 'tis to be in love, how pruce is
Become of late, as he were always going
To a feat? and talks as if he were ome
Citie Orator. Why can I not do o? I'm
Sure I am in love as well as he. But
I'll go hire ome journey-man Poet, or other,
And he hall make me ome veres
For my Carmela: And that will do as
Well, as if I made them my elf; I'll
Set my brand upon them, and then no
Body will quetion them to be mine, no
More than they do my heep that are mark'd.
Ay, ay, it hall be o. Oh Melecertus,
Yonder is the finet hepherdes that ever
The moon held the candle of her light to; the
Shepherd Menaphon has got her to him, as
If becaue he is the Kings hepherd, he
Mut have the Queen of Shepherdees.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Hat een her, Doron? and dot know her name?

lg.l: Seen her? ay, and igh to ee her too; her name, I
Think, is Stamela—no, no,—Samela, Samela,
Ay, ay, that's her name, I have it now, I would
I had her too.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What kind of woman is he, cant thou tell?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, or ele I were naught to keep heep.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Can thy tongue paint her forth to mine • ar?

lg.l: Ay, ay, legible, I warrant you.
Her eyes are like two diamonds, I think, for
I never aw any before; and her locks are
All gold, like the golden fleece our hepherds
Tell of.
It were good vent'ring for that golden fleece,
Doron, as Jaon long ince did for his.
Her hands are all ivory, like the bone-haft
Of my bet knife, her alablater, and her
Eyes black as my blacket lamb, her cheeks
Like roes red and white that grow together.
What think you of her now? have I not made
A fair picture on her?
Ay Doron, were this picture painted to
The life, as thou hat here decribed it,
It could not chue but make an abolute,
Rare, and compleat piece of deformitie.
Nay, nay, if you don't like it, I don't
Care, but I had it out of an old book of
My brother Mor •• 's, they call 'm
Rogue-mances, I think: my brother
Ha's a whole tumbrel full on 'm, he's
Such a Bookih block-head—
Nay, be not angry, Doron, I believe
Thou mean't a beautie beyond expreion
And uch an one I had, till envious fate
Rob'd me of her, and all my joyes at once,
Heavens envying at my happines,
Sent death to fetch her from me, and he's dead,
Dead, Doron, dead,—he's dead to me, and to
The world, and all but to my memorie.
Fie, Melecertus, what dot mean to
Weep? what, wilt thou make dirt of
Her ahes with thy teares?
Well, Doron, we forget our flocks, and we
Shall mis the hepherds merry meeting.
That's true, and there will be the hepherdees
Too, and Menaphon will bring his fine
Mitris thither; there halt thou ee her,
But firt mask thine eyes, let thou loe
Them, and become love-blind, as I am.
Good Melecertus take the pains to lead me.
How wretched am I grown, I hate my elf,
And care not now for my own company:
I loath thee light, and fain would hide my elf
From mine own eyes; I'm wearie of my life.—
Where hall I hide my elf, that there I may
Deceive th'approaches of dicov'ring day?
I'll eek ome gloomy cave, where I may lie,
Entomb'd alive in hades of ecrecie.
His thoughts are much perplex't, & black depair,
May puh him on unto ome dep'rate act,
If not prevented by our vigilance.
This is th'effect of rah reolves, when hat
And paion hurry men to do thoe things
Reaon would wih undone, at leat delay'd.
Our wills pur'd on by rage, ne're top, till we
(Blinded with anger) headlong throw our elves
From dangers praecipice, into a gulf
Of black depairing thoughts; and then too late
Repentance lends us o much light as may
Shew us our madnes, and our mierie.
Ill actions never go unpunihed;
They are their own tormentors, and do prove
At lat, furies to lah the guilty oul.
When reaon is depos'd, & paion reigns,
Nothing but lawles actions do appear:
When paion hath uurp't the helm,
And teers a wild uncertain coure, not by
The card and compas of advice, the hip
Will never make good voyage, but be tot
Upon the waves, and all her lading lot.
He by his wilful rage hath cat away
Himelf, and floats upon the waves of ruine:
Let's try if we can waft him afe to hore,
Lend him our helping hands, let he do ink
Into that deep and black gulf of depair.
Let's after him, and try what we can do,
In aving him, we ave our Kingdom too.

div.head: Scaen. 5.
div.stage: Enter Menaphon, with Samela, and Peana after them, Melecertus leading Doron.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Hey day, what's here, my brother Doron?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Doron conceits himelf that he is blind.

lg.l: Ay, Doron's as blind as any door: what
Creep I here upon? Carmila, oh Carmila,
The very ight of thee hath recovered mine
Eyes again.

div.stage: He tumbles on Samela in Carmila's cloaths.

lg.l: Nay, now I ee,
Doron, th'art blind indeed,
That dot not know Carmila from her cloaths.
No, no, 'tis Samela, not Carmila.
Which is my Carmila? good Melecertus.
Shew me where he is.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: It eems, Doron, Carmila is not here.

lg.l: Why, what do I do here then? I thought
It was omething I mis'd, onely I
Mitook; for I had thought it had
Been my eyes were lot, but now I
See it is my Carmila is miing, whom
I had rather ee than my own eyes.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: This is my corrival in Menaphon's love.

lg.l: She is a beautie indeed; and ince my
Sephetia is drown'd, without compare.
I cannot blame Menaphon, but envie
Him rather, for his o happy choie.
O happy! yet to me unhappy beautie!
That doth (as in a glas) preent unto
My frighted enes the remembrance of
My los, which, unles by this fair piece,
Cannot be recompenced by the world.—
Mitris, y'are welcome to our company.
By my troth, Mitris, you are very welcome,
As I may ay, unto our meeting.
Thanks hepherds: I am a bold intruder
Into your company; but that I am
Brought by your friend, and my hot Menaphon.
Mitris, your preence is Apologie
Sufficient; yet do we owe him thanks,
That by his means we have the happines
T'enjoy your weet ocietie in this
Our rural meeting, when hepherds ue
To cheer themelves with mirth & pleaant tales.
I hope my company hall not forbid
The Banes between your meeting & your mirth.
Then by your leave, fair hepherdes, I will
Begin with you. If the gods hould decree
To change your form, what hape would you deire?
I would be careful how to ail between
The two rocks, of immodet boldnes, or
Of peevih coynes; therefore to anwer
Unto your quetion, I would be a heep.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: A heep? Mitris, why would you be a heep?

lg.l: Becaue that then my life hould harmles be,
My food the pleaant Plains of Arcadie,
My drink the curious treams, my walks
Spacious, and my thoughts as free as innocent.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I would I were your Keeper.

lg.l: But many times the fairet heep are drawn
Soonet unto the hambles to be kill'd.
And ure a heep would not repine at that,
To feed them then, who fed her long before.
Then there's more love in beats, than contancie
In men, for they will die for love, but when?
When they can live no longer, not before.
If they'r o wie, it is their mother-wit,
For men have their incontancies but from
You women, as the ea it's ebbs and tides
Hath from the moon.—Your embleme to an hair.
Menaphon, if you hate my iter, I'll—
Love yours for't in pight of your teeth
Your mother urely was a weather cock,
That brought forth uch a changeling; for your love
Is like the lightning, vanihed as oon
As it appears; a minute is an age
In your affections. You once loved me—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, I would you lov'd him no better.

lg.l: If that I be o changing in my love,
It is becaue mine eye's o weak a Judge,
It cannot pleae my heart upon trial.
If that your eye's o weak, then let your eares
Be open to your loves appeals and plaints,
Come, for to end this trife, pray let us hear
Th' opinion of good Doren, who's o mute,
As if h' had lot his tongue too, with his eyes.
By my • ay, fair Mitris, I was thinking
All this while with my elf, whether in being
A heep, you would be a ram, or an ewe?
An ewe, no doubt; if I hould change my, hape
I would not change my Sex; and horns are held
The heaviet burthen that the head can bear.
I think then I were bet be an ewe too,
So I might be ure to have no horns:
But I would not greatly care to wear horns,
Were I a ram, were it but where you were and gives
An ewe.—
VVell, hepherds, come, the day declines,
Us timely warning for to fold our flocks.
VVere my Sephetia living, I hould think
This heperdes were he: Such was her hape,
Such was her countenance; her very voice
Doth peak her my Sephetia. But alas!
How fondly do I dream! I do embrace
A cloud in tead of Juno. Yet I love,
And like her, 'caue he is o like my Love.
VVe love the pictures of our abent friends:
And he's the living picture of my dear,
My dear Sephetia. Me thinks I feel
A kind of ympathy within my bret
To like and love her of all women bet.
Forgive me, my Sephetia, if thou livet,
If I do love another for thy ake:
Thy likenes is the loadtone which doth draw
My heart to her, that nothing ele could move.
Thou mot impartial deitie of Love!
Can there be two Suns in Loves Hemiphere?
Or more loves in one heart than one that's true
Or can the tream of true love run in more
Channels than one? Shall I be thus paid
For my love to fale Menaphon? Hereafter,
Venus, never will I adore thee, nor
Will I offer up o many Evening
Prayers unto Cupid, as I have done.—
Was ever poor maid o rewarded with
An incontant lover, as I daily am
With this ame fickle-headed Menaphon!
How now Peana! what's the newes with thee?
News! marry 'tis the news I complain of;
Were Menaphon the old Menaphon, that
He was wont to be, I hould not complain
Come—plain Peana mut not grutch to give
Way unto fine Samela that hath turn'd his
Heart, and if he do not turn again
Quickly, he'l be burnt on that ide; well,
Be content a while, by that time he hath loved
Her, as long as he did thee, he'l be as
Weary of her, as he is now of thee.
But in the mean time Doron, I mut be
A tale to her uurps my right in him.
Ay, that's the reaon he doth not care
For thee, becaue thou art tale.
Thus do poor lovers run through
The briars and the brambles of difficulties,
And ometimes fall into the ditch of undoing.
Good Doren, be my friend to Menaphon.
And mind him of his former love to me,
Or I hall learn at lat to light him too.
Ay, ay, he has a iter, jut uch another
As himelf, I'm zure he has e'en broken
My poor heart in twain; and if it be
Piec'd again, it will never be handom.
How happy are thee hepherds! here they live
Content, and know no other cares, but how
To tend their flocks, and pleae their Mitris bet.
They know no trife, but that of love, they pend
Their days in mirth; and when they end, weet leeps
Repay, and eae the labours of the day
They need no Lawyers to decide their jars,
Good herbs, and wholom diet, is to them
The onely Aeculapius; their skill
Is how to ave, not how with art to kill.
Pride and ambition are uch trangers here,
They are not known o much as by their names
Their heep and they contend in innocence,
Which hall excell, the Mater or his flocks.
With honet mirth, and merry tales, they pas
Their time, and weeten all their cares:
Whilt Courts are fill'd with waking thoughtful trife,
Peace and content do crown the hepherds life.

div.head: Scaene 1.
div.stage: Enter King of Thealy, and his daughter Euriphila.

lg.l: DAughter, it is enough, we will it, ee
You hew your dutie in obeying us;
Since I have made choie of him for my Son,
Accept him for your husband: He's a man
Ancient in virtues, although young in yeares:
He's one whoe worth is far beyond his age.
Father, it grieves me that the cros Fates have
Forc'd me to hate the man you o much love
Cupid hath truck me with his leaden dart,
I cannot force my own affections.
How's this? you hate him whom I love! can he
Be th'object of your hate, who is alone
The ubject of my love and reverence?
He whom the gods in mercie have deign'd
The happy Succeor unto my crown,
And to your love? Bethink your elf again.
Great Sir, the gods themelves are ubject to
That little deitie of love can I
Withtand his power, or love againt his will?
Force cannot work on love, which mut be free,
And uncompell'd, ele can it not be true,
Nor lating. Sir, urge me no more in vain.
What a trange change is here! Your will was wont
Freely to toop to all my jut deires;
Is it now grown o tiff 'twill not be bent
By my commands? I know thou dot but feign.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: I would obey your will, could I command Mine own affections, or chue my love.

lg.l: Do it, or ele by Jove, whom I preent
ll punih thy neglect.—I cannot think
Thy words and thoughts agree. Surely to love,
Is natural, why then not to love him,
Whom nature made to be belov'd? He hath
Artillery enough about him to take in
The toutet heart at the firt ummons.—Well,
Think on't Euriphila, when I am gone,
I'll leave thee here, Lovers are bet alone.
How rarely have I play'd this part, & hid
My love under a mask of hate!—but now,
Me thinks, I feel the fi • e of love to rage
More fiercely in my breat; for being kept
So cloe, it will break out too oon: I mut
Invert the coure of love, and woo him firt.
He comes, and fitly: Cupid, intruct me now,
To war and conquer in this bloodles fight,
That wins the field by flight, and not by force.
Yet mut I veil my love till, and eem coy,
Till by a fale retreat I make him fall
Into thoe nares I et, and wih him in.—
What means this bold intruion? do't befit
You to intrude into my privacies?
Lady, the fault's not mine, fortune hath led
Me to this place: mine ignorance (I hope)
Will plead mine innocence. As I have found
Your Royal Fathers noble favours far
Exceed my hopes, or my requital, let
Not your frownes trike dead whom he hath rais'd
To life; crueltie cannot lodge within
That tender breat was onely made for Love.
Dare you preume to talk of love to me?
Am I a mate fit for your choice? Be gone,
And eek ome hrub may fit your lownes bet.
Madam, this torm becomes you not. It is
Degenerate from your noble Fathers train.
I cannot think this hould proceed from one,
That is the Heir to his name and worth.
My fathers ears hall ring with this, that he
Hath warm'd a viper, which would bite him now,
And entertain'd a guet would rob his hot.
Lady, my pirit tels me that my birth
Is not o bae as you conceit. I mean
To try my pirit, and my fortunes in
Mars his Camp, but not in Venus Courts.
Since nature's o unkind, as not to let
Me know what honour I was born unto,
I'll win ome to my name, by actions, which
Shal peak me noble; I had thought t'have made
You the fair goddes at whoe hrine I meant
T'have offer'd up, and acrific'd my elf,
And all my ervices; but caue you prove
So rough, I will not harbour here but eek
The world through, for an altar worthy of
My labours. So, fair proud, farewel.
Art gone! I did not well to tempt a part
I knew not how to act, to hide a flame
I could not well conceal: for hereby have
I drove him quite away.—Euriphila,
Thou wer't too blame.—Well, I will after him,
And try if I can fetter him with gifts,
Whom love cannot entangle: Mars is his god,
Not Venus; once more will I try, and hew
Him plainly how I love him: Juno help,
And thou, O little deitie of Love
Beiege the catle of his tubborn breat,
Bend all thy batteries unto his heart,
Make it the mark of all thy golden darts.
Let him no more reit, but know thy power,
That Mars with all his armour, nor his forts,
Catles, or coats of mail, can fence him from
Thy little piercing hafts, which wound uneen.
And I will try what work a womans arts
Can make againt thee tubborn warriors hearts.
I have but one heart to betow, and that
Mut not be Menaphon's; mine eyes do fix
On Melecertus, the bet counterfeit
Of my lot Maximus: I cannot yet
Think on that name, but it doth eem to chide
My haty choie, and drown my love in tears.
What mean thee udden paions, Samela?
Hat thou not here all thou cant wih? what dot
Thou want can make one happy, but content?
'Tis true, I nothing want, that a poor wretch
Can wih for; but this happines doth mind
Me of my fore-pat happines that's lot.
Is't poible the vein of true love can
Be broken, and the wound not bleed afreh
At every thought! Alas! my heart's o full
Of tears and grief, that ome will over-flow.
Had thy tears power to raie the dead again,
Then were they lawful and commendable:
But ince that tears are fruitles, and your friends
(Like water pilt) now pat recoverie,
It is but folly to weep for the dead.
Purue no more fled joyes, turn and receive
Thoe comming pleaures which do court your hand
To take them. If thou wilt liten to my love—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I like my grief much better than thy love.

lg.l: Why o nice and coy fair Lady
Prethee why o coy?
If you deny your hand and lip
Can I your heart enjoy?
Prethee why o coy?
For thy flitting joyes are pat,
I will give thee joyes at lat.
Joyes that hall create each other,
Make thee both a wife and mother.
Y're merry, Menaphon, but I can't joyn
In conort with you. Seek ome other mate;
I have no heart to give, nor hand to take
Your gift. Another reaps what you have own,
And like t'enjoy what you have hop'd in vain.
Another reap what I have own! Is this
Your gratitude you o much boated of?
Have I upplied your wants with plenty, and
With corn do you repay my charitie?
Did I relieve you in ditres for this?—
By Pan, the god of hepherds, or return
Love for my love, or be turn'd out of doors.
My heart ne're knew what baenes meant,
Of thankful thoughts for your civilities; (it's full
If thoe will atisfie, I'll employ all
Th'exchequer of my breat; bu • as for love,
Alas! that is not in my power to give
I aw your looe eyes at the hepherds feat,
Rov'd every where, but Melecertus was
The mark they aym'd at mot. Well, get you gone,
Expect no more from me, but light and corn.
My grief was ominous, and did preage
This ad mihaps was I not cros'd enough
Before? when will my uff'rings have an end!
Well, I'll go eek my uncle Lamedon,
The comfort and companion of my woes.
Love bids me go, but reaon bids me tay;
Reaon! thou hat no hare in love; I'll on
Love is a paion paions know no lawes,
The gods themelves cannot be wie and love.
Friend Pluidippus, hark, who would have thought
You o faint-hearted, that a maidens frowns,
Could turn the edge of your affections?
No, madam, but your corn hath whet the edge
Of my reolves, to eek ome other clime
May prove more temperate: Arcadia is
The place I aym at, where, I'm told, there dwels
A Lady of that beautie, that the world
Can't hew her econd; thither am I bound.
You do but jet, I hope, I'm ure I did
No other; for I love thee with my heart,
And may thee igns confirm it that I do.
I mut not dwell at thee igns, well I may
Bait for a while, but cannot make a tay.
Arcadia is the place I viit mut,
That is the center whereunto I tend,
And where my labours hope to find an end.
What, mut a Lady wooe you to accept
Her favours? Come, what need hat thou to eek
Dangers, and love abroad, who hat at home
The onely daughter of a King, who courts
Thee for thy love? what mean thoe ilent looks?
Hear me, my Pluidippus: what, till mute?
Th'attractive of that beautie I have een
But in a picture. will not let me ret,
Until I ee that creature o divine,
Arcadia is blet withal, to be
The happy casket of o rich a jewel.
By all the love thou ow't my fathers care,
I do adjure thee to tay here with me,
And in mine arms I'll lodge thee until time
Shall make thee King of Thealy; mean-while
Let me be happy in th'enjoyment of
Thy companie, and eek not toils and care,
When thou mayt live more happy here, than
Cant wih, or find in any other place.
My Genius prompts me, that I mut not ret thou
Here, for the gods do eem to call me hence
And their decrees I may not break, nor will.
This corn tormenth me, yet can I not
Repay his hate with hate; but I do love
Him more. Love, this is tyrannie in thee.
Here comes my Father, may his newes be good.
Now forward girle, did I for this provide
An husband for you? do you thus reward
My love to you, to light him whom I love?
Your cornes will force him from our Court to flie.
And now I hear, he'l to Arcadia.
Believe it, Sir, 'tis far from me to wih,
Or be the caue of his departure hence.
Yes, yes, your peevihnes I hear's the caue,
Nay, I my elf have heard, with hame to think
You o much corn'd a man, I o much lov'd.
Did I grace him, that you hould digrace him?
Great Sir, the greatet los is mine; & none
Can tell with what an heavy heart • hall
Be forc'd to part with him. And therefore, if
You pleae to ue your power to tay him here,
You may o be my father the econd
Time by preerving the life you gave me,
Which, without his preence, is nothing worth.
As you tender the life of a daughter,
Or the welfare of a maid, endeavour
His tay, or I hall follow him to death.—
I'll find him out and try what power I have
Upon him: I uppoe my kindnees
To him, may well deerve his acceptance,
They have not been uch as hould wearie him,
Nor is a Crown a thing to be lighted,
Nor eaily obteined; yet his tay
May purchae mine, and 'tis an eaie rate.
What, Neece, till weeping! cannot curing time
Invent a plaiter for thy wounds, but that
They till thus bleed afreh? what is the caue?
Dearet Uncle! who hitherto have been
The onely Partner and Phyician
Of all my griefs; unles your skill can fit
A cure unto my preent cares, I mut
Yeild to their trength, for with continued
Batteries they o aault me now, that
I mut be forc'd to ink under their weight.
Why, what new cros hath hapned unto thee?
That thus renews thy grief? Come, tell it me;
And doubt not of my readines to trie
All means for thy relief; but firt 'tis fit
I know the caue, the firt tep to the cure.
Unboome then thy grief, and give it vent;
Is Menaphon as kind as he was wont?
That name it is that is my orrows pring
From whence thee tears do flow, 'tis he alone—
Unkind and fale, bae-minded Menaphon.—
Out with it all, and tell me how he hath
Abued thee, and I will try to right
Thee, and requite him for his injuries.
When as he aw I would not atisfie
His foolih fancie, for which caue alone
He hitherto hath entertained us,
And not for to relieve our wants; he ees
His hopes are frutrated, and I depie
His clownih love, he turn'd me out of's doors:
Where hall we lie? we are expos'd unto
The mercie of the kinder elements;
The heavens mut be our canopie, and th'earth
Our bed, the poor flocks our companions.
Well, fear not, S ••• la, already I
Have found a way to cae thy mind; I have
A little money left, and there withal
Soon hall I purchae a mall flock for thee:
Where thou halt live ecure, and free from fear,
Enjoy thy little with content; there is
A hepherd lately dead, whoe flock I'll buy,
And thou halt be it's Mitris, Samela.
Uncle, my thanks hall ever ready be
For you, as always is your care for me.
But let your hate prevent my comming griefs,
For griefs have wings, wherewith they flie to us,
Comforts are leaden heel'd, and move but low.
Fear not, I will dipatch it uddenly,
The hepherd Doron's brother's lately dead,
And he hath the dipoal of the flock,
As oon as I can find him, we will try
If reaonable price will make them ours,
See where he comes preventing me; Doron,
The merry hepherd! whither away o fat
I'm running for my life, Sir, my brother's
Lately dead, and I'm afraid death will catch
Me too, if I don't make hate. I'm ure
Carmela has half cut the thred of my
Life in twain, with the hook of her crueltie:
Beides, Moron's heep are roving to find
Their mater, and they I go till they loe
Themelves, if I find them not the ooner.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Moron! what was he a kin to a fool?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why he was my own brother, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I thought o. Dor. I mut be gone.

lg.l: Nay, tay Doron, what wil • thou take, and we
Will eae thee of the trouble of thy heep.
By my troth Sir, and you hall have them, but
What will you give me, and you hall have
His flock,—ay and me too, if you will, for
I think Carmela won't.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Will thee content thee for thy heep?

lg.l: Ay marry, this is omething lik—you
Shall have them Sir, were there as many
Of them as there are hairs on their
Backs.—They talk of a golden fleece
But I think I have made their fleeces
Gold now. Come Sir, I'll deliver you the heep.
Forlorn, foraken, and the object made
Of all the hepherds torms! what hall I do
Love is no god, Fortune is blind, and can
Not help; leep flies, and cares poes my head.
Mirth makes me melancholy, company
Yields me no comfort: when I am alone,
A thouand fancies do ditract my thoughts:
And when I try to drown my cares in wine,
They wim aloft, and will be uppermot.
I'll try if I can ing my cares aleep.
Ye retles cares, companions of the night,
That wrap my joyes in clouds of endles woes,
Spare not my heart, but wound it with your •• ight,
Since love and fortune prove my equal fo • s.
Farewel my hopes, farewel my happy dayes,
Welcom weet grief, the ubject of my layes.
Now will I take time by the fore-lock, and
Creep into Menaphon's breat, through the cracks

His minion S ••• l •
has made in it.
Friend Menaphon, what is your courage cool'd?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Cold entertainment hath my courage cool'd.

lg.l: You know where you might have been let in, long
E're this, without aault or batterie.
But you'r erv'd in your kind, for being coy:
Now you have met with your mate (friend) I hope.
She et my heart on fire by her preence,
That will not be put out by her abence.
Then I ee you mean to follow her with
Your uit and ervice till, for all her corn.
No, he hath wounded me too deep, to make
Puruit after her, therefore let her go.
Now then you know what 'tis to be lighted;
So once you lighted me, now I'll light you.
Ah cruel love! whoe muick is compos'd
Of Lovers jars an dicords, mixt with ighs!
If I turn traytor once more unto love,
I'll rob him of his deitie, and pull
His little Kingdom down; I'll pull his wings,
And with the quils made into pens, and dipt
In addet lovers tears, in tead of ink,
I'll Satyres write againt his tyrannie.

div.head: Scaen. 7.
div.stage: Enter King Agenor, Pluidippus, and Euriphila.

lg.l: Why then, my Pluidippus, will you leave
Us, and your fortunes? It is my reolve
To make you heir to my crown, my Son
And Succeor.
Great Sir, I would not be
Fondly injurious to my elf, or you,
Or o prophane unto the gods, to light
Their and your gifts, when proffer'd me o fair:
I mut obey their dictates, and my vowes,
Which call me to Arcadia, till when,
I cannot ret. Give me your Royal leave
To go, I will engage my hopes, and all
My future happinees, to return
In o hort a time as you hall limit me.
Then daughter, ince it mut be o, I can
Not tell how to denie his jut requet:
But ee you part with him in friendhip. And
The like Sir, I require of you to her.
Far b • it from me to denie o fair
Requets Lady, in igne hereof, I take
This parting kis, and may it cancel all
Micarriages and eal Loves covenants.
And thus I take my leave but for a while.
Then take thee this my dearet heart, and bear
It with thee; may it be a charm to keep
Thy chate affections from a Strangers love:
May your return horten my tedious hours,
Since I neglect mine own content for yours.
It eems our Kink hath pretty well outgrown
His griefs; and now he meditates new Loves.
The fire of love hath thaw'd his frozen breat,
And turn'd his cold December into May:
His Scepter's chang'd into a heep-hook, He
Is gone on pilgrimage to eek a wife
Amongt the hepherdees; there is one
Whom I have een, and he is gone to ee,
May vie with Juno for precedencie:
Who in the habit of a Country las,
Carries a Prince-like countenance and grace.
In th'Arcadian Plains he keeps a flock
Of heep, whoe innocence and whitenes he
Surpaeth, whilt the hepherds daily trive
VVho hall bid fairet for this fairer prize.
And he'l out-bid them all, if that will do.
But what a motley mixture will it be,
To ee his grey hairs joyned with her green
And pringing youth? The trange effects of love
VVell may he be his nure, but not his wife:
VVhat's love in young, is dotage in old men.
Love can create an Autumn Spring, in • u ••
New pirits in the old, and make them young
Beides, Honour's a bait frail women know
Not to reit: who would not be a Queen?
Once more doth Fortune flatter me, with hopes
Of a contented life: now am I free
From jealous Menaphon's upitions,
And without fear enjoy my wihed love.
See where he comes, the picture drawn to th'life
Of my dead Maximus, my former joy.
All hail unto the fairet Samela,
And to her happy flock: I envie them
She is their Mitris, I her ervant am.
Long ince my heart was hers, may he but pleae
To take that kindly, which I freely give.
But, Melecertus, can I hope to find
You real unto me, whoe worth I know
Cannot but be engag'd already to
Some more deerving creature than poor I.
Lady, my ervices were never due
To any, but to one, which bond harh death
Hath cancelled to make me yours alone.
You call death harh for freeing you from them,
And would you be in the like bonds again?
Your heavenly likenes doth compel me to't
You are the ame, but in another dres.
Let me no longer therefore trive to win
That fort, I o much covet to be in.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Then Melecertus take thy Samela.

lg.l: Oh happy word! oh happy fate! the gods
If they would change with me, hould give me odds.

div.head: Scaen. 1.
div.stage: Enter King Damocles, like a Shepherd.

lg.l: THus Jove chang'd hapes to atisfie his love,
He laid his god-head by; my Kingdome I
Have for a time foraken, and exchang'd
My royal robes for hepherds weeds. How light
(Me thinks) I feel my elf! having laid by
My crown, with its companions heavy cares!
But who comes here? His paces to me tend.
Shepherd, well met, but why without a flock?
What, hath the rot conum'd thy heep? or are
They gone atray?
No, not my heep, but I,
So far, I almot know not where, or what
I am—to eek, as yet I know not whom.
This old man dotes, and knows not what he ayes;
Where is thy bag-pipe, and thy merry layes,
That hepherds ue to have in readines?
Surely thou art no hepherd, but ome goat
Crept lately into a heeps habit.—Dot
Thou know the field of the fair Samela?
This boy will be my Rival, for that name
Sounds like the creatures that I eek for.—No,
Go eek your Stamela, I know no uch.
This is intolerable,—I will courge
Thee into better manners.—But that divine
Appearance makes my pirits calm, and trikes
An awful reverence into my breat.
This is the beautie of th'Arcadian Plains,
Sh'has hot her rayes o home into my heart,
But partial fame was niggardly and bae,
In giving but a glimpe of this rare beautie.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: D'you know me, Sir, or have you lot your way?

lg.l: I cannot likely loe my way, where I
Do find uch glitring goddees as you.
Indeed the force of uch a light, may rob
Me of the office of mine eyes, and make
Them dark with too much brightnes; can I chue
But gaze upon the Sun, when firt I ee't.
I think you lot your wits, or ele your eys,
That you mitake a glo-worm for the un,
And make a goddes of a hepherdes.
Lady, if I have lot my wits or eyes,
It was with eeking you, whoe beautie drew
Me hither; for your ake alone have I
Shook hands with Thealy, and all my friends,
Onely to joyn my hands and heart with you.
I hould be loth to give my hand unto
So udden a concluion, and my heart
Is neither in my power or poeion.
Fair Shepherdes, my errand is in love,
To yield my heart into your hands; 'tis yours,
By gift and conquet; I'm at your command.
If that you are at my command, be gone,
I cannot, will not liten to your words.
And have I left my dear Euriphila
For this! I ee beautie makes women proud,
I would I were at Thealy again,
There hould I welcome be unto Euriphila,
Whoe heart I know's my fellow-traveller,
Her alt rears, by this time, would make a ea,
Wherein I might wim back again with eae.
I ee this youth's repul't, and he is young
And tout, and well deerving, how hall I
Hope to prevail with her? if lively youth
She do depie, then much more cripling age:
Nor do I know what arguments to ue,
Unles to tell her that I am a King,
And lay my Crown and Scepter at her feet,
Which he will carce believe: my hepherds hook
Will not be taken for a cepter, nor
This poor cap for th'uurper of a crown.—
I have a way whereby to work my will,
And this young man hall be my intrument:
There tands a catle hard by, whither he
Perforce hall carry her. I'll work my will
Upon her, when I have her there confin'd.
I will revenge this corn, if force or wit
Will do, I'll make her pride come down.
Be wie,
Young man, and valiant, and I will tell
Thee how thou halt obtein thy full deire.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: But tell me how, and then let me alone To act, what e're it be.

lg.l: A Catle tands
Near by, guarded with crows and negligence,
Thither thou mayt by force convey her, and
Then force her unto what entreaties can't.
Old man, if I do gain her by thy means,
Thou halt not want reward: I know the place
Where he doth tend her flock, and I'l watch her,
As he doth them; and when I ee my time,
I will convey her where you hall direct.
I will attend you here.—Now mut I plot
To get her in my power, and then I hall
Advance her to a crown againt her will.
But yet, I cannot think Honour hould need
An Advocate; womens ambitious thoughts
Do wim aloft, they love to be above
Their neighbours, envying ev'ry one whoe height
Doth over-look, and eemeth to upbraid
Their lownes by comparion; their minds
Are always climbing up to honours hill,
And pride, and elf-conceit, are the two wings
Which elevate their thoughs to flie aloft.
Now, Mitris Coy, y'are not in your own power,
But mine. Old hepherd, take thee charge of her.
Lady, you ee what folly 'tis for you
To denie men what they can take without
Your leave. Now mut you yield unto the
Of Thealy.—But if you will be wie,
And ee a good when proffer'd, you may be Knight
A Queen by granting of my uit, who am
King of Arcadia, although thus diguis'd.
My father Damocles! 'tis he now ues
To me his dauughter: He's incetuous grown.
This is too woman-like, to turn away
From your own happines.—And it is trange,
That honour doth not tempt her; thou halt have
A Crown and Kingdom at thy ole command,
And change thee rural weeds for princely robes,
If thou wilt be my wife, pleaure for pain,
And plenty for thy povertie. What ayt?
Your potent batteries, and golden baits
Might win (perhaps) on ome ambitious oul:
They nothing move me, to remove my love
Already plac'd on Melecertus, He,
He onely doth, and hall poes my heart.
A hepherd. Shall a hepherds banee tand
In competition, and out-weigh a King?
A ubject be before his Sovereign
Prefer'd? Oh how prepotrous are the minds
Of thee fond women! Come, be well advis'd,
And change that pettie pebble for a pearl.
'Tis in my power to make thee happy, or
With one breath to blat the flower of thy hopes.
And to repay thy folly with thy hame.
Do not go on to kindle uch a fire
Within my breat, as hall conume both thee,
And all that cros the current of my will.
I have already ad experience of
The wilde effects of his enraged will,
Yet uch the crones of my fortune is,
I mut again be made the ubject of
His furious tyrannie; but I'm reolv'd.
Know Sir, I value more my minds content,
Than all the gawdie hows Courts can preent:
I am too well confirmed in the blis,
And weet content attends a Country life,
To leave it for the giddy-headed Court.
Beides, my true affections are o riveted
Unto my Melecertus, that nor frowns,
Nor flatteries hall part my heart from him.
Ceae therefore farther to commence a uit
Nature forbids me grant, and you to ask.
And have I with my Kingly robes laid by
My Kingly mind? No, it hall ne're be aid
A womans will hath contradicted mine.
But 'tis by policie that I mut work,
Since I have laid my Kingly power aide,
I'll et my brains o'th'tenterhooks, and tretch
Them to their uttermot abilities,
To win this cornful beautie to my wife,
Or ele revenge it with her dearet life.
My life hath hitherto been chequer'd with
Varietie of fortunes; ometimes with
A white of happines, and then a black
Of mierie; thus loves bright day of mirth,
Is follow'd with a darker night of woe.
How fair of late my fortune eem'd to be,
And now, alas! o're-cat with blacket clouds
Of dicontents, wherein I labour with
Important uits, I cannot, may not grant.
No, no, my Melecertus, I am firm
To thee, nor hall the rain of tears,
Or winds of threats remove me from thy love.
Be thou but contant, nay, I know thou art,
I will not wrong thee with o foul a thought,
As once to doubt thou cant be otherwie.
You're from your hepherds now, or their defence,
Preume not they can recue you, 'tis pat
Their skill or power, to force you from mine arms.
Alas, fond boy! I corn thy threats, as much
As I hate thee, or light thy boated trength.
Were but my Melecertus here, he would
Whip thy rudenes into better manners.
'Tis well you are a woman (not a man,)
And have no other weapon but your tongue,
Which you are priviledg'd to ue, and we
To laugh at. But in hort, if you'l accept
My love and ervice, then hall you be afe,
And happy: Souldiers cannot talk, but with
Their words, and then they trike gain-ayers dumb.
All this is nothing; for your words, nor words
Shall not remove me from my dearet friend,
He hath my heart, and I have nothing left
But hate, if you'l accept of that, 'tis all
That I can give, or you receive from me.
You mut be dealt with as we ue to do
With ullen birds, I'll hut you up, and then
Perhaps you'l ing another note, you are
Not yet in tune, you are too high for me,
But I will take you lower. I will plough
Your heart with grief, and then (perhaps) it will
Better receive the eed of my true love.
Sooner the turtle hall forget her mate,
Than I my Melecertus; and when I
Can't ee him with mine eys, my mind hall rove,
Wing'd with deire, throughout the pacious world,
And find no ret, until it meet with him.
And though our bodies never meet, our ouls
Shall joyn, and love each other after death.
Thus is true love immortal, and hall never
Die, but with our ouls hall live for ever.
Shepherd, who e're thou art, I cannot chue
But envie thee thy happines, who hat
So true a love: I cannot but admire
This noble oul and love her, though he hate
Me for't; I'll treat her civilly, and if
I can't obtain her for a wife, he hall
My goddes be, and I'll adore her name,
Though at a ditance. Lady, will you walk?
It is an ill wind that blows no man good;
Though the Thealian lad have got the prize
In his poeion, it hall not be long,
But I will have them both in mine, I have
Dipatch'd a letter to my Lords, to end
Me uddenly ome ervants to ait
My plot. Now Menaphon, what is the newes?
Great Sir, the meenger's return'd, and brought
The men you ent for, they are here at hand.
'Tis well; direct them to the catle that
I told you of, and give them charge to eize
Upon the buzzard and his prey, and bring
Them both to me: mean-time go you, and find
Out Melecertus, that I may be ure
Of him, for he's my rival in my love.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My Liege, all hall be done to your deire.

lg.l: Blet policie, thou far exceed't dull trength,
That wanders in the dark of ignorance,
Wanting the eye of wiedome, both to guide,
And to defend it from approaching harms.
Thus art with eae doth move the pondrous load,
Which trength could never mater, or remove.
The Foxes tail mut piece the Lions skin.
Little Ulyes with his wit did more
Againt the foe, than Ajax with his trength.
It is ome comfort yet that I can change
My prion, though I am a pris'ner till,
Would I could change my companie as oon.
But ah! mot wretched Samela, who wert
Born to misfortunes, and to nothing ele:
As if that I alone were fortunes mark,
At which he onely ayms her angry darts.
The morning of mine age was clouded with
Mihaps, and now my noon is like to be
The fatal night unto my mierie.—
My Gaoler is o kind, as if he meant
To bribe my love; but thee are gilded pills
I cannot wallow. Should my Father get
Me into his poeion once again,
I were as bad, or wore: I know too well
His paion, to hope any help from him.
I'll tell him plainly who I am, and trie
If time have dull'd the edge of's crueltie:
Perhaps the kinder gods may move his heart
To pitie, and convert his rage to love.
He is my father till, and though unkind
To me, yet can I not forget I am
His child, and owe a dutie to his name.
He is my King, and o I mut obey
His will; if I mut uffer, let it be
From his, rather than from a trangers hands.

sp.l: I think I am provided now, if Poetrie
Will do't, my Carmila is mine; thee
Wittie knaves, what fine devices they
Have got to fetter maidens hearts?
The Poet Orpheus made the Thracian
Dames dance after his pipe, and Ovid
His Poetrie; there are ome ecret
Charms in thee ame veres ure.
Let me ee here what I have got.
Ha Carmila, look here, I think
sp.p: Carmila—A Miracle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A miracle, for what, Doron?

lg.l: Why, a miracle of beautie, and I think
You'l be a miracle of folly, if you
Don't love me now.
What mall Poet have you hired
To make a miracle of my name.
Nay, I have more yet, and better,
That I found in the Nichodemus
Of Complements, that's a weet book,
'Tis a very magazine of Poetrie, a
Store-houe of wit; do but hear
Them Carmila.
Let's hear them, Doron, are they
Worth a laughing at? Let's hear.
Well, well, it is no laughing matter; but I'm
Sure your laughing ha's made me crie.
Now Carmila, you mut imagine that 'tis
I, and only I, ay this to you, and none but you:
For the unhappy wag ha's o fitted my
Fancie, as if 'twere made for no bodie but me.
Excellent Mitris, brighter than the Moon,
Than cowred pewter or the ilver poon:
Fairer than Phoebus, or the morning Star,
Dainty fine Mitris, by my troth you are.
Thine eyes like Diamonds hine mot clearly,
As I'm an honet man, I love thee dearly.
What think you now, Carmila, is not this
Admirable? if thee trong lines will
Not draw your love, I know not what will.
Had it been your own mother-wit,
Doron, I could have like't it well:
But for you to father the brat of
Another's brain, is too ridiculous.
I like your love much better than your
Hackney lines: but bought wit's bet.
If you like not my lines, becaue they are
None of mine, you will not love my
Heart neither, for that's not mine, but yours.
Yes, Doron, if you have given me your
Heart, I will not die in your debt, but
Give you mine in exchange for yours.
Than welcome to me my new found heart,
We'l live, and love, and never part.
Revenge hall oon o're-take this proud boy, who
Committed hath o bold a rape upon
My Samela: He had been better to
Have lodged nakes in his breat, than to teal
This park, that hall conume him and his net.
Samela! Samela! that name alone
Infueth pirits into me, inflames
My oul with vengeance, till I recover
My dearet love.
Now hall I be reveng'd on Samela,
And on her Melecertus both at once:
I'll make her know neglected love may turn
To hate, and vengeance take the place of corn.
Well met friend Melecertus, what, alone?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I'm olitarie ince my mate is gone.

lg.l: Your mate has taken flight, he's on the wing,
But I can tell thee where he nets, and bring
Thee guickly where thou halt retrive the game.
If thou wilt do this, Menaphon, I hall
Be tudious to requite thy love with mine:
I pay thee terling thanks and ervices.
I will not ell my favours to my friends,
My work is all the wages I expect.
Come, follow me, I'll lead thee to the place,
Where the freh gameters have thy love in chae.

div.head: Scaen. 8.
div.stage: Enter King Damocles in his Royal robes, Pluidippus and Samela, prioners.

lg.l: Now Sir, you ee the hepherd is become
A King; and though you have deerved death,
Yet ince you have but acted our commands,
We here releae you, and not onely o,
But entertain you with all due repect,
At once belonging to our neighbour-Prince,
And near Allie, the King of Thealy.—
Some ecret power doth force me love him o,
That if I had a daughter to betow,
I'de wih no other Son-in-law, but him.
Now my Sephetia, what would I give,
Thou wert alive, I had thee, and thou him.
He little thinks I am o near, or that
It is his daughter he would make his wife.
Thus, Gentlewoman, you are once more faln
Into my hands, I am th' Arcadian King:
Be udden therefore to give me your love,
Or ele foreit your life for your contempt;
Think on't, and chue which you'l rather do.
Sir, I am till the ame I was before:
My love, like to a mighty rock, tands fat,
Didaining the proud billows of your threats.
Crowns cannot tempt, nor Kings command my love,
My love is free, and cannot be compell'd.
True love admits no partners, is content
With one, and Cupids tatute law forbids
Pluralities of loves.
Since y'are o tiff,
You will not bow, I'll make you bend, or break.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I am betray'd by this bae Menaphon.

lg.l: Here comes my Rival; when I have dipatch'd
Him to the other world, your plea is poil'd:
My word hall cut your gordian knot in two;
Your ghots may wed, your bodies never hall.
I'll be his Executioner my elf,
I'll trut no other eyes to ee it done.
Now is it time t'unmask, and let him know
He wounds his daughter through her Lovers ides.
Father, your furie once expos'd me to
The greedie jaws of death, which yet more kind,
In pitie av'd my life, you ought to loe.
I'm your Sephetia, Father, know your child.
And is it poible, Sephetia lives,
Once more t'enjoy her truet Maximus?
My Maximus, I'm thy Sephetia:
Oh that our Pluidippus too were here!

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: And I am he, my name is Pluidippus.

lg.l: My dearet on! 'tis he; now were my joys
Compleat indeed, were but my Uncle here.
I am o wrapt with joy, I carce can get
Breath, to expres my thanks unto the gods.
What will become of me? I hall be hang'd,
Or loe my place at leat; I'll get me home,
Amidt their mirth they will not think on me.
My onely daughter! Dear Sephetia,
And you, kind Maximus, I ask
Both of you pardon for your injuries,
And for requital, thus I do create
Thee King of Arcadie; and may the gods
Requite your ufferings, and forgive my crimes.
Long may ye live, and happy; may your dayes
Be un-hine all, and know no clouds nor night.
And that we may not leave one tring untun'd,
My brother comes to make our conort full;
The bet of brothers, and the bet of friends,
Thanks for your care of her, whom you have made
Your daughter by a better claim than mine.
Now let the whole land wim in mirth, and load
The altars with their thankful acrifice
Unto the kinder deities, who through
A ea of woes, have ent us happines.
Let's in, and hear the trange adventures have
Befaln your heaven-protected perons; griefs
Grow les by telling, joyes are multiplied.
Although againt them all things eem to trive,
At lat jut men and lovers alwayes thrive.

div.p: Fragmenta Poetica: OR, Poetical Diverions. WITH A PANEGYRICK UPON HIS SACRED MAJESTIE'S Mot happy Return, on the 29. May, 1660. By THO. FORDE, Philothal.
LONDON, Printed by R. and W. Leybourn, for William Grantham, and are to old at the Signe of the Black Bear in St. Pauls Church-yard. 1660.

lg.l: WHat, have we lept! or doth the hatie Sun
Bring back the day, before the night be done?
What melodie is this that charms our ears?
Is it the muick of th'harmonious Sphears?
Peace hepherds, peace; glad tidings we ye bring,
Your God hath got a Son, and ye a King:
And he hath ent us with this newes to tell,
Who late was Ours, is your Immanuel.
Up, up to B • thlehem, there hall you ee
An Human hape encloe the Deitie.
Behold, a cratch imprions him, whoe hands
Have fram'd the earth, and curbs the ea with bands.
He now begins to be, that no beginning knew,
He now begins to live, who being gave to you.
Go ee th'Eternal God a child's become,
The ever-peaking Word himelf lies dumb,
Who by his word feeds all is fed by meat,
Th' Almighty King of Heaven hath left his eat,
And now keeps Court on earth: hate ye and ee
The cratch his throne, beats his attendance be.
And all to be your Saviour, and to free
Ye men from in, and Satans laverie.
Glory to God on high, and peace on earth,
Good will to men by this our God-mans birth.
Come, let's go ee thee wonders which are told,
Let what our ears have heard, our eyes behold.
Croud in, my oul, and ee amongt the ret,
And by thy ight, oh be for ever blet!
Hark how the Angels ing, the heavens rebound,
And earth with th'eccho of th'Angeli • k ound.
Never till now were the well-tuned Sphears
Heard to make melodie to mortal ears.
Now every pretty bird with's warbling throat,
To's new-born Maker elevates a note.
See how the earth, being big with pride to be
Out-gone by heaven, puts on her liverie
Of mirth, and laughs with joy to hear
Her Maker now will pleae to dwell on her.
The whole world was agreed to entertain
The King of peace, who now began his reign:

l.U: hrunk for fear, Bellona hid her head,

lg.l: When peace was born, all dicords lay for dead.
Then why hould bloody characters decrie
The bleed day of his Nativitie?
O let the puret white note out that morn
From all the ret, when Innocence was born.
Hail holy tide,
Wherein a Bride,
A Virgin, and a Mother,
Brought forth a Son,
The like was done,
Except her, by no other.
A Virgin pure,
She did endure
After her Son, or rather.
It may be aid,
She was a maid,
And this Son was her Father.
Here riddles vex,
And do perplex
The eye of humane reaon;
Heaven did combine,
With earth to joyn,
To conecrate this eaon.
Hail bleed Maid,
For by thine aid,
Eternal life is Ours,
Thou didt lie in,
And without in,
The on of God was yours.
Hail happy birth,
Wonder of Earth
And heaven; the Angels ing
Anthems to thee,
As glad to ee
Their new-born heavenly King.
Though thou art poore,
Kings thee adore,
And precious preents bring,
They kneel to you,
And humbly bow,
As to ome acred thing.
Thou that art able
To turn a table
Into a Temple, come,
Poes my heart,
Cleane every part,
And take it for thy home.
LEnd me a pen pull'd from an Angels wing,
That I the news of this blet day may ing;
Or reach a feather of that holy Dove,
Wherewith to hew this miracle of love.
Darknes is turn'd to light, mid-night to morn;
Who can be ilent when the Word is born!
Hark how the Angels ing, they bow, and more
Than Perians they this riing Sun adore.
The Court's remov'd, and the attendants flie
To wait upon this humane Deitie.
He, who was cloath'd with glorious Majety,
Is veil'd with fleh, the better to comply
With mortal eyes; di-robes himelf of light,
Lays by his beams, toops to our weaker ight:
And with his other favours this doth give
That man may ee the face of God, and live.
The Son of God becomes the on of man,
That men may be the ons of God again!
Here God is man, and man is God, he takes
Our nature to him, not his own forakes.
A mortal God, Immortal man in one,
Thus heaven and earth are in conjunction.
See how the hepherds flock, and Kings (as proud
To be his ubjects) to his preence croud.
Hate, hate my oul, there's danger in delay,
Since thou hat nothing ele to offer lay
Thy elf down at his feet; pray him to make
His lodging in thee, as he deign'd to take
Thy nature on himelf.—But tay fond oul,
He's puritie it elf, thou art too foul
To lodge o bright a guet, in whoe pure eyes,
Heavens and Angels are deformities.
Yet ee, he miles, and beckens thee to come,
As if he meant to take thee for his home,
To wah thee with his blood; do not repine,

l.U: ins are His, His righteounes is thine.

lg.l: Hark, he invites himelf to be thy guet,
Whoe preence is thy phyick and thy feat.
Behold he bowes the heavens, and comes down,
Takes up thy Cros, that thou mayt wear his Crown.
And in exchange aumes thy povertie,
Pays all thy debts, ets thee at libertie.
He ues to erve thee, and expects no more,
Thou houldt give him than he gave thee before.
His work is all his wages, and his will
Is all his hire; be thou obedient till:
Love him as he loves thee, and 'caue th'art poor,
Give him thy elf, thy all, He asks no more.
Lord 'tis not fitting thou houldt come
Into o bae a room
Firt, with thy pirit cleane my heart,
And by thy powerful art,
Thine and my enemies expel,
Make an Heaven of my Hell,
Then for ever in me dwell.
But, Lord, if thou vouchafe to dwell
Within o dark a cell,
Take thou charge of the familie,
And let me dwell with thee.
Thine is the cot, be thine the care,
That Satan have no hare,
For thou wilt find no room to pare.

lg.head: Invocat.
lg.l: The Day, thy day is come,
O thou mot glorious Sun,
When thou didt veil thy elf, that we
Mortals might thy glory ee.
Lend me a ray of light,
That I may ee to write,
And Carol forth thy praie,
In ever-living layes.
WHat made the Sun pote hence away
So fat, and make o hort a day?
Seeing a brighter Sun appear,
He ran and hid himelf for fear:
Aham'd to ee himelf out-hin'd,
(Leaving us, and night behind)
He neak'd away to take a nap,
And hide himelf in Thetis lap.
When, loe, a brighter night ucceeds,
A night none of his lutre needs:
A night o plendent, we may ay,
The day was night, and night was day.
See, Damon, ee, how he doth hroud
His baffl'd glory in a cloud;
From whence he peeps to ee the Sun,
That hath his luters all out-done.
But ventring on he pies a tar,
More glorious than his Heper far;
Which with a fair and peaking ray,
Told plainly where his Mater lay.
Ambitious then to teal a ight,
He aw it was the God of light;
Then trait he whips away his team,
The well lot minutes to redeem;
And flies through all the world, to tell
The newes of this great miracle
It was not long before he came
Unto the lofty houe of fame,
Where every whiper, every ound
Is taken at the firt rebound,
And like an aiëry bubble blown
By vainer breath, till it be grown
Too big to be conceal'd, it flies
About a while, gaz'd at, then dies,
Something he tells, and hats away
He could not, and fame would not tay,
To near the ret; for he well knew,
By mixing of fale tales with true,
To make it more. To Rome he plyes,
Her greatet Mart of truths and lyes;
The gods (ays he) will dwell on earth,
And give themelves a mortal birth.
But they of fame had got the ods,
For they themelves made their own gods;
And car'd not to encreae their tore,
For they had gods enough before.
To Solyma he takes her flight,
And puts the Citie in a fright:
Unwelcome newes fills Herods ears,
And then his head, with thoughts and fears.
The King of whom the Sages told,
And all the Prophecies of old,
Is born, ayes fame; a King who hall
Deliver Judah out of thrall:

l.U: hall his ubjects be, and lay

lg.l: Their cepters at his feet; his way
Shall know no bounds, nor end, but he
Beyond all time, o fates decree.
By this the Sun had cros'd the eas,
And told the newes to th' Antipodes.
The aiëry pirits pack'd hence away,
Chas'd by the beams of this bright day.
The fiends were in an uproar, hell
Trembl'd with the dimal yell.
The Prince of darknes was in doubt
The Lord of light would find him out;
And that the word of truth being come,
His oracles mut all be dumb.
Pale death foreaw he was betray'd,
That King of terrors was afraid.
Glory be to God above,
For this miracle of love:
Ever bleed be the morn,
When the God of Love was born.
Love o charming that it can
Contract a God into a Man.
And by the magick of his birth,
Make an Heaven of the Earth.
Ever, ever ing we thus,
Till Angels come and joyn with us.
They rejoyce with all their powers,
Yet the Benefit is Ours.
They with joy the tydings bring,
Shall We be ilint when They ing?
Then Bildad anwers, dominion and fear
(Which rule us mortals) loe his In-mates are.
Can numbers hallow bounds confine his hoats?
Or does his light baulk any unknown coats?
Can man be Gods Corrival to be jut?
Can he be clean that is defiled dut?
The Moon in th'ocean of his light is drown'd,
The tars impure in his bright eyes are found.
Then what is man? (alas!) poor worthles pan,
Or what's his on? a worm les than a man.
Then 'gan Elihu peak, vilenes dot dare
Thy righteounes with Gods thus to compare?
Thou ayt, what gain will righteounes bring in?
Or hall I thrive by that more than by in?
I'll anwer thee. Behold, the clouds that tand
His urer guard againt thy inning hand.
Legions of doubled ins cannot aault
Thy God, or pierce his tarry-guarded vault.
Nor can thy tock of good encreae his tore,
Thy hand may hurt, or help (like thee) the poor. &c.
How comes it that the widows mites are more
Than the abundance the rich gave the poor?
Whilt they their worldly goods lib'rally hurl'd
She gave her heart, more worth than all the world.
As from a Tree at firt came all our woe,
So on a tree our remedie did grow.
One bare the fruit of death, the other life;
This was a well of Salem, that of trife.
What, can God die, or man live, being lain?
He dy'd as man, as God he roe again.
When man was made, God ent an helper to him,
And o he prov'd, for he help'd to undoe him.

div.head: On the miracle of the Loaves.

lg.l: This was a miracle indeed, when bread
Was by ubtraction multiplied:
Why wonder we at this trange feat,
When Gods's both giver, and a guet?
The Lord of life lay in a tomb,
as in the womb,
His Reurrection was a econd birth,
from th'womb of th'earth.

div.head: On M. M. weeping at Chrits death.

lg.l: What, weep to ee thy Saviour die,
Whereby thou liv't eternally?
But now I know, 'twas caue thy ins
Were the harp pears that wounded him.
Give God and Caear both, how hall I do?
Give Gods receiver, and thou giv't him too.
That the worlds goods are o incontant found,
No wonder is, for that it elf is Round.
Wherefore doth Dives love his Money o?
That's earth, So's Hee Like will to like we know.
Calvus of late extream long locks doth wear:
The reaon is Calvus hath lot his Hair.
Mal • ido on his neighbour looks o grim,
Proximus is Potremus ure with him.

div.head: On Will: who had run through all trades and was now a Cobler.

lg.l: I prethee Will whither wilt thou o fat?
Thou cant not farther, for th'art at thy Lat.
Whilt that the Huntman tared, he became
Unto his dogs their banquet and their game:
But from Acteons fortune I am free,
Becaue whilt I aw her, he could not me.
Cornuto cries Hee's weary of his life,
He cannot bear the Lightnes of his wife,
She wants o many Grains, he'l go with los;
Yet a Light Woman is an Heavie Cros.
If unjut fortune hale thee to the bar,
In rags, paler than guilty prioners are,
I'll tick to thee; banîhd thy native oyl,
Through Seas and Rocks I will divide thy toyl.

div.head: On one who fell in love with Julia, throwing Snow-balls at him.

lg.l: I'me all on fire; trange miracle of Love,
Thee Watry Snow-bals Hand-Granadoes prove?
If from cold clouds thou dot thy lightnings dart,
Julia, what Element will • ence my heart?
A Thracian lad on Ice-bound Heber playes,
The glaie Pavement with his waight decayes.
Whilts with his lower parts the river fled,
The meeting Ice cut off his tender head,
Which having found, the Son-les mother urnd,
Thoe to be drownd were born, this to be burnd.
Trina mihi juncta et variis aetatibus vxor,
Haec Juveni, illa viro, tertia nupta eni et:
Prima et propter Opus, teneris ociata ub annis,
