Altera propter Opes, tertia propter Opem.

lg.head: Englihed.
lg.l: Three wives I had in everall ages Pat,
A Youth, a Man, an old man had the lat;
The firt was for the Work, a tender maid,
The econd was for VVealth, the third for Ayd.
My Mitris hath my heart in hold,
But yet 'tis under locks of gold,
In which the wind doth freely play,
But my poor heart doth prioner tay:
What happier prion can there be?
Confinement is my libertie.

div.head: H. Grotius, S. Pet • i Querela.

lg.l: Quae me recondet, recondet regio? quâ moetum diem
Fallam latebrâ? quaero nigrantem pecum
Quâ me epeliem vivus: ubi nullum videns
Nulli videndus, lachrymas foveam meas.

lg.head: Englihed.
lg.l: What place will hide my guilt? that there I may
Deceive th'approaches of dicovering day.
I'll eek ome gloomy cave, where I may lie
Entomb'd alive in hades of ecrecie:
There eeing none, nor any eeing me,
I will indulge my tears with libertie.
I am a child, and cannot love,
Ah me! that I my death mut prove.
Wilt thou that I thee adore,
Cruel thou mut be no more.
Torments my heart cannot bear,
Nor mut any grief come there.

div.head: To Henry the 4th. out of Bahuius.

lg.l: O mighty King! glory of Princely race,
Thy Kingdoms afety, and it's chiefet grace:
We wih our Mue worthy thy worth t'adorn,
She nothing more deires, can nothing les perform.
Thou grace of arms, mak't war a port to be,
To labour's ret, to wake is leep to thee
Thy call makes ouldiers, whom th'hat o in awe,
Thy word is a decree, thy beck a law.
Thou lead't them on, thy deeds erve for commands,
They learn their dutie from thy feet and hands.
Thou conquer't e're thou fight't, fortune's decree
Aures thee triumph, 'fore the victorie.
Thy helmet lawrel, fights all trophies be,
To fight and conquer is all one with thee.
Thy mercie trives thy word for to reprieve,
And when thou trik't thy foe, thy elf doth grieve.
Though forc'd to fight, to expiate their deed,
Thine eyes do weep, fat as thy foes do bleed.
Pardons are thy revenges, whilt thy word
Doth wounds dipence, thy hand doth help afford.
Like dreadful lightning to the war thou com't,
Conquerour, than conquer'd milder thou return't.
To conquer others were too mall, but thou
A nobler triumph o're thy elf dot how.
CUpid all his arts did prove,
To invite my heart to love:
But I alwayes did delay,
His mild ummons to obey:
Being deaf to all his charms,
Strait the god aumes his arms.
With his bow and quiver, he
Takes the field to duel me.
Armed like Achilles, I
With my hield and pear defie
His bold challenge: as he cat
His golden darts, I as fat
Catch'd his arrows in my hield,
Till I made him leave the field.
Fretting and di-armed, then
Th'angry god returns agen,
All in flames; 'tead of a dart,
Throws himelf into my heart,
Ueles, I my hield require,
When the fort is all on fire;
I in vain the field did win,
Now the enemy's within.
Thus betray'd, at lat I cry,
Love! th'hat got the victory.

l.hi: Goe happy paper, view thoe eyes,

lg.l: The quiver whence he takes his darts,
Wherewith he wound's poor mortalis hearts.
But yet, fond paper, come not near
Thoe all-conuming flames, for fear
Thou perih by their cruell art,
That have inflam'd thy maters heart.
Yet if thou wil't o hardy be,
To venture on a batterie,
On that preuming Catle, ay,
Wonder not I have found the way;
For (fairet Lady) hereby know,
The dart came firt from your own Bow.
You need inflict no other banihment,
The fault it elfe's my greatet punihment.
Oft would I pardon crave; but till my Mue
Prompts me, foul weather is a fair excue.
If that will not uffice; then let this be,
That I have none, my bet apologie.
Convict me of my crime, and as 'tis meet,
I'le do you daily Penance in a heet.
But, prove me abent firt, and then,
I'le write apologies, or burn my Pen.
Planets are where they worke, not where they move,
I am not where I live, but where I Love.
The Poet's now become a Priet, and layes
His Poem at your feet, expects no Bayes,
But your acceptance; kind'le it with your eyes,
And make this Offering prove a Sacrifice.
The Vetal fire that's in your breat, will burn
Up all his droe, and make it Incene turne;
And then your mile a econd life will give,
Hee'l fear no death, if you but bid him live.
Pardon this bold ambition, tis his drift,
To make the Altar anctifie the Gift.
Viit this Temple, at your vacant houres,
Twas Herberts Poem once, but now tis Yours.

div.head: On the death of M. A. S.

lg.l: Fain would I pay my tribute to thy Here,
And igh thy death, in never dying vere.
But I in vain invoke my Mue, for he
(Alas!) is dead with him for company.
Like to thoe Indian wives who count the thred
Of their life ended when their Mate is dead.
When ouls thus linck'd divorce, one cannot part,
Without the breaking of the others heart.
To vent my orrowes yeelds me no relief,
He grieves but little that can tell his grief.
Let others les concern'd this truth approve,
And trive to hew their Wit, more than their Love
My grief confutes the Laws of Numbers, I
Whilt others Write, will Weep thine Elegie.
Each line my tears a Colons charge defray,
Veres have Periods, but no Period they.
Reader ince He my better half is gone,
My heart is but his Monumentall Stone,
On which this Epitaph incrib'd hall be:

l.hi: I di'd in him, and yet he lives in me.

div.head: Laus & votum vitae Beatae. Out of Lipius.

lg.l: EQuall unto the Gods is he,
And much above what Mortalls be,
Who the uncertain day of fate,
Nor wiheth nor repineth at:
T'whom impotent Ambition, nor
The hope of gaine's Solicitor.
Whom Princes thundring threats can't move,
No, nor the darts of angry Jove.
But eated in Securitie,
Laughs at the vulgars vanitie.
Whoe life's thread's pun o ev'n, that there
Can not be een th' leat knot of care.
O might I but thus far apire,
To hape my life to my deire:
Nor Offices, nor Wealth I'de crave,
Nor with white Stee'ds in triumph brave,
To lead along poor Captiv'd Slaves.
I in vat Solitude hould dwell,
A neighbour to the Mues Well:
Orchards, and Gardens to frequent,
There would I eat my ole content;
So that when as full ripened Death,
Shall put a period to my breath,
Tedious to none, and without trife,
Calmely to end my aged life.

div.head: On T. Batard, and his Epigrams.

lg.l: That thy names Batard, friend, is thy hard fate,
Thy Births I'm ure are Legitimate.
Well may't a Batard be, all Common race
To thy diviner wit mut need give place:
No, Jove himelf begat thee, and thy Birth,
Gets in us Wonderment as well as mirth.

lg.head: Momus to Batard.
lg.l: The proverb ayes, Batards (remember it)
Mut fling no tones; leat they their father hi •

lg.head: Anwer.

l.U: tand off gald backs will winch, tis true,

lg.l: Here's Salt, or we hould never hear of you.

lg.head: Again to Batard.
lg.l: Batard, that is of bet wit, ay the Dutch,
Then as thy name is o's thy nature uch:
What if the multitude laugh at thy Name,
Know, their diprayes do advance thy fame.

div.head: To the Reader, Out of Faius.

lg.l: Who will read thee? None. Why? nor mock, nor jeere.
Nor Baudry (wihd by many) comes not here,
But one or other hap'ly they may finde,
Preferring good before Jets, he will minde.
But if none read, griefe doth not me aault,
For if none read, then none can find a fault.

div.head: Upon His Sacred Majeties mot happy Return, on the 29th. of May 1660.

lg.l: AVVake dull Mue, the Sun appeares,
Open thine eyes, and dry thy teares:
The clouds dipere, and Sable night
Reignes to Charles his conquering light
Batts, Owles, and Night-birds flie away,
Chac'd by the beames of this bright day.
A day deign'd by Detinie,
Famous to all Poteritie.
Firt for the birth of Charles, and now
'Tis His Three Kingdoms Birth-day too.
VVee mov'd before, but knew not how,
We could not ay we liv'd, till now.
Like Flies in VVinter, o lay we,
In a dull, enceles Lethargie.
Toucht by his healing beames, we live,
His Preence a new life doth give.
Each loyall heart trook by his Rayes,
Is fill'd with gratitude and praie.
Thoe Phaëtons who had got the Raine,
And needs would guide great Charles his Waine;
Have found their Folly in their Fate;
And Phoebus now aumes his State.
The Trees who choe a woodden King,
To be their hade and covering:
Whilt they injuriouly decline
The fruitfull Olive and the Vine
Conuming fire from the Bramble came;
They read their Folly by the Flame.
True Emblems of our giddy age,
Not rul'd by Reaon, but by Rage:
The tayle would quarrell with the Head,
And no longer would be Led:
Th' inferiour Members oon give way,
And the Tayle mut bear the way,
Blind as it was ('to ur miery)
With many a Sting, but never an Eye.
Then were we drag'd through mire & tones,
Which bruid our fleh, and brake our bones,
Our Feet and Legs foundred and lame,
We aw our Folly in our Shame.
We praid, but no releif could find,
The Tayle was Deaf, as well as Blind:
Drums, Trumpets, Pulpits with their ound,
All our intreaties did confound;
Till pittying Heaven heard our cry,
And God vouchafes, what men deny.
After a twelve years uffering,
Jut Heaven Proclaims Great Charles our King:
Free (like Ulies) from the harms
Of Forreign Syrens tempting charmes.
And now our Joyfull Land doth ring,

With
• ö Paean's to our King:
All England eemd One bonfire, Night
Seem'd to contend with Day for light.
For Bells our Kingdome hath been fam'd,
And the Ringing-Iland nam'd:
More truly now, when every Bell
Aloud the joyful news doth tell.
That Charles is landed once again,
With Peace, and Plenty, in his Train.
No more hall brother brother kill,
Nor onnes the blood of fathers pill:
No more hall Mars & Madnes rage,
No more hall Loyalty be Treaon,
Errour truth, and non-ence reaon;
Nor will we ell our Liberty,
For a too-dear bought Slavery.
No more hall Sacriledge invade
The Church, nor Faction make a trade
Of Holy things; nor Gopel be
Lot in a law-les liberty.
No more hope we to ee the time
When to be innocent's a crime.
No more, no more hall armed might
Though Wrong'd, o'recome the weaker Right.
Now hall all jar • ing dicords be
Drown'd in the pleaing Harmony
Of peacefull lawes, whoe tiller voice
Shall charme the Drum & Trumpets noie,
The Church hall be Triumphant, more
Than it was Militant before.
The withered Lawrell, and the Bayes
Revive to crown our happy dayes
Thee, and all other bleings we
Great and Good Charles, Expect from thee
VVhoe Vertues were enough alone,
To give Thee Title to the Crown.
You Conquerd without Arms, Your Words
VVin hearts, better than others Swords.
Pardons are Your revenges, we
Jov in Your Boundles Victory.
What others ue to do with blowes,
You by Forgiving kill your foes:
Your mercy doth your Sword reprieve,
And for their faults, You mot do grieve.
Your Martyr'd Fathers charity
(His lat and greatet Legacy)
You mot do prize. Could we but tread
That pace of virtue which you lead,
How quickly hould we all agree,
To live in Love and Loyalty!
VVhilt others their rich Preents bring,
All I can give's, GOD SAVE THE KING.
